fields.headline: Naylor nails rocky Rovers
fields.trailText: Tony Naylor's 72nd-minute improved Port Vale's position while that of Bristol Rovers looks increasingly tenuous.
fields.body:
Tony Naylor's 72nd-minute goal may well secure Port Vale's Second Division future while increasing the chances of relegation for Bristol Rovers.

A game dominated by brutal challenges, one bringing a deserved red card for the Rovers midfielder Trevor Challis was won by Vale after Naylor converted a Marc Bridge-Wilkinson cross from six yards.

Earlier Nick Culkin made several fine saves to keep Vale at bay, even if he should have been beaten when Naylor missed a glorious six-yard chance.

With the a pitch resembling a lunar landscape this was a million miles from the Premiership, as was the two-footed lunge by Robbie Pethick on Sagi Burton after 30 minutes which received only a yellow card from Keith Hill. Pethick was fortunate the chal lenge was not caught by cameras.

Challis was not so fortunate moments later, however, after a wild challenge on Michael Walsh. On this occasion, Hill went straight for his red card.

Since this game's initial postponement on New Year's Day Brian Horton, Vale's manager, has now guided his team to a 16-game unbeaten run to stave off the threat of a second successive relegation for the club.

Last season's fall from the First Division was the first time as a manager that Horton experienced relegation.

How ironic then that three of Horton's former clubs, Manchester City, Huddersfield and Oxford, could all be tasting life at a lower level next season. Vale should take note. Let Horton leave at your peril!

Horton should have few fears after their fine run. The Rovers manager Garry Thompson is in need of a similar revival for his side to escape the bottom four.

Burton's free header after less than a minute saw Culkin produce the first of his saves. Then the Rovers forward Chris Lee saw a 20-yard shot fly narrowly wide on four minutes and his side almost struck on 48 minutes after Vitalijs Astafjevs beat Burton to a ball that stuck in the mud. He released the substitute Kevin Gall, whose angled drive was well saved by Mark Goodlad.

webTitle: MPs call for commission to speed Whitehall reform

fields.headline: MPs call for commission to speed Whitehall reform
fields.trailText: Tony Blair should attack the refusal of Whitehall to embrace fundamental reforms by establishing a royal commission on the future of the civil service, a Labour controlled select committee of MPs recommends today.
fields.body:
Tony Blair should attack the refusal of Whitehall to embrace fundamental reforms by establishing a royal commission on the future of the civil service, a Labour controlled select committee of MPs recommends today.

The proposal has support in parts of Downing Street where there is growing frustration at the slowness of change in Whitehall and civil servants disinterest in the outcome of Labour's many policy initiatives. Mr Blair and his senior advisers want civil servants to focus much more on results and spend less time fighting departmental turf wars.

The proposal for a royal commission comes from the Commons public administration committee which says there is a feeling "in some quarters that the civil service has once again absorbed attempts at reform. A possible conclusion may be that the service is incapable of effectively changing itself and that reform must be imposed from the outside".

The MPs also point out that the head of the civil service, Sir Richard Wilson, has admitted he will not meet his target of 35% women in the senior civil service by 2005. "If this one target cannot be met for reasons which could have been foreseen ... it raises questions about the basis for such target setting," the report says.

The MPs also call for the posts of permanent secretaries - the most senior departmental post - to be opened up to external open competition. In recent months, both the Home Office and the Education Department have filled such vacancies from within Whitehall.

The report says local councils and agencies have complained of the "constant need to bid and rebid for central funds and the requirement to comply with a plethora of inspection regimes and externally imposed targets".

The MPs say these targets imply a lack of trust and stem from an excessive centralism.

They suggest "the twin imperatives of performance and accountability seem to us point inexorably towards a system of elected regional government combined with unitary local authorities".

The report also calls for the government's much criticised annual report to be changed so that claims about the government's record are subject to independent verification and endorsement.

webTitle: Tonga's ten at the back lucky to get nil

fields.headline: Tonga's ten at the back lucky to get nil
fields.trailText: Australia set a world record yesterday when they trounced Tonga 22-0 in their opening match of the Oceania World Cup qualifiers, the biggest ever victory in international football.
fields.body:
Australia set a world record yesterday when they trounced Tonga 22-0 in their opening match of the Oceania World Cup qualifiers, the biggest ever victory in international football.

It was a particularly good day for Coventry City's reserve striker John Aloisi, who scored six times, and Wolves' Kevin Muscat, Australia's captain, who added five. But Australia, 75th in Fifa's world rankings, could smash their record tomorrow when they play American Samoa, ranked No203 and officially the worst team in the world.

Tonga, commonly known as the "Friendly Islands", conceded 10 goals by half-time despite their defensive 10-0-0 formation. Aloisi netted his double hat-trick in the first 61 minutes but was subsequently substituted after a 14-minute goal drought.

Although Australia left many of their Premiership stars in England, the Tongan coach Gary Phillips criticised the Socceroos for picking eight foreign-based professionals. "I do not see the point of some of these superstars coming back for this," Phillips said. "If you add together the value of the Australian team and then divide it by five, then you have the value of the Tongan economy." Many of their club managers, including Dick Advocaat of Rangers, are equally disgruntled.

With a population of just over 100,000, Tonga lost their first international 8-0 to Fiji in 1979. They have since won five international matches and are ranked 185th in the world.

The five biggest World Cup victories:

1 Tonga 0 - 22 Australia, April 9 2001

2 Iran 19 - 0 Guam, November 24 2000

3 Maldives 0 - 17 Iran, June 2 1997

4 Tajikistan 16 - 0 Guam, November 26 2000

5 Australia 13 - 0 Solomon Islands, June 11 1997

webTitle: Saints set to report Spurs to league

fields.headline: Saints set to report Spurs to league
fields.trailText: Southampton are considering reporting Tottenham Hotspur to the Premier League for allegedly poaching Glenn Hoddle.
fields.body:
Southampton are considering reporting Tottenham Hotspur to the Premier League for allegedly poaching Glenn Hoddle. The Southampton board meet this week to discuss whether to lodge a complaint which would spark a Premier League inquiry into the events surrounding Hoddle's change of clubs two weeks ago.

"We are seriously looking at making a complaint but I want to discuss it with the board first," said the Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe.

Tottenham's captain Sol Campbell may have played his last game for the club after picking up an ankle injury in Sunday's FA Cup semi-final defeat to Arsenal.

The defender, who has long been linked with a summer move away from White Hart Lane, could also miss England's friendly with Mexico on May 25 and the World Cup qualifier in Greece on June 6.

Arsenal are to come face-to-face with the referee who sent off Patrick Vieira at Sunderland - in the incident which led to Arsène Wenger's controversial tunnel row - in the FA Cup final against Liverpool.

Steve Dunn, who dismissed Vieira at the Stadium of Light on the opening day of the season for lashing out an arm at Sunderland's Darren Williams, will take charge of the final on May 12.

David Beckham will be left out against Charlton tonight as Manchester United try out alternatives. With the England captain suspended for the next week's Champions League clash with Bayern Munich, Sir Alex Ferguson is keen to try out alternatives, particularly the 20-year-old Luke Chadwick. "Chadwick hasn't got the experience but he has got the ability," said Ferguson.

Middlesbrough are expected to complete the signing of the Slovakian striker Szilard Nemeth on a five-year contract in the summer. "I can reveal that from July 1, I will be a player with Middlesbrough," he was quoted as saying.

One man was yesterday arrested by police fraud squad officers investigating possible corruption at Chesterfield.

Roma's lead at the top of Serie A was reduced to six points yesterday when they lost 3-1 to Fiorentina, with Enrico Chiesa scoring two of Fiorentina's goals - the first a free-kick and the second a volley eight minutes from time.

webTitle: Financial sector firms feel slowdown's chill

fields.headline: Financial sector firms feel slowdown's chill
fields.trailText: The darkening outlook for the global economy has hit the City, causing confidence to fall at its fastest rate for two years, the CBI said yesterday.
fields.body:
The darkening outlook for the global economy has hit the City, causing confidence to fall at its fastest rate for two years, the CBI said yesterday.

Financial services firms are planning layoffs - the first time for more than a year that they have predicted lower employment levels in their responses to the CBI's quarterly sector barometer.

"The global slowdown seems to have affected sentiment in the financial services sector, despite continued growth in volumes," said Douglas Godden, the CBI's head of economic policy.

With stocks firmly in the grip of a bear market, the loss of confidence was sharpest among those firms linked to the equities sector, such as securities traders and fund managers, the CBI said. Firms have already started tightening their belts, instructing staff to take public transport and to limit their entertainment bills.

But with tough competitive conditions sqeezing fees, the cost cutting measures instituted so far have yet to improve profitability. "It's not surprising that employment prospects are weakening," said Mr Godden.

A recent survey suggested that up to 20,000 jobs could be lost in the financial services industry this year.

Meanwhile, inflationary pressures in the economy are easing, according to official figures released yesterday, raising hopes that the Bank of England will sanction another reduction to borrowing costs next month.

The price of goods leaving the factory gate rose by just 0.8% in the year to March, according to the office for national statistics, the weakest increase for two years. Producer price inflation has declined steeply since its peak of 2.8% four months ago.

"The underlying picture is one of rapidly weakening price pressure in manufacturing," said Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at Capital Economics.But consumers defied the growing economic gloom, causing retail sales to rise during March by 7%, the British Retail Consortium reported.

fields.headline: Blackpool's towering gamble
fields.standfirst: The tycoon planning a Las Vegas-style makeover to revitalise the Golden Mile is meeting opposition
fields.trailText: Monday morning in the off-season at Blackpool and the resort's famous Golden Mile is almost deserted. A gale is whipping in off the Irish Sea, battering billboards advertising forthcoming shows starring Alvin Stardust, the Grumbleweeds and Roy "Chubby" Brown.
fields.body:
Monday morning in the off-season at Blackpool and the resort's famous Golden Mile is almost deserted. A gale is whipping in off the Irish Sea, battering billboards advertising forthcoming shows starring Alvin Stardust, the Grumbleweeds and Roy "Chubby" Brown.

There is not a donkey in sight. Guest houses to the north of the promenade are mostly shut, the bowling alley and nightclubs lifeless and several bars boarded up.

One of the few signs of activity is at Gifts Galore, a seafront store opposite the north pier where jesters' hats and beachballs hanging from an awning bob defiantly in the wind.

Huddled inside is a small group of pensioners, browsing through the sticks of rock, postcards and rows of Britney Spears mugs while they wait to get on the coach back home. Two old ladies have strayed into the 'adults only' section and are sniggering uncontrollably at a extensive display of phallic novelty gags.

Yet their laughter disguises a more serious reality.

After decades of decline Britain's most popular holiday resort, synonymous with kiss-me-quick hats and hen parties, is in urgent need of resuscitation.

Unique solution

Blackpool still attracts 12m people each year but visitor numbers are 30% down on six years ago and, for a local economy that derives 85% of its income from tourism, that is a serious issue.

It is a similar story at most other seaside towns, though some are attracting tourists who cannot visit the country during the foot and mouth crisis.

Holidaymakers are shunning British resorts to take advantage of cheap packages and budget flights to go abroad for the sun, according to a recent study by the English Tourist Council.

A unique solution has been proposed for Blackpool. A reclusive multimillionaire wants to turn the town into a Las Vegas for the north, making it a gambling mecca that would attract tourists from all over Europe and revitalise the local economy.

Trevor Hemmings, a former builder who made his first fortune from Pontins holiday camps and is so low profile that some locals liken him to the Wizard of Oz, wants to build a series of Vegas-style casino, hotel and retail complexes on the seafront.

He proposes to build the Pharaoh's Palace Resort, a £130m complex with an ancient Egyptian theme, 100,000 sq ft of gaming floors to be open 24 hours a day, 2,500 slot machines, 100,000 sq ft of conference and exhibition space, a 3,000 sq ft auditorium, a 500-bed hotel and extensive retail space.

To some it is so extravagant as to be unrealistic but minister for tourism Janet Anderson was in town yesterday to hear the results of a new poll that claims 71% of locals are behind the concept and to underline that the government is taking it seriously.

Locals say she has to. Allan Cavill, chief executive of the Blackpool Challenge Partnership, a forum representing local public and private sector interests, says GDP is the 12th lowest in the UK and the third lowest in the region.

Unemployment in the town's four most central wards is 10% to 12%, the area is the third most deprived in the country and 6,000 homes have more than one family living in them.

"There are some pretty frightening social problems right behind the promenade," Mr Cavill said.

"We lost visitors throughout the 1980s and 1990s and it was probably only the slap in the face the Labour party delivered in 1998 when it said that it wouldn't hold its party conference here again until things improved that made people realise it wasn't OK."

Leisure Parcs, the company that Mr Hemmings has formed in partnership with Bank of Scotland and venture capitalists Electra, believes resort casinos can be used as a tool of urban renewal in the same way as they have transformed Atlantic City and Biloxi in the US.

Over there tax from gaming is ploughed back into the local community and into regeneration projects.

Marc Etches, the managing director of Leisure Parcs, claims that the introduction of up to six resort casino hotels offering up to 6,000 rooms could potentially create 15,000 direct jobs, a further 10,000 ancillary jobs and gross revenues in excess of £500m.

Leisure industry watchers believe predictions of 30m annual visitors spending £2bn by 2020 are optimistic. Mr Etches disagrees.

"If we can get 10m visitors now when we have an off-season that runs from October to May then 30m has to be realistic if we have a year round resort," he said. "Without this plan, Blackpool may be supping at the last chance saloon."

Basil Newby, owner of gay nightclub chain In the Pink Leisure, warns the town's image will have to change. "We've got a long way to go," he said. "Las Vegas gets Shirley Bassey and Tom Jones. We get Cannon and Ball and Hale and Pace."

Gaming review

Leisure Parcs has already spent £85m over the past three years buying up local landmarks including the Blackpool Tower, the resort's three piers, the Opera House Theatre, the Winter Gardens entertainment centre, Louis Tussauds Waxworks and the Savoy and Clifton Hotels.

However, it still has some obstacles to overcome if its vision is to become a reality. The first requires a change to the 1968 Regulation of Gaming Act which was introduced to kick organised crime out of gambling. It restricts the way that casinos advertise, bans live entertainment, limits the number of jackpot slot machines and says casinos can only admit new members after a 24-hour "cooling-off" period.

Government sources suggest an ongoing review of gaming will recommend the rules be relaxed when it reports to home secretary Jack Straw in June.

Levying taxes locally may be more difficult, confirms a Treasury spokesman. Regional councils do not have the power to tax local businesses or ring fence where the proceeds are spent. Leisure Parcs will have to modify its proposals.

It will also need other financial partners. The BCP is ready to commit £20m of cash it won through a single regeneration budget bid, but London Clubs International, Mr Etches' commercial partner, has already had its fingers burnt by a casino venture in Las Vegas and its share price has collapsed.

Despite the overwhelming support shown by yesterday's survey there is a growing sense of unease among local small businesses.

Dennis Smith has been running the Abbey Hotel, a 10-bed hotel since moving from Featherstone in west Yorkshire 12 years ago.

He is broadly in favour of casinos but fears shiny new four-star hotels offering subsidised rooms at two-star rates to encourage more gamblers could be disastrous for him and the 2,500 other small hotels in town.

"My business is down 70% over the past five years, the place next door has gone bankrupt twice since I've been here and, despite spending £80,000 improving a property that I bought for £126,000, I've been told it is now only worth £115,000," Mr Smith said. "This could be the straw that breaks me."

His concerns are echoed by David Gee, the owner of Gifts Galore, who last year saw trade rise to record levels after he decided to target the stag and hen parties and stay open beyond midnight.

"Casinos could destroy this town and my business," said Mr Gee. "The seafront will be nothing but pawn brokers and strip joints."

Infrastructure will also need to be improved. Seven million people live within a one hour drive of Blackpool but car parking and rail links would not be able to cope with the volume of visitors. Even now it is often quicker and cheaper for Londoners to fly to southern France or Spain than brave the Virgin train service to Blackpool.

Yet what worries locals most is that there is no alternative on the table if the Leisure Parcs plan falls at the first hurdle.

"How can highly trained people only come up with one option?" Mr Smith said. "There's a set of farts in the town hall who've been presented with this plan and think its manna from the gods. They think the town will be quids in but I tell you, ten years from now, thousands of us will be out of business."

The bets have been placed and the stakes are high. Blackpool must wait until the gaming review body reports in June to find out if it has any chance of winning.

Levying taxes locally may be more difficult, confirms a Treasury spokesman. Regional councils do not have the power to tax local businesses or ring fence where the proceeds are spent. Leisure Parcs will have to modify its proposals. It will also need other financial partners. The BCP is ready to commit £20m of cash it won through a single regeneration budget bid, but London Clubs International, Mr Etches' commercial partner, has already had its fingers burnt by a casino venture in Las Vegas and its share price has collapsed. Despite the overwhelming support shown by yesterday's survey there is a growing sense of unease among local small businesses. Dennis Smith has been running the Abbey Hotel, a 10-bed hotel since moving from Featherstone in west Yorkshire 12 years ago. He is broadly in favour of casinos but fears shiny new four-star hotels offering subsidised rooms at two-star rates to encourage more gamblers could be disastrous for him and the 2,500 other small hotels in town. "My business is down 70% over the past five years, the place next door has gone bankrupt twice since I've been here and, despite spending £80,000 improving a property that I bought for £126,000, I've been told it is now only worth £115,000," Mr Smith said. "This could be the straw that breaks me." His concerns are echoed by David Gee, the owner of Gifts Galore, who last year saw trade rise to record levels after he decided to target the stag and hen parties and stay open beyond midnight. "Casinos could destroy this town and my business," said Mr Gee. "The seafront will be nothing but pawn brokers and strip joints." Infrastructure will also need to be improved. Seven million people live within a one hour drive of Blackpool but car parking and rail links would not be able to cope with the volume of visitors. Even now it is often quicker and cheaper for Londoners to fly to southern France or Spain than brave the Virgin train service to Blackpool. Yet what worries locals most is that there is no alternative on the table if the Leisure Parcs plan falls at the first hurdle. "How can highly trained people only come up with one option?" Mr Smith said. "There's a set of farts in the town hall who've been presented with this plan and think its manna from the gods. They think the town will be quids in but I tell you, ten years from now, thousands of us will be out of business." The bets have been placed and the stakes are high. Blackpool must wait until the gaming review body reports in June to find out if it has any chance of winning. Related article Discreet art of the buyback

fields.headline: Brown Field
fields.standfirst:
Market, Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Market, Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Market, a new artist-run space on the site of what was the Fly Gallery in Glasgow's east end, makes you think about the urban built environment even before you see the work in two related exhibitions. (Next door to Brown Field is Michael McGraw's engaging 60-second Interlude, which runs until April 14, and playfully explores issues of intervention and surveillance in urban landscapes.)

Occupying two tiny commercial spaces, Market is on Duke Street, a road linking the gentrified Merchant City and its lofts at one end with decrepit public housing scrawled with UVF graffiti at the other. In such a context, these exhibitions inevitably take on a deeper resonance than if they were at pristine galleries in the city centre.

At first sight, Katrine Hjelde's miniature paintings of follies look like bullet holes in the wall. Small discs are randomly placed from ground level to ceiling, each replicating a Classical building in the style of 17th-century European landscape painting. Her badge-like works remind us of the connection between capital and landscape in art - the money to build follies, the funds to commission paintings of them.

Franz Ackermann's Mental Maps, small-scale, obsessive paintings, like a deranged version of Klimt, focus on perception, what it might look like, and how we might chart it. Replacing geography with a personal mapping, he includes some stressful locations ("fucking malaria areas") and some soothing counterparts ("tiger balm museum").

Hayley Tompkins's watercolours are restful, limpid blues and mauves painted on pages torn from a lined exercise book. How they relate to each other is as important as how they relate to the scene these abstract works suggest. The same enigmatic quality haunts Laura Emsley's papier-mché Reef, an assortment of marine wonders, which also uses pages from a very mixed assortment of works (Paradise Lost, The Cat in the Hat Comes Back) as malleable material.

A final revelation comes in an untitled drawing by Don Van Vliet, an untrained artist prevented from attending art school by his parents. It's a fluid, expressive work with echoes of Japanese art, beautifully simple and - unless you know - without a hint that the artist is better known as Captain Beefheart.

Until April 28. Details: 0775 128 1620.

fields.headline: Tragedy: a Tragedy
fields.standfirst:
Gate, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Gate, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
It is sometimes possible for a play to be both potentially profound and tedious at the same time. Occasionally you see something that is acted with acute clarity and yet remains obtuse. Every now and again you understand all the words but don't have a clue what they mean. Such is the case with Tragedy: a Tragedy by Will Eno, the last offering in the Gate's disappointing Liberty season. The play has an edgy, enervated quality that is always interesting, but for much of its 65 minutes it bored the pants off me.

It spends a lot of time telling us nothing we don't already know about the way news agendas are set and the way 24-hour news media operate when faced with disaster (lots of on-the-spot television reporters confronted with nothing happening and forced to waffle to fill in the silence). And it ends by telling us something we may not know: that apocalypse may come not in a flash of lightning and a clap of thunder but with a simple putting out of the light and closing of the door.

It starts, and continues for some time - in, fact rather too long - like a satirical sketch on a Radio 4 comedy programme. The premise is that the sun has set and shows no sign of ever rising again. A news team has been sent to cover the event. John is in a field, Constance is reporting from outside a deserted house and John is on the steps of the governor's mansion. They are all as much in the dark as anyone. The more they report, the less everyone knows. They speak for us but do not report what we see.

Frank, the anchorman, a kind of tinpot god in the artificial light of the TV studio, tries to hold things together. But gradually, as the long night continues, everyone and everything begins to collapse: meaning, language, even the reporters themselves. In the end, as the professionals who control the news are unable to continue, an ordinary man bears witness. His simple testimony replaces their gobbledygook; his truth replaces their attempts to control the news.

Eno's play is clever and you don't doubt for a moment he can write. And while I didn't like this play very much, his is such a quirky talent that I'd be prepared to travel quite some way to see his next one.

Until April 28. Box office: 020-7229 0706.

fields.headline: Music's answer to DH Lawrence
fields.standfirst:
BBCSO/Davis
Barbican Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
BBCSO/Davis
Barbican Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Karol Szymanowski was the composer who put 20th-century Poland on the musical map. He's also an acquired taste. In some respects, he's temperamentally akin to DH Lawrence: a dark, mystic sensualist who peers beneath the crumbling veneer of civilisation in search of primal, archetypal experience. His heady lyricism, swaying and unfurling rather like Lawrence's incantatory prose, is something you either can or can't take. I've always found him a tad self-indulgent. However, Andrew Davis and the BBC Symphony Orchestra, closing a concert of Polish music with his Third Symphony, made the best possible case for Syzmanowski.

Subtitled The Song of the Night, the Third is a setting of Sufi poetry for tenor, chorus and a colossal orchestra. Written during the first world war, it marks a turning away from contemporary events towards a world of sexual and spiritual introspection. The tenor meditates on the "ecstasy" of being "alone with God", but his ecstasy is primarily erotic, as percussive throbs and string undulations gradually build to seismic climaxes during which the chorus interject raucous, wordless cries.

Szymanowski's orchestral palette is opulent and kaleidoscopic, an unremitting display of tone colour that owes much to Scriabin's Poem of Ecstasy and Stravinsky's Firebird, though it surpasses both in its range. Davis seemed not so much to conduct it as to fling himself into its world with delirious abandon. The choral singing was rich, if in places a bit staid. The tenor, Paul Groves, combined dreaminess with athletic virility. When it was over, I felt I needed a cold shower.

Witold Lutosklawski admitted to feeling giddy when he heard Szymanowski's Third. His own music, composed under the communist regime and later equated with the voice of Solidarity, inhabits an altogether different terrain, that of the artist searching for individuality in the face of totalitarianism.

The Concerto for Orchestra was the work that made him both a national and international success in 1954. Its brilliance is deceptive, compounded of a folksy melodic and rhythmic drive and dissident atonal harmonies. Davis couldn't quite disguise the fact that the closing passacaglia goes on too long, though the opening movement, in which a defiant, lurching theme ricochets from the depths of the orchestra to its heights, was electrifying.

In between came Chopin's Second Piano Concerto, with Maria Joao Pires as soloist. She defies criticism in this music, probing it with the combination of supreme intelligence and emotional spontaneity that is uniquely her own. In the slow movement, the audience held its breath as the slow cascade of sound unfurled with perfect limpidity.

Chopin's orchestration has often been criticised as weak. Davis avoided the usual tendency to make it sound as if it was written by someone else (many conductors shade it towards Brahms), unearthing some beautiful woodwind and brass sonorities in the process. The BBCSO's playing had a ferocious energy throughout the evening, communicating the orchestra's almost tangible delight at having its former chief conductor back.

fields.headline: Greenspan blamed for bubble
fields.standfirst: Fed chairman encouraged 'irrational exuberance' among investors
fields.trailText: The fond belief that Alan Greenspan, venerable chairman of the US Federal Reserve Board, is a superman who can prevent a crash inflated American stocks to twice their fair value last year, economic researchers are warning.
fields.body:
The fond belief that Alan Greenspan, venerable chairman of the US Federal Reserve Board, is a superman who can prevent a crash inflated American stocks to twice their fair value last year, economic researchers are warning.

Although US stocks have lost $4 trillion since the height of the Greenspan "bubble" last March, the market is still overvalued by $3.5 trillion, according to Professor Marcus Miller of Warwick University and his colleagues.

"There will be a market crash when investors realise that Mr Greenspan is not superhuman," he will tell his colleagues at the Royal Economic Society's annual conference in Durham today.

Prof Miller said US investors ignored the risks and piled into stocks because they believed that Mr Greenspan would bail out the market if it nosedived - precisely the kind of "irrational exuberance" which the Fed chairman warned against in a landmark speech four years ago.

Despite his warning, Mr Greenspan encouraged the exuberance, according to Prof Miller, because he failed to take a tough line after his speech. Mr Greenspan cut interest rates twice in the space of six weeks during the Russian debt default crisis in autumn 1998, which led investors to believe that he would always act to prevent sharp falls in share prices.

Exaggerated faith in Mr Greenspan caused investors to discount the risks of investing in shares and sent the market soaring. Prof Miller estimates that the wider measure of US shares, the S&P 500 index, which has fallen by 400 points from its high of 1500 last March, needs to lose a further 350 points.

Such a fall would bring it back to the level it stood at in December 1996, when Mr Greenspan made that speech. According to Prof Miller, four years of subsequent economic growth means that this is now a fair value for the US market.

Prof Miller's paper has been discussed by senior central bankers on both sides of the Atlantic. The Bank of England has held a seminar on the paper and the Fed asked for a copy of the preliminary version a year ago.

A further crash is not inevitable, if the Fed chairman could gradually bring investors to their senses.

"Mr Greenspan would confirm his status as a great central banker if he can do it," said Prof Miller.

webTitle: Amazon bounces back on better sales

fields.headline: Amazon bounces back on better sales
fields.trailText: Online retailer Amazon, the world's largest e-commerce company, yesterday offered internet stocks investors a little relief following the recent wave of profit warnings from its rivals by revealing that sales were ahead of expectations and losses lower.
fields.body:
Online retailer Amazon, the world's largest e-commerce company, yesterday offered internet stocks investors a little relief following the recent wave of profit warnings from its rivals by revealing that sales were ahead of expectations and losses lower.

Traders took heart from the news, marking Amazon shares up by as much as 40% at one stage and helping a wider stock market rally.

In a statement the dot.com bellwether described the reporting period as the "best quarter in our history", and said losses per share were likely to be around 15% less than predicted due to increased international sales and lower costs.

The company is still making heavy losses but its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, said his pledge that Amazon would turn a profit at an operating level this year was unchanged. "For the fifth quarter we saw substantial improvement in our operations and bottom line performance," he said.

Amazon shares have fallen around 40% this year in the wake of a series of profit warnings from on- and off-line retailers and concerns about the US economic slowdown.

But its confident statement helped shares in other former dot.com favourites such as eBay and Yahoo! stage slight rallies of their own.

The National Retail Federation recently reported that sales of books, videos and music - Amazon's three staple products - were down 25% in the first two months of this year. But the e-tailer said it had bucked the trend and recorded a "very, very slight rise in sales" in the three categories. "In the light of that we're very pleased with our performance, and with the fact that our gross profit rose," chief financial officer Warren Jenson said.

Net sales for the quarter, due on April 24, are expected to exceed $695m (£480m), a 20% increase on the same period last year. Analysts' expectations had put the figure at around $670m. Operating losses are forecast to narrow from $308m to $150m year on year, leaving it with cash and assets worth $640m.

The figures helped to dispel rumours circulating over recent weeks that Amazon was facing a cash crisis. Some analysts had claimed that it could run out of cash before the summer but the company has dismissed such an eventuality.

However, it has taken steps to reduce its cost base by firing around 1,300 staff - many of them workers at its head office in Seattle, Washington.

"Amazon's cash position appears to be healthy, above what we expected and in line with management's outlook," said Henry Blodget, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.

Shares in the company were trading up at around $11 yesterday afternoon but remain a long way from their $68 year's high.

At that stage Amazon was seen as the dot.com sector leader but the last 12 months have been troubled, leading to questions about its cash levels, reporting standards and ability to reach profitability without raising further funds.

Mr Bezos has also come under fire for telling private investors he would not invest in the company because its share price was so volatile.

fields.headline: No mud, no didgeridoos: call this a festival?
fields.standfirst:
All Tomorrow's Parties
Pontins, Camber Sands
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
All Tomorrow's Parties
Pontins, Camber Sands
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Thus far, 2001 has proved a difficult year for the music festival. First Glastonbury was cancelled amid fears over crowd control, then the spectre of foot and mouth cast doubts over every summer event in a pastoral setting. Yet, in the windswept and unlovely environs of a south-coast branch of Pontins, one festival at least is thriving. Now in its third sold-out year, All Tomorrow's Parties serves up three days of alternative music, crazy golf and cramped chalet-living to a 3,000-strong crowd.

Even to the seasoned festival-goer, All Tomorrow's Parties is an anomalous event, as distant from the star-studded stages and corporate hospitality of a major rock festival as Camber Sands's grey coastline is from the bucolic majesty of Michael Eavis's farm. It is the anti-Glastonbury, where nobody is on drugs, nobody is covered in mud and nobody is hosting a free didgeridoo workshop or having their chakras realigned in a "healing space".

The bands playing are so wilfully esoteric and uncommercial as to make the average Glastonbury look like Live Aid. "Curated" by Chicago "post-rock" sextet Tortoise, All Tomorrow's Parties is a parallel musical universe: here no one raises an eyebrow at the Sun Ra Solar Arkestra playing woozy, exploratory jazz while wearing extravagantly sequinned turbans, and people actually dance to the atonal, ear-rupturing racket generated by freeform guitarist Derek Bailey.

In the festival's sole concession to a newsworthy commercialism, Tortoise have persuaded Television - the brainy New York punks whose 1977 album Marquee Moon remains an art-rock benchmark - to reform. Bearing in mind that Television's influence far outweighs their record sales, their surprise appearance is unlikely to oust Hear'Say from the tabloid headlines.

Tortoise themselves embody the festival's uncompromising spirit - their four albums of rambling guitar instrumentals influenced Radiohead's audience-baiting Kid A - and their Friday-night set demonstrates both the advantages and drawbacks of ignoring rock music's rulebook. They display breathtaking musical range, shifting from cocktail jazz to dub reggae to filmic atmospherics, frequently within the space of one track, but they are stymied by an alarming self-indulgence (their love of the extended xylophone solo would test even Patrick Moore's patience) and a complete absence of stage presence.

Live, Tortoise's furrowed brows and static postures suggest men conducting a particularly tricky chemistry experiment. The audience respond in kind. When Tortoise play Monica, a lithe sliver of Curtis Mayfield-influenced funk from their recent album Standards, nobody moves. By the end of the set, at least four members of the crowd are lying prone at the rear of the grandly named Stardust Ballroom. They are fast asleep.

However, Tortoise's problems with stagecraft are minimal compared with those of Saturday-night headliners Boards of Canada. The appearance of the mysterious Scots techno duo is a surprise as they rarely play live, and their performance displays a recalcitrance that suits a band who make their records in a disused nuclear bunker. The stage is so dark, it is virtually impossible to see what's going on. Two bearded figures are occasionally visible, mournfully prodding synthesisers. Grim public information films flicker on an overhead screen and melancholy, distended bleeping fills the air. The effect is intended to be atmospheric and sinister, but Boards of Canada are so remote from their audience that they cannot generate any atmosphere or transcend their surroundings. And when your surroundings are the tatty ballroom of an off-season holiday camp, this is a major problem.

Abstract techno, free jazz and post-rock are not genres generally noted for their sense of humour and, over three days, the high seriousness with which many bands perform becomes rather wearing. Alt-country collective Lambchop provide welcome light relief with a tongue-in-cheek encore of the Sisters of Mercy's overblown goth anthem This Corrosion. Even better is Sunday's set from veteran New York trio Yo La Tengo, which intersperses raging guitar noise with gently introverted pop songs and a wisecracking wit. The sense of relief when singer Ira Kaplan throws his guitar down mid-song, or chucklingly accepts a shouted request, is almost palpable: at last a band interacting with the audience, rather than playing at them.

If Television's entrance bodes badly - they spend 15 minutes tuning up - the band soon ignite. The strained relations among the quartet are legendary and the atmosphere onstage is distinctly frosty, but this only seems to spur guitarists Tom Verlaine and Richard Lloyd on.

Television have the receding hairlines and paunches of men in their 40s, yet play with a visceral passion lacking in much of the weekend. But they are from another era: in these corporate-sponsored times, it seems that some bands outside the mainstream confuse commercial appeal with the desire to entertain, and steadfastly refuse to indulge in either. A pity, particularly if you're in the audience.
fields.bodyText: Thus far, 2001 has proved a difficult year for the music festival. First Glastonbury was cancelled amid fears over crowd control, then the spectre of foot and mouth cast doubts over every summer event in a pastoral setting. Yet, in the windswept and unlovely environs of a south-coast branch of Pontins, one festival at least is thriving. Now in its third sold-out year, All Tomorrow's Parties serves up three days of alternative music, crazy golf and cramped chalet-living to a 3,000-strong crowd. Even to the seasoned festival-goer, All Tomorrow's Parties is an anomalous event, as distant from the star-studded stages and corporate hospitality of a major rock festival as Camber Sands's grey coastline is from the bucolic majesty of Michael Eavis's farm. It is the anti-Glastonbury, where nobody is on drugs, nobody is covered in mud and nobody is hosting a free didgeridoo workshop or having their chakras realigned in a "healing space". The bands playing are so wilfully esoteric and uncommercial as to make the average Glastonbury look like Live Aid. "Curated" by Chicago "post-rock" sextet Tortoise, All Tomorrow's Parties is a parallel musical universe: here no one raises an eyebrow at the Sun Ra Solar Arkestra playing woozy, exploratory jazz while wearing extravagantly sequinned turbans, and people actually dance to the atonal, ear-rupturing racket generated by freeform guitarist Derek Bailey. In the festival's sole concession to a newsworthy commercialism, Tortoise have persuaded Television - the brainy New York punks whose 1977 album Marquee Moon remains an art-rock benchmark - to reform. Bearing in mind that Television's influence far outweighs their record sales, their surprise appearance is unlikely to oust Hear'Say from the tabloid headlines. Tortoise themselves embody the festival's uncompromising spirit - their four albums of rambling guitar instrumentals influenced Radiohead's audience-baiting Kid A - and their Friday-night set demonstrates both the advantages and drawbacks of ignoring rock music's rulebook. They display breathtaking musical range, shifting from cocktail jazz to dub reggae to filmic atmospherics, frequently within the space of one track, but they are stymied by an alarming self-indulgence (their love of the extended xylophone solo would test even Patrick Moore's patience) and a complete absence of stage presence. Live, Tortoise's furrowed brows and static postures suggest men conducting a particularly tricky chemistry experiment. The audience respond in kind. When Tortoise play Monica, a lithe sliver of Curtis Mayfield-influenced funk from their recent album Standards, nobody moves. By the end of the set, at least four members of the crowd are lying prone at the rear of the grandly named Stardust Ballroom. They are fast asleep. However, Tortoise's problems with stagecraft are minimal compared with those of Saturday-night headliners Boards of Canada. The appearance of the mysterious Scots techno duo is a surprise as they rarely play live, and their performance displays a recalcitrance that suits a band who make their records in a disused nuclear bunker. The stage is so dark, it is virtually impossible to see what's going on. Two bearded figures are occasionally visible, mournfully prodding synthesisers. Grim public information films flicker on an overhead screen and melancholy, distended bleeping fills the air. The effect is intended to be atmospheric and sinister, but Boards of Canada are so remote from their audience that they cannot generate any atmosphere or transcend their surroundings. And when your surroundings are the tatty ballroom of an off-season holiday camp, this is a major problem. Abstract techno, free jazz and post-rock are not genres generally noted for their sense of humour and, over three days, the high seriousness with which many bands perform becomes rather wearing. Alt-country collective Lambchop provide welcome light relief with a tongue-in-cheek encore of the Sisters of Mercy's overblown goth anthem This Corrosion. Even better is Sunday's set from veteran New York trio Yo La Tengo, which intersperses raging guitar noise with gently introverted pop songs and a wisecracking wit. The sense of relief when singer Ira Kaplan throws his guitar down mid-song, or chucklingly accepts a shouted request, is almost palpable: at last a band interacting with the audience, rather than playing at them. If Television's entrance bodes badly - they spend 15 minutes tuning up - the band soon ignite. The strained relations among the quartet are legendary and the atmosphere onstage is distinctly frosty, but this only seems to spur guitarists Tom Verlaine and Richard Lloyd on. Television have the receding hairlines and paunches of men in their 40s, yet play with a visceral passion lacking in much of the weekend. But they are from another era: in these corporate-sponsored times, it seems that some bands outside the mainstream confuse commercial appeal with the desire to entertain, and steadfastly refuse to indulge in either. A pity, particularly if you're in the audience.

fields.headline: The dazzling Akram Khan
fields.standfirst:
Akram Khan
Purcell Room, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Akram Khan
Purcell Room, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Twenty years ago Michael Clark hit the dance world as one of those once-in-a-generation artists who floor the competition with their sheer beauty. Clark's body seemed to have been programmed to create nothing but lustrous shapes, and he had the face of an angel. Akram Khan, 26-year-old dancer of Kathak and modern dance, may be built in a different mould - bigger, darker and more majestic than Clark - but he possesses the same magic on stage.

Polaroid Feet, Khan's current show, is the first I've seen in which he presents a full solo evening of Kathak, and it's a pure showcase for his gifts. Even a first-time viewer of Kathak would guess Khan to be a virtuoso. In the fast weighted turns that are special to the style, he achieves a heady contradiction of precise physical detail preserved within a blur of speed. In the intricacies of Kathak footwork, Khan's feet seem to call on more joints and muscles than is humanly possible as he refracts choreographic rhythm into the most delicate of tremors and the most thrilling of percussive stamps.

But it is Khan's upper body, and especially his face, that hold the key to his uniqueness. His torso has a strength and elasticity that allow him to arch, dip and spiral with extravagant grace; his broad arms are as opulent as a ballerina's; and while there is nothing archaic or precious about his face, its expressive range in performance is rapt, fierce and joyous by turns. His control is such that he can brake from passages of vertiginous speed into a monumental stillness that makes the stage hold its breath.

Two hours of one man dancing may seem a tough call for an audience but the programme feels varied. The first half, I guess, inspires the title Polaroid Feet, for it is the section in which Khan and his four musicians improvise mathematical variations within a 16-count cycle, which Khan then develops into instant snapshots of dance. These show off not only Khan's inventiveness but also the exemplary talents of his band. The tabla player in particular, Vishnu Sahai, is blinding, producing drumming of such complexity that it sounds like the work of several musicians.

This is followed by a narrative dance in which Khan not only articulates, with startling expressiveness, a dialogue between the gods Shiva and Parvati, but also manages to balance within his body the physical power and delicacy of each. The closing dance (choreographed by Khan's guru, Sri Pratap Pawar) is a return to pure virtuosity. At this point, after nearly two hours, Khan has reached the kind of high where, as a dancer, he has become inseparable from the dance. His body, brain and heart are all running free. Even though he's dripping, he looks as if he could continue half the night. And most of us would happily stay and watch.

Ends tonight. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

webTitle: Van Nistelrooy shines as Ferguson looks on

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy shines as Ferguson looks on
fields.trailText: With Manchester United not in action this weekend, their manager Sir Alex Ferguson was in Amsterdam to see Ruud van Nistelrooy play for PSV in their match against Ajax.
fields.body:
With Manchester United not in action this weekend, their manager Sir Alex Ferguson was in Amsterdam to see Ruud van Nistelrooy play for PSV in their match against Ajax.

PSV moved 10 points clear of their nearest rivals Feyenoord with a 1-0 victory through Adil Ramzi's goal. While Van Nistelrooy impressed after recvoering from injury, he played down talk of a move to Manchester. "We are close to winning the title," he said. "Nothing is more important at the moment than PSV."

United's European Cup quarter-final opponents Bayern Munich, 1-0 winners in Manchester last week, managed to hold top spot in the Bundesliga on Saturday despite having two players - Bixente Lizarazu and their captain Stefan Effenberg - sent off in a bad-tempered 1-1 draw with Borussia Dortmund. Schalke 04 joined Dortmund and Bayer Leverkusen a point behind the lead after a 5-1 thrashing of Kaiserslautern.

In Spain, Barcelona drew again but the game could hardly have been more different to their 0-0 stalemate against Liverpool last week. Patrick Kluivert's injury-time goal completed his hat-trick and secured a 4-4 result at Villarreal.

Arsenal's European Cup opponents Valencia, beaten 2-1 at Highbury last Wednesday - their third successive defeat - returned to form on Saturday by beating Rayo Vallecano 4-1 away.

Juventus kept in touch with the Serie A leaders Roma after a 45th-minute penalty from Alessandro del Piero gave them a 1-0 win at Verona yesterday. Juve are now six points behind the leaders, who play Fiorentina today. Lazio missed the chance to catch up when their home match with Parma was abandoned after six minutes due to torrential rain.

Udinese beat Bari 2-0, the first win under their new coach Luciano Spalletti, thanks to one very early and one very late goal. Stefano Fiore scored their first in the first minute; Roberto Mussi the second in the third minute of injury time.

In France, Nantes remain on course for an historic treble after a 2-1 win at Metz left them two points clear of second-placed Lille with four games to play.

Over the next two weeks Nantes, winners of the French Cup for the past two seasons, contest semi-finals in the two domestic cup competitions. They are bidding to be the first club to win all three titles in one season since the League Cup was first played in 1995.

fields.headline: Rangers cower in Celtic's shadow
fields.trailText: After the Lord Mayor's show that was Celtic's wrapping up of the title, this third versus second contest - with a Champions League place nominally at stake - was something of a dustman's cart.
fields.body:
After the Lord Mayor's show that was Celtic's wrapping up of the title, this third versus second contest - with a Champions League place nominally at stake - was something of a dustman's cart.

It was not difficult to discern why these sides had entered the game on the back of poor results. The early going was punctuated by free-kicks, mostly untroubling despite a few being within firing range. Among the better used, Bert Konterman's direct strike in the 16th minute was straight and true but did not ask more from the Hibernian goalkeeper Nick Colgan than to keep his concentration.

For Hibernian, Franck Sauzée swung in a ball from the left four minutes later which had Rangers' keeper, Stefan Klos, electing to punch under pressure. Konterman's attempt came after a period of sustained Rangers pressure. Even though much of it consisted of lateral passes, the exercise allowed the visitors to find their touch. Hibs, scrappier, were more reliant on kinder breaks of the ball.

Rod Wallace's conversion of an Arthur Numan cross in the 27th minute may have been ruled offside, but it posted a warning, confirmed as Rangers grew in confidence in midfield.

While Hibs looked most dangerous down their left, they also looked at their most vulnerable on that side, the Fernando Ricksen-Tore Andre Flo combination for Rangers giving Ulrik Laursen and Paul Fenwick an awkward time.

Flo eluded his marker six minutes before the interval to run on to a Billy Dodds pass and force Colgan to block with his knees. Fenwick earned his corn, however, in the 68th minute when he made a saving tackle on Rod Wallace's breakaway and shot.

Greater determination on the part of both sides in the second-half delivered a Numan shot tipped on to the crossbar by Colgan and an open-goal miss by Dodds when he over-cooked his connection with a Ricksen cross. However, it ended as it had begun: Rangers remain six points ahead of the Edinburgh side.

fields.headline: Fulham forget script
fields.trailText: Expectation was as high as the afternoon sun as the Fulham fans queued for entry and a steel band, laid on by the club for Racial Harmony Day, went through their repertoire.
fields.body:
Expectation was as high as the afternoon sun as the Fulham fans queued for entry and a steel band, laid on by the club for Racial Harmony Day, went through their repertoire.

Mohamed Al Fayed's walkabout went down well and, after a procession of old favourites, the show of anti-racism red cards from the terraces was uplifting. Then the whistle blew and the Fulham players forgot their lines.

Within minutes a drizzly rain was blowing in from the Thames, fifth-placed Albion were moving the ball around with purpose and Fulham's normally fluent football had all but deserted them.

Bob Taylor could have made the difference, seeing a looping header turned over by his namesake Maik and then, just before the interval, a left-foot shot flash off a post. In the second half, Lee Hughes stood on the ball when presented with a clear run at goal.

The home side's best efforts came from the substitute Karlheinz Riedle, an acrobatic volley from a corner that flew narrowly wide and a low shot that Russell Hoult did well to block.

"We haven't passed the ball as well as we can," said the Fulham midfielder Lee Clark, "but even the top clubs and top players have off days. It was probably one of our worst performances of the season."

At this stage last season Charlton, the champions, had 15 more points than the eventual runners-up Manchester City, but picked up four draws and three defeats in their final seven games to take the title by only two points.

Fulham, described by the Albion manager Gary Megson as "the best team I have ever seen in this division", are showing all the signs of a similar limp to the line.

fields.headline: Claridge silences the doubters
fields.trailText: Doubts, they've had a few, but after this win they may be difficult to recall. Millwall dealt with theirs in the first half-hour and Steve Claridge dealt with his in the next.
fields.byline: Robert Pryce at the New Den
fields.body:
Doubts, they've had a few, but after this win they may be difficult to recall. Millwall dealt with theirs in the first half-hour and Steve Claridge dealt with his in the next.

After taking a seven-point lead in February, Millwall stumbled through March as though they had shied at promotion. Now they look like the champions elect. "That was a wonderful performance," said the Rotherham manager Ronnie Moore. "Nobody in this division can touch them."

Some supporters had questioned Mark McGhee's transfer moves. They wanted a midfield leader to stiffen a young unit that had lost some confidence, or a long-term striking partner for Neil Harris, not ageing stop gaps. But Claridge, 35 tomorrow and short of match fitness, has provided all the confidence, composure, willingness and ability they required.

"He's just lifted the whole place," said McGhee. "There's no doubt he's the reason we've played so well the last two games."

The last time McGhee signed Claridge on deadline day, for Wolves three years ago, the striker scored no goals in five games and was then packed off to Portsmouth. It looks like working out better this time. Claridge picked up two goals and two man-of-the-match awards on Saturday, and though he has two years left on his contract he has no intention of returning to Portsmouth.

"I love it here," he said. "It's proper. It's proper football. It's my sort of club."

Rotherham, for some reason, looked as though they would rather be elsewhere. They turned up only 50 minutes before kick-off and then absented themselves whenever a cross came over. "I wonder if one or two didn't have the bottle for it," said Moore.

Central defence has been a problem. In the three games since David Artell, a composed, powerful and mobile 20-year-old, was injured, Rotherham have conceded 11 goals. "We've got five 6ft 2in lads out there," Moore pointed out, "yet they still conceded three goals from set pieces."

Artell's return on Saturday did not help, but a visit to shot-shy Swansea on Saturday might. This race keeps turning round and there are a few fences left yet.

fields.headline: City stock is falling fast
fields.trailText: With only one point from the past 18 Birmingham City's promotion hopes are plummeting faster than dotcom share values. In contrast, the chances of Wimbledon making an instant return to the Premiership remain bullish.
fields.body:
With only one point from the past 18 Birmingham City's promotion hopes are plummeting faster than dotcom share values. In contrast, the chances of Wimbledon making an instant return to the Premiership remain bullish.

In beating Trevor Francis's crestfallen side Wimbledon stretched their unbeaten sequence to 10 games and brought themselves to within six points of the play-offs. With eight games remaining and six of those at home the London club have breathed new life into a season that for so long had seemed dead.

The Wimbledon manager Terry Burton said: "While we're playing like we are and picking up points the chance of getting into the play-offs is there. We're probably as close as we have been all season.

"We've just got to look forward. There are enough games and enough points to play for and if we can go into the remaining games with the same positive attitude then we won't go far wrong."

That positive attitude was in abundance on Saturday as the hosts took only 15 minutes to shatter their visitors' fragile confidence. A long goal kick from Kelvin Davis fell to the deadline-day signing David Nielsen, who marked his home debut with a goal, finishing powerfully past Ian Bennett from the edge of the area.

Birmingham's attacking threat in the opening period was negligible and Trevor Francis opted to switch to a more offensive 4-3-3 formation after 28 minutes, bringing on Dele Adebola for Stan Lazaridis. However, the substitute was clearly unfit and was replaced 16 minutes later by Geoff Horsfield.

The second-half introduction of Michael Hughes turned the game as the Northern Ireland international, who was making his sixth appearance of the season following a broken leg, took only five minutes to double Wimbledon's lead, squeezing a 25-yard free-kick past Bennett.

Two minutes later Hughes floated another free-kick on to the head of his fellow Northern Ireland international Mark Williams to extend the hosts' lead. Although Birmingham replied with a consolation effort from Marcelo four minutes from time their performance suggests that their own play-off place is far from safe.

"We certainly don't have enough points," Francis said. "We need quite a few more but I don't know what that figure is. Whatever the problem is - obviously there are tired legs and tired minds - we've got to snap out of it."

With away games at Tranmere tomorrow and Bolton on Good Friday Francis knows that any more performances like this could well see a season of promise fall apart at the seams. "It's a vitally important week for us," he said.

fields.headline: Blackburn on the up
fields.trailText: Hard to believe, but last season Blackburn Rovers finished below Queens Park Rangers in the league, one place behind the London side who were in 10th. This time round Rovers will indubitably finish the higher but what is increasingly likely is that they will take the second automatic promotion slot behind Fulham as well.
fields.body:
Hard to believe, but last season Blackburn Rovers finished below Queens Park Rangers in the league, one place behind the London side who were in 10th. This time round Rovers will indubitably finish the higher but what is increasingly likely is that they will take the second automatic promotion slot behind Fulham as well.

Saturday's victory put clear daylight between Graeme Souness's men and third-placed Bolton Wanderers, and as the manager said: "We are in a wonderful position because our destiny is in our hands.

"We're not going to win all the games but neither are the teams who are challenging us: we'll be punched on the nose and it's how we're going to deal with those punches when they come. To date when that's happened to us we've bounced back and shown great character and if we're going to get out of this league we're going to have to keep that kind of attitude."

Character is not a word that has been much used in conjunction with Blackburn since their championship win in 1995 but that is one commodity Souness does not lack.

In just over a year in charge the tough Scot has managed to succeed where Ray Harford, Roy Hodgson and Brian Kidd have failed before him and instil plenty of character into his team. So much so that when they fell behind to an early QPR goal they never faltered, rolling their sleeves up and grinding out a good result.

Rovers were unflustered after Chris Plummer's header from a corner had surprisingly put the home side ahead and David Dunn's scrambled shot soon restored parity. When Matt Jansen fired Rovers ahead on the stroke of half-time the game was up for QPR and Eyal Berkovic's late strike was no more than they deserved.

"It wasn't a classic but given that Birmingham lost and Bolton didn't play it was a good afternoon for us," said Souness. For poor old QPR, on the other hand, only heartbreak awaits. Under the less than inspiring management of Ian Holloway they have lost five, drawn two and are eight points adrift of safety with just six games remaining.

Worse, their parent company, Loftus Road plc, is losing £570,000 a month and they were put into administration last week along with their sister club Wasps by Chris Wright, who then did some adroit wheeler dealing and bought the rugby operation back. The football club and the ground still await a new owner, though Wright will underwrite their costs until October.

Relegation would be a hammer blow. They would lose out on more than £2m of television money, their gate receipts would be reduced and they have 22 players coming out of contract this summer who can leave on free transfers. And to think they were in the Premiership just five years ago.

fields.headline: Black rocket in photo finish
fields.trailText: There are still more runners in the race to avoid relegation from the First Division than finished the Grand National, but the bad news for Crystal Palace is three of them cleared big fences on Saturday.
fields.body:
There are still more runners in the race to avoid relegation from the First Division than finished the Grand National, but the bad news for Crystal Palace is three of them cleared big fences on Saturday.

A late piece of Black magic earned a point for Palace after they had led for most of the game, but victories for Stockport, Grimsby and Huddersfield pushed them to the back of the field and into the relegation places.

At least Palace extended their unbeaten run to three matches - they had lost the previous six - and their manager Alan Smith did not bear the countenance of someone sinking in the relegation mire. "It was a pretty good performance," he said. "We've taken four points off Watford this season. It just goes to show that there's a thin dividing line in the division."

More pertinent is the thin dividing line towards the foot of the table that now separates Palace from Huddersfield, who have a game in hand. Smith has only six matches to prevent that slide into the Second Division. Not since Terry Venables dragged them out of the old Third in 1977 have they stooped so low.

A fine finale will outshine memories of an otherwise turgid game here - even Watford's manager Graham Taylor was moved to call it "crap" - as each team lost their grip on three handy points.

Palace took the lead with an early penalty: the leggy Ricardo Fuller gangled into the area and was brought down by Robert Page, who saw yellow before Dean Austin did the business from the spot.

"I couldn't see Watford scoring, but then you never know with a Graham Taylor side," said Smith ruefully later.

Inside the last quarter-hour Allan Nielsen surprised him by heading home and then, two minutes later, Tommy Mooney hammered the ball beyond the leaping Aleksandrs Kolinko and was duly buried at the bottom of a seven-man pile as the play-offs hoved back into view.

Yet Tommy Black obscured the vision by lashing a 20-yard shot through a thicket of players at the last and the hands-on-head exasperation switched back from south London to north.

fields.headline: O'Neill accepts the title deeds
fields.standfirst: Mike Wilson on what comes next for a triumphant Celtic
fields.trailText: Celtic celebrated Scottish championship victory on Saturday as if it were their first title in ages when, in fact, it was only two seasons ago that they last performed the feat.
fields.body:
Celtic celebrated Scottish championship victory on Saturday as if it were their first title in ages when, in fact, it was only two seasons ago that they last performed the feat.

Back then, the celebrations were muted by brooding anticipation, confirmed when Wim Jansen left the club, and the acrimony surrounding the manager's departure was only accentuated by the difficulties in recruiting his successor.

That the next Celtic manager should happen to be the highly respected Dr Jozef Venglos was a tribute to the club's powers of persuasion. But the stop-gap nature of the appointment underlined an uncomfortable fact - the notion of Celtic being a world power was simply a delusion.

Two ordinary European campaigns since are further corroboration. Celtic may have been the first British club to win the European Cup, but that was in 1967, well over 30 years ago. As the title celebrations ebb, it is towards Europe that Martin O'Neill will be looking. Before and in the immediate wake of the slender, at times nervous, 1-0 win over St Mirren, he was insisting that his side are far from the finished article.

"It was as satisfying a moment as I've ever had," said O'Neill about the championship victory. "I certainly do not want to diminish anything else I've done. When I was at Wycombe Wanderers and we won the Vauxhall Conference I thought it was the greatest moment on earth. It didn't matter whether Real Madrid were winning the European Cup on the same night. But we've won a championship here in what has been a long season.

"It started on the last Sunday of July and the culmination is here. We have played in all sorts of weather and conditions and we have had all sorts of performances too. But to win 28 out of 33 games is incredible.

"We'll have to improve. The nucleus of the side is strong and will deal with European football. But I don't have enough on the periphery. We need a bigger and better squad."

The surprise would be the board refusing to furnish him with at least some money to strengthen the squad. After all, there is not only Europe to think about but the likely re-emergence of their Old Firm rivals, Rangers.

"Rangers will come roaring back with a vengeance," said O'Neill. "Could you tell [owner] David Murray not to produce any more money? I'm of the belief they have a lot of talented footballers. They were a point away from qualifying for the second stage of the Champions League. They will be massively disappointed. I expect Rangers not to take this lying down."

Hard cash is not, however, the stuff of legends. Of all the attractions of being at Celtic, the possibility of becoming a legend must figure highly in O'Neill's mind. In which case, he may be inclined to build steadily rather than risk failing wildly with someone else's money. That is why the celebrations at Celtic Park were so uninhibited on Saturday. This was not a chequebook victory. Integrity remained intact.

Understandably, O'Neill's name is being linked to the manager's job at Manchester United, which falls vacant when Sir Alex Ferguson's contract expires next year. He is, after all, just a Tennent's Scottish Cup win away from a domestic treble. Imagine, though, if O'Neill were to take over from Ferguson. Even if he were to win another Champions Cup - a tall order in a hard act to follow - he could end up no more than a keeper of the flame.

It is a happy coincidence that the championship should be won during the same weekend as the US Masters. Celtic should aspire to that level of detail which has the green keepers at Augusta tending their lawns with nail scissors. Celtic are a long way from that - on and off the field - which places O'Neill in an enviable position. Sir Alex is Sir Alex because of how far he developed Manchester United. O'Neill is obviously attuned to Celtic and he has quickly delivered silverware.

This season he has created a team that is the antithesis of the swashbuckling Celtics of old without a murmur of protest. It is because there is a sense of one being perfect for the other.

Two seasons ago, Celtic were not a world power and the fans knew it. This time, the fans sung with such gusto because of the wonderfully endless possibilities that now await.

fields.headline: Nationwide round-up
fields.trailText: Tranmere look doomed to relegation from the First Division. The Merseysiders' recent FA Cup heroics were a dim memory as a 3-1 defeat at Grimsby - achieved despite Jason Koumas's 27th-minute goal that gave the Merseysiders a lead they held until the final half-hour - left them 10 points from safety.
fields.body:
Tranmere look doomed to relegation from the First Division. The Merseysiders' recent FA Cup heroics were a dim memory as a 3-1 defeat at Grimsby - achieved despite Jason Koumas's 27th-minute goal that gave the Merseysiders a lead they held until the final half-hour - left them 10 points from safety.

The result allowed the Mariners to climb out of the bottom three, as did Huddersfield , 1-0 winners over Wolves at Molineux. Sheffield Wednesday were pulled back into trouble with a 2-1 defeat at their fellow strugglers Stockport .

But the most exciting game in the division came at the Priestfield Stadium. Gillingham raced into a 4-0 lead, Norwich recovered to 4-3 down and only a pair of fine saves from Vince Bartram denied them a draw.

With seven games still to play, Oxford United have become the first side in the Nationwide League to be relegated.

The Second Division stragglers were beaten 1-0 at home by Oldham thanks to David Eyres's last-minute free-kick, but even a draw would not have been enough to save them.

David Kemp, the Oxford manager, said: "I felt we didn't do a lot wrong. Being relegated is nothing new. The club was in a desperate way before I came here."

Relegation capped a terrible weekend for the club: a fire of "doubtful origin" caused between £20,000 and £60,000 worth of damage to their ground on Friday night. Oxford could soon be joined by Swansea , who lost 1-0 at Bristol Rovers .

Cardiff regained second place in the Third Division with a 2-1 win over last-placed Torquay . More impressive, however, was the 2-0 win over the leaders Chesterfield that cemented a play-off place for Leyton Orient.
