webTitle: Pinpoint Pires has the final say

fields.headline: Pinpoint Pires has the final say
fields.standfirst: Haphazard Gunners rely on the French connection to reach Cardiff
fields.trailText: Arsenal made a nice Sunday roast of Tottenham Hotspur here yesterday but went easy on the stuffing. The narrowness of the scoreline belied the ultimate comfort of their victory, even though Spurs took an early lead.
fields.body:
Arsenal made a nice Sunday roast of Tottenham Hotspur here yesterday but went easy on the stuffing. The narrowness of the scoreline belied the ultimate comfort of their victory, even though Spurs took an early lead.

The only doubt about the ability of Arsène Wenger's team to reach the club's 14th FA Cup final, where they will meet Liverpool in a re-run of the 1971 final, concerned the waywardness of Arsenal's finishing, allied to a series of excellent saves from Neil Sullivan. These factors alone kept Tottenham in the contest after half-time as they found themselves outrun,outpassed and eventually outclassed.

So Highbury's old guard - David Seaman (37), Tony Adams (34), Martin Keown (34) and Lee Dixon (37) - plus a Frenchman or two are now set to seek some familiar glory against a fresh background, the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff. For Wenger it will be a chance to win the FA Cup for the second time in four years.

That Arsenal's winning goal, scored by Robert Pires, was delayed until the 73rd minute was as much a tribute to the Spurs goalkeeper as a reflection on the haphazard shooting of Wenger's attack. Nevertheless should Arsenal's sense of direction prove as awry on May 12 they may set out for Cardiff but end up at Holyhead.

For Glenn Hoddle, with all of a week's experience as Tottenham's new manager, the afternoon offered little except confirmation that rebuilding this Spurs team will take more than a few new roof tiles and a spot of grouting. The sheer ordinariness of the side bequeathed to him by the peremptory dismissal of George Graham was there for all to see.

In addition there was a timidity about much of Spurs' football which in any North London derby is asking for trouble, let alone an encounter with Arsenal in a Cup semi-final. As Hoddle admitted after the game: "Mentally we weren't big enough and strong enough on the ball."

The combination of physical and cerebral power that makes Patrick Vieira such an awesome force between the penalty areas threw Spurs' shortcomings into even starker relief. When Vieira strode forward things almost invariably happened; when Tim Sherwood or Stephen Clemence stepped out few Tottenham movements survived a second pass before the ball was lost.

Neither Sherwood nor Clemence, each barely match fit, would have played yesterday had this been a run-of-the-mill fixture and Stephen Carr and Sol Campbell fell into a similar category. In fact, when Vieira headed Arsenal level just past the half-hour Campbell was off the field for treatment, soon departing for good with another ankle injury.

In addition, the loss of Les Ferdinand 10 minutes into the second half with a damaged hamstring put paid to the remnants of Hoddle's original tactical plan, which employed Ferdinand as a lone striker supported by Steffen Iversen and Sergei Rebrov and a four-man midfield.

This demanded much of Ferdinand, who worked hard and covered a lot of ground before he was forced off. Thereafter Spurs played with Iversen and Rebrov up front but by then their passing had become so ragged and bare of ideas that it was a struggle to cross the halfway line.

Arsenal's performance was as rounded and resolute as one would expect it to be, their only real disappointment being the lack of impact made by Thierry Henry, whose speed alone had been expected to win the match. In losing a league game 2-0 at Highbury eight days earlier Tottenham had choked on the French forward's vapour trails but yesterday Henry seemed unusually reluctant to take on their defenders for pace.

The regularity with which Silvain Wiltord spun off opponents to find space in threatening areas caught the eye more when Arsenal came within scoring range. The authority of Pires, Lauren and Ray Parlour, strong at the outset, was absolute long before the finish, by which time Tottenham's exhausted legs were starting to look like wet string.

Yet this semi-final still managed to produce an eye-catching contest and although the outcome seemed clear long before the end there was always the chance, with one goal separating the teams, that Spurs would find fresh stamina from somewhere and at least take the game to extra-time. Certainly Vieira did his best to prolong the suspense with two uncharacteristic, unforced errors in the closing minutes.

That Arsenal were forced on to the back foot at all added more interest to the match than there might have been. It was, however, a little like Henry Cooper flattening Cassius Clay, as Muhammad Ali then was; the outcome proved inevitable but the moment could still be savoured.

Up to the 14th minute Tottenham had done little except pass warily back and forth across the pitch. Then Gary Doherty chested down a cross from Sherwood to Ferdinand, who made space for a shot and drew a fine blocking save from Seaman. Dixon headed the ball clear only for Iversen to drive it back towards the far post, where Doherty, almost on his knees, nodded it into the net.

For a time Arsenal did their utmost to preserve Spurs' lead, Pires racing clear after catching Clemence in possession but failing to beat Sullivan and Parlour wasting two slightly harder opportunities. Then Campbell collected his injury plus a booking for a foul on Parlour and from Pires's free-kick Vieira, rising just where the Tottenham captain would have been, glanced the scores level.

Pires, Parlour and Wiltord continued to squander chances but with 17 minutes remaining, and as if to say that enough was enough, Vieira surged through once more to send Wiltord to the right-hand byline. A low centre to the far post, a tap-in by Pires and if all else fails Arsenal's season can still find a Welsh silver lining.

fields.headline: Heskey heads off bravehearts
fields.standfirst: Liverpool leave it late to reach a second final, writes  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: An hour and a half before the kick-off, the players of Wycombe Wanderers walked out on to the Villa Park pitch in their new warm-up kit. Each had just been handed his copy of the match programme, and most of them were busy ensuring that their names were there, next to the legends of Liverpool in a real-life FA Cup semi-final.
fields.body:
An hour and a half before the kick-off, the players of Wycombe Wanderers walked out on to the Villa Park pitch in their new warm-up kit. Each had just been handed his copy of the match programme, and most of them were busy ensuring that their names were there, next to the legends of Liverpool in a real-life FA Cup semi-final.

In all honesty, that was the closest they were to come to taking the next step. Despite the display of copious amounts of courage and endeavour, there was never any real doubt that the side currently 18th in the Nationwide Second Division would be forced to yield to the team standing fourth in the Premier League.

Not that they made it easy for their opponents. As the match went into injury-time, with Liverpool desperately clearing their lines, it was impossible not to admire the way Wycombe had conducted themselves. Their limitations were plain to see, but they had strained every sinew to give an account of themselves that would at least do justice to their feat in reaching the last four and reward the 20,000 fans who made the journey up the M40.

Even when goals from Emile Heskey and Robbie Fowler, in the 78th and 83rd minutes, had appeared to put the issue beyond doubt, Wycombe came back to keep the match alive with a classic underdog's route one goal, finished off by a looping shot from their captain, Keith Ryan. And then, urged on by the blue-clad mass in the Holte End, they produced a feverish final assault which Liverpool repelled only at some cost to their manager's nerves.

So Lawrie Sanchez could lead his team back home with a real sense of pride. After all, with 45 minutes gone the score had been nil-nil -just as it had been at the Nou Camp on Thursday - except that then Liverpool's opponents had been Rivaldo, Kluivert and the rest of Barcelona's all-star team, rather than Andy Rammell, Paul McCarthy, and Wycombe's collection of Conference veterans and honest journeymen. And the other difference was that this time Liverpool were trying to score goals rather than prevent them.

Liverpool had appeared in 21 previous semi-finals in the competition, and Wycombe in none. Now Liverpool will attempt to win it for the sixth time, which would give them their second trophy of the season, with a third - the Uefa Cup - still a possibility. No wonder Gérard Houllier received an ovation as he left the pitch.

Once again Houllier shuffled the starting line-up to meet the particular requirements of this tie, selecting Gary McAllister to provide the service for the two strikers, Fowler and Michael Owen, but the plan was foiled by a glistening surface which made accurate through-balls difficult to achieve and McAllister a peripheral figure. The first half passed with few chances for either side, although Martin Taylor in the Wycombe goal distinguished himself by twice dashing out to smother the ball at Owen's feet.

Wycombe's goal attempts before half-time were limited to a speculative 30-yard chip from Ryan which floated over Sander Westerveld's bar and a glancing header with which the same player met Michael Simpson's free-kick, caught with some difficulty by the Liverpool goalkeeper. Both sides had penalty claims denied, first when Chris Vinnicombe appeared to clip Owen's ankles and then when Markus Babbel seemed to push Steve Brown as they tussled under a cross.

The first of Liverpool's two crucial substitutions came six minutes into the second half, Steven Gerrard replacing the limping Nick Barmby and immediately injecting extra pace into Liverpool's attacks. Sanchez replied by throwing on Roy Essandoh, scorer of the last-minute winner in the quarter-final against Leicester City, after 55 minutes, but Wycombe were never able to attack the penalty area with the sort of high balls that might have made the most of his ability in the air.

When Houllier sent on Heskey for Christian Ziege just after the hour, Liverpool switched to a 4-3-3 formation and immediately raised the pressure. After the Wycombe goalkeeper met Heskey's powerful 75th-minute header with a tremendous diving catch, the cries of "Taylor for England" were still ringing around the Holte End when the 34-year-old former coalminer raced out yet again to dive at Owen's feet as the England striker tore in to meet Gerrard's incisive pass. The ball went out for a corner but, after Taylor had punched McAllister's kick away, it was knocked back in by Gerrard with such speed and accuracy that all Heskey had to do was incline his head to send the ball into the net and give Liverpool the lead.

The immediate arrival of Danny Murphy in place of Owen saw Liverpool revert to their original formation, but they were soon able to extend their advantage. After Jamie Bates was adjudged, perhaps harshly, to have brought down Heskey while they tussled for the ball just outside the area, Fowler carefully curled his free-kick inside Taylor's left-hand post.

Ryan's reponse raised the vision of a last-minute miracle, adding statistical respectability to a proud day in the history of a club which played its first match in 1887 but which entered the Football League only eight years ago. The refusal of the dignified Sanchez to employ the tactics of cynicism against more gifted opponents did enormous credit to him and his players, among whom the resolute Brown and his midfield partner Dannie Bulman were outstanding.

webTitle: Coventry's faith and hope boosted by Leicester's charity

fields.headline: Coventry's faith and hope boosted by Leicester's charity
fields.trailText: True to the club's traditions, Coventry City are saving their best until last. Successive away wins have given Gordon Strachan's side the momentum to believe that another famous escape from relegation is possible. The hard work, however, starts now.
fields.body:
True to the club's traditions, Coventry City are saving their best until last. Successive away wins have given Gordon Strachan's side the momentum to believe that another famous escape from relegation is possible. The hard work, however, starts now.

So often have City survived by the skin of their teeth during their 34-year stint in the top flight that the qualities required to stay up are ingrained in supporters, players and staff alike. Yet should they manage the miracle this season, it will represent one of their more impressive efforts.

After visiting Old Trafford next Saturday they face Sunderland at home, Ipswich away and Liverpool at Highfield Road. In terms of difficulty, Manchester United away speaks for itself, and the other three games will be just as important for Coventry's opponents with European places up for grabs.

A comfortable win over a dismal Leicester side on Saturday - only the second time Coventry have won matches back to back all season - showed, however, that City are the one team of the bottom four who are finding form and piled the pressure on Middlesbrough, the side one point ahead of them, to beat Sunderland at the Riverside Stadium tonight.

Strachan has instilled the need to scrap and battle into his players and it took Leicester until half-time to gain a semblance of control against the passion and pace with which Coventry started. By then Lee Carsley's firm header had restored the visitors' lead after Ade Akinbiyi's close-range finish, following a mistake by Chris Kirkland in the Coventry goal, had equalised Craig Bellamy's first-minute strike.

Carsley was relegated with Blackburn Rovers two years ago but is convinced that the tame capitulation by Brian Kidd's side will not be repeated by his present club.

"Everyone knows what it takes to get out of trouble by scrapping," Carsley said. "The difference at Blackburn was that it took six or seven games for the players to realise that we were in a sticky situation and that we may not get out of it. The players were just presuming that we would be all right."

The thrust for Saturday's victory came from Bellamy, a constant attacking threat from left midfield, Mustapha Hadji and John Hartson, whose third goal since his move from Wimbledon dispelled any hopes Leicester had of winning their first match since Wycombe knocked them out of the FA Cup a month ago.

Indeed the weekend could not have gone worse for Peter Taylor's side, who saw their former manager Martin O'Neill lift the Scottish title with Celtic on Saturday and watched what might have been in the Cup semi-final at Villa Park yesterday. This fifth successive defeat has virtually ended Leicester's hopes of qualifying for Europe and Taylor must be thankful for the tremendous start his side made to the season.

fields.headline: Sanchez takes a million consolations
fields.standfirst: Roy Collins sees Wycombe fail bravely in their bid for Cup history
fields.trailText: As his players cried in the dressing room about what might have been, Lawrie Sanchez, Wycombe's highly impressive manager, was already mapping out the future in his head, poetically declaring: "This is the beginning, not the end.
fields.body:
As his players cried in the dressing room about what might have been, Lawrie Sanchez, Wycombe's highly impressive manager, was already mapping out the future in his head, poetically declaring: "This is the beginning, not the end.

"I can build a team with the £1m we have made from this Cup run and this time next year I hope to be sitting here talking to you because we have won promotion."

First, of course, he has to inspire his side to the two victories he believes they need to secure Second Division safety this season, beginning at Swansea tomorrow. Training for that, however, had to wait until the formalities of semi-final losers had been properly observed.

"We're having a wake at the Belfry tonight and then we'll get on with the rest of our season," Sanchez said. "I told the players they were magnificent today but then, like me, they really believed we would be the first Second Division side to reach the final."

Wycombe's display reflected their belief. And on a day when it was Liverpool, the hottest semi-final favourites in history, who froze, they will be heartbroken at failing to make FA Cup history.

Forget all the nonsense about Wycombe coming to Villa Park for a day out. They came to fulfil what they believed was their destiny and until Paul Durkin's final whistle woke them from their dream, they could not be shaken from their belief.

That is why Keith Ryan picked the ball out of his net after his late strike and ran back to the centre line with it. And why there was a tear or two on the faces of the rest of the players as they took the crowd's salute at the end, most of them by then wearing Liverpool red.

Wycombe clearly won the colour pageant as the teams emerged from the tunnel, bringing out their little squares of cardboard to paper the Holte End with perfectly co-ordinated two tone blue.

They also topped the gesture at the end of last season's FA Cup final when the Chelsea captain Denis Wise became the first man to receive the trophy while holding his son. Yesterday Wycombe's Steve Brown became the first man to walk out for a semi-final carrying his child, 13-month-old Maxwell, who recovered from serious illness to fulfil his role as one of the mascots.

To add to the touching image of Brown warming up while cradling his baby on his hip, Sanchez, wearing his club jacket and buckled matchday shoes, unselfconsciously exchanged passes with his five-year-old Jack, whose mother tragically died of cancer.

Those pictures seemed to be a sign that Wycombe, in their light and dark blue quartered shirts that gave them the appearance of undecided Boat Race supporters, were, after all, only here for a day out.

As they settled, Ryan, a signing from Berkhamsted Town, and Dannie Bulman, once of Ashford Town, began to get the better of Nick Barmby and Gary McAllister in the midfield exchanges. That caused the Kop army to fall silent for the first time since the first wave of them arrived in Birmingham at breakfast time, realising that they might, after all, be involved in a real football match.

The feeling grew in the second half and Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier, in sending on Emile Heskey and Steven Gerrard, also acknowledged that he needed sledgehammers to crack these unexpectedly hard nuts.

"I am a great believer in substitutes as 10% of our goals this season have come from them," Houllier said. "And I didn't want to play extra-time. I was a bit upset at the people who said that we would be taking this game lightly. We had them watched six times."

Liverpool fans finally rediscovered their voices after the goals from Heskey and Fowler. "Sanchez, Sanchez, what's the score?" they chanted, proving that they have not forgotten losing to his goal for Wimbledon in the 1988 final. Sanchez, to his credit, cupped a hand to his ear as though he had not got the message.

His wonderful Wycombe lads certainly refused to accept the writing on the wall, forcing an 87th-minute goal from Ryan. Sanchez began conducting the Wycombe choir to greater efforts but, after a five-month adventure, they finally had to pack away their instruments.

fields.headline: Redknapp finds the balance
fields.trailText: Harry Redknapp is adamant that, contrary to rumours, Frank Lampard is not for sale. But as the West Ham manager knows only too well following the departure of Rio Ferdinand to Leeds United, every player has his price.
fields.body:
Harry Redknapp is adamant that, contrary to rumours, Frank Lampard is not for sale. But as the West Ham manager knows only too well following the departure of Rio Ferdinand to Leeds United, every player has his price.

Moreover, Lampard's late equaliser at Villa Park may well prove priceless. Scored three minutes from time, the goal ensured the Hammers arrested a run of four successive defeats that had taken them to the cusp of the drop zone.

More important is the effect Lampard's strike will have on his side's confidence. A fifth reverse on the bounce would surely have set the Nationwide League Ahead warning signs flashing at Upton Park, especially with three of their remaining six fixtures against clubs similarly troubled.

Middlesbrough, Manchester City and Derby County all lie in wait but Redknapp remains confident his side will prevail.

"We've got six games left and there won't be any hassle picking up plenty of points," he predicted.

On the evidence available at Villa Park, Redknapp's confidence does not look misplaced, but where that leaves Joe Cole between now and the end of the season creates an intriguing subplot.

Redknapp decided he could not afford to have the creative but sometimes ephemeral talents of both Cole and Paolo di Canio in his side.

"At the moment I find it difficult for the team to have a shape if both Cole and Di Canio are in the side, that's why I left him [Cole] out," Redknapp explained.

"Cole has great ability, great skills and will be a great player. At the moment it's a question of finding him a position. It may sound strange but maybe he's got to learn a position. Perhaps his best role will be as a secondary striker."

Even a tertiary striker would have been short odds to convert one particular opportunity presented to Di Canio. But the Italian failed to add to Frédéric Kanouté's opener when he scooped the ball over an open goal rather than into it.

To add to Redknapp's dilemma, the introduction of Cole as a substitute resulted in him winning the free-kick from which Frank Lampard equalised on 87 minutes.

In between times David Ginola showed there is a place for entertainers by curling a free-kick into the top corner of Shaka Hislop's goal before delivering the cross for Lee Hendrie to score his third goal in as many games.

Villa's failure to hold on to a lead added up to an all-too-familiar story for the manager John Gregory, who claimed: "That's nine times this season we've conceded a lead like that and that's 18 points wasted. We could have won the league by now!"

Not quite, but qualification for the Uefa Cup might be less of an outside bet than it is now.

fields.headline: City freewheel towards the drop
fields.trailText: With red cards flying like sparks in the fiery finale, the wheels appear to have fallen off Manchester City's frantic sojourn in the top flight.
fields.body:
With red cards flying like sparks in the fiery finale, the wheels appear to have fallen off Manchester City's frantic sojourn in the top flight.

Their plight was typified by Nicky Weaver who single-handedly kept Everton out with a trio of eye-catching stops and saved a penalty at full stretch before undermining everything by allowing David Weir's innocuous late header to creep into the net.

"Nicky made some outstanding saves," sympathised his manager Joe Royle, back at his spiritual home for the first time since he resigned amid acrimonious whisperings in March 1997. "I was more disappointed with the free header than the save for the last goal. It was just a dead bounce. That's symptomatic of our season. We continue to shoot ourselves in the foot."

With six games remaining, City wallow in 19th place, four points from safety. That margin may be extended to seven should Middlesbrough emerge victorious from the Teesside-Wearside derby today.

All three of the home goals came courtesy of distinctly Nationwide League defending, while the late dismissals of Paul Dickov and Alessandro Pistone for handbags on the touchline added to the farce.

Such an emphatic defeat was hard on City who tore the home side apart in the opening minutes. Andrei Kanchelskis dragged a shot across Paul Gerrard's goal and wide of the far post after barely 20 seconds; when the Ukrainian's shot three minutes later hit the recalled Paulo Wanchope, Dickov fluffed his effort from just outside the six-yard box.

With the Toffees rattled, the visitors found reward. Kanchel skis and David Unsworth tussled on the ground and City were awarded a free-kick. Danny Tiatto, whose feet had been dancing merrily while the home side laboured, crossed for Jeff Whitley to head his first goal of the season.

The cat-calls sparked an immediate response. Niclas Alexandersson's cross was nodded back across goal by Kevin Campbell for Duncan Ferguson to sidefoot an equaliser. Five minutes before the interval Michael Ball lobbed forward and with Richard Dunne static, Campbell burst through before being tripped as he strode round the sprawling goalkeeper. Ball's penalty, low to Weaver's left, was palmed out, but the England defender calmly prodded the loose ball into the empty net.

"It was a strange first half for us," said the Everton manager Walter Smith. "City put us under pressure in all parts of the pitch, but we still created chances. I feel we've got a bit to do to ensure we stay up, but this was a massive result."

Subsequently faced by a calmer rearguard, City rarely threatened parity. Instead, Everton prospected on the break. Weaver denied Steve Watson, who had sprinted from inside his own half after dispossessing Alfie Haaland on the edge of the home area. With the visiting supporters still cooing after Weaver's instinctive save from Scott Gemmill's shot, Weir's header from the resultant corner bounced in the mud and crept through.

"I know my position is under scrutiny, but I've got faith in my own ability," insisted the Under-21 international. At least he did not have to test his confidence late on against either Ferguson, who limped off, or his replacement Francis Jeffers.

The livewire striker, who continues to deliberate his future at the club, dislocated his shoulder and is unlikely to feature over Easter.

With six games remaining, City wallow in 19th place, four points from safety. That margin may be extended to seven should Middlesbrough emerge victorious from the Teesside-Wearside derby today. All three of the home goals came courtesy of distinctly Nationwide League defending, while the late dismissals of Paul Dickov and Alessandro Pistone for handbags on the touchline added to the farce. Such an emphatic defeat was hard on City who tore the home side apart in the opening minutes. Andrei Kanchelskis dragged a shot across Paul Gerrard's goal and wide of the far post after barely 20 seconds; when the Ukrainian's shot three minutes later hit the recalled Paulo Wanchope, Dickov fluffed his effort from just outside the six-yard box. With the Toffees rattled, the visitors found reward. Kanchel skis and David Unsworth tussled on the ground and City were awarded a free-kick. Danny Tiatto, whose feet had been dancing merrily while the home side laboured, crossed for Jeff Whitley to head his first goal of the season. The cat-calls sparked an immediate response. Niclas Alexandersson's cross was nodded back across goal by Kevin Campbell for Duncan Ferguson to sidefoot an equaliser. Five minutes before the interval Michael Ball lobbed forward and with Richard Dunne static, Campbell burst through before being tripped as he strode round the sprawling goalkeeper. Ball's penalty, low to Weaver's left, was palmed out, but the England defender calmly prodded the loose ball into the empty net. "It was a strange first half for us," said the Everton manager Walter Smith. "City put us under pressure in all parts of the pitch, but we still created chances. I feel we've got a bit to do to ensure we stay up, but this was a massive result." Subsequently faced by a calmer rearguard, City rarely threatened parity. Instead, Everton prospected on the break. Weaver denied Steve Watson, who had sprinted from inside his own half after dispossessing Alfie Haaland on the edge of the home area. With the visiting supporters still cooing after Weaver's instinctive save from Scott Gemmill's shot, Weir's header from the resultant corner bounced in the mud and crept through. "I know my position is under scrutiny, but I've got faith in my own ability," insisted the Under-21 international. At least he did not have to test his confidence late on against either Ferguson, who limped off, or his replacement Francis Jeffers. The livewire striker, who continues to deliberate his future at the club, dislocated his shoulder and is unlikely to feature over Easter.

webTitle: Chelsea deliver as time runs out

fields.headline: Chelsea deliver as time runs out
fields.trailText: Chelsea's golden oldies enjoyed a glittering day here; age could not wither them even on their travels. What motivated them? The spectre of the Intertoto Cup, with its long summer journeys to Europe's more obscure venues? Or must they get on the right side of Claudio Ranieri before the surplus-to-requirements list is finalised?
fields.body:
Chelsea's golden oldies enjoyed a glittering day here; age could not wither them even on their travels. What motivated them? The spectre of the Intertoto Cup, with its long summer journeys to Europe's more obscure venues? Or must they get on the right side of Claudio Ranieri before the surplus-to-requirements list is finalised?

A bit of both probably combined to alleviate the travel sickness which has plagued their pursuit of greater honours this season.

They pulled Derby all over Pride Park leaving the hosts decidedly groggy. Yet Chelsea's best away performance will soon be forgotten if they do not take something tangible from this season.

Title failure weighs heavily on Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, who even in his moment of personal triumph was dismissive of any compensations. "I'd give 10 of my goals to be competing with United," he said.

It is questionable whether the £15m import has heard of Kerry Dixon, the last Chelsea player to score 20 goals in a season, back in 1990. A place in club folklore means nothing to Hasselbaink unless accompanied by a winner's medal.

Chelsea's record signing, at 29, has more time on his side than several Chelsea colleagues. Gus Poyet, 33, admitted he was running out "of years and opportunities" to win his first league title. The Uruguayan sought to make up for lost time here, coming on for the second half and setting up Hasselbaink's landmark goal, before scoring twice himself at the death with a low shot and a glancing header.

Poyet bows in seniority to Dennis Wise and Gianfranco Zola, both 34. Each made light of their years, the captain's passion embellished by passing which rarely can have been more precise and the Italian's touch remaining a thing of wonder. Sadly Zola's sublime ability is likely to be lost to Chelsea in the summer with family factors pulling him back to Sardinia.

It was not such a happy day for one senior servant. Jim Smith paid tribute to Zola and his team-mates, putting this heavy home defeat down "to facing an outstanding side. We weren't hurting them at all and they were very positive."

Some will be less charitable and point to the team's obvious weaknesses which, if exposed too often in the run-in, will surely see a re-evaluation of the role of one of the Premiership's elder statesmen.

The return of Taribo West made little difference, and Derby were ineffectual in midfield and lightweight in attack.

Derby probably need two wins out of the last six games to be safe. If they do not get them, the 60-year-old Smith's insistence that "I still have a year left on my contract and plan to fulfil it" will be challenged from within. In that case Colin Todd, seen as the manager-in-waiting, will be installed sooner rather than later.

fields.standfirst: From Simon

Sue - "Sunday... from sunny Australia to rather cold and rainy New Zealand..."

Sue - "I was going to set off south on Monday, but the relentless heavy rain... continued..."

Sue - "...It was still raining on Tuesday morning..."

Milly - "Today was the most perfect day imaginable; the air was clean, the sky was blue..."

Have fun, Simon.

webTitle: Batigol gets no sympathy from Florence

fields.headline: Batigol gets no sympathy from Florence
fields.trailText: In a specially re-arranged match, Gabriel Batistuta made his return to Fiorentina this afternoon. For weeks thousands of ticketless Roma fans had promised to descend on Florence [nearly 2000 riot police were on duty to stop them getting close to the stadium]. For weeks commentators had speculated on the reaction of the volatile Viola fans to Batigol's return [he was greeted with a mixture of warm applause and isolated whistles from a 35,000-strong Florentine crowd]. But in the end only one story mattered: Roma's shock 3-1 defeat, which throws the Scudetto race wide open.
fields.body:
In a specially re-arranged match, Gabriel Batistuta made his return to Fiorentina this afternoon. For weeks thousands of ticketless Roma fans had promised to descend on Florence [nearly 2000 riot police were on duty to stop them getting close to the stadium]. For weeks commentators had speculated on the reaction of the volatile Viola fans to Batigol's return [he was greeted with a mixture of warm applause and isolated whistles from a 35,000-strong Florentine crowd]. But in the end only one story mattered: Roma's shock 3-1 defeat, which throws the Scudetto race wide open.

Enrico Chiesa scored two of Fiorentina's goals, the first with a brilliant free kick in the 12th minute, his second an instinctive volley eight minutes from time. Vincent Candela's 58th minute own goal completed the win, Brazilian midfielder Emerson scored for Roma, his 30th-minute header levelling the scores at 1-1 for a while.

Roma's defeat was only their third in 25 Serie A matches this season, while Fiorentina's victory was their first win under Roberto Maldini. Batistuta, meanwhile, had a quiet match and rarely threatened to score.

Juventus close the gap

Every week, as Roma's lead at the top of Serie A has grown, Juventus coach Carlo Ancelotti has popped up like a modern day Canute to insist that his side's Scudetto hopes aren't yet washed up on the banks of the Tiber. But for all coach Carlo's zeal, even golden boy Alessandro Del Piero admitted this week to doubts about Juve's title ambitions.

"We mustn't think about Roma, because Fabio Capello's team are playing in a different league," he admitted. "They are just like a UFO."

This weekend Juve travelled to relegation-threatened Veron and played like a team on another planet themselves - a particularly poor football-playing planet - as they meandered to an unconvincing 1-0 win.

Without Zinedine Zidane, who was suffering from flu, Juve struggled to break down Verona throughout the first half. But on the stroke of half-time Filippo Inzaghi was hauled down in the area by Luigi Apolloni, and Del Piero slotted the penalty home.

It proved to be enough. Juventus were uninspiring and insipid - even when Verona were reduced to 10 men when Apolloni was sent off in the 68th minute - but their victory closes the gap at the top of Serie A to six points

And after a defeat to Lazio and home draw with Brescia in their last two games, Ancelotti was delighted with the result. "We wanted this win badly and we gave everything for this victory," he said, before repeating a familiar mantra. "We still believe in this championship and coming after two negative results this was a very important win for us," he added. After Roma's defeat at Fiorentina, he's been proven right.

The race for the Champions League places gets tight

With Parma's match against Lazio abandoned after six minutes because of torrential rain, Atalanta boosted their chances of a Champions League place with a 2-0 win at Lecce. Second-half goals from Nicola Ventola and Domenico Morfeo took Giovanni Vavassori's side onto 40 points, level with Parma.

But AC Milan and Internazionale's hopes of playing in the Champions League stuttered as they were both held to draws by lowly opposition.

Inter's mini-revival ended with a poor performance against improving Vicenza. Sierra Leone striker Mohammed Kallon, on loan from Inter, put Vicenza ahead in the 30th minute - slotting home from close range after a neat lay-off from Luca Toni. But in injury time Alvaro Recoba won a barely deserved point with a free kick which deflected in off the wall.

AC Milan had several chances to pick up full points after Napoli defender Salvatore Fresi was sent off in the 42nd minute for hacking down Andriy Shevchenko. But both Shevchenko and Oliver Bierhoff missed late opportunities and the game finished 0-0.

With both Milan clubs stumbling, Atalanta's match against Parma next Saturday takes on an added significance. What price Atalanta v Ipswich in Europe next season?

fields.headline: Computer nerds now the norm
fields.trailText: A University of Leicester survey shows that students' attitudes to technology are changing - but academics may not be keeping up.
fields.body:
Computer nerds have become the norm, according to a University of Leicester survey, but academics may not be keeping pace with the change in student expectations.

Dr Alan Clark, a senior lecturer in the department of immunology and microbiology, has every year measured his students' attitudes towards technology. Across the second half of the 90s there was a roughly even distribution of students who saw themselves as "techno-nerds", "techno-phobes" and as "normal".

This year, nearly 70% of the 140 students joining the department in the first year fitted the criteria of a "nerd". But, as attitudes to computers have changed, so have attitudes to technophiles. Carrying pens in your top pocket is still not cool, but liking computers is now socially acceptable.

Shane Parker, a second year computing and information systems student at Brighton University, said, "Maybe ten years ago people were not so into technology, but for a younger generation it's definitely more trendy. And with older people, as it becomes friendly to use, like with digital TV allowing people to e-mail."

There are two reasons for the change, according to Dr Clark, the first being the increased ownership of computers among the general public and the increased emphasis on computer technology in the national curriculum.

Regardless of the cause, there has been a significant change in attitudes. His research also found that in 1999, 70% of the students on his virology course liked the use of e-mail in their course. This year over 90% responded in favour of e-mail.

The danger, however, is that academics are not keeping pace with their students. "Teacher attitudes are starting to change, but the pace of change in student attitudes is much more impressive. We might have a discrepancy between students' expectations and course design," Dr Clark said.

webTitle: Leader: Economists give ministers a new target

fields.headline: Taxing sex
fields.standfirst: Economists give ministers a new target
fields.trailText: Could it be the one area where Labour would not be afraid of introducing a new tax? Today, on the opening day of the Royal Economic Society conference, two economists will suggest that the introduction of a tax on prostitution could raise £250m.
fields.body:
Could it be the one area where Labour would not be afraid of introducing a new tax? Today, on the opening day of the Royal Economic Society conference, two economists will suggest that the introduction of a tax on prostitution could raise £250m.

The two academics, Peter Moffatt of East Anglia University and Simon Peters of Manchester University, have used a new website for clients of prostitutes to make an estimate of the oldest profession's earnings. Surveys in the past have been regarded as unreliable because of the trade's suspicions that they were being carried out by the Inland Revenue or even the vice squad. Accordingly, the economists analysed the first 1,000 clients to use the "punternet" website, where punters detail the price, different services, satisfaction ratings and their readiness to return. The gross earnings of the sex workers are estimated to be £770m.

The 10-page paper could not be more dry and professional with its histograms of price, scatter plots tracking price and duration, plus its tables of regression analysis. The statistical terms themselves could cause misunderstanding. Its hedonic pricing model has nothing to do with hedonism (it is a statistical exercise tracking what people will pay for extra services) and its "goodness of fit", below the list of prostitute services, is another statistical term, not a definition of the client/prostitute relationship.

Like sociologists, the economists produce some predictable results: clients pay a higher fee for young rather than old prostitutes; they pay 35% more in London, except in Soho, than in Manchester and Liverpool; and more money (about £1 a minute) the longer the encounter lasts. Yet while 20-year-olds charge the most, 30-year-olds provide the most satisfaction. The average charge is £50. Like all researchers, the economists believe further research is necessary. It certainly is. The sample would seem to be far from representative; it could be distorted by false claims from prostitutes, only too ready to drum up business; and it does not explain how the tax would be collected.

fields.headline: How to live longer
fields.standfirst:
To defeat the ageing process, we must overcome our fears of genetic engineering and set to work

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: To defeat the ageing process, we must overcome our fears of genetic engineering and set to work.
fields.body:
This year's Reith lecturer, Professor Tom Kirkwood, claims ageing is "neither inevitable nor necessary" and invites us to "prepare for the longevity revolution". While, as he states, we are not programmed to die, it is also true that our genes have not been designed for long life.

Most of our ancestors were hunter-gathers who led short and brutal lives before falling prey to disease, starvation, predators or competitors. Their genes evolved to inhabit bodies for just a couple of decades before being passed on to their offspring.

The fate of the bodies left behind was of little concern to genes that had already fled into the next generation. Defects that showed up only in later years, leading to cancer, heart disease, Alzheimer's or stroke, would have escaped the attentions of natural selection. Long-term maintenance and repair was never a priority.

Our genes haven't changed. They are still designed for the short term, no matter how carefully we maintain and service our bodies. Ageing is a genetic disease. To cure it, we will need to turn short-term genes into long-term genes and this will be accomplished only by genetic engineering and gene therapy.

Ever since the first microbe crawled out of the primordial soup, Mother Nature has operated a strict policy of breeding from only the fit and healthy. The vast majority of creatures born into this world have departed from it without leaving any descendants. For many it might have been just bad luck, but others inherited bad genes that led to illness, frailty or plain lack of sex appeal.

Darwin described this motor of evolution but lamented its "clumsy, wasteful, blundering, low and horribly cruel" action. His cousin Francis Galton and others proposed to replace human natural selection with breeding programmes to "improve the racial qualities of future generations".

This "eugenics" movement was openly racist with the aim of ensuring that the "feeble nations" give way before the "nobler varieties of mankind".

In Germany, the 1934 racial hygiene law led to the enforced sterilisation of more than 80,000 people considered "unworthy". US eugenics policies between 1907 and 1960 resulted in the enforced sterilisation of at least 60,000 individuals. Even in liberal Sweden, more than 62,000 people (mostly women) with handicaps, or considered "undesirable", were sterilised against their will.

With such a terrible history, it is perhaps not surprising that many fear the human genome will become a eugenicist's toolkit. But there is a huge difference. Whereas eugenics seeks to restrict fertility by enforced or coerced sterilisation, gene therapy seeks simply to correct gene defects that make us sick.

The aim is not to produce Galton's "highly bred human race" but to eliminate genes that cause disease, including the infirmities of old age. Just as vaccines have conquered smallpox, gene therapy may eliminate genetic diseases like cystic fibrosis and muscular dystrophy and, eventually, the most common of them all, the ageing process.

Hardly a day goes by without Prince Charles warning us of the dangers of genetic engineering. Yet the human genome has revealed that nature is the busiest genetic engineer. More that 200 of our genes appear to have been captured from bacteria and much of the rest of the genome is a junkyard filled with the corpses of retrovirus and other parasites that have been hopping in and out of our chromosomes for millennia.

Comparing our chromosomes to those of other species, we can see that in addition to inserting new genes, nature has reshuffled, duplicated and deleted large segments of our chromosomes making about one major rearrangement every million years.

So if nature is not averse to a bit of genetic tinkering, why should we be so wary? With the decline of religion, the genome seems to have emerged as the secular equivalent of the soul: genes are sacred. Yet DNA is not spiritual. DNA comes out of your cells looking like strands of slimy cotton. You can store it in the freezer, post it to your friends; you can even eat it without suffering any ethical crisis. Genes are just bits of us and gene therapy is just another form of medicine. Fixing a broken arm is not considered to interfere with God's plan so why should fixing a broken gene be any different?

Of course any technology can be abused. But anyone wishing to use the human genome to make a super-race would not know where to start. Identifying those genes whose defects cause disease is a difficult enough task; unravelling the genetic and environmental interactions that lead to complex characters like good looks, physical strength or intelligence is far harder.

It would be foolish to by-pass the potential benefits of gene therapy because of unreasonable fears of its misuse. A surgeon could stab us in the heart but we trust him not to: we don't ban scalpels from operating theatres.

If we really wish to banish genetic diseases, including the ageing process, then we must overcome our fears of dabbling in our own genome.

 Johnjoe McFadden is professor of molecular genetics at the University of Surrey

His cousin Francis Galton and others proposed to replace human natural selection with breeding programmes to "improve the racial qualities of future generations". This "eugenics" movement was openly racist with the aim of ensuring that the "feeble nations" give way before the "nobler varieties of mankind". In Germany, the 1934 racial hygiene law led to the enforced sterilisation of more than 80,000 people considered "unworthy". US eugenics policies between 1907 and 1960 resulted in the enforced sterilisation of at least 60,000 individuals. Even in liberal Sweden, more than 62,000 people (mostly women) with handicaps, or considered "undesirable", were sterilised against their will. With such a terrible history, it is perhaps not surprising that many fear the human genome will become a eugenicist's toolkit. But there is a huge difference. Whereas eugenics seeks to restrict fertility by enforced or coerced sterilisation, gene therapy seeks simply to correct gene defects that make us sick. The aim is not to produce Galton's "highly bred human race" but to eliminate genes that cause disease, including the infirmities of old age. Just as vaccines have conquered smallpox, gene therapy may eliminate genetic diseases like cystic fibrosis and muscular dystrophy and, eventually, the most common of them all, the ageing process. Hardly a day goes by without Prince Charles warning us of the dangers of genetic engineering. Yet the human genome has revealed that nature is the busiest genetic engineer. More that 200 of our genes appear to have been captured from bacteria and much of the rest of the genome is a junkyard filled with the corpses of retrovirus and other parasites that have been hopping in and out of our chromosomes for millennia. Comparing our chromosomes to those of other species, we can see that in addition to inserting new genes, nature has reshuffled, duplicated and deleted large segments of our chromosomes making about one major rearrangement every million years. So if nature is not averse to a bit of genetic tinkering, why should we be so wary? With the decline of religion, the genome seems to have emerged as the secular equivalent of the soul: genes are sacred. Yet DNA is not spiritual. DNA comes out of your cells looking like strands of slimy cotton. You can store it in the freezer, post it to your friends; you can even eat it without suffering any ethical crisis. Genes are just bits of us and gene therapy is just another form of medicine. Fixing a broken arm is not considered to interfere with God's plan so why should fixing a broken gene be any different? Of course any technology can be abused. But anyone wishing to use the human genome to make a super-race would not know where to start. Identifying those genes whose defects cause disease is a difficult enough task; unravelling the genetic and environmental interactions that lead to complex characters like good looks, physical strength or intelligence is far harder. It would be foolish to by-pass the potential benefits of gene therapy because of unreasonable fears of its misuse. A surgeon could stab us in the heart but we trust him not to: we don't ban scalpels from operating theatres. If we really wish to banish genetic diseases, including the ageing process, then we must overcome our fears of dabbling in our own genome.  Johnjoe McFadden is professor of molecular genetics at the University of Surrey

fields.headline: Prof Kenneth Cameron
fields.standfirst: Scholar regarded as the leading authority on English place names
fields.trailText: Scholar regarded as the leading authority on English place names.
fields.body:
Kenneth Cameron, who has died aged 78, was a scholar of place names - a toponymist - who demonstrated the vital relevance of such work to the understanding of English settlement history.

His publications included a survey of The Place-Names of Derbyshire (1959), and the best introduction to the subject, English Place-Names (1961), finally revised, with characteristic lucidity, for its fourth edition in 1996. Scandinavian Settlement in the Territory of the Five Boroughs (1965-1971) developed the technique of relating names to the drift geology of a region in order to demonstrate the secondary character of the Scandinavian names of the east Midlands. It also established the hitherto disputed theory of substantial Danish colonisation in the wake of the campaigns of 876-7.

Eccles in English Place-Names (1968) and The Meaning and Significance of Old English in English Place-Names contributed to our understanding of Celtic survival in the Anglo-Saxon period. Having completed the text of the sixth volume of his Survey of Lincolnshire Place-Names, he was working on the seventh.

He was the director of the English Place-Name Survey from 1967 to 1992. He instituted the society's Journal in 1969 and saw the transfer of the society's library from London to Nottingham into permanent premises.

Born in Burnley, Lancashire, Ken was educated at Burnley grammar school and Leeds University, and served as a wartime RAF pilot. In 1947 he became an assistant lecturer at Sheffield University, where he took his doctorate. From 1950 to his retirement in 1987 he was at Nottingham University, becoming successively reader (1962), professor of English language (1963), and head of department (1984).

At Nottingham language and literature were not, as elsewhere, compartmentalised. Language was liberally interpreted by Ken and under him the study of Old English language and literature, Middle English, Icelandic, Anglo-Saxon antiquity, place names and modern English language flourished, the last becoming a separate department in 1979. He also sat on many university committees.

Ken made a memorable, beautifully constructed Israel Gollancz memorial lecture to the British Academy in 1976. He was made a fellow of the academy, received an honorary doctorate from the University of Uppsala and was made a CBE in 1987.

In 1947 he had married Kathleen Heap, by whom he had two children. She was a geographer, and the geological element of Ken's work owes much to her. They were a devoted couple, famous for their warm hospitality - high teas and currant cake. When Kath became ill Ken nursed her up to her death in 1977.

In 1998 he married Jean Russell-Gebbett, who contributed to his Lincolnshire work and was his companion on his practical place-name trips. She and his two children survive him.

 Professor Kenneth Cameron, place-name scholar, born May 21 1922; died March 10 2001

fields.headline: Patently absurd
fields.standfirst: Big drugs companies may be keen to improve their image, but patenting new remedies for malaria and TB is not the way forward
fields.trailText: Big drugs companies may be keen to improve their image, but patenting new remedies for malaria and TB is not the way forward.
fields.body:
Penicillin, the first modern wonder drug, wasn't patented. When Alexander Fleming invented it at St Mary's hospital in London in 1928, the government decided that something of such great benefit to the world should not be a monopoly.

Today the drugs industry takes a different view. Protecting its intellectual property rights is a major priority, even if that means preventing poor countries from making cheap copies of the drugs that they urgently need.

Next week, 40 of the world's biggest companies will resume their court case with the South African government. They hope to prevent South Africa importing cheaper Aids remedies to help the 4.2m of the country's citizens who have the disease.

Behind the scenes though, many of the companies are desperate to find a way out of the public-relations disaster they have created. They argue that the price of drugs is not the main problem for third world health systems - the poor state of the health systems is a bigger issue. But the public perception has been that the companies are indifferent to the suffering of the millions who die each year in the developing world from treatable diseases.

As the storm of protest over the South African case has grown, many of the big companies have slashed the costs of their patented Aids treatments for African governments. They have also signed up to a European Union plan for a worldwide system of differential pricing for drugs which would offer steep discounts to the poorest developing countries, not just on Aids treatments but for a range of essential medicines.

Tiered pricing is part of the solution, but campaigners want to see more. They argue that poor countries must be allowed to exploit safety provisions in World Trade Organisation rules which allow patent rights to be overridden in the public interest.

The pharmaceuticals industry has used its extensive lobbying power to make sure that poor countries don't take advantage of these rules. The US government regularly writes to African countries warning them that it will suspend special trade privileges if the country imports generic copies of patented drugs.

The companies argue that patents are their lifeblood - unless they have the monopoly right to market their inventions for a fixed period, there is no point investing huge amounts in researching and developing new remedies. The actual costs of manufacturing most drugs aren't huge - without patents, competitors could rip off their inventions and they would never recoup their investment.

Until the creation of the WTO in 1995, few poor countries had intellectual property laws and countries like Egypt, Thailand and India developed thriving generic drugs industries. Competition from generic manufacturers like India's Cipla doesn't appear to have threatened the industry - pharmaceuticals is one of the industrialised world's most profitable business sectors.

Under the new WTO rules however, strict American intellectual property rights rules, which extend patent rights for 20 years, have become standard. All 140 WTO member countries must change their laws to conform, although some developing countries have been given until 2006 to make the change. Kevin Watkins, Oxfam's senior policy adviser, says that the 20-year monopoly has no particular economic rationale - it was chosen because the American pharmaceuticals industry was extremely influential in drawing up the WTO's patent provisions.

Even the campaigners agree that some patent protection is necessary to encourage R&D. But it's not clear whether 20 years is the correct period, and whether the rules need to be the same in every country. What is clear is that weakening patent protection would lower prices. In countries where there is still competition from generics manufacturers, the big drug companies lower the prices of their patented treatments. The industry's rash of one-off offers on Aids drugs to Africa was partly motivated by the need to restore its reputation. But a big factor was the decision in January by Cipla to cut the price of its main Aids drug to $600 a year per patient.

It would be possible to have different patent regimes in different parts of the world - there is no reason to suppose that a one-size-fits-all system is the best. Some companies argue that if they can't get protection in poor countries for their inventions, then there is no incentive to research cures for poor country diseases.

However, the brutal facts of the market suggest that there is little incentive anyway. These countries are not rich enough to buy the new remedies - the combined purchasing power of south Asia and sub-Saharan Africa's health budgets is the same as the market for around 15m people in the US who suffer from heart failure and angina.

One company which has developed a vaccine for Japanese encephalitis, a mosquito-borne virus which kills 10,000 people a year in the developing world, plans to market it to western backpackers planning trips to Africa. Gap-year kids are a more lucrative market than the locals.

The British government maintains that intellectual property rules are not the most important factor - 95% of the World Health Organisation's list of essential medicines are no longer covered by patents. But Oxfam and other campaigners point out that the new remedies being developed for resistant strains of diseases such as malaria and TB are patented. A stricter intellectual property regime, they warn, threatens to cut off the supply of the newest and most effective remedies - the penicillins of our day.

 Charlotte Denny is the Guardian's economics reporter

fields.headline: 'Unteachable' boy loses high court case
fields.trailText: Members of teachers' union NASUWT cannot be compelled to teach a 16-year-old boy who was expelled because of his behaviour, the High Court ruled today.
fields.body:
Members of the National Union of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers (NASUWT) cannot be compelled to teach a 16-year-old boy who was expelled because of his behaviour, a High Court judge ruled today.

The boy, P - who cannot be named for legal reasons - was described as unteachable by staff at the Bonus Pastor school in Lewisham, south London, from which he was expelled last summer after allegedly assaulting fellow pupils and threatening teachers. Governors later overturned the decision.

Mr Justice Morison ruled that union members were acting lawfully in refusing to teach the boy. Their action constitutes a legitimate trade dispute under the terms of the 1992 Trade Union and Labour Relations Act.

The boy's counsel had argued that the teachers' action was illegal because it was unrelated to their terms and conditions of employment.

But Mr Morison said it would be "superficial" for him to pass any judgment on the boy's behaviour. "I do not know how badly P truly behaved; I do not know how reasonable the teachers have been in seeking P's removal or whether they should have approached the matter differently." He said he had simply approached the questions of law without any assumption as to the general merits of the case.

NASUWT said that the boy's education had not suffered because he was now being taught in isolation by two supply teachers. The judge commented: "On a superficial basis, it might be said that the union in this case has taken the law into their own hands and, by organising industrial action to compel P's exclusion from the classroom, have subverted the will of Parliament. "Can society tolerate a position in which a union can, through industrial muscle, effectively decide who will and won't be taught in a classroom?

"On the other hand, teachers are generally held in high esteem. The public appreciates the stresses and strains under which they work and, generally speaking, the professionalism they display in carrying out their important and difficult work. If a pupil has become unmanageable then they might be thought to deserve support."

NASUWT general secretary Nigel de Gruchy said he was relieved at the judgement. "The judge was right in his belief that the real needs of pupils with serious difficulties of this kind are unlikely to be met in the courts."

He added: "The teachers' right to resist unreasonable directions from any source - headteachers or governors or appeal panels - which imply they must accept risk of physical assault or abuse in the course of their duties, has been upheld.

"By implication, the rights of other pupils to receive their education free from disruption and intimidation have, likewise, been upheld. Teaching already has enough recruitment problems. I dread to think what the future would have held had NASUWT lost this case."

Related articles
Teachers' boycott of pupil goes to court

webTitle: Blair aims to woo teachers as industrial action looms

fields.headline: Blair aims to woo teachers as industrial action looms
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will this week join his education ministers to canvass the crucial votes of teachers during their annual Easter conference season, as the unions threaten a new bout of industrial action over their call for a 35-hour week.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will this week join his education ministers to canvass the crucial votes of teachers during their annual Easter conference season, as the unions threaten a new bout of industrial action over their call for a 35-hour week.

The prime minister's address this week to the Association of Teachers and Lecturers conference in Torquay signals the importance of education as an election issue.

Two years ago Mr Blair addressed the National Association of Head Teachers' conference, but this would be the first time a prime minister has attended a classroom teacher union conference. Mr Blair is expected to highlight the government's commitment to education, which it insists will still be its top priority in a second term.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, will attend the National Union of Teachers' conference in Cardiff where, before coming into government, he was once forced into a cupboard by angry activists.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, who was heckled last year by NUT members over performance-related pay, will address the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers in Jersey.

Mr Blair's education team are likely to face accusations that they are implementing a two-tier state education system and failing to give teachers powers to deal with unruly children.

Today the Association of Teachers and Lecturers is expected to endorse a motion, supported by the executives of NUT, the NASUWT, and the Welsh teaching body UCAC, calling for an agreement on conditions similar to those agreed for Scotland, including a wide-ranging independent inquiry, a limited working week and a maximum 22.5 hours contact time in the classroom.

The motion calls for "effective action, short of strike action" if the government does not agree to their demands. Mr Blunkett has rejected the call.

Doug McAvoy, the general secretary of the NUT, believes teachers could be ready to take action - effectively by bringing in a work to rule - in October, following union ballots. But the NUT executive fears its activists may want to amend the motion to call for strike action if its demands are not met.

Campaigners for professional unity - a single union representing rank and file teachers - are encouraged by recent developments.

The NUT and NASUWT have held joint industrial action over teacher shortages in many areas of the country, which has led to hundreds of pupils being sent home.

The Association of Teachers and Lecturers, which has signed an alliance with the Association of University Teachers, would like to have taken part and protested to the TUC general secretary, John Monks, an advocate of unity, that it had been excluded. The other two unions apologised. The unions feel threatened by the new General Teaching Council for England, set up to promote and regulate the profession, which they feel is trying to usurp their role as the "voice of the profession".

A legal row over whether teachers are within their rights in refusing to teach an allegedly violent and disruptive teenager will be decided by a high court judge today.

The 16-year-old boy, who has been refused lessons by some teachers at a school in Bromley, south London, is suing the NASUWT, claiming the industrial action is unlawful and seeking an injunction directing staff to let him back into the classroom.

fields.headline: Appealing advice
fields.trailText: Nowadays, April is the busiest month for the Advisory Centre for Education. "At this time of year, it's mammoth," says Susan Rees, a barrister and co-ordinator at the charity, which was founded in 1960 to advise parents on educational matters. Currently, about a fifth of the calls to the ACE helpline are from parents who want to appeal against their local authority's decision on a school for their child.
fields.body:
Nowadays, April is the busiest month for the Advisory Centre for Education. "At this time of year, it's mammoth," says Susan Rees, a barrister and co-ordinator at the charity, which was founded in 1960 to advise parents on educational matters. Currently, about a fifth of the calls to the ACE helpline are from parents who want to appeal against their local authority's decision on a school for their child.

The two lines are so busy that she advises parents to send off for the ACE booklet on school appeals (free on request - send an A5 stamped addressed envelope to the address at the end of this article) before trying to call.

Susan, who began to work for ACE after becoming a school governor, estimates that about a third of appeals are successful, although that figure varies widely from school to school. " A lot of parents want to leave no stone unturned," she says, "and it's a very stressful time. But you've got to remember that there are a lot of other people appealing, and you've got to back up everything you say.

"Try to think of the needs your child has and link them to the school you want. I would look at the school's prospectus and its Ofsted reports. For example, if your child has been bullied in the past, you could point out in your appeal that the school you want has a strong anti-bullying policy."

The number of appeals has increased due to parental choice, the effect of league tables and as schools have diversified, she says, and the growth in foundation, religious and specialist schools has made it easier for parents to find schools they badly want their child to attend. The tendency of church schools to hold interviews has further complicated the admissions process.

 You can obtain a free copy of ACE's booklet on school appeals by sending an A5 stamped addressed envelope to the following address:

Advisory Centre For Education
Department A
Unit 1C Aberdeen Studios
22 Highbury Grove
London
N5 2DQ

Parents can also call the free helpline on 0808 800 5793, which is open between 2pm and 5pm on weekdays. ACE's website is at www.ace-ed.org.uk.

Advice on what to do if your child is not offered a place

Susan, who began to work for ACE after becoming a school governor, estimates that about a third of appeals are successful, although that figure varies widely from school to school. " A lot of parents want to leave no stone unturned," she says, "and it's a very stressful time. But you've got to remember that there are a lot of other people appealing, and you've got to back up everything you say. "Try to think of the needs your child has and link them to the school you want. I would look at the school's prospectus and its Ofsted reports. For example, if your child has been bullied in the past, you could point out in your appeal that the school you want has a strong anti-bullying policy." The number of appeals has increased due to parental choice, the effect of league tables and as schools have diversified, she says, and the growth in foundation, religious and specialist schools has made it easier for parents to find schools they badly want their child to attend. The tendency of church schools to hold interviews has further complicated the admissions process.  You can obtain a free copy of ACE's booklet on school appeals by sending an A5 stamped addressed envelope to the following address: Advisory Centre For Education Department A Unit 1C Aberdeen Studios 22 Highbury Grove London N5 2DQ Parents can also call the free helpline on 0808 800 5793, which is open between 2pm and 5pm on weekdays. ACE's website is at www.ace-ed.org.uk. fields.headline: Sink or Swim?
fields.standfirst: So, your child hasn't got in to any of the schools you chose. Neither have the children featured here. Over the next few months,  Martin Wainwright  and  David Grace  will follow their fortunes as they go to war with the system. Today: planning the appeal
fields.trailText: So, your child hasn't got in to any of the schools you chose. Neither have the children featured here. Over the next few months, Martin Wainwright and David Grace will follow their fortunes as they go to war with the system. Today: planning the appeal
fields.body:
You've read those letters of rejection, you've wept, raged or simply groaned in resignation, and now you're facing the fact that your secondary transfer saga has entered a new and even more desperate phase.

It's not as if you haven't already invested enough time and energy trying to secure a place at a secondary school that's to the liking of you and your worried year 6 child. Depressed or even frightened by what your local education authority has to offer close to your home, you devoted most of last autumn to trekking around, attending open evenings, poring over admissions criteria, listening to headteachers assure you that your already slender hopes will disappear completely unless his or her school is at the top of your wish list, unless your little Nibs or Nellie is a violin virtuoso or an intellectual giant, or unless the 300 children likely to be ahead of yours on the waiting list all emigrate or drop dead before September.

After intense consideration you pitched your applications and have spent the last two months sleeping with your fingers crossed. And now you've received the bad news.

So, what do you do next? First, take what grim comfort you can from knowing you are far from alone. The logical consequences of "parental choice" fostered under the Conservatives manifest themselves ever more clearly under new Labour. The over-subscription of popular secondary schools continues to increase, leaving the unpopular ever more beleaguered, and more and more education-minded parents with the distinctly bitter feeling that, in the end, they've been left with no choice at all.

The concentration of demand upon the best-regarded schools is a major social phenomenon. Homes are sold, jobs are changed, private tutors are hired and serious lies are told in the battle to be included on next year's year 7 roll. Even schools whose admissions policies conform absolutely to comprehensive principles find their intakes slanted towards those in society best equipped to become winners in the great admissions game.

Here, we have interviewed four very different families who have found themselves bruised by this trend. Today, we ask them what exclusion from the school of their choice means to them, and what they intend to do about it. In the weeks to come we shall follow their attempts to overcome that exclusion, peering over their shoulder as they struggle with letters of appeal, following them to the appeal room itself and, finally, accompanying their child to the school gates - wherever they end up.

It is impossible to predict what will happen to these families, and to the thousands of others like them. It is certainly true that many will find they have been too quick to dismiss so-called "sink" schools. Some will reluctantly settle for such a school in the interim, only to find that, actually, their child settles happily there.

It is also true that many disappointed applicants will still get the school they want if they hang on for a bit before calling in Pickfords: even long waiting lists shorten, with places sometimes cropping up as late as the first week of September.

But all that notwithstanding, most - like the four families featured here - will already be pondering an appeal. This time two years ago that's just what I was doing. Not for any thing fancy: just a reasonably proximate non-selective, non-denominational mixed school with a broad social blend, wise pastoral policies and an attitude to teaching that combined liberal values with intellectual grit. In other words, one of those "bog standard" comprehensives.

From the excellent Advisory Centre for Education (ACE) I learned that there are basically two ways to succeed. One is to show that the LEA has messed up its procedures. The other is to convince the panel of (usually three) neutral experts that the problems caused for the school by having to accommodate an extra child would be less than those your child would endure if he or she had to go anywhere else. You make your case for being let in, someone from the school or LEA makes the case for keeping you at bay, and the panel makes its judgment in due course. In other words, you go to war, not only against the school, but against all the other children who have been turned down.

My appeal was successful, and I'm glad. But the whole experience also made me sad: sad for other parents and sad that such situations should arise in the first place. The extension of "choice" and competition has brought us to a point where the most affluent and well-informed parents tend to take most of what is best while the children of the rest have to make do with what's left over. Even in scenarios where there is no selection by examination, other forms are becoming more entrenched: selection by mortgage, by social skills, by stealth. And the more there is selection, the more there is exclusion.

fields.headline: Scheduling of Paxman interviews angers BBC staff
fields.trailText:
3.30pm update: Staff have slammed the BBC for scheduling the party-leader interviews on BBC2, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Apr 9: BBC lets Paxman loose on Blair
fields.body:
Senior Newsnight staff have slammed the BBC for deciding to run Jeremy Paxman's interviews with Tony Blair and William Hague as Newsnight specials on BBC2, rather than on BBC1.

They say Paxman's interview with Blair will be such "box office" it should be given as wide an audience as possible.

"What they've effectively done is killed off the exposure an interview with a party leader should have on the BBC's flagship channel," said one source.

The source pointed out that during the 1997 general election interviews with the party leaders had gone out on BBC1 and BBC2 and, crucially, the BBC1 interviews had been conducted by David Dimbleby on Panorama.

The insiders believe the decision to run the interviews on Newsnight means they have been sidelined.

"We're quite happy to be on BBC2," said the source, "but the interviews should be on a mass-audience channel."

But BBC news and current affairs bosses have said they believe the three election editions of Question Time, which will be scheduled at 9pm on BBC1, will be the centrepiece of the corporation's election coverage.

Mark Damazer, the BBC's assistant director for news, defended the decision, saying the interviews were being more "aggressively scheduled" this time around.

"We did Panorama specials for the last election, which aren't happening this year," he said, "but last time neither were scheduled aggressively."

Mr Damazer said the "Big Dimbleby experience" - the Question Time editions where party leaders will be questioned individually by members of the audience - would be shown at 9pm on BBC1.

He said it would not be appropriate for the Newsnight interviews to "come into BBC1's universe".

Meanwhile, contrary to reports, Mr Damazer said the BBC's Ten O'Clock News would be extended at election time by approximately seven minutes each weekday evening.

He said the Nine O'Clock News's extended coverage at the last general election had been "too long".

It emerged today that Mr Blair and Mr Hague had agreed to the Paxman interviews.

Mr Hague last appeared on Newsnight two years ago, when Mr Paxman grilled him about the sacking of Lord Cranborne, leader of the Conservative peers.

Mr Paxman, who is famed for his aggressive interviewing style, told the Tory leader: "You can't even control a toff in the House of Lords", and asked him: "Do you ever wonder if you're up to the job?".

The Conservative leader has refused to appear on the programme ever since.

However, it is believed he has agreed to go head to head with Mr Paxman on the advice of his press secretary Amanda Platell and friend Sebastian Coe, who claim he would appear frightened if he backed out.

Related story
