fields.headline: £1m RBS chief faces revolt
fields.standfirst: Fund managers urge vote against re-election of remuneration committee members
fields.trailText: Royal Bank of Scotland is preparing for a stormy confrontation with shareholders this week after it emerged that outgoing chief executive Sir George Mathewson is sitting on a paper profit of £1m as a result of a new award of share options.
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland is preparing for a stormy confrontation with shareholders this week after it emerged that outgoing chief executive Sir George Mathewson is sitting on a paper profit of £1m as a result of a new award of share options.

Details of the award are likely to anger shareholders who are already being urged by the National Association of Pension Funds to vote against the re-election of two leading members of RBS's remuneration committee at the bank's annual shareholders' meeting on Wednesday.

The NAPF is protesting about an amount of £2.5m in special bonuses paid to Sir George and three other directors as a "thank you" for last year's acquisition of NatWest.

Sir George dismissed criticism of the bonuses, claiming they "wouldn't give you brag ging power in a Soho wine bar".

The new row centres on the fact that in 1999 Sir George was not granted any fresh options because he was two years away from the retirement age of 60. Then, RBS had a policy of rewarding only those directors who could influence the bank's performance over the medium term.

Yet the following year Sir George was granted 147,397 new options at 781p, which based on Friday night's closing price of £15.70p, would be worth £1.16m if exercised.

RBS claims that Sir George was entitled to the options because during the battle for NatWest he was appointed executive deputy chairman and nominated to succeed Viscount Younger as chairman on his retirement on Wednesday.

As Sir George was no longer within two years of retirement he was therefore, RBS says, entitled to options.

This explanation is likely to cut little ice with shareholders who will want to know why Sir George, who becomes non-executive chairman on Wednesday, was given options. Non-executive directors are not normally eligible for inclusion in such schemes as they are not full-time employees.

"The current policy is to ensure that the individuals who will be the key drivers for the group's future success will be able to participate in the executive share option scheme," an RBS spokesman said.

"Sir George will devoting the majority of his time to further the interests of the group and the board is confident that his continuing influence and strategic vision will provide an ideal complement to Fred Goodwin as group chief executive and that this will be to the long term benefit of all shareholders."

Asked if that meant that Sir George would be eligible for share options this year the spokesman said that it was a matter for the board.

News of the award could raise further questions about the independence of RBS's remuneration committee, led by Viscount Younger. The Association of British Insurers has already voiced disquiet about the make-up of the committee, while the NAPF is trying to remove non-executive directors Sir Iain Vallance and Sir Angus Grossart from the board on Wednesday.

The NAPF dislikes the takeover bonuses because they reward making deals rather than the creation of shareholder value.

fields.headline: How R-JH's clients reacted to the 'Sophie tapes' scandal
fields.trailText:
Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts
Announced its decision to drop R-JH as its PR agency after the publication of the News of the World tapes, in which managing director Murray Harkin suggested the company's hotels could be used for gay sex parties.
fields.body:
Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts
Announced its decision to drop R-JH as its PR agency after the publication of the News of the World tapes, in which managing director Murray Harkin suggested the company's hotels could be used for gay sex parties.

Boodle & Dunthorne
The receptionist at society jeweller Boodle & Dunthorne said: "We're not making any comment on that. Thank you. Goodbye" and promptly put down the phone.

Thomas Goode (a Mayfair china and glass shop)
Jim Gill, general manager, said: "We continue to be a R-JH client and have always found them to be very good. We are just carrying on as normal."

Shiseido
"The R-JH PR team working on the Shiseido account have been continually professional and maintained a high level of service on an ongoing basis," said a spokeswoman.

DFS
The marketing department referred all calls on the subject to the chairman. But the chairman, Graham Kirkham, was not available. No one at the company was able to say when he would be back.

Hoover European Appliance Group
"We have no comment to make," said a spokeswoman. "We will continue to work with R-JH for the immediate future."

JCB
"We don't work with them any more," said a spokesman. "They did a one-off project for us last year."

Mastek (an Indian software company)
UK managing director Mike Cast said: "We are definitely still a client and saddened to see Sophie forced to resign the chairmanship. But we dealt with Sophie and an account manager who is still there.
"We always review our suppliers all the time but we deliberately chose a small company and now they are smaller than they were."

British Luxury Council
"We are extremely happy with the services of R-JH," said a spokesman. He declined to comment further.

The Haven Trust
Refused to comment except to confirm it was still an R-JH client.

Tuberous Sclerosis Association
Refused to confirm it was still a R-JH client and would say nothing apart from: "Sophie is a committed and dedicated professional."

fields.headline: BBC lets Paxman loose on Blair
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Jeremy Paxman is to step out of the shadow of the Dimblebys and do a set-piece interview with Tony Blair for the BBC, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
He has been the scourge of politicians for years but has never been allowed to get near the prime minister during an election.

Now, for the first time, the BBC's in-house rottweiller Jeremy Paxman is to step out of the shadow of the Dimblebys and do a set-piece interview with Tony Blair.

The interview is expected to last 35 minutes and will appear on Newsnight as part of a series of election specials.

Insiders say the prime minister had "no choice" but to accept the engagement after the BBC put forward its plans.

"There are always a number of programmes that get interviews with the party leaders like Today and the news bulletins," said one senior source.

"This year, however, we have decided to promote Newsnight this time. We put forward our plans and they would have looked stupid if they hadn't agreed."

In the past the big interviews have been with David Dimbleby, a decision that clearly offended Paxman, who is famed for his relentless and combative interview style.

During the 1997 election campaign he quipped: "It is part of the constitution of this country that all major events have to be presented by a Dimbleby."

Despite being sidelined, it was Paxman who made the more memorable TV, interviewing a pompous-sounding Michael Portillo just hours before he was defeated.

The Newsnight interviewer asked him whether he wanted to drink his chalice of poison now or later.

"There is no doubt that Paxman brings a frisson of danger. I'm sure it will be the interview of the election campaign," said one BBC insider.

 Michael Brunson, former political editor for News at Ten and other ITV bulletins, is being lined up to front GMTV's election coverage.

One insider claimed the approach to Mr Brunson was already causing upset at the breakfast station.

"There are a number of noses out of joint here. Some presenters believed they would get the job," said the source.

webTitle: Tenants kept in the dark over housing fraud

fields.headline: Tenants kept in the dark over housing fraud
fields.trailText: Exclusive: A housing association has come under fire for failing to tell its tenants about a fraud in its finance department that involved the theft of more than £300,000 to fund a gambling habit. Matt Weaver reports.
fields.body:
A housing association has come under fire for failing to tell its tenants about a fraud in its finance department that involved the theft of more than £300,000 to fund a gambling habit.

Allan Newman, a finance manager at London-based Family housing, was imprisoned for three years for embezzling £344,844 over a period of 15 years from the housing association's rent roll.

He pleaded guilty to the theft and admitted the money was used for bets on horse and dog racing, and later fruit machines.

The conviction took place in November 1999 but it has only come to light now, after an investigation by SocietyGuardian.co.uk. Family housing informed its regulator, the housing corporation, about the case but did not inform its 23,000 tenants or make a public statement about the scandal at the time.

Family housing, where housing minister Nick Raynsford was once a board member - though long before the fraud was detected - stressed that it has put in place measures to prevent a recurrence of the fraud.

But Family's failure to inform tenants about the fraud have prompted calls for more openness and transparency within housing associations.

The case is the latest in series of scandals in housing associations. Last month the housing corporation rapped Liver housing association for proposing to pay three of its directors £1.7m in pay-offs.

Pete Challis, Local Government Association executive member for housing, said: "The issue of transparency and accountability is now a critical issue for housing associations.

"The shocking revelations that Liver proposed to pay three people £1.7m between them was not something made public by the organisations involved.

Mr Challis added: "We need a framework where there is a duty on housing association chief executives to inform, initially to their board members and tenants, but also the local communities in which they work."

Tenant campaigner Michael Beverley claimed that Family housing tenants had a right to know about the case.

"In the spirit of openness and honesty, it is the kind of thing that does deserve public scrutiny especially if it involves someone in housing finance," he said.

Mr Beverley, who is a member of the Tenant Participation Advisory Service's national policy forum, added: "I would much rather there was a public debate to show probity is being upheld and that action has been taken. If it leaks out the back door it makes matters worse."

He called on associations to be more "proactive" about openness.

In a statement, Carol Radmore, chief executive of Family, refused to say why it did not inform tenants at the time. It said: "We dealt with the matter promptly and responsibly. Family's board, which includes tenant representatives, immediately informed the housing corporation, to whom they are accountable."

fields.headline: Israel wins war of words
fields.standfirst:
Brian Whitaker on the dangers of sloppy journalism

Users' responses to this article
fields.trailText: Brian Whitaker on the dangers of sloppy journalism.
fields.body:
A familiar tale from the Middle East: "Palestinians launched three bombs overnight against the Eile Sinai settlement in the far north of the Gaza Strip. Israeli troops responded with tank shells, destroying a Palestinian border post and hitting two houses."

This report, which happens to have come from the BBC, is familiar not only for the events it describes but also for the way it describes them: the Palestinians attack and the Israelis "respond".

Military actions by the Israelis are always a "response" to something, even when they strike first. If they haven't actually been attacked, it's a "response" to a security threat.

"Response" is a very useful word. It provides a ready-made reason for the Israelis' actions and neatly brushes off demands for further explanation. It says: "Don't ask us why we did it, ask the other side."

There's no point in blaming the Israelis for using this device; the question is whether journalists should let it shape their reporting of the conflict.

Portraying the conflict as a series of Palestinian actions and Israeli responses is dangerous, for several reasons.

Firstly, it lends support to the Israeli argument that if only the Palestinians would stop their violence everything would be fine. That might be true for many Israelis, but not for the Palestinians.

Secondly, it builds up - through constant repetition - into a misleading picture of the overall conflict. The violence is not a series of discrete actions and reactions but a cycle (or spiral) in which actions on both sides feed off those on the other.

Thirdly, while Israeli actions are reported as a self-justifying "response", actions by the Palestinians are rarely allowed either a proper context or an understandable motive.

Obviously there is a limit to what can be said in a news story of 300-400 words, and some journalists will argue that their main job is to report the day's events, not to explain the background.

But I am not suggesting they should turn it into a history lecture; merely that they should at least hint at a broader picture and acknowledge that the Palestinians might have some genuine grievances.

To do this is neither difficult nor unduly word-consuming. Some news agency reports, for instance, routinely work into their stories a five-word reference to the "Palestinian struggle against Israeli occupation".

The Israeli occupation lies at the root of the conflict - and yet, more often than not, journalists fail to remind their readers of it.

The Guardian's electronic newspaper archive contains all the British national dailies, plus the London Evening Standard. A search of this reveals 1,669 stories published during the last 12 months that mentioned the West Bank.

Of these, 49 contained the phrase "occupied West Bank". A further 513 included the word "occupied" or "occupation" elsewhere in the text. That leaves 1,107 stories - 66% of the total - which managed to talk about the West Bank without mentioning one of the key facts.

Some journalists - particularly Americans - seem reluctant to treat occupation as an established fact and instead treat it as an opinion which should be attributed to someone. Last October, for example, CCN's Jerusalem bureau chief told viewers that Palestinians were angry at "what they regard as the Israeli occupation".

Others resort to euphemisms: the West Bank is "disputed" or "administrated by Israel". Some adopt the practice of Israeli officials by shortening "the Occupied Territories" to "the Territories".

Journalists are also rather timid on the question of Jewish settlers, usually portraying them as a target of violence but more rarely as one of the major causes (which they plainly are). Some of the recent stories about the killing of a 10-month-old Jewish baby, Shalhevet Pass, in Hebron made clear that the settlers there are a tiny and particularly fanatical bunch - though many did not.

One report described Hebron as a "divided city", when in fact 99.8% of the inhabitants are Arabs. (Jerusalem, on the other hand - with two-thirds of the population Jewish and one-third Arab - is constantly described by Israelis as "undivided".)

Over the last 12 months, 394 stories in the archive mentioned Jewish settlers. Of these, seven included the phrase "extremist settler" and eight "extremist Jewish settler". The word "extremist" did occur in 44 of the stories, though not necessarily applied to settlers. Some stories juxtaposed settlers characterised simply as "Jewish" with Palestinians characterised as "extremist".

The illegality of the settlements under international law also often escapes mention. The phrase "illegal settlement", used in an Israeli-Palestinian context, appeared only eight times during the last 12 months - and three of those were in readers' letters to the editor.

During the early stages of the intifada newspapers were accused of "dehumanising" Palestinians by publishing numbers but not names of those killed. This was contrasted with the wealth of personal information, helpfully provided by the Israeli authorities, about Jewish casualties.

The lack of Palestinian names was certainly not due to a conscious policy on the part of journalists and, although there are sometimes difficulties in getting the names, efforts have been made to remedy it.

However, last week's search of the archive highlighted another practice which has a similar effect: Jews mainly live in "communities" but Palestinians live in "areas".

Palestinian "areas" scored 109 mentions over the last 12 months; "neighbourhoods" scored 15 and "communities" only three (one each in the Guardian, Observer and Independent).

In the case of Jews, the positions were reversed: "communities" scored 87, "neighbourhoods" 30 and "areas" 21.

This is clearly not intentional and it may be partly due to the way we speak of Jewish communities in the diaspora. But the overall pattern does suggest a perception - perhaps an unconscious one - that Palestinians are less civilised. Another factor is that "neighbourhood" and, to a lesser extent, "community" are used as euphemisms for settlements. Israeli spokesmen regularly describe the settlement at Gilo as a "neighbourhood" of Jerusalem because it has been unilaterally annexed.

A recent report in the Times, following in the tradition of CNN, said that "Palestinians regard" Gilo as an illegal settlement. Indeed they do, but then so does international law.

fields.headline: MIA charade turns tragic
fields.standfirst:
This weekend's fatal helicopter crash highlights America's morbid obsession with bringing back its lost sons from Vietnam, says Mark Tran

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: This weekend's fatal helicopter crash highlights America's morbid obsession with bringing back its lost sons from Vietnam, says Mark Tran.
fields.body:
More than 25 years after the end of the Vietnam war, America retains an unhealthy obsession with tracking down every soldier missing in action from a conflict that still traumatises the American body politic.

That obsession turned tragic on Saturday when seven Americans and nine Vietnamese died, when their helicopter crashed into a mountainside in central Vietnam. It was the first loss of life since America and Vietnam began conducting search expeditions for American MIAs - soldiers missing in action - in 1985.

When the war ended in 1975, 2,583 Americans were listed as missing and the issue crystallised the pain and anguish of defeat. America wanted to be able to retrieve those remains and insisted on its right to scour Vietnam's jungles for its dead. For Vietnam, which has 300,000 of its own soldiers and civilians unaccounted for, the demand must have seemed inordinately fanciful.

But desperate for an end to America's economic embargo and a restoration of normal relations, Vietnam has humoured the US. It has allowed American teams to conduct their searches, contributing manpower and equipment to the effort - the helicopter that crashed at the weekend was a Russian M1-17 with a Vietnamese pilot under the controls.

There have been successes. Since 1985, the US says it has recovered and identified the remains of more than 600 Americans and the search continues for another 1,498 missing soldiers in Vietnam and a further 496 in Cambodia, Laos and south-eastern China. It is extremely unlikely that the US will be able to account for every single one of these soldiers, but it is politically impossible for an administration to close the book. Such as decision would be greeted with howls of outrage from MIA pressure groups.

A veritable cottage industry on MIAs has flourished, tinged with various degrees of paranoia. The National League of Families used to take a fairly sensible attitude, but it has bought into the notion that some Americans may still be alive in captivity. The league is relatively mainstream compared to those fringe groups that accuse the US government of being in cahoots with Vietnam by keeping quiet about these survivors, in return for future economic gains such as oil.

There have been instances when angry vets appeared before congressional hearings to throw bones on the table, claiming they were American remains. Even someone like senator John McCain, Vietnam war hero and Republican presidential candidate, is not immune to the wrath of these groups. Some vets accused him of betrayal when he expressed his belief that there were no living American captives from the war.

Under such pressure, no American administration has the guts to say "enough". So the US persists with a futile exercise and prolongs the agony for the relatives involved. Hanoi knows a full accounting is hopeless, but connives in this cynical operation. Yet who can blame Vietnam, with a full accounting a key condition for better relations? But as the loss of life at the weekend shows, charade can sometimes turn to tragedy.

fields.trailText: In the wake of The Common Good, the Guardian's highly praised recent series highlighting the work of public servants, we are running a competition to find photographs that best capture nature and value of public service.
fields.body:
In the wake of The Common Good, the Guardian's highly praised recent series highlighting the work of public servants, we are running a competition to find photographs that best capture nature and value of public service.

If you have a camera and work in public service, you could win the £2,000 first prize - and have your work printed in the Guardian.

The competition will be judged by Alan Rusbridger, Guardian editor, Eammon McCabe, Guardian picture editor, and Richard Sennett, professor of sociology at the London School of Economics.

Send entries - which can be in colour or black and white, prints, slides or digital - to Eammon McCabe, Public Images, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Closing date for entries is Thursday, April 20. We will do our best to return any pictures if you enclose an sae.

fields.headline: Any colour, as long as it's white
fields.standfirst:
How did The Simpsons save BBC2 from humiliation when the channel was subjected to a survey of its portrayal of black and Asian people? Gurbux Singh explains

Special report: race issues in the UK
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: How did The Simpsons save BBC2 from humiliation when the channel was subjected to a survey of its portrayal of black and Asian people? Gurbux Singh explains.
fields.body:
Ask anyone, Asian or black, which they think is the larger group in British society, black people or Asians. They'll almost always say the same thing. It's a view that is extraordinarily persistent, despite the fact that the Asian population in Britain is twice or more the size of the black one. There can only be one culprit. Our window on the world around us gives us that message day after day. Even black and Asian members of the public see the myth rather than the reality.

The latest television research conducted for the Commission for Racial Equality makes the point once again: the balance of people that we see on our screens does not reflect that in the community, and most under-represented are Asians.

The survey looked at a total of 204 programmes, the top 10 programmes each week on the five terrestrial channels, over a period of four weeks late last year. (It came to 204, incidentally, because The Simpsons and Friends had double-bill episodes, which we counted twice.) Amazingly, for one week's worth of top 10 programmes on BBC2, The Simpsons was the only show with a non-white presence. Britain's supposed highbrow channel was only saved from presenting an all-white world by a satirical American cartoon.

The record is just as dismal elsewhere: in the total sample of 204 programmes, 100 had black or Asian people with speaking parts. And the survey was generous in the way it tallied the score: if the people spoke, even only a couple of words, they were counted. For most people's money, The Full Monty is very much a white film  even though the original idea was in fact to have a black lead and other key black characters. Yet our method of analysis gives the black and Asian percentage in The Full Monty as 15.4, the figure being boosted by a few minutes in the film when a group of black women get to make a few comments.

What really worries me is that the annual monitoring by the Broadcasting Standards Commission does not reveal any progress since the surveys began in 1993. We can all see some very positive changes  the presence of the younger Asian and black reporters in the news programmes, the development of multicultural programmes but, for the blockbuster shows, the mainstream programmes that present the broadest picture of Britain, there is still a real hesitation when it comes to taking the material steps that will ensure change.

A year ago, the director general of the BBC, Greg Dyke, came to the CRE's annual Race In The Media Awards and committed the corporation to new targets for ethnic minority employment levels across its work force. Even better, he set those targets for a date when he would still be in office, so he was taking personal responsibility for their fulfilment. Within the overall targets, he set even tougher ones for boosting the black and Asian presence in the higher grades, the ones where decisions can be influenced rather than just carried out.

Some people may have balked at his talk of the BBC being hideously white", but Dyke was delivering accountable managerial programmes for practical change as well as trenchantly worded criticisms of the present state of affairs.

And it is there that we need to be looking. In reality, we do not need another research report to tell us that British television still does not reflect British society. What we need are sensible measures that will move television on from a situation in which race equality is talked about more than practised.

Making sure that the decision-takers in our television corporations reflect the population at large is one crucial step. At this year's awards we heard about another important new approach when it comes to programming policy.

Clive Jones, the chief executive of Carlton Television, suggested the idea of a commissioning clause that would require anyone judging a programme proposal to make diversity a key commissioning criterion. Channel 4 has already been piloting the idea, and the television industry alliance on diversity, the Cultural Diversity Network, which Clive chairs, is pushing the proposal, expecting all major broadcasters in Britain to adopt the idea over the coming months. The network is quite blunt about why it is doing so. If British television does not recognise the importance of diversity, it will neither liberate the full range of the talent it needs, nor will it appeal to the growing new audiences that make up modern Britain. If British television continues to marginalise these audiences, they will marginalise British television in their lives.

This is a difficult challenge. The problem has to be tackled across the board. No one measure will give the change that the leaders in the industry say they want, and that all viewers have a right to expect. Employment targets as set by Greg Dyke and a commissioning clause as outlined by Clive Jones are positive steps. Without them the changes will not come, but they have to be part of a comprehensive process that brings out into the open exactly what British television is doing at the moment (such as who it is employing and where, and what it is showing on screen) and then pinpoints the problems and lays out programmed action to put them right.

It helps no one that young people still grow up looking at the world and themselves through a television screen that hides much of the reality that it does not distort. It is not television's fault that the world out there is infested by racism and discrimination, but television needs to play its part in helping to deal with the problem instead of compromising with it.

Television executives need to stop repeating the old mantras that have been the excuses for doing nothing for so long, the claim, for instance, that the talent is not there when it so obviously is. They need to face the fact that much of the responsibility for the failure of television on the diversity fronts lies in the details of the decisions they take.

How is it that for four weeks in a row, BBC1's Antiques Roadshow fails to have a single black or Asian talking presence? One can perhaps understand how Channel 4's Neanderthal had no black or Asian presence given that everyone has made the assumption that we know they were white, but Heartbeat, four episodes in a row?

 Gurbux Singh is chair of the CRE.

What we need are sensible measures that will move television on from a situation in which race equality is talked about more than practised. Making sure that the decision-takers in our television corporations reflect the population at large is one crucial step. At this year's awards we heard about another important new approach when it comes to programming policy. Clive Jones, the chief executive of Carlton Television, suggested the idea of a commissioning clause that would require anyone judging a programme proposal to make diversity a key commissioning criterion. Channel 4 has already been piloting the idea, and the television industry alliance on diversity, the Cultural Diversity Network, which Clive chairs, is pushing the proposal, expecting all major broadcasters in Britain to adopt the idea over the coming months. The network is quite blunt about why it is doing so. If British television does not recognise the importance of diversity, it will neither liberate the full range of the talent it needs, nor will it appeal to the growing new audiences that make up modern Britain. If British television continues to marginalise these audiences, they will marginalise British television in their lives. This is a difficult challenge. The problem has to be tackled across the board. No one measure will give the change that the leaders in the industry say they want, and that all viewers have a right to expect. Employment targets as set by Greg Dyke and a commissioning clause as outlined by Clive Jones are positive steps. Without them the changes will not come, but they have to be part of a comprehensive process that brings out into the open exactly what British television is doing at the moment (such as who it is employing and where, and what it is showing on screen) and then pinpoints the problems and lays out programmed action to put them right. It helps no one that young people still grow up looking at the world and themselves through a television screen that hides much of the reality that it does not distort. It is not television's fault that the world out there is infested by racism and discrimination, but television needs to play its part in helping to deal with the problem instead of compromising with it. Television executives need to stop repeating the old mantras that have been the excuses for doing nothing for so long, the claim, for instance, that the talent is not there when it so obviously is. They need to face the fact that much of the responsibility for the failure of television on the diversity fronts lies in the details of the decisions they take. How is it that for four weeks in a row, BBC1's Antiques Roadshow fails to have a single black or Asian talking presence? One can perhaps understand how Channel 4's Neanderthal had no black or Asian presence given that everyone has made the assumption that we know they were white, but Heartbeat, four episodes in a row?  Gurbux Singh is chair of the CRE.

fields.headline: Rules for the royals
fields.standfirst: Lord Luce is due to publish a code of conduct for the royal family. Stephen Bates imagines what he might say...
fields.trailText: Lord Luce is due to publish a code of conduct for the royal family. Stephen Bates imagines what he might say...
fields.body:
re: Code of conduct for Royal Business Practice

Your Royal Highness,

I think we should implement the following:

1) No member of the royal family shall in future attend any event at which their status might be exploited. They will therefore travel incognito and wear a yashmak to disguise their features at public engagements. This might pose difficulties for some male members of the household and inhibit the intake of food and alcohol but would at least diminish the incentive for front-page photographs in the national press. It would also have the side effect of going down well with Your Majesty's Muslim subjects.

2) Public transport will be taken on all occasions. This should prove an incentive for Virgin Rail services etc to arrive on time when carrying a royal personage.

3) The practice of endorsing certain products with a royal warrant shall cease forthwith. This may persuade suppliers to supply large quantities of their products for free in return for discreet product placement: a bottle of gin beside HM during her Christmas broadcast may suffice to compensate Gordon's for the loss of a coat of arms above the main entrance to their head office.

4) As a counter-strategy, we could encourage commercial sponsorship of royal activities. How about the Tesco Banquet for the President of the United States during his next visit to London (or his first visit to London for that matter)? Or: "this official visit is sponsored by British Airways" during trips abroad?

5) Members of the royal family shall in future only attend events that will enhance their public image as hard-working, diligent, professional etc. This will have the added benefit of reducing the royal workload of public engagements quite considerably.

6) Public speeches should have more jokes and may have discreet product placements inserted in them, so long as they are not intrusive, viz: "And furthermore, my lord mayor, councillors, ladies and gentlemen, I shall have further thoughts on care in the community after the break. Meanwhile, why not try Brasso, ideal for polishing your crown at any time of day? I never go anywhere without it..."

7) Charitable work should be largely exempt from any of the above. This is a safe area, so long as the charity is chosen sensitively. Race horses and fox hunts are particularly appropriate.

8) Engaging in any form of public relations is strictly forbidden.

9) Never express an opinion on any subject whatsoever. If someone says, "It's turned out nice again", the correct response is, "I'll have to take a rain-check on that one."

10) Never accept a drink from an Arab. Particularly not one who keeps talking meaningfully into the vase of flowers on the table next to you.

fields.headline: PR pundits pessimistic about R-JH's future
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: PR firm R-JH will struggle to survive this weekend's revelations, according to top industry experts, writes Julia Day.
Apr 9: Sophie's partner fights for survival
fields.body:
Sophie Wessex's public relations firm R-JH will struggle to survive this weekend's revelations, according to top PR industry experts.

As the first of Mayfair-based R-JH's clients moves to disassociate itself from the company, R-JH will have to take radical action to stop business flowing out of its doors.

Founded in 1997 by the Countess of Wessex and Murray Harkin, R-JH employs 12 consultants and reported a modest turnover for the year March 1999 to March 2000 of £661,819 and pre-tax profits of £141,983.

Jack Cassidy has been appointed acting managing director to replace Mr Harkin, who quit as managing director yesterday.

The countess has stepped down as chairman.

Little is know about Mr Cassidy, a 59-year-old American from Pennsylvania.

He joined R-JH six months ago as a non-executive director of the company.

A R-JH statement said Mr Cassidy has been a marketing and public relations consultant for more than 25 years, but the company was unable to supply MediaGuardian.co.uk with his biography.

In the statement, Mr Cassidy is upbeat about R-JH's future: "Murray Harkin has done a fine job as managing director of this company and his leadership has been important in creating an excellent platform for future growth.

"My priority for R-JH is to ensure its continued success by focusing on the needs of our clients."

But Gavin Grant, managing director of corporate and public affairs Burson-Marsteller, said: "For those that are left to pick up the pieces, it is going to be very difficult.

"They need to consider some rebranding - the agency and its name relates to those two individuals [Wessex and Harkin]. They also need to rededicate themselves to the PR industry."

Another PR expert said the company may not even have a future.

Most of its business is based on project work rather than continuous accounts, which makes it is easy for clients to pull out.

fields.headline: M&S shares slump despite leak
fields.standfirst: The confidential accounts published at the weekend have not benefited the company, says Paul Murphy, executive financial editor
fields.trailText: The confidential accounts published at the weekend have not benefited the company, says Paul Murphy, executive financial editor.
fields.body:
A letter received by the Guardian on Friday morning contained a simple plea: "Please publish and help restore M&S."

The writer was referring to an accompanying document that detailed the trading performance of Marks & Spencer across each and every division - from food to knickers.

Produced in January, this highly confidential set of management accounts, which would have been circulated amongst just a handful of the retailer's most senior executives, tracked back through the preceding 10 tough months and then set out forecasts through to the end-March close of Marks's financial year.

The numbers, needless to say, are grisly. At best, the company only expects to meet the very worst City expectations on profitability. The only part of the business where things are improving is in its food halls, and even here the advance is marginal. Everywhere else, from lingerie to soft furnishings and menswear, sales are in precipitous decline.

And, predictably enough, publishing these figures at the weekend has not had the effect of "restoring M&S" in the short term. This morning, shares in the retailer dropped another 4% to 250p against an all-time high of 664p. The value of a business which was once a British icon has slumped from over £18bn to close to £7bn.

Whether a truer and more public understanding of the depth of crisis at M&S helps secure the company's future longer-term - gilding management (existing or new) into action - is difficult to say. Many retailing experts believe the company is in irreversible, secular decline and say the only course of action is to break the business up. Others simply say it needs more retailing nous - the "Arab trader with a rolled-out carpet mentality", as one major high street rival puts it - to restore key areas of Marks's business, principally womenswear and menswear.

In the meantime, the existing management, led by Belgian chairman and chief executive Luc Vandevelde, seems to be tearing itself to shreds. Tempers appear to have been inflamed by last week's revelation in the Guardian that Mr Vandevelde is still in line to collect a £650,000 bonus agreed at the time of his appointment, even though the new man has singularly failed to fashion a revival in Marks's fortunes.

Other senior management are not so lucky. The document which landed at the Guardian on Friday details how a £10m provision for executive bonuses has been routed back into profits, since second and third tier management have failed to meet any of their sales or profitability targets for individual parts of the business. They feel deeply aggrieved, having to pay the price for what they perceive to be failure at the top, and the result has been a relentless round of internal bickering about where the problems really lie and who is best placed to fix them.

To make matters worse, there are fresh noises from those outside who have threatened in the past to try and take Marks over. Best known of these is Phillip Green, the Monaco-based entrepreneur who currently runs Bhs and who was close to raising the finance for a bid last year. Expect fresh aggressive rumblings from this man.

fields.headline: Amazon surprises critics
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Amazon.com has surprised its critics by predicting a better than expected start to the year, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online retailer Amazon.com has surprised its critics by predicting a better than expected start to the year.

The doyen of dot.coms said its losses for the first quarter of 2001 would be less than £177m, beating analysts' forecasts.

Amazon has been the focus of unrelenting criticism for the supposed weakness of its balance sheet, with some analysts openly doubting if it will ever reach profitability.

But chief executive Jeff Bezos said Amazon was continuing to set the pace for web retailers.

"For the fifth consecutive quarter we saw substantial improvement in our operations and bottom-line performance," he said.

Amazon also predicted first quarter revenues of more than £482m, against analysts' predictions of £465m.

Mr Bezos added that the most impressive growth came from sales of electronic goods, with the US market for books and CDs showing "very slight" growth.

The news from Amazon brought some cheer to Wall Street, which has been hammered by a series of profit warnings from dot.coms and technology companies.

The technology heavy Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1% percent, with Amazon soaring more than 41%.

fields.headline: The internet twins: timeline
fields.trailText: January 16: The saga begins when Alan Kilshaw and his wife Judith reveal to The Sun that they bought the twins after contacting an internet adoption agency.
fields.body:
January 16: The saga begins when Alan Kilshaw and his wife Judith reveal to The Sun that they bought the twins after contacting an internet adoption agency.

The couple from north Wales tell the paper they adopted the six-month-old girls in Arkansas, after paying £8,200 to adoption broker Tina Johnson. Mr Kilshaw, a solicitor, says they were forced to find children overseas because adoption in the UK was "over-regulated".

But it emerges that the girls, who the Kilshaws named Belinda and Kimberley, had previously been sold to a Californian couple by the same broker for £4,000. Richard and Vickie Allen claim they were duped into returning the twins to their natural mother Tranda Wecker and say they will fight to regain custody of them.

January 17: Prime minister Tony Blair promises swift action to stop the "deplorable" trading of children for adoption.

Mr Blair pledges to implement the Adoption (Intercountry Aspects) Act, which was passed in 1999 but not brought into force. It could be used to refuse recognition to adoptions conducted in countries that do not comply with the Hague convention, which gives protection to children in these circumstances.

January 18: An emergency protection order is served on the Kilshaws and the twins are taken into the care of Flintshire county council following a swoop by police. The papers are saturated with lurid tales about the couple who have now appeared on several TV programmes, ranging from GMTV to Newsnight.

January 20: The council lodges an appeal to the family division of the high court to make the twins wards of court.

January 22: The government warns UK-based internet service providers not to carry material that breaks adoption laws.

January 23: A High Court judge rules the internet twins will remain in emergency foster care until their future is decided. Mr Justice Kirkwood, sitting behind closed doors at court in Birmingham, also asks the Kilshaws not to speak publicly about the case.

January 24: A judge in the state of Missouri awards custody of the twins to their natural father, Aaron Wecker. But the order in favour of Mr Wecker has no immediate effect because the twins remain in the care of Flintshire social services.

February 1: The Kilshaws come face-to-face with the Allens on The Oprah Winfrey Show on US TV. A lawyer acting for the American couple then serves the Kilshaws with a writ, summoning them to appear before a court in Arkansas.

February 8: The natural mother of internet twins Tranda Wecker appoints a child law specialist to represent her at the UK hearings in an attempt to get them back.

March 1: Richard Allen is arrested on suspicion of child abuse following complaints from two teenage babysitters. He appears in court two days later and pleads not guilty to the charges. But the Allens withdraw from the custody battle for the twins.

March 6: Another US judge decides the twins belong to neither the Kilshaws nor the Allens. Judge Mackie Pierce, sitting in Arkansas, says the girls' fate should be decided in Missouri where they were born last June. But it remains to be seen whether the UK High Court judge will decide they should return to the US.

March 15: Health minister John Hutton announces jail sentences for people avoiding child protection procedures by adopting children from overseas will be introduced in April.

Prospective adoptive parents bringing children to the UK without first gaining approval from a recognised adoption agency will be subject to a prison term of up to three months, a £5,000 fine or both.

April 9: The UK high court decides the internet twins should be returned to the US. Mr Justice Kirkwood said it was not in the welfare interests of the girls to be returned to the Killshaws. Their fate will now be decided in Missouri.

webTitle: Church of England under fire over rent rise

fields.headline: Church of England under fire over rent rise
fields.trailText: The Church of England has been accused of betraying the poor over its decision to raise rents by hundreds of pounds on more than 1,000 London homes that have had affordable rents for over a century.
fields.body:
The Church of England has been accused of betraying the poor over its decision to raise rents by hundreds of pounds on more than 1,000 London homes that have had affordable rents for almost a century.

The church commissioners propose to phase in rent rises on homes across the capital on its Octavia Hill estates - named after the social pioneer who successfully convinced the church in the early 20th century that the homes should be reserved for the poor.

No Octavia Hill tenant pays more than about £500 a month - and in some cases as little as £350 a month. But the rent on one home in Waterloo has been increased to £1,464 a month to test the idea.

Church commissioners were handed 30 pieces of silver and a petition protesting against the decision at a demonstration today, which included government minister and Vauxhall MP Kate Hoey.

Protesters claimed the plan exposed the commissioners as hypocrites on social exclusion.

A spokesman for the commissioners stressed that the increases will be used to fund repairs, and will only be implemented once homes become vacant. He added that commissioners have a legal duty to ensure the church gets the most from its assets.

But general synod member, the Rev Benny Hazlehurst who led the protest said the church's duty on assets was open to legal interpretation and that in the past the church had successfully argued it could continue to charge affordable rents.

He said: "The big issue is that the church is in danger of saying all the right things on social exclusion and doing something completely different."

Mr Hazlehurst claimed the plan would make Octavia Hill turn in her grave.

He added: "These proposals fly in the face of everything the church stands for. If adopted, they will remove over 1,000 homes from hard pressed social housing and make them available only to the very rich."

"Over 100 years of commitment to people on low incomes will be thrown away."

The proposals are expected to go before the general synod in July.

No Octavia Hill tenant pays more than about £500 a month - and in some cases as little as £350 a month. But the rent on one home in Waterloo has been increased to £1,464 a month to test the idea. He said: "The big issue is that the church is in danger of saying all the right things on social exclusion and doing something completely different." Mr Hazlehurst claimed the plan would make Octavia Hill turn in her grave. He added: "These proposals fly in the face of everything the church stands for. fields.headline: Couple lose internet twins
fields.trailText: British couple Alan and Judith Kilshaw today lost their high court battle to keep the nine-month-old American-born babies they said they had adopted legally via the internet.
fields.body:
British couple Alan and Judith Kilshaw today lost their high court battle to keep the nine-month-old American-born babies they said they had adopted legally via the internet.

Justice Andrew Kirkwood ruled that the twins should be returned to the US, where they would be looked after by foster parents in Missouri until an American court will decide what is in their best interests.

Earlier, as the judge was giving his ruling behind closed doors, Judith Kilshaw ran from the high court in London screaming: "There is no justice! They said I lied!"

As the judge continued inside the court with his private judgment, Mrs Kilshaw had to be retrained by court staff as she harangued media representatives outside the courtroom.

She then returned seeming calmer, but was escorted from the courtroom 20 minutes later.

The Kilshaws, from north Wales, brought the babies to Britain in January after paying a California-based internet adoption agency $12,000 (about £8,300) for the babies. They twins were taken into care by Flintshire social services soon after.

The twins' adoption by the Kilshaws was declared void on March 6 when an Arkansas court ruled that the UK couple and the babies' biological mother, Tranda Wecker, had not met a 30-day residency requirement to qualify for adoption. The Kilshaws appealed that decision.

A Californian couple, Richard and Vickie Allen, initially contested the Kilshaws' claim to the twins, claiming they had paid $6,000 to adopt them.

The Allens bowed out of the battle after Richard Allen was accused of molesting two baby sitters. Allen has pleaded innocent, but the couple has also lost custody of a two-year-old boy they were seeking to adopt.

The twins' adoption by the Kilshaws was declared void on March 6 when an Arkansas court ruled that the UK couple and Ms Wecker had not met the 30-day residency requirement to qualify as state residents at the time of the adoption. The Kilshaws appealed that decision.

Last week, lawyers for each of the twins' estranged biological parents, Tranda and Aaron Wecker of St Louis, Missouri, filed papers asking Kirkwood to declare the girls abducted children under the Hague Convention on Inter-country Adoption.

webTitle: Barker and Balding get the National thumbs-up

fields.headline: Barker and Balding get the National thumbs-up
fields.trailText: If you are looking for a reliable witness on the quality of the BBC's Grand National coverage, don't come to me. While for most of you losers, the world's greatest steeplechase will have proved about as attractive a weekend investment as shares in Marks & Spencer, I won money on the race. Real actual money - sixty-six pounds please, Surrey Racing - which does tend to leave you favourably disposed towards the afternoon's entertainment. I enjoyed it immensely.
fields.body:
If you are looking for a reliable witness on the quality of the BBC's Grand National coverage, don't come to me. While for most of you losers, the world's greatest steeplechase will have proved about as attractive a weekend investment as shares in Marks & Spencer, I won money on the race. Real actual money - sixty-six pounds please, Surrey Racing - which does tend to leave you favourably disposed towards the afternoon's entertainment. I enjoyed it immensely.

Can there be anything more agreeable than sitting in your favourite armchair, placing interactive bets from the comfort of your own remote control, while watching other punters getting soaked in the knowledge that they have probably had to suffer the vagaries of our rail system just to get there? (American comedian Reg D Hunter: "Are your trains called Virgin, because it's like they've never done it before?")

Schadenfreude is, if you will permit me to be pan- European, le mot juste.

The heavy rain, which started in Liverpool round about Christmas time and they are hoping will end some day soon, was obviously the big story in the build-up to the race, and for those of us unfamiliar with the effects of persistent rain - viewers newly arrived perhaps from Luxor or Baghdad - the BBC very considerately planted Clare Balding out in the middle of it.

While this was no particular help in making a judgment on the outcome of the race, it was rather interesting as a graphic illustration of how wet a woman can get if you leave her out in the rain.

Clare clearly was not expecting to spend quite so long at the mercy of the elements, because she had dressed up in a rather smart high buttoned quasi-military tunic like something off the Sgt Pepper album sleeve; but then had to hide it by throwing what appeared to be borrowed rainwear over the top.

"I've grabbed a hat and grabbed a mac," she apologised, and one is forced to say she had grabbed none too wisely. The hat was a beret, possibly loaned by some props guy who had kept it as a souvenir of Michael Crawford's triumph as Frank Spencer in the sit-com Some Mothers Do 'Ave 'Em.

It fitted Clare no better than Crawford, perching at a comical angle, and permitting a strand of wet hair to hang down from underneath it, looking like Madonna's microphone.

In no other respect did Clare resemble Madonna. To the pouting princess of pop, image and appearance are everything, but racing's first lady has a refreshingly cavalier attitude to such fripperies.

Clare - and apologies to those of you who have strayed here from more politically correct bits of the newspaper, but this is the only way to put it - is a game filly, and no mistake. Game as a peanut, in fact. Not for one moment did she allow the fact that she was doing a passable impersonation of Kate Winslet on the deck of the Titanic (after it hit the iceberg) deflect her from her discussion of horse flesh.

National day used to be Des's day. For those of us not in thrall to all things equine, Des's ironically arched eyebrow and relaxed approach to the race used to act as a welcome counterbalance to all the unabashed enthusiasm on display. But Clare and Sue Barker - and I hope this is not just the money talking - now look a very acceptable replacement.

Young Clare should be careful, though, not to allow her bosses to take advantage of her.

It was interesting, I thought, that Sue stayed undercover while Clare got drenched. It occurred to me, as I turned the gas fire up a notch and poured another large vodka, that it would have been nice to have seen Sue Barker out in the wind and rain for once. But maybe that's just me.

I did, of course, watch the re-run of the race three times. It is so rare you can enjoy an entertainment in the sure and certain knowledge that everything will turn out for the best - apart from Hollywood movies, and who would want to watch one of those? - that I wanted to take the opportunity while I could.

The replays also gave the bonus of some excellent pictures from the jockeys' room where the mud-spattered heroes relaxed by watching themselves falling off their mounts.

I have written before that the camaraderie of National Hunt jockeys is almost unique in sport. It was palpable in that room. The post-modern shot of Tony McCoy and Ruby Walsh watching themselves helping each other out of danger and back on to their horses, was remarkably moving. I am sure I would have found it memorable even if I hadn't been dipping my hand into Surrey Racing's wallet at the time.

Some of my profit was invested in Sky Box Office's broadcast of Naseem Hamed versus Marco Antonio Barrera, which provided the other great uplifiting moment of the weekend, namely Hamed's dignified acceptance of defeat.

I never thought I would use the words dignified and Hamed in the same sentence, but after a great fight, Naz gave credit exactly where it was due. It is tempting to say that in losing his title, he became a true champ.

fields.headline: Advertisers jump onto mobile phones
fields.trailText: 11am: Advertisers are queuing up to get their message across on phones, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
It is still a fledgling business but advertisers are queuing up to get their message across on new-fangled email phones.

Amstrad has told MediaGuardian.co.uk its new telephone service combining email and text messaging has just signed up its 25th client.

Simon Sugar, commercial director of Amstrad and son of entrepreneur Alan, said he was developing a number of new revenue streams for the Emailer product, and was in the process of expanding the advertiser base.

"As we update the software we can offer more targeted and premium services. We're still really in trial status but are starting to offer more advertising opportunities," said Mr Sugar.

One new "value-added service" launching this week is a greetings card facility allowing users to email electronic templates for birthdays and other anniversaries.

Other services in the pipeline are pre-loaded branded pizza menus, phone numbers and localised advertising.

This week Norwich Union joins the growing list of companies keen to try out the new medium.

Other big names signed up include Interflora, BSkyB, Direct Line, Britannia Music, Dixons, UCI Cinemas and Dial-a-Phone. The adverts typically flash up on the screens throughout the day and can carry direct phone call links to call centres.

Adverts stay on the service for up to eight days and cost between 15-25p per advert delivered.

So far 90,000 users have Emailer telephones while the cost of an eight-day campaign varies between £13,500 and £22,500.

Mr Sugar is trying to make Emailer pay its way to offset losses from drastic cost-cutting in the price of the units, which are sold at £79 even though they cost almost £200 to make.

fields.headline: 'Metric martyr' convicted
fields.trailText: A market trader was today convicted of breaking weights and measures legislation by selling fruit in pounds and ounces in the first prosecution of its kind in Britain.
fields.body:
A market trader was today convicted of breaking weights and measures legislation by selling fruit in pounds and ounces in the first prosecution of its kind in Britain.

Greengrocer Steven Thoburn, 36, of Sunderland, now faces a maximum fine of £1,000 on each of the two offences and court costs estimated at up to £60,000.

He was convicted of breaching the Weights and Measures Act 1985 in a hearing which district judge Bruce Morgan said centred on the "most famous bunch of bananas in legal history".

Mr Thoburn denied the charges, which were brought after trading standards officers from Sunderland city council raided his market stall in the Southwick area of the city in July last year and seized two sets of scales.

Mr Thoburn - dubbed "the metric martyr" by his supporters - was prosecuted for selling his produce in pounds and ounces.

In his ruling, Mr Morgan told Sunderland magistrates court that he was aware that regardless of the verdict the case would be going to appeal.

"It has been made clear to me that despite the decision of this court the matter will be taken elsewhere."

Earlier, Mr Thoburn said: "I wake up at night in a panic and try to work out how we got to this state and how my mates and I could find ourselves persecuted for doing nothing more than selling fruit and veg."

Eleanor Sharpston QC, for Sunderland city council, maintained during the case that if Britain wanted to be part of Europe it had to abide by its laws.

She closed her case by saying: " We are not, as has been suggested, living in a UK which is sovereign in the classic British empire 19th century way.

"That UK is part of political and legal history."

fields.headline: German firm takes over Powergen
fields.trailText: The German energy firm Eon today announced it is to take over Powergen, the British electricity company, in a £9.6bn deal hailed as a platform for overseas growth.
fields.body:
The German energy firm Eon today announced it is to take over Powergen, the British electricity company, in a £9.6bn deal hailed as a platform for overseas growth.

The long-awaited offer has been recommended by Powergen's board and was described by Eon as a major step that would give it a "leading position in the UK utilities market".

Powergen's chairman, Ed Wallis, said: "I am delighted we have been able to reach agreement with Eon. This is a good deal for our shareholders, our employees and our customers as well as for Eon."

Powergen said that there were no plans for large-scale job cuts as a result of the deal, describing it as "good news for UK jobs" and a "platform for growth rather than for cost cuttings".

The company employs 13,000 staff, 7,000 of whom are based in the UK. Today's deal comes three months after Powergen first disclosed that it had received a takeover approach from Eon.

The deal is expected to give Eon a foothold in the American as well as the British market. Eon's chairman, Ulrich Hartmann, said that, following the merger last year that created Eon, the group had positioned itself as one of the "top players in Europe".

John Rowse, national secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, which represents Powergen staff, said: "We welcome the stability for workers and the company's assurances that there would be no negative impact on jobs."

Shares in Powergen rose by nearly 1% following the announcement - rising 6.5p to 712.5p in early trading. Under Eon's offer, Powergen's shares are valued at 765p each.

fields.headline: The indiscretion of Sophie Wessex
fields.standfirst:
Sophie Rhys-Jones has obliged Buckingham Palace to rethink its policy of allowing minor royals to pursue careers with her ill-judged remarks to a phoney 'sheikh'. Derek Brown explains

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Sophie Rhys-Jones has obliged Buckingham Palace to rethink its policy of allowing minor royals to pursue careers with her ill-judged remarks to a phoney 'sheikh'. Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
Did Sophie have a choice?
Not really. Following the second instalment of the News of the World saga - a complete transcript of the secretly taped interview - she announced within hours that she was leaving the chair at RJH.

At the same time, her business partner, Murray Harkin, announced that he would resign as managing director over his own indiscreet remarks - including the casual revelation that he had dabbled in cocaine and ecstasy.

How did the story start?
An employee of RJH, Kishan Athulathmudali, was unhappy that the firm was exploiting its royal connections to drum up business. He approached PR guru Max Clifford, who peddled the story around the tabloids.

It was taken up by the News of the World, which set up a bogus appointment for Sophie Wessex and Murray Harkin to meet a 'sheikh' - in fact, the paper's star reporter, Mazher Mahmood.

What did she say?
Some of the wilder speculations of last week - for example that she had called Cherie Blair "horrid, horrid, horrid" were laid to rest by the News of the World's publication of the full transcript.

Nevertheless, there was still a lot of damaging stuff in Sophie's chitchat. For example, her assertion that Tony Blair is "ignorant" about the countryside, and her glib remark that "we call him President Blair, because he thinks he is".

But much more damaging was her throwaway suggestion that a PR outfit with royal contacts has inherent commercial advantages: "It's not something anybody promises, it's just something that occurs".

The significance is that Sophie thought she could land a lucrative contract with the 'sheikh', who was posing as a rich Dubai-based businessman, and was shamelessly drawing attention to her royal credentials.

Is the Palace furious with Sophie?
No, it's sympathetic. But it's livid with the News of the World. The official word: "The Queen deplores the entrapment, subterfuge, innuendo and untruths to which [the Wessexes] have been subjected in recent days."

What does Sophie say?
"I am deeply distressed that the carrying out of an entrapment operation on me and my business but I also much regret my own misjudgment in succumbing to that subterfuge."

Is that the end of it?
Not in the least. The royal establishment is now to conduct a wholesale review of royal careers and business connections.

There is known disquiet in the Palace that both the Wessexes have been apparently using their name to make cash: Sophie by attracting new clients to RJH, and Prince Edward by spending time on official royal tours to secure the backing of foreign royals for programmes to be produced by his loss-making TV company, Ardent.

Are there constitutional implications?
Yes, say Labour MPs who want a review not only of royal incomes, but of the monarchy itself. To some extent the conventions governing the relationship between the monarchy and the government have already been abandoned. Tony Blair has pointedly declined to chastise ministers who have criticised the countess.

fields.bodyText: Did Sophie have a choice? Not really. Following the second instalment of the News of the World saga - a complete transcript of the secretly taped interview - she announced within hours that she was leaving the chair at RJH. At the same time, her business partner, Murray Harkin, announced that he would resign as managing director over his own indiscreet remarks - including the casual revelation that he had dabbled in cocaine and ecstasy. How did the story start? An employee of RJH, Kishan Athulathmudali, was unhappy that the firm was exploiting its royal connections to drum up business. He approached PR guru Max Clifford, who peddled the story around the tabloids. It was taken up by the News of the World, which set up a bogus appointment for Sophie Wessex and Murray Harkin to meet a 'sheikh' - in fact, the paper's star reporter, Mazher Mahmood. What did she say? Some of the wilder speculations of last week - for example that she had called Cherie Blair "horrid, horrid, horrid" were laid to rest by the News of the World's publication of the full transcript. Nevertheless, there was still a lot of damaging stuff in Sophie's chitchat. For example, her assertion that Tony Blair is "ignorant" about the countryside, and her glib remark that "we call him President Blair, because he thinks he is". But much more damaging was her throwaway suggestion that a PR outfit with royal contacts has inherent commercial advantages: "It's not something anybody promises, it's just something that occurs". The significance is that Sophie thought she could land a lucrative contract with the 'sheikh', who was posing as a rich Dubai-based businessman, and was shamelessly drawing attention to her royal credentials. Is the Palace furious with Sophie? No, it's sympathetic. But it's livid with the News of the World. The official word: "The Queen deplores the entrapment, subterfuge, innuendo and untruths to which [the Wessexes] have been subjected in recent days." What does Sophie say? "I am deeply distressed that the carrying out of an entrapment operation on me and my business but I also much regret my own misjudgment in succumbing to that subterfuge." Is that the end of it? Not in the least. The royal establishment is now to conduct a wholesale review of royal careers and business connections. There is known disquiet in the Palace that both the Wessexes have been apparently using their name to make cash: Sophie by attracting new clients to RJH, and Prince Edward by spending time on official royal tours to secure the backing of foreign royals for programmes to be produced by his loss-making TV company, Ardent. Are there constitutional implications? Yes, say Labour MPs who want a review not only of royal incomes, but of the monarchy itself. To some extent the conventions governing the relationship between the monarchy and the government have already been abandoned. Tony Blair has pointedly declined to chastise ministers who have criticised the countess. fields.headline: 10m tune into muddy farce
fields.trailText:
3pm TV overnights: Two-thirds of Saturday afternoon viewers tuned in to BBC1 for the Grand National, writes Jason Deans.
Sky feels the force
fields.body:
The Grand National may have descended into muddy farce, but that did not stop two-thirds of Saturday afternoon viewers tuning in to BBC1's Grandstand to watch the world's greatest steeple chase.

The Martell Grand National, which just four horses completed, two of those after their jockeys had remounted, began at 3.45pm on Saturday afternoon.

In the quarter-hour that followed 10m - 66% of the available audience - tuned in, according to unofficial overnights.

Last night ITV showed there is still an appetite among viewers for costume drama, with a successful first outing for its two-part Nicholas Nickleby adaptation between 9pm and 11pm.

The Life and Times of Nicholas Nickleby had 8.2m viewers and a 37% audience share.

It easily beat the second part of BBC1 religious documentary Son of God, which took just 4.8m.

On a big weekend for sport, 7.1m watched ITV's live coverage of the Liverpool versus Wycombe Wanderers FA Cup semi-final on Sunday afternoon.

The game attracted a 44% audience share between 3.30pm and 6.05pm.

Later on Sunday BBC2's live coverage of Tiger Woods's victory in the US Masters golf tournament also rated well by the channel's usual standards between 9pm and midnight.

During that time BBC2 had 2.8m and a 15% audience share.

On Saturday night, a strong Parkinson line-up featuring Hugh Grant, Robbie Williams and Amanda Burton helped the BBC1 show to a ratings victory over ITV opposition Meet the Popstars.

Parky had 7.6m and a 32% share, while Meet the Popstars had 6.1m.

On Friday night, BBC2 successfully premiered its big new US import, sitcom Malcolm in the Middle, between 6.45pm and 7.10pm.

Malcolm in the Middle had 3.3m and a 17% share, against Channel 4's Dawson's Creek, with just 1m.

fields.headline: News of the World cries foul after Observer reveals identity of undercover reporter
fields.trailText: 5pm: The News of the World is to complain to press watchdogs after the Observer printed a photo of the reporter at the centre of the 'Sophie tapes' scandal. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The News of the World is planning to complain to the Observer about its decision to print a photograph of the undercover reporter at the centre of the 'Sophie tapes' scandal on Sunday.

Mazher Mahmood, the man who spearheaded the "sting" that has forced the Countess of Wessex, Sophie Rhys-Jones, to resign from her PR company, said the move was "absolutely outrageous".

A spokeswoman for the News of the World confirmed the paper was "very angry and disappointed" at the newspaper's decision to publish the picture.

She continued: "We are considering all options and are appalled and immensely saddened at the Observer's consciously reckless conduct."

"All newspapers were specifically asked not to publish his picture," she said.

The spokeswoman said publication of the picture of Mr Mahmood - who has carved out a successful career as an undercover journalist - not only threatened his career but also put his safety at risk.

"Work by Mazher Mahmood has been used to secure over 108 convictions," she said, "and there are people out there who would very much like him identified."

The situation raises the ironic potential for the News of the World to make a complaint to the Press Complaints Commission against the Observer for invasion of privacy.

The PCC did not want to comment ahead of a complaint. But a source said: "The PCC has always been against becoming involved in disputes between newspapers."

The Observer said: "We acknowledge the News of the World's concern over the publication of a photograph of one of their investigative journalists. However, this is not the first time a photograph of Mazher Mahmood has appeared in the national press.

"We firmly believe that Observer readers have shown almost as great an interest in the provenance of this story and they have done in the detail allegedly revealed in the so-called 'Sophie tapes'. As such Mazher Mahmood is very much part of the story."

webTitle: Bush writes to widow of Chinese pilot

fields.headline: Bush writes to widow of Chinese pilot
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: US President George Bush has written to the widow of a Chinese pilot presumed killed in a mid-air collision with an American spy plane.
fields.body:
US President George Bush has written to the widow of a Chinese pilot presumed killed in a mid-air collision with an American spy plane.

The contents of the letter are unknown, but Ruan Guoqin, the recipient, accused the president of being "too cowardly" to apologise for the loss of her husband.

Her public anguish has fuelled tensions between the US and China.

The secretary of state, Colin Powell, said the purpose of the letter was to respond in a humanitarian way to a grieving widow.

"Whatever you think about the politics of it, she's lost her husband."

He also said he was "sorry" for her loss, using a contentious word that Washington had previously avoided. However, he made it clear that the US would not apologise for the collision, which Washington maintains took place in international airspace.

American officials yesterday tried to balance their sympathy with tough reminders to Beijing that the standoff was damaging relations between the two countries.

"I don't want to put a timetable on it; every day that goes by without having it resolved raises the risks to the long-term relationship," said the vice president, Dick Cheney.

Twenty-four American service men and women are being held by China on the southern island of Hainain, where the US EP-3 spy plane made an emergency landing on April 1.

Mr Bush spent the weekend at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland, conferring with aides including the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and senior adviser Karen Hughes.

Ms Rice said Mr Bush had not called the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin.

Some in Washington suggested the standoff over the air crew was related to broader tensions between China and the US.

"I think they're pawns being used by the Chinese to try to gain some goals that they're not going to achieve," said Senator Carl Levin, a Democrat.

Frustrated that the impasse was dragging on, some members of Congress have said it could lead to a bitter trade fight later this year. Possible US opposition to China's bid to stage the Olympics in 2008 is also an option.

fields.headline: TBWA promotes Bainsfair
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: TBWA's UK chief Paul Bainsfair has been promoted to president for northern Europe in a management shake-up, writes Claire Cozens. Mar 16: TBWA confirms Greenlees departure
fields.body:
Paul Bainsfair, chairman of TBWA's UK operations, has been promoted to president for northern Europe as part of a management shake-up.

The reshuffle follows the appointment of Jean-Marie Dru as president and chief executive of the advertising agency last month.

Mr Dru replaced Mike Greenlees, who left to take up a new post at TBWA's parent company Omnicom.

Mr Bainsfair will chair the company's European board. He will work alongside Nick Baum, president of TBWA/France, who takes responsibility for southern Europe, and Perry Valkenburg, president of TBWA\Netherlands, who will take on the new role of president for central and eastern Europe.

"The new appointments will enable us to leverage the heads of some of our largest and most successful offices into key regional management positions," said Mr Dru.

"They will be in a position to translate our local entrepreneurialism and quality into network strength.

"In addition, I have been able to appoint a very experienced worldwide team who can develop our people, drive our overall growth and lock our network together across the regions."

As part of the shake-up Carl Johnson, president of TBWA\Chiat\Day New York, takes on the additional title of chief operating officer of TBWA\Worldwide. He will report directly to Mr Dru.

TBWA is among the top 10 US-based agency networks, with offices in 69 countries, and clients including Absolut Vodka, Apple Computers, Nissan and Sony PlayStation.
