webTitle: Life gets tougher for Australia's immigrants

fields.headline: Life gets tougher for Australia's immigrants
fields.standfirst: A series of protests by asylum seekers has prompted Canberra to clamp down harder, reports Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: A series of protests by asylum seekers has prompted Canberra to clamp down harder, reports Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
A week ago today Shahraz Kayani set himself alight outside the Australian parliament in Canberra. He had been waiting five years for Australia's immigration department to permit his wife and children to join him and had given up hope. With burns on 60% of his body, he has a "fighting chance" of surviving, say hospital staff.

Two days later, 200 asylum seekers rioted at Curtin detention centre, one of six secure units where Australia detains its asylum seekers, including women and children, while their claims are assessed.

Tear gas was used against the Curtin detainees by guards from Australasian Correctional Management (ACM), a subsidiary company of the US corporate penal giant, the Wakenhut corporation, which makes a tidy profit out of running Australia's detention centres. (The Conservative party proposes a similar system in Britain.)

The Australian government's response to these protests has been to get tougher. Hardline immigration minister Philip Ruddock yesterday claimed that facilities in the detention centres were better than in many Australians' homes.

Last week he introduced new legislation to increase staff powers in the centres, proposing to enable staff to strip-search detainees as young as 10 to find and confiscate weapons. He also proposed three-year prison sentences for asylum seekers caught trying to escape the centres.

Three United Nations reports condemned Australia's treatment of asylum seekers last year. The country flouts the UN high commissioner for refugees' recommendation that children should be spared detention.

In February, two highly critical internal reports on the Woomera detention centre were released. Woomera, set up on an old military base in the south Australian desert, where temperatures regularly reach 40C, witnessed several riots last year and was subject to allegations that staff did nothing to prevent child abuse.

One report by Australia's former high commissioner to London found that the sexual abuse of a 12-year-old boy in the centre had not been managed properly by ACM staff. Another by the Commonwealth ombudsman said that staff had racially abused and intimidated asylum seekers, treating them like prisoners. Former Liberal prime minister Malcolm Fraser called Woomera a "hell hole" and said it must be shut immediately.

The government momentarily softened its stance, agreeing to trial the release of a small number of women and children from Woomera into the community.

Politically, fears about the "illegal tide" of "boat people" "swamping" Australia were talked up by the emergence of Pauline Hanson in 1996. Both mainstream parties swiftly responded to her populist scaremongering. Moves to create the current detention system were made by the last Labour government and enthusiastically adopted by the coalition government, which opened new centres and now plans to build two more in Brisbane and Darwin.

The coalition claims Australia accepts more refugees per capita each year than any country except Canada. Asylum seekers whose claims are approved are given temporary protection visas, which permit a three-year stay but limit access to benefits and English language classes.

The government is fearful that if it doesn't detain asylum seekers it will be seen as a "soft touch". John Howard, the prime minister, said on Friday: "If the message gets around the world that this country is easy to get into and almost impossible to be expelled from then you are going to attract more and more people."

But four years of draconian detention centres doesn't appear to be deterring desperate people from Afghanistan, Iraq and other Middle Eastern countries from paying Indonesian people smugglers to make the treacherous trip across the Timor sea.

Between December 1999 and January 2001, almost 4,000 people arrived in Australia by boat without visas, more than the total number of unauthorised arrivals by boat in the previous three years. So far this year, 1,033 immigrants have been intercepted off Australia's remote coastline.

Research has shown populist fears that immigrants fleece taxpayers by soaking up welfare benefits to be misguided. A greater proportion of Australian-born people receive benefits than overseas-born people. Big business has also said that resource-rich Australia's future economic prospects depend on it expanding its internal markets by increasing its population of 19m.

Despite this, the mass detention of asylum seekers looks set to continue. Even if the Labour party wins the federal election in the autumn, its half-hearted opposition to the coalition's measures look unlikely to lead to scrapping compulsory detention for asylum seekers.

Meanwhile, the government is to allow the 85-year-old father and 12-year-old daughter of Shahraz Kayani to travel from Pakistan to see him in hospital. Despite being an Australian citizen since 1999, there is still no word on whether Mr Kayani's family will be able to join him permanently if he recovers from his critical burns.

fields.headline: Straw launches £220m local drugs initiatives
fields.trailText: The government today fired its latest salvo in the war against drugs with a £220m fund aimed at creating a network of regional partnerships to help fight drug related crime.
fields.body:
The government today fired its latest salvo in the war against drugs with a £220m fund aimed at creating a network of regional partnerships to help fight drug related crime.

The scheme - the money for which was first announced in the chancellor's Budget last month - will see 376 local initiatives funded over the next three years as part of the government's "communities against drugs" campaign.

Manchester United star Andy Cole and manager Sir Alex Ferguson will today pledge their support for the scheme at a meeting with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the cabinet office minister, Ian McCartney, in Manchester.

Mr Straw said: "The funding that we are announcing today will make a real difference to hundreds of communities across the country and the money will allow local solutions to local problems.

He expected the cash to be spent on equipment like mobile police stations and schemes to set up more police bases in shopping centres.

Security cameras, security lighting and so called "private policemen" or neighbourhood wardens could also be recruited.

The home secretary pledged the funds would be "available quickly without a long-winded bidding process".

The package would concentrate on highly addictive class A drugs like heroin and cocaine, added Mr Straw.

Mr McCartney made an impassioned speech in support of today's announcement.

His son Hugh, 23, died after a heroin overdose in September 1999, and Mr McCartney spoke with emotion about the damage caused to families by drugs.

"No longer can we simply leave it to the police. The police need the eyes and ears of the community," he said.

"Drugs weaken and damage and even destroy communities. They certainly weaken and damage families who have lost children to drugs. It's difficult enough having someone in your family die but to lose a child in these circumstances is extremely difficult to cope with.

"It's not just the loss of their life but the loss of the life to come."

Asked whether there was any evidence that such schemes had any effect, Mr McCartney said 28 pilot projects had shown positive results.

Youngsters who are disillusioned, disenfranchised and without role models in life are granted something to aim for, he said.

"It gives them an opportunity to engage with someone locally who they do look up to. Some of these children are really talented but they did not even realise they had any talent."

Among the likely initiatives to receive the funding are police operations that target specific drug problems such as Scotland Yard's current clampdown on crack cocaine houses in London.

Other schemes include mobile police stations in rural areas where there are drug problems and centres of education for former and recovering drugs abusers.

Home Office figures show that the cost of crimes committed to feed addicts' habits each year is £2.5bn and 12,250 suspected offenders are arrested every week who have taken heroin cocaine or crack in the previous 48 hours.

And an independent study estimated that half of criminals entering prison had a serious drugs problem.

Earlier this year the government's drug tsar Keith Hellawell announced every local authority in the country was to appoint a drugs co-ordinater to identify potential problems and local hotspots.

webTitle: Profile of film studio portraitist Cornel Lucas

fields.headline: Rank insider
fields.standfirst: Cornel Lucas's dazzling photographs could do more for a star's image than a movie.  Peter Lennon meets Britain's first film studio portraitist
fields.trailText: Cornel Lucas's dazzling photographs could do more for a star's image than a movie. Peter Lennon meets Britain's first film studio portraitist.
fields.body:
In the early days of film, John Russell Taylor and John Kobal wrote in their book Portraits of the British Cinema, "American stars had faces; British stars had voices." In the 1950s, Cornel Lucas was the first to change that, working with Rank, which at its peak had more than 40 "artistes" under contract. It was Lucas who created the star image of, among others, the young Joan Collins and Diana Dors, and gave manly glamour to Dirk Bogarde, Peter Finch and Trevor Howard.

It was not easy to persuade Rank that Britain should go the American way and employ specialist portraitists, even though Hollywood's photographers had done a better job of immortalising the likes of Greta Garbo, Hedy Lemarr and Marlene Dietrich than their often unreliable films. "The problem for the British," Lucas says, "was that it was too expensive. It required a special studio, assistants and expensive, heavy plate cameras and accessories."

It was Lucas and Dietrich who eventually convinced the studios that an in-house portraitist was worth the investment. Dietrich came to England in 1937 to make Knight Without Armour with Robert Donat. Lucas was told to do a portrait. It did not start off well.

"I was very nervous," he says."While I waited in this big empty studio I put on the radio to keep me company. Suddenly she appeared in the narrow door with a string of assistants - secretary, hair stylist, make-up man, etc - walking in single file behind her. At that moment the radio started playing Colonel Bogey. She marched straight up to the radio and turned it off. 'That won't be necessary, Mr Lucas,' she said frostily. I thought it was a terrible start but she was pleased with the pictures.

"She was adamant that her key light had to be in a certain position. She told me she had discovered the advantages of this '12 o'clock light' one day in Berlin after a show when she slipped out to a photo machine to get a passport photo. She could actually tell from the heat whether the light was right for her. She was a perfect technician."

Lucas started photography at the age of 13. His brother ran a film library and one day he took Lucas with him in the car to pick up prints. "At that moment I saw the director Anthony Asquith and Gloria Swanson walk towards me from a dark alley between two stages. That image of one of the world's greatest actresses and a handsome young director made me decide film portraits was the job for me."

His brother got him a job as a lab technician at Rank. He hated sitting all day in a dark room, supervising the film going into the bins. "One day," he says, "I was taking care of a Jack Buchanan film, Brewster's Millions, and I fell asleep. I was awakened by someone shaking my shoulder and to my terror found myself wrapped in celluloid. A large section of the film was destroyed. I was fired on the spot. But the shop steward said, 'How old are you, son?' 'Sixteen,' I told him. 'You're too young to be on a negative machine,' he said. And I got my job back."

In the war Lucas worked on secret night photography with the RAF experimental photographic group at Farnborough. It was not until the war was over that he got his famous "pool studio" at Pinewood. "They covered over the swimming pool," he recalls. "It was very glamorous, with a fountain and dressing rooms." Settled at Pinewood, he married one of Rank's most glamorous starlets, Belinda Lee. They divorced and she was killed in a car accident aged 26. (He remarried and now has four children.)

When the pool studio was in full swing, every week thousands of prints were sent out around the world. "We had to be very careful with censorship abroad," he said. "In some middle eastern countries, you could not show a belly button and in Italy you could never show the zip at the back of a lady's skirt."

One of the future stars he helped to groom was Joan Collins. He remembers this teenager from the Rank Charm School trying desperately to get the lead in Renato Castellani's Romeo and Juliet (1954). Romeo was the handsome, suave newcomer Laurence Harvey. Juliet eventually went to an unknown "discovery". The film bombed. "Joan was a very sweet girl with a great sense of humour," Lucas says. But she had to wait another 20 years for real stardom in the role of Dynasty's Alexis Carrington.

Did he never think of going to Hollywood? "I did intend emigrating. I got my papers in 1949 and I went to New York, where Paul Hesse, a great glamour photographer of his day, allowed me to sit in on his work. I went to Hollywood too. But I decided not to emigrate." His reason suggests a mentality no longer common in our greedy world. "Everywhere you went you got these bumper steaks. I had just come from a country still on terribly strict rationing. I couldn't face the enormous meals. I found that very offensive."

So in a fit of solidarity he came back to share his country's austerity. It has been good for his figure - as he passes 80, he is as trim and active as the most disciplined of Rank's starlets in training.

 Cornel Lucas's exhibition opens at the Photographer's Gallery, London WC2, on Wednesday. Details: 020-7831 1772.

fields.headline: Sky feels the force
fields.trailText: 2.15pm TV overnights: The UK TV premiere of Star Wars: The Phantom Menace brought in 1.5m viewers for Sky on Saturday night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The UK television premiere of Star Wars: The Phantom Menace brought 1.5m viewers on Saturday night, during a big weekend for BSkyB's pay-TV channels.

The Phantom Menace, the prequel to the three original Star Wars movies, went out on Sky Premiere and Sky Premiere Widescreen between 8pm and 10.15pm on Saturday.

It drew an audience of 1.5m, according to unofficial overnights - an impressive figure for Sky Premiere, and the fourth Saturday night on the trot when a Star Wars movie premiere has topped 1m viewers.

The digitally remastered and reissued versions of the original trilogy began with Star Wars, which had 1m on March 17.

The Empire Strikes Back and Return of the Jedi both pulled in 1.2m on subsequent Saturdays.

Elsewhere, the premiere of Dervla Kirwan drama the Bombmaker helped Sky One to its best Sunday night this year.

The Bombmaker, a two-part thriller about a former IRA operative whose daughter is kidnapped to force her back into action, opened with 0.8m and a 7.8% share of viewing in multi-channel homes.

Overall, Sky One had a 6% share of viewing in multi-channel homes between 6pm and 10.30pm last night.

Yesterday afternoon it was Sky Sports 2's turn to pull in a big audience.

Live FA Cup semi-final action between Arsenal and Tottenham, had 1.6m viewers and a stonking 30% share of the audience in multi-channel homes.

webTitle: John Patterson's weekly look at US movies

fields.headline: Drugs by numbers
fields.standfirst: The rags-to-riches tale of America's Mr Pot puts clothes before character, says  John Patterson with his weekly look at US movies
fields.trailText: The rags-to-riches tale of America's Mr Pot puts clothes before character, says John Patterson with his weekly look at US movies.
fields.body:
Perhaps the first green shoots of spring are finally pushing through. This week I found myself looking forward to most of the new releases instead of dreading them all, even if they did quickly prove inferior to their trailers.

Blow's trailer was a knockout: all fast editing, narcotic excess, Johnny Depp in boss threads, and a soundtrack pulsing with 1960s junkie-rock riffology and 1970s funk grooves. Great, I thought - it'll be like Goodfellas and Boogie Nights. And since Martin Scorsese and Paul Thomas Anderson won't have new movies out for the rest of the year, this'll have to tide me over. But when I finally saw the movie, the scale of director Ted Demme's debt to these two masters was such that it almost capsized the whole movie.

Blow, the rags-to-riches-to-prison-stripes story of George Jung, a pioneering pot and coke dealer in the 1960s, 1970s and early 1980s, seems precisely calculated to appeal to the same largely male demographic that responded to Boogie Nights and Goodfellas. It shares their rainbow-shaped story architecture: bottom to top and right down again. It lets skillfully edited music do its work for it. And it leaves a lot of creative power in the hands of the costume and production design departments.

Like a less gifted version of Scorsese or Anderson, Demme gleefully ransacks Hollywood's technical toy closet, digging out the SteadiCam, splitting his screen, working with a number of film stocks and editing the results at a frenzied pace. To depict 20 years of loudly changing fashions Demme even hired Boogie Nights's costume designer, and his breathless editing is heavily indebted to Scorsese's collaborator, Thelma Schoonmaker-Powell.

All in all, Blow feels like a distinctly third-hand experience. Where Scorsese and Anderson paid meticulous attention to character and moral consequence, Blow is all join-the-dots and colour-by-numbers. Johnny Depp, for all his good taste in projects, has a tendency to languish like a supermodel at the centre of his films, less an actor or a character than an element of the film's design, and here he fails to find the empathy that might earn Jung's story some pathos, or the tragic dimension that Demme is apparently seeking.

The fact that one never really gives a stuff about this man who helped swamp America with cocaine is a major problem. You remember the flares, the disco babes, the Tony Montana-levels of nasal ingestion, some nice work from Paul Ruebens of Pee-Wee's Playhouse, and any number of funny, smart sequences, but Demme's movie never hangs together.

Lee Tamahori, however, is someone whose movies are worth watching. The Edge, which was Jack London by way of screenwriter David Mamet, was an exhilarating snowbound Deliverance, with a rampaging bear taking the place of redneck rapists. It was an odd-sounding experience for everyone involved, but Tamahori made it compelling. The opening sequence of his new movie, Along Came a Spider, has the same sort of headlong energy, as an FBI sting operation goes haywire and ends with an agent hanging over a 500ft dam in an open-topped Mustang. Thereafter, however, the mechanics of the sub-Silence of the Lambs serial-killer genre get the better of Tamahori's sprightly talents.

When Jodie Foster pulled that butterfly pupa out of a victim's throat in Lambs, she - or rather Thomas Harris - spawned a subspecies of murderers apparently raised on the mental gymnastics of grandmaster chess and the Times cryptic crossword. But real serial killers don't build elaborate puzzles for their pursuers to unravel; they frenziedly hack at their inert victims like dogs disinterring bones, and then dump the leftovers. But this film, and The Bone Collector and Kiss The Girls, are reheating ingredients that went stale the third time you saw Silence.

Morgan Freeman reprises the role of Alex Cross, serial-killer profiler and hero of Gary Fleder's Kiss the Girls, in an adaptation of another novel by James Patterson. It's familiar territory: a narcissistic, diabolically clever kidnapper laying a trail of red herrings and smarty-pants clues for Cross and his new partner Monica Potter, both of whom rely far too much on implausible bursts of magical intuition.

Freeman, as always, is a still centre of dependable calm and intelligence, but Potter registers only as another generic blonde. Like its predecessor, which boasted a tag-team of two killer-geniuses, Along Came a Spider comes equipped with a clever 180-degree sting in its tail, but by the time it hits you, you're just worn out by all the dead-ends.

Since I had no plans to endure Pokemon 3: the New Movie, that leaves Just Visiting, a John Hughes-backed remake of the 1991 French time-travel comedy Les Visiteurs. It's about a 12th-century French knight and his rancid, Baldrick-like villain, who are accidentally zapped into present-day Chicago.

Wisely, the remake retains the original's stars, Jean Remo (whose beaky profile comes straight off a medieval coin) and Christian Clavier. It's the kind of project you don't mind seeing remade. Every joke - the astonished pair bathing in the toilet, killing a car ("Look at its eyes of fire!"), or screaming like teenage girls in an elevator - is worth seeing one more time.

fields.headline: 'Sophiegate': what the papers say
fields.standfirst: We round up the papers' verdicts on the Countess of Wessex affair
fields.trailText: We round up the papers' verdicts on the Countess of Wessex affair.
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN
Now she is stepping down as chairman of her company, Ms Rhys-Jones should find plenty of uses for her PR skills in places such as the British Council or the NHS. Alternatively, she could drop her titles, the civil list payments and the Bagshot mansion and make it on her own two feet. Either is an honourable course. It must be increasingly obvious to all at the palace that she can't do both.

DAILY MAIL
It hardly needed the 20/20 vision of hindsight see that Sophie and Edward's work in public relations and television was bound to conflict with their obligations as royals. This is why the decision to quit her job - as this paper had often implored her to do - was essential to any damage-limitation exercise. Prince Edward should also find a new job in a less contentious area. If there is a truly valuable lesson to be taken from this grubby affair, it is that the royal family must instigate its own reforms to see off the republican threat.

THE INDEPENDENT
The countess should not have reacted so defensively to being secretly tape-recorded. Her opinions are nothing to be ashamed of and she should have stuck to them.

THE SUN
It makes our blood boil that Edward and his ambitious missus were sent abroad to represent the people of this country. Charles's gamble is that a downsized monarchy will save the crown. Our guess is that it may - for one generation at the most. After that, all bets are off. This is our country. Why do they have a right to be heads of it?

FINANCIAL TIMES
The best, and least likely, outcome would be that the countess and other sprigs of the royal family decided their careers were worth pursuing and abandonded their public role and privileges. At least their Sunday mornings would then be a lot more relaxing.

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH
Sophie has done the right thing [by resigning]. There is no objection to a member of the royal family earning money, but a job in public relations is likely to involve conflicts of interest which a job in, say, cabinet-making or equestrianism does not.

THE MIRROR
Both Sophie Rhys-Jones and her husband find being royal rather convenient for business reasons. She must stop trading on the connection. He must stop pretending he is an important part of the monarchy. We don't need these pipsqueak royals. Let alone their wives.

DAILY STAR
If Sophie and Edward want careers then that's fine. But they can't expect us to cough up constantly to help out. Sophie should do the decent thing and persuade her definitely-not-gay husband to resign from the Civil List. Now that would really sheikh us all up.

DAILY EXPRESS
Sophie must choose an uncontentious career if she intends to pursue a professional life.

DAILY MAIL It hardly needed the 20/20 vision of hindsight see that Sophie and Edward's work in public relations and television was bound to conflict with their obligations as royals. This is why the decision to quit her job - as this paper had often implored her to do - was essential to any damage-limitation exercise. Prince Edward should also find a new job in a less contentious area. If there is a truly valuable lesson to be taken from this grubby affair, it is that the royal family must instigate its own reforms to see off the republican threat. THE INDEPENDENT The countess should not have reacted so defensively to being secretly tape-recorded. Her opinions are nothing to be ashamed of and she should have stuck to them. THE SUN It makes our blood boil that Edward and his ambitious missus were sent abroad to represent the people of this country. Charles's gamble is that a downsized monarchy will save the crown. Our guess is that it may - for one generation at the most. After that, all bets are off. This is our country. Why do they have a right to be heads of it? FINANCIAL TIMES The best, and least likely, outcome would be that the countess and other sprigs of the royal family decided their careers were worth pursuing and abandonded their public role and privileges. At least their Sunday mornings would then be a lot more relaxing. THE DAILY TELEGRAPH Sophie has done the right thing [by resigning]. There is no objection to a member of the royal family earning money, but a job in public relations is likely to involve conflicts of interest which a job in, say, cabinet-making or equestrianism does not. THE MIRROR Both Sophie Rhys-Jones and her husband find being royal rather convenient for business reasons. She must stop trading on the connection. He must stop pretending he is an important part of the monarchy. We don't need these pipsqueak royals. Let alone their wives. DAILY STAR If Sophie and Edward want careers then that's fine. But they can't expect us to cough up constantly to help out. Sophie should do the decent thing and persuade her definitely-not-gay husband to resign from the Civil List. Now that would really sheikh us all up. DAILY EXPRESS Sophie must choose an uncontentious career if she intends to pursue a professional life. fields.headline: Digital radio Q&A
fields.trailText: What is digital radio? Amy Vickers explains.
fields.body:
What is digital radio?
The nirvana of radio, it is the evolution of analogue radio into crystal clear sound with absolutely no interference. This means the days of crackling reception and confusing, changing frequencies when moving areas are over. Digital radio also means an infinite amount of stations. By the end of 2002, it is expected there will be nearly 310 digital radio stations in the UK.

Why do I need to buy a new radio?
It's the same as upgrading to digital TV in that to receive digital radio a listener needs the right decoder chip and the right equipment. Look out for the letters DAB (digital audio broadcasting) as only receivers that carry this logo are smart enough to decode digital radio signals.

How much does it cost?
At the moment it's expensive, but as with all new technology, prices start high and soon come down. Look at how expensive VHS was when it first hit the market. There are various models of digital radio on the market and the cheapest is around the £300 mark. The GWR announcement today means that within 12 months, the mass market will begin to adopt digital radio.

What radio stations are available on digital?
Some are analogue favourites but digitised to produce clearer sound. Digital radio is perfect for niche programming, such as books, plays, comedy, music genres and children's entertainment.

Will I still be able to record off the radio?
Absolutely. In fact, soon you will be able to pre-programme the radio to save, replay or download specific programmes from a wide range of channels.

What is Digital One?
Digital One operates the UK's only national commercial digital radio network under a renewable 12-year licence from the Radio Authority. Controlled by radio group GWR and cable group NTL, its national network of transmitters cover 78% of the UK population. As more transmitters get switched on over the next few years, that number will grow to 85%.

Who else is offering digital radio?
At the moment it would seem that the MXR consortium (which includes Chrysalis, Capital, Jazz, Ford and Guardian Media Group as shareholders) is cleaning up on the local licences, given that it has won the past four major local licences. Emap is another strong operator with a clutch of local licences, and the BBC automatically gets six national stations.

What's exciting about digital radio?
Aside from the benefits mentioned above, digital radio has an LCD display that allows you to see what track is being played on what radio station, and it may even give you background on the artist, details of their current tour and the box office number to call for tickets.

Will my new car have a digital radio?
Not just yet, but it's not far off. Ford announced last year that from 2004, every new car in the UK would have digital radio as standard. Luxury car manufacturer TVR is the first to fit a digital radio as standard in one of its lines, the Tuscan, and some car manufacturers, such as Fiat, Honda, Mercedes, Alfa Romeo and BMW, said they will offer digital radio as an upgrade option.

Can I listen to digital radio now?
By and large, digital radio is still in development, although a number of broadcasters have already launched services - to the 0.1% of the population that currently has digital radio.

fields.headline: Digital radio becomes accessible
fields.standfirst: Digital radio Q&A
fields.trailText: 11.45am: The price of a digital radio is set to tumble from £300 to £100 within the next 12 months, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The price of a digital radio is to tumble from £300 to £100 within the next 12 months.

This will mean digital radio is now for the first time accessible to most consumers.

National multiplex operator Digital One, controlled by GWR and cable group NTL, today put the finishing touches on a £3m joint venture with Imagination Technologies to produce a cheaper second-generation chip that will slash the price of boxes.

The plan is to cut the price to £99 for a basic radio within the next 12 months and speed up consumer acceptance of the new technology.

At present, only 0.1% of the population has digital radio, despite the fact there are 178 different services running off 35 digital radio services in London and 20 digital multiplexes across the rest of the UK.

"Progress continues on the expansion of transmission areas, with 78% of the population already able to receive digital quality radio," said Ralph Bernard, chief executive of GWR Group,

"The availability of a lower cost and a broader range of digital radios earlier than anticipated should speed the development of the consumer market in digital radio."

Last month all UK digital broadcasters joined together in a pooled Digital Radio Development Board to promote the benefits of digital radio to consumers.

Knocking down the price will go a long way to securing the future of the fledgling industry.

fields.headline: Guinness man to step into Jones's shoes at BBC
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Stephen Dando will join the BBC in early June as head of HR and internal communications, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC has hired the former human resources director of Guinness to take over from Gareth Jones, one of director general Greg Dyke's key lieutenants.

Stephen Dando will join the BBC in early June as head of HR and internal communications.

He will replace Mr Jones, who was brought in by Mr Dyke to lead his "One BBC" restructure of the corporation before quitting in a surprise move last month.

The BBC dismissed claims from some sources that Mr Jones had become frustrated in his role.

The corporation said Mr Jones had never intended to stay more than two years at the BBC.

Mr Dando took a leading role in integrating Guinness and UDV for parent company Diageo. He has also been involved in overhauling Diageo's global HR operation.

"Stephen has an impressive track record of leadership in human resources," said Mr Dyke. "I look forward to working with him."

Mr Dando added: "The BBC is a unique organisation with a wealth of creative talent.

"I look forward to working with new colleagues on the many challenges and opportunities that lie ahead for the corporation."

Related story
Mar 20: BBC loses 'symbol of change' as Jones quits

Scottish Catholics are to be warned by their bishops that taking the morning-after pill, authorised for sale to over-16-year-olds by the government earlier this year, is the equivalent of a 'chemically induced abortion'.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health/story/0,7890,470749,00.html

New rights for mothers choosing to work part-time will be drawn up by an independent commission under plans being considered by Tony Blair.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare/

Dilapidated psychiatric wards are to be modernised in a £30m refurbishment programme that the government has called the 'biggest ever boost' to in-patient mental health care.

webTitle: In brief: Mike Myers' Oscar joke angers technicians

fields.headline: Mike Myers' Oscar joke angers technicians
fields.standfirst: Plus: BBC shells out for Spielberg's Band of Brothers; Spy Kids stays on top in US; Michelle Pfeiffer finds a screen daughter; Lopez and De Niro team up for remake
fields.trailText: Plus: BBC shells out for Spielberg's Band of Brothers; Spy Kids stays on top in US; Michelle Pfeiffer finds a screen daughter; Lopez and De Niro team up for remake
fields.body:
 Mike Myers has infuriated Hollywood's sound technicians with the irreverant comments he made whilst presenting an award at last month's Oscar ceremony. The Austin Powers star introduced the Best Sound and Sound Editing categories by joking: "Now I know you're asking yourself will the winner this year be Chet, Flippy or Tommy Blub-Blub, or perhaps even Chad? We don't know, but what I do know is that what's in this envelope is gonna send shockwaves through the industry." Floods of complaints came in from Hollywood sound technicians who felt that Myers had undermined their profession. Robert Rehme, president of the Academy, has issued an apology, stressing that he: "Will certainly endeavour to see that this doesn't happen again."

 The BBC is splashing out a record £15m for the rights to show Steven Spielberg's new TV war drama Band of Brothers this autumn, according to reports this morning. The series, which is seen as something of a follow-up to Spielberg's Oscar-winning Saving Private Ryan, is co-produced by Spielberg and Tom Hanks. Much of the 10-part series, based on Steven Ambrose's bestseller about the Easy Company, the 506th Regiment of the 101st Airborne Division, was shot on location in the UK.

 Spy Kids has spent its second week on top at the American box office this weekend, taking a further £11.8m. The family oriented caper, starring Antonio Banderas, fought off stiff competition from two new adult movies, the Morgan Freeman thriller Along Came a Spider and the Johnny Depp drug drama Blow.

 After an exhaustive search that included casting calls in eight cities and auditions by a raft of Hollywood's hottest young actresses, relative newcomer Alison Lohman has landed the leading role of Michelle Pfeiffer's daughter in White Oleander. The 21-year-old will play a young woman who stays in a number of foster homes after being separated from her jailbound mother. Robin Wright Penn and Renee Zellweger are on board to play the foster mothers and Patrick Fugit, last seen as the young Rolling Stone journalist in Cameron Crowe's Almost Famous, has also signed up to play an orphan. Adapted from Janet Fitch's bestseller and directed by Peter Kosminsky, the film is due to go into production on April 23.

 Jennifer Lopez and Robert De Niro are rumoured to be in negotiations to star in a remake of the 1955 Doris Day/James Cagney musical Love Me or Leave Me. According to the the Hollywood Reporter, the 29-year-old singer/actress will take the role of a singer discovered by a Chicago racketeer (to be played by De Niro) who uses his showbiz connections to help her career. No start date has been set for the project as both actors have prior commitments. De Niro has signed up for a sequel to the hugely successful Meet the Parents and Lopez is finishing off the police drama, Angel Eyes.

fields.headline: Captain Paul Bootherstone
fields.standfirst: Frigate commander whose skill saved 225 men
fields.trailText: Frigate commander whose skill saved 225 men.
fields.body:
After 26 years in the Royal Navy, Captain Paul Bootherstone, who has died of a heart attack aged 62, faced the supreme test of his career in the Falklands war of 1982. He won the Distinguished Service Cross as commander of HMS Arrow, the frigate that rescued the crew of the doomed destroyer Sheffield.

Both ships were in the first wave of the 27-warship task force sent to the south Atlantic after the Argentine invasion on April 2. Arrow was one of an eventual total of 10 escorts with the carrier task group formed to seize control - with alarmingly slender resources - of the 200-mile exclusion zone around the islands.

The frigate fired the first shot in a bombardment of Port Stanley airfield on May 1. Arrow was also the first British ship to be hit by the daring Argentine pilots who, flying at the very limit of their range, constituted the main threat to the expedition. One sailor was wounded and the ship lightly damaged.

The bizarre conflict passed the diplomatic point of no return the next day, when the nuclear attack submarine HMS Conqueror sank the old cruiser General Belgrano outside the zone, with the loss of more than 350 men. On May 4, determined to exact revenge, the Argentine navy sent two Super-Etendard bombers against part of the task force commander Rear-Admiral Sandy Woodward's screen. These were the type 21 frigates, Arrow and Yarmouth, and type 42 destroyer Sheffield, patrolling between 40 and 70 miles south of Stanley and helping to cover the aircraft carriers Hermes and Invincible a further 40 miles out.

Each French-built Super-Etendard carried one Exocet missile. Both targeted the anti-aircraft ship Sheffield. One missed, while the other penetrated the hull without detonating its warhead. But the explosion of the missile's residual fuel was enough to set off a fire which raged through the Sheffield's hull.

Yarmouth helped to fight the blaze from starboard while the Arrow took up position on the port side. Several other ships came up in support. The battle lasted for many hours as a huge pall of black smoke formed the destroyer's funeral pyre.

With the flames drawing nearer to the magazines, the Sheffield's captain, Sam Salt, decided to abandon ship. HMS Arrow could easily have been damaged or even sunk by an ammunition explosion, but Bootherstone lifted 225 of the 266 survivors by skilful manoeuvring to enable them to jump the gap between the two bows; only 20 men were killed and 24 wounded.

Six days later, on May 10, Arrow sailed in support of her sister Alacrity in a northward sweep up the sound between East and West Falkland and was fired upon by the modern, German-built submarine San Luis, whose torpedo smashed Arrow's towed decoy. The strains of service in the stormy South Atlantic added to Bootherstone's woes, exposing serious design and construction faults including hull cracks and many mechanical problems. These brought out other key attributes in the accomplished sailor - the gifts of sustaining morale and keeping calm in a crisis.

Born in Blackpool and educated at Blackpool grammar school (1949-54), Bootherstone joined the service as an 18-year-old cadet in 1956. After early service on minesweepers, he turned to flying, qualifying in 1961 and serving on Hermes and elsewhere in Gannets, the navy's last fixed-wing airborne early-warning aircraft (hastily adapted helicopters had to perform this vital service as best they could in the Falklands). In the same year he married Janet Ferris; they had two girls and two boys.

His flying skills led to stints as an instructor and an exchange with the United States Navy. He confirmed his versatility in 1968 in his first seagoing command, a minesweeper. After training appointments he served as executive officer of a frigate before an air staff job in Whitehall in 1977. He played an important role in the navy's readaptation to fixed-wing aviation when the Sea Harrier came into service and pilots had to turn to the RAF for retraining.

Promoted to captain in 1983, Bootherstone left the Arrow for the staff of the Fleet Air Arm until 1985, when he got his third ship, the destroyer Battleaxe. His final three years of active service were spent in Canada, first at the National Defence College and then at the British High Commission in Ottawa. On retirement in 1992 he took up charity work.

He is survived by his wife, two sons and two daughters.

· Captain Paul Jeffrey Bootherstone, sailor, born May 7 1938; died March 1 2001

On May 4, determined to exact revenge, the Argentine navy sent two Super-Etendard bombers against part of the task force commander Rear-Admiral Sandy Woodward's screen. These were the type 21 frigates, Arrow and Yarmouth, and type 42 destroyer Sheffield, patrolling between 40 and 70 miles south of Stanley and helping to cover the aircraft carriers Hermes and Invincible a further 40 miles out. Each French-built Super-Etendard carried one Exocet missile. Both targeted the anti-aircraft ship Sheffield. One missed, while the other penetrated the hull without detonating its warhead. But the explosion of the missile's residual fuel was enough to set off a fire which raged through the Sheffield's hull. Yarmouth helped to fight the blaze from starboard while the Arrow took up position on the port side. Several other ships came up in support. The battle lasted for many hours as a huge pall of black smoke formed the destroyer's funeral pyre. With the flames drawing nearer to the magazines, the Sheffield's captain, Sam Salt, decided to abandon ship. HMS Arrow could easily have been damaged or even sunk by an ammunition explosion, but Bootherstone lifted 225 of the 266 survivors by skilful manoeuvring to enable them to jump the gap between the two bows; only 20 men were killed and 24 wounded. Six days later, on May 10, Arrow sailed in support of her sister Alacrity in a northward sweep up the sound between East and West Falkland and was fired upon by the modern, German-built submarine San Luis, whose torpedo smashed Arrow's towed decoy. The strains of service in the stormy South Atlantic added to Bootherstone's woes, exposing serious design and construction faults including hull cracks and many mechanical problems. These brought out other key attributes in the accomplished sailor - the gifts of sustaining morale and keeping calm in a crisis. Born in Blackpool and educated at Blackpool grammar school (1949-54), Bootherstone joined the service as an 18-year-old cadet in 1956. After early service on minesweepers, he turned to flying, qualifying in 1961 and serving on Hermes and elsewhere in Gannets, the navy's last fixed-wing airborne early-warning aircraft (hastily adapted helicopters had to perform this vital service as best they could in the Falklands). In the same year he married Janet Ferris; they had two girls and two boys. His flying skills led to stints as an instructor and an exchange with the United States Navy. He confirmed his versatility in 1968 in his first seagoing command, a minesweeper. After training appointments he served as executive officer of a frigate before an air staff job in Whitehall in 1977. He played an important role in the navy's readaptation to fixed-wing aviation when the Sea Harrier came into service and pilots had to turn to the RAF for retraining. Promoted to captain in 1983, Bootherstone left the Arrow for the staff of the Fleet Air Arm until 1985, when he got his third ship, the destroyer Battleaxe. His final three years of active service were spent in Canada, first at the National Defence College and then at the British High Commission in Ottawa. On retirement in 1992 he took up charity work. He is survived by his wife, two sons and two daughters. · Captain Paul Jeffrey Bootherstone, sailor, born May 7 1938; died March 1 2001

fields.headline: Tiger Woods
fields.standfirst: Tiger Woods has just pulled off what some say is a golfing grand slam. Here' s our guide to the best websites on the golfing great
fields.trailText: Tiger Woods has just pulled off what some say is a golfing grand slam. Here' s our guide to the best websites on the golfing great.
fields.body:
1. Tiger Woods was yesterday (and is most probably today) celebrating an achievement which, in his own words, is one that "may come to be regarded as one of the top moments in our sport."

2. The sport is, of course, golf and Woods can now claim to be its master.

3. At the age of 25, he holds the US Open, the Open, the US PGA and the Masters, which, some say, is the golfing equivalent of a grand slam.

4. And, with yesterday's win at Augusta, Woods got to wear the Masters' green jacket for the second time.

5. He turned professional in 1996. Victory in the 1997 Masters led him to be hailed as golf's first black champion, though Woods himself preferred "Cablinasian" - a word combining his Caucasian, black, Indian (native American) and Asian roots.

6. Before that, he was a child prodigy. Aged two, Woods putted against Bob Hope, shot 48 for nine holes aged three and appeared in golf digest at five.

7. A lucrative sponsorship deal with Nike did not, however, spread the image of his face across the world. Instead, a television advert showed Nike-clad children declaring: "I'm Tiger Woods."

8. But his real name is Eldrick.

9. His father nicknamed him so after his Vietnamese soldier friend, Vuong Dang Phong, who went by the name of Tiger.

10. Woods senior hoped his son would become famous and that Mr Phong would see the name and get in touch.

webTitle: Letter from Nick Brown to farmers

fields.headline: Letter from Nick Brown to farmers
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth

Full text of a letter from the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, to all farmers affected by the foot and mouth epidemic
fields.trailText: The traumatic events of the past few weeks have put great pressure on everybody within the industry and have evoked great sympathy throughout the country.
fields.body:
The traumatic events of the past few weeks have put great pressure on everybody within the industry and have evoked great sympathy throughout the country.

I appreciate that some of you will have suffered the terrible consequences of an outbreak on your farms. Others will be waiting anxiously as we fight the disease.

I assure you that we are doing everything within our power to get the industry back to normal as quickly as possible. This will still be a long haul.

Origins and Disease Spread

It is likely that the outbreak originated at a pig farm at Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland.

The subsequent spread of infection is traceable to some extent. Virus from the source farm spread to seven other farms in Tyne and Wear. Sheep from one of these farms were sent to Hexham market on 13 February. Sheep from the 13 February market at Hexham were sent to markets at Longtown and were further dispersed between 14-24 February.

Within days, before any suspicion of the disease had been reported, infected sheep were criss-crossing the country in hundreds of separate movements, putting them into contact with other livestock.

The 1967 outbreak was very different. It mainly affected pigs and cattle. But this outbreak quickly spread to sheep, which made the course of the infection more difficult to trace. The strain of the virus we are currently dealing with does not manifest itself clearly in sheep - even apparently healthy animals may be disease carriers.

The course of the disease has shown how critical animal movements can be to the spread of FMD. It is obviously essential that everyone observes the very tight restrictions which we have had to place on animal movements in the interests of controlling disease. And if you fail to comply with licensing requirements you could be subject to prosecution and penalties.

Taking account of what we have learned from this outbreak, the government is consulting on proposals to ban the feeding of swill to pigs, and to introduce limitations on the movements of cattle, sheep and goats.

Strategy

Our strategy remains focused on three key priorities:

Firstly, all animals on infected farms - cattle, sheep and pigs - are to be slaughtered within 24 hours of the infection report.

Secondly, all animals on contiguous premises (i.e. all farms neighbouring an infected premises) are then to be slaughtered within 48 hours.

Thirdly, in the heavily infected area of Cumbria we are seeking to remove all sheep and pigs within 3km of infected premises. We are concentrating our efforts on clearing all animals identified for slaughter in the Solway area, and on the southern edge of the infected zone as well as on culling all animals which may have been exposed to the disease.

We need your co operation if the strategy is to succeed.

We are devoting massive resources to fighting the disease, including full use of the Army's resources and a new network of regional operations directors. There are now over 1500 soldiers working on disease control: at Great Orton, a burial pit the size of 64 football pitches was dug and in use within three days. We also have over 1500 vets in the front line - compared with the normal 220.

The advice of independent scientists, led by the government's Chief Scientific Adviser, suggests that while it is too early to make firm predictions the signs are encouraging. It is particularly important to ensure that slaughtering on contiguous premises is accomplished within 48 hours.

Vaccination

We have carefully considered the possibility of using vaccination to help damp down the disease and protect cattle in the heavily infected areas of Cumbria. We were particularly concerned that turning out cattle during the next few weeks would leave them open to infection particularly if they mixed with sheep.

Discussions with the NFU and other farmer's representatives, however, suggested that this could be managed by keeping cattle housed longer and ensuring that they do not graze with sheep. I enclose urgent guidance on how to prevent the spread of the disease from sheep to cattle. This advice has been produced in partnership with the British Cattle Veterinary Association, The Sheep Veterinary Society, the National Sheep Association, and the National Farmers Union. The government intends to publish separate advice for the general public about how FMD is spread, likely to appear in the next few days.

The government has not ruled out vaccination but it is not an easy option.

Compensation

The government is committed to supporting the farming industry. Since 1997, this government has injected some £1.2bn into the agriculture industry on top of the £3bn annual CAP payments, and paid £786m agrimonetary compensation.

We have also done a great deal to help farmers financially during this crisis . This includes full compensation for animals slaughtered on disease grounds estimated to be worth £200m to producers so far. I enclose a summary of the position for payment of agrimonetary compensation - which is worth, for example, £2750 to the average dairy farmer.

In addition, we have opened the Livestock Welfare Disposal Scheme as a last resort for livestock farmers whose animals face welfare difficulties as a result of FMD-related movement restrictions. The scheme provides for the removal and disposal of animals, with a generous scale of compensation payments.

We also intend to make full use of CAP subsidy entitlements under EU rules on force majeure. Where animals have been slaughtered compulsorily because they are infected, are dangerous contacts or are part of a cull of animals which may have been exposed to the disease, subsidies validly claimed before 22 February will be paid in full. There may be other cases where force majeure may apply if producers have been unable to comply with CAP rules and you should notify your RSC in writing within ten days. We will be writing to all livestock producers shortly with more detailed information.

We are also streamlining the valuation of animals by giving farmers the option of payment at a standard rate tariff or an individual valuation without affecting their right of appeal against valuation - even when the animal has been culled.

We are doing everything within our power to deploy enough resources to meet the unprecedented demands on the Ministry's staff and ensure that these payments are paid as promptly as possible.

Alternative land use

Farmers on infected premises, whose stock has been slaughtered, regularly ask whether their land can be put to an alternative use - such as the growing of crops. In theory there is no reason why this can't take place. I recognise that the movement restrictions imposed on infected premises may make things difficult - particularly if contractors have to be brought in to take work forward. As we move towards lifting the restrictions on infected premises following disinfection this might become easier.

Helplines

We do understand the anguish that this disease is causing. This can result stress or business and financial difficulties. A range of organisation can provide help and support. I have attached to this letter a comprehensive list of national support helplines together with some useful local contact numbers.

Agrimonetary compensation

The £156m in optional agrimonetary compensation is split between the sectors as follows:

Beef: £57m Sheep: £20m Dairy: £79m

On average it is worth some £2,750 to the average dairy farmer, £650 to sheep farmers, £650 to suckler cow premium claimants and £450 to beef special premium claimants. We will be paying this money as quickly as we can under the EU rules. The Intervention Board are writing to all eligible producers with the payment dates for dairy agrimonetary compensation. For beef and sheep producers we will start payments on the following basis:

Beef - compensation for market support equals £33m and will be paid from April 2001, to recipients of 2000 beef scheme payments.

Beef - compensation for direct aid equals £15m and will be paid from October 2001, to recipients of 2000 beef scheme payments.

Beef - compensation for direct aid equals £9m and payments will be paid with 2001 scheme payments, which begin in the Autumn of 2001.

Sheep - compensation for direct aid equals £15m and will be paid from mid-April 2001, to recipients of 1999 scheme payments

Sheep - compensation for direct aid equals £5m and will be paid from mid-April 2001, to recipients of 2000 scheme payments

We are doing our best to get this money to you as soon as possible.

fields.headline: Client dumps Sophie's PR firm
fields.standfirst: Exclusive
fields.trailText: 11.30am update: The Countess of Wessex has lost her first client in the wake of the 'Sophie tapes' scandal, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Countess of Wessex has lost her first client in the wake of the "Sophie tapes" scandal.

A Thai luxury hotel chain has dumped her PR firm, branding as "unprofessional" and "disappointing" her partner's claims that it could stage discreet gay sex parties for the fake sheikh.

Sophie Wessex's business partner, Murray Harkin, told an undercover News of the World reporter he could call the Banyan Tree in Phuket to get a "discreet villa" for gay sex between young boys and the Sheikh, who had hinted he was gay.

Today the Banyan Tree said it was furious with the claims and said the countess's PR firm had grossly exaggerated its claims that it was a client.

"We were surprised and disappointed by the unprofessional conduct of R-JH," said Reene Ho-Phang, director of marketing communications for the Thailand-based company.

"We believe those who know our company will realise that Mr Harkin's comments are completely unfounded. But we are frequented by many celebrities and important people and we are concerned about the effect this might have," she added.

The Banyan Tree is one of Asia's most prestigious hotel groups, charging up to £1,500 a night for a poolside villa.

Last year Prince Andrew entertained friends there on the golf course.

Ms Ho-Phang said the Banyan Tree group had not signed an official contract with R-JH, but had been in direct negotiations with the Countess for the past month about using her agency.

Incredibly, though, the Banyan Tree already appears at the top of R-JH's client list. The PR company's website boasts it has been hired to "raise consumer awareness of the Banyan Tree brand (Asia's leading resort) in the UK".

And comments made by Mr Harkin to the undercover reporter imply a much closer relationship with the hotel group than actually existed.

Asked for advice about visiting Thailand, Mr Harkin asks: "Do you want me to talk to the Banyan Tree, if you're going to Phuket? I can say to them that I want these people to be looked after."

Later, asked whether Phuket is the best place to go, he says: "If you want young boys go to Phuket."

Asked whether he knows of any houses that could be hired for the purpose, Mr Harkin says: "That would be much better. In fact, I can ask the Banyan Tree, 'Could you recommend me, I need a very discreet villa'."

Ms Ho-Phang said she had written personally to the Countess of Wessex asking her to explain her actions. The Banyan Tree group is now talking to other UK PR agencies about its business.

The company is keen to raise its profile in this country, although the publicity it has received over the past few days will hardly have been what it had in mind when it decided to hire a PR agency.

webTitle: Bruce's phone call, and Fergie's Ruud call

fields.headline: Bruce's phone call, and Fergie's Ruud call
fields.trailText: NEARLY AS MANY GOALS AS TINNIES
fields.body:
NEARLY AS MANY GOALS AS TINNIES

G'day Pommies. It's Bruce Fiver here, from your favourite ex-penal colony. I've just done over a phone box and I've got a free five minutes to gloat about our sporting prowess. Here's a teaser for you. Which team featuring a Chinese restaurant robber playing on a pitch just next door to Russell Crowe's farm set a new record for an international victory today? That's right cobbers, it's the new record breakers of world football, Australia (Fifa world ranking 75)! We trounced Tonga (Fifa world ranking 185) 22-0 at Coffs Harbour - that's about five hours in the Ute up from Summer Bay by the way.

As you might expect, our six-goal hero was Coventry striker John Aloisi, who bamboozled a 10-0-0 Tongan formation before being substituted after an unforgivable 14-minute goal drought! Not being John Hartson's understudy was obviously a weight off his mind. Who needs to call up world class players such as Harry Kewell, Mark Viduka and Danny Tiatto when you've got Wandering Kevin Muscat chipping in with five goals? Tinnies on the Wolves man tonight!

But most of all, hail Con Boutsianis!!! In the driving seat in the second half, the Socceroos sent on the aptly-named South Melbourne midfielder who was fined $7,000 last week for being the getaway driver in a faked robbery of a Chinese restaurant (netting Con $300 from the insurance payout). With that sort of creativity in the engine room, watch out for another record-breaking Australian victory against America Samoa (Fifa world ranking 203) on Wednesday night. Anything less would be crimin... Gawd, here's the police... [click, brrr]

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We can't celebrate. We are having to live like monks at the moment." - Poor put-upon Gerard Houllier can't get anyone to drink his champagne or pull his party popper.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

VAN DRIVER

Anyway, the Imperial Lord Ferg fancies Ruud van Nistelrooy. He fancies him so much that he even went to Holland to see him. But Ferg won't speak to Ruud, and Ruud won't speak to Ferg either, and the only person who will speak is PSV coach Eric Gerets and that's because he's got a congenital chat defect. Honestly, it's like hanging around with a bunch of 13 year-old girls. Not that the Fiver's been doing that recently (school usually finishes at 3.20, just when we're doing the TV bit).

Ferg watched his favourite Dutch crock in PSV's 1-0 defeat of Ajax at the weekend. "I just went over see the game, it's as simple as that," he said, "and I didn't speak to anyone." So unlike Ferg that. And at the same time as Ferg was playing down any move, Ruud was being similarly coy. "Before anything happens I have to show myself, PSV and the fans that I'm there again," he said, the word "there" presumably not referring to writhing around on the floor in agony. "If and when United think I'm good enough, they can come and talk to PSV."

So with Ferg trying to talk the price down, and Ruud doing his best not to offend anybody, it was left to Eric Gerets to try and stir up a bit of business. "If Ruud stays with us for next season I will be as happy as a young lad of 12," said Gerets of his star striker today, strangely equating happiness with the development of pubic hair. "But if he has to go away I hope there will be a solution in two to three weeks because otherwise it will be difficult for me as coach of PSV." Yeah, yeah. Difficult to squeeze £10m in your pocket, perhaps.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Reports suggest that Middlesbrough have beaten off competition from Sunderland and Internazionale to sign Slovakian striker Slizard Nemeth. The Inter Bratislava player is expected to join Boro in the summer.

Bari midfielder Daniel Andersson has been linked with a summer move to Liverpool. The highly-rated 23-year-old is worth around £8m and told the press in his native Sweden: "Liverpool are one of the finest clubs in Europe. To be linked with them is flattering."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe has held preliminary discussions with the Premier League with a view to making an official protest against Tottenham for allegedly poaching Glenn Hoddle. Lowe said: "We are seriously looking at making a complaint but I want to discuss it with the board first of all. Those discussions will be informal and not the subject of a regular board meeting. We have to put together a timetable of events and the reasons why we think they have broken the code of conduct. Then we will take it from there."

Referee Steve Dunn will officiate in next month's FA Cup final between Arsenal and Liverpool.

Celtic will be presented with the Scottish Premier League trophy at their next home game against Hearts on Sunday 22 April.

Dundee United duo Charlie Miller and Paul Robinson are expected to be fit for next Sunday's Scottish Cup semi-final with Celtic.

fields.headline: Sophie's partner fights for survival
fields.standfirst: IPR code of conduct
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Murray Harkin's career hangs in the balance as an investigation is launched into his professional conduct, writes Julia Day.
IPR code of conduct
fields.body:
Murray Harkin's career hangs in the balance this morning as an investigation is launched into his professional conduct is launched.

The Institute of Public Relations, the trade body of which Mr Harkin and Sophie Wessex are members, is to investigate whether his conduct could contravene its code of conduct.

Members of the IPR agree to adhere to a strict code that includes a promise to "maintain the highest standards of professional endeavour, integrity, confidentiality, financial propriety and personal conduct".

The IPR is writing to Mr Harkin to ask him to explain his behaviour, but does not believe Sophie has contravened the code.

But if the IPR receives a complaint about the conduct of either Mr Harkin or the countess, a complaints procedure will be put place that could result in disciplinary measures or even expulsion.

A complaint can be made by anyone.

Expulsion from the IPR could be potentially devastating to the pair's careers. PR executives do not have to belong to the IPR, but membership allows clients to make sure codes of conduct and standards of practice are adhered to.

IPR president Ian Wright believes Mr Harkin's actions may elicit a complaint.

"I think the allegations about Harkin and R-JH are more of a matter of concern than Sophie's conduct. There could be a professional practice complaint," he said.

"Expulsion is a very rarely used sanction, but if you are thrown out of the IPR it is a very serious blow to your credibility.

"We have to strike a balance between upholding the interests of the PR industry and protecting our members," said Mr Wright.

He considers the weekend's revelations about R-JH's activities, and the types of services Mr Harkin appears to offer, including gay parties, are damaging to the PR industry.

"The kind of PR services offered by R-JH are not comparable to those offered by the mass of our members."

Mr Harkin has already resigned as managing director of R-JH.

fields.headline: Straw launches £220m local drugs initiatives
fields.standfirst: Special report: Drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The government today fired its latest salvo in the war against drugs with a £220m fund aimed at creating a network of regional partnerships to help fight drug related crime.
fields.body:
The government today fired its latest salvo in the war against drugs with a £220m fund aimed at creating a network of regional partnerships to help fight drug related crime.

The scheme - the money for which was first announced in the chancellor's budget last month - will see 376 local initiatives funded over the next three years as part of the government's "communities against drugs" campaign.

Manchester United star Andy Cole and manager Sir Alex Ferguson will today pledge their support for the scheme at a meeting with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the cabinet office minister, Ian McCartney, in Manchester.

Mr Straw said: "The funding that we are announcing today will make a real difference to hundreds of communities across the country and the money will allow local solutions to local problems.

He expected the cash to be spent on equipment like mobile police stations and schemes to set up more police bases in shopping centres.

Security cameras, security lighting and so called "private policemen" or neighbourhood wardens could also be recruited.

The home secretary pledged the funds would be "available quickly without a long-winded bidding process."

The package would concentrate on highly addictive class A drugs like heroin and cocaine, added Mr Straw.

Mr McCartney made an impassioned speech in support of today's announcement.

His son Hugh, 23, died after a heroin overdose in September 1999, and Mr McCartney spoke with emotion about the damage caused to families by drugs.

"No longer can we simply leave it to the police. The police need the eyes and ears of the community," he said.

"Drugs weaken and damage and even destroy communities. They certainly weaken and damage families who have lost children to drugs. It's difficult enough having someone in your family die but to lose a child in these circumstances is extremely difficult to cope with.

"It's not just the loss of their life but the loss of the life to come."

He gave his backing to the sporting projects which will attempt to draw young people away from a life of crime and drug abuse by encouraging them to take part in sporting and education projects.

Asked whether there was any evidence that such schemes had any effect, Mr McCartney said 28 pilot projects had shown positive results.

Youngsters who are disillusioned, disenfranchised and without role models in life are granted something to aim for, he said.

"It gives them an opportunity to engage with someone locally who they do look up to. Some of these children are really talented but they did not even realise they had any talent."

Among the likely initiatives to receive the funding are police operations that target specific drug problems such as Scotland Yard's current clampdown on crack cocaine houses in London.

Other schemes include mobile police stations in rural areas where there are drug problems and centres of education for former and recovering drugs abusers.

Home Office figures show that the cost of crimes committed to feed addicts' habits each year is £2.5bn and 12,250 suspected offenders are arrested every week who have taken heroin cocaine or crack in the previous 48 hours.

And an independent study estimated that half of criminals entering prison had a serious drugs problem.

Earlier this year the government's drug tsar Keith Hellawell announced every local authority in the country was to appoint a drugs co-ordinater to identify potential problems and local hotspots.

webTitle: Scotland could turn PFI on its head

fields.headline: Scotland could turn PFI on its head
fields.standfirst: If the unions and the SNP join forces on an overhaul of the private finance initiative, big changes could be on the way
fields.trailText: Mark Irvine: If the Scottish unions and the SNP join forces on an overhaul of the private finance initiative, big changes could be on the way.
fields.body:
As unions meet today for the Scottish TUC annual congress, it will be interesting to see whether they back the Scottish national party (SNP) in demanding big changes to the private finance initiative (PFI).

PFI is a rare thing in modern politics: a subject that can stir the blood and rouse debate. First introduced by the Tories in 1992, PFI turned traditional public spending on its head. Instead of government borrowing directly to finance public investment (in roads, bridges, schools and hospitals) responsibility is transferred to the private sector.

In Scotland, as elsewhere, Labour learned to love PFI. Party leaders knew the 1997 general election was in the bag and wanted to distance themselves from the angry rhetoric of opposition. The Scottish people wanted their kids taught in decent schools; their loved ones cared for in modern hospitals. So Labour switched to a pragmatic policy of "what matters is what works". PFI was here to stay after all, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, became a devoted fan. In a classic New Labour touch, PFI was rebranded as PPP (private-public partnership).

Trade unions should be an obvious opponent to PFI. But they are hamstrung because many of their senior people are influential Labour party members. As Scotland slowly embraces a new politics, the unions remain a deeply conservative force where Labour interests are more important than those of ordinary members. The SNP is breathing down Labour's neck in Scotland, challenging its dominance as never before. As the official opposition, the SNP is a credible party of government at Holyrood. More significantly, it is finding the confidence to take the fight on policy into enemy-held territory, as Margaret Thatcher did in the 1970s, Tony Blair following her example 20 years later.

The SNP is seeking allies in the PFI debate - and could look to the Scottish TUC. A strategic single-issue alliance with the unions is an obvious way forward. But we'll have to see if the top trade unionists can put their member's interests before their party loyalties.

PFI is certainly becoming an issue again as the next general election approaches. The SNP has launched a plan to create a new Scottish trust for public investment. The party believes this is the best of both worlds: an investment trust will, they say, achieve better value for money than PFI/PPP by squeezing borrowing rates, but spending will stay off the public sector balance sheet. Using trusts to get round the UK's antiquated public spending rules is nothing new. What is different is the suggestion that a body should be created with the expertise and leadership required to build Scotland a world-class infrastructure.

Potentially, the advantage of the SNP scheme is that it provides cheaper finance. A Scottish-wide trust would enjoy a real competitive advantage because of its sheer size and its quasi government role.

"Current budget commitments in Scotland amount to £7bn, a figure that will increase exponentially as new PFI/PPP deals are signed," according to Andrew Wilson, SNP finance spokesman. "Our proposal could save up to £240m for every £1bn invested over a contract period of 30 years. The key issue is to get a better deal for the taxpayer, service providers could be from the public private or voluntary sectors."

London mayor Ken Livingstone is also unwilling to use an unreconstructed PFI/PPP as the vehicle for modernising London's underground system. The mayor's secret weapon has been his non-ideological campaign; recruiting Bob Kiley (saviour of New York's underground) was a stroke of genius.

The government has conceded big changes about management of the new system. A year ago, government ministers said it was impossible to change the rules of PFI/PPP. If the risk transferred to the private sector, management of the London Underground could not remain in public hands. Now John Prescott is eating his words.

Back in Scotland, we'll have to see which way the STUC swings. But even if it refuses to join the SNP in a single issue campaign, there's hope. Holyrood's finance committee is mounting an inquiry into PFI/PPP. An even-handed, cross party examination of the issue is exactly what's required.

webTitle: The CV to make a local government recruiter's heart sink

fields.headline: The CV to make a local government recruiter's heart sink
fields.standfirst: Finding the right person for that council vacancy may be difficult. But some candidates should always be rejected out of hand. Lorraine Langham uncovers the local government CV every personnel manager dreads
fields.trailText: Finding the right person for that council vacancy may be difficult. But some candidates should always be rejected out of hand. Lorraine Langham uncovers the local government CV every personnel manager dreads.
fields.body:
Recruiting staff is probably one of the most important acts any manager routinely undertakes. A wrong decision can lead to devastating consequences for individuals and organisations. Judgments made in a few hours of selection, testing and interviewing can take an eternity to undo. At worst they can end in industrial tribunals and expensive out of court settlements. We've all seen it happen.

It is true to say that everyone should be forgiven the occasional "blip" on their curriculum vitae. The most astute can sometimes find themselves in situations beyond their control.

To err may be human, but if it happens more than once, questions have to be asked. After all would you really want to employ someone who constantly courts disaster, and whose sorry tale of bad luck follows them like a sunset shadow?

I'd pick the lucky guy every time.

Curriculum vitae: Francis Arthur Kenneth Ellis, divorced, age 45

Educated: Hackney Downs, four O-levels

Degree: The University of Life

I started work as a sales and marketing assistant for Betamax videos where I was involved in developing their international brand reputation and sales strategy, in competition with VHS.

At the same time, I was putting my undoubted commitment to local government into action by standing for election as a Labour councillor for Hackney. Unfortunately I wasn't successful on this occasion.

In 1980 I was selected as a councillor for Lambeth and gave up work to fully commit to my responsibilities on the finance committee. The rest is history.

After four years as a leading London councillor I moved to Liverpool, where I started a local taxi company. This followed a temporary contract as employee and industrial relations adviser to the city council, during which time I assisted in devising and implementing a corporate termination and reengagement policy (under the leadership of renowned radio broadcaster Derek Hatton).

I then formed a business alliance with my good friend Clive Sinclair to develop the ground breaking C5 car. This design was very influential in the development of BMW's recently released, highly popular two-wheel concept bike, and opened up the market for a massive expansion in the sale of motor scooters to young style leaders.

After achieving my certificate in media studies at the University of the Fourth Age, I became an after dinner speech-writer.

I was immediately employed by an international jewellery company, travelling and working for Mr Gerald Ratner. During this period, my work massively increased his reputation and made him a household name. I understand he is soon to make a star appearance on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.

I was then head hunted by Doncaster council, where I worked developing standards in public life. This leading edge work preceded the Nolan report and I like to think that I contributed to shaping his national recommendations.

Indeed I was responsible for both developing Doncaster's integrity policy and monitoring its effectiveness.

Following the break up of my marriage, I spent a short spell travelling and studying, including six months in an Indian ashram. Developing a new spiritual approach to life has undoubtedly provided work as well as personal benefits.

I returned to my policy roots in the late 1990s giving freelance advice to Bristol's Labour leadership on their budget consultation. This led to the most high profile public vote on the level of council tax ever, securing unprecedented national media coverage and a pioneering reduction in the schools budget.

I am currently working as a freelance consultant public relations adviser. My clients include the Ministry for Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and a former minister and MP for Hartlepool. However, I would welcome the chance to return to local government and believe that I have a positive contribution to make to its future.
