fields.headline: Past notes
fields.trailText: Anniversary of the week: safety pin patented.
fields.body:
Anniversary of the week: safety pin patented. Pins have been holding clothes together since the Bronze Age. Unfortunately, they have also been coming undone and inflicting flesh wounds. A development in 1842 involved the introduction of a tiny sheath to protect the flesh from the point of the pin. Finally, Walter Hunt of New York licked the problem with his "dress pin", which he patented on April 10 1849.

Hunt's inventions ranged from an early repeating rifle to a sewing machine. He didn't mind people using the gun, but he never patented the sewing machine as he thought it would put little seamstresses out of business.

This was not shrewd business practice and, naturally enough, Hunt ran up debts to the draughtsman who illustrated his designs. A deal was worked out. The draughtsman agreed to write off Hunt's debt and give him $400 - in return for an old piece of wire. The inventor would hand over the rights for whatever he could devise from it.

Hunt fiddled for three hours and came up with a safety pin, kept in place by its built-in spring. The rest - nappies, punk, Liz Hurley's dress - is haberdashery.

webTitle: Los indios de México reclaman sus derechos

fields.headline: Los indios de México reclaman sus derechos
fields.standfirst: For two weeks members of the Zapatista guerrilla group and Mexico's poverty-stricken indigenous communities have run a political campaign to defend their rights and autonomy within the country. How much do young people support their cause? Eulàlia Furriol finds out
fields.trailText: For two weeks members of the Zapatista guerrilla group and Mexico's poverty-stricken indigenous communities have run a political campaign to defend their rights and autonomy within the country. How much do young people support their cause? Eulàlia Furriol finds out
fields.body:
Guerrilleros del Ejército Zapatista de Liberación Nacional (EZLN) y representantes de las comunidades indias de México luchan, desde hace cinco siglos, por los derechos de los indígenas. El mes pasado más de cincuenta autobuses y camiones formaron una caravana para ir del estado de Chiapas, al sur de México, hasta Ciudad de México. Más de 3.000 kilómetros y dos semanas de ruta en defensa de una ley de autonomía para diez millones de indígenas. El "subcomandante" Marcos, con su pasamontañas y su pipa, también estaba. En 1994 la guerrilla del EZLN inició una revolución con armas en el estado de Chiapas. Ahora sus armas son las palabras.

La caravana llegó hasta la tribuna del Congreso de los diputados. Y la comandante Ester pidió autonomía para las comunidades indígenas dentro de México pero sin fragmentar la integridad territorial. El futuro del diálogo entre gobierno y EZLN es incierto. En el congreso faltaban los 207 diputados del Partido de Acción Nacional, el partido mayoritario del país.

¿Votarías a favor de la ley sobre derechos y culturas indígenas que defiende el EZLN?

Mariana (tiene diez años y es de Ciudad de México): En primer lugar debe haber igualdad entre todos los mexicanos, sin importar su raza o su religión. Votaría a favor de la ley pero con algunas modificaciones a la propuesta indígena. Es importante que les respeten sus derechos, pero deben ser iguales que los demás. Creo que no es bueno que tengan una autonomía como piden los pueblos indígenas.

Arnau (tiene diecisiete años y es de Barcelona): Todas las personas del mundo deben ser iguales. Las culturas indígenas en México están machacadas desde hace cinco siglos. Todas las culturas oprimidas tienen los mismos derechos que la española o la inglesa, por ejemplo.

¿Cómo puede ayudar esta ley a las comunidades indígenas?

Mariana: Si se aprueba la ley serán respetados como merecen. Y el resto del país y el gobierno deberán mejorar sus condiciones de vida.

Arnau: Yo visité Chiapas el verano pasado. Es una de los estados más pobres de México. Allí los niños sólo van al colegio hasta los cinco años. Y el gobierno les manda a los profesores borrachos y a los peores de todo el país. Pegan a los nios y les prohiben hablar su lengua. A partir de los cinco aos empiezan a trabajar. Una ley indígena puede mejorar esta situación. En sus comunidades a los doce años ya pueden votar y a los quince o dieciséis empiezan a casarse y tener hijos.

Las actuaciones del "subcomandante" Marcos han creado mucho debate.

Mariana: Creo que es una buena persona. A veces se excede un poco pero si no es imposible negociar.

Arnau: Marcos es el logotipo del EZLN. Es un "subcomandante" y no un comandante. Es el portavoz. La sociedad occidental necesita alguien para identificarse y éste es Marcos, que no es indígena.

¿Estás a favor o en contra de que representantes del EZLN hablaran desde la tribuna del Congreso?

Mariana: En contra. El Congreso es la máxima tribuna de mi país, y no debía ser utilizada en este caso. Debían reunirse en otro lugar. La ley establece que la tribuna sólo puede ser usada por los representantes legislativos. La ley es la ley y debe respetarse.

¿Crees que tienen futuro las negociaciones de paz?

Mariana: Espero que sí, que muy pronto lleguen a un acuerdo justo y digno. Y no sólo para los indígenas sino también para todos los mexicanos.

Arnau: De momento ya ha servido para movilizar a la población. Yo soy revolucionario, y fui a Chiapas porque quería ver cómo era una revolución. Y me encontré con personas sencillas que conservan sus valores y tienen leyes de respeto hacia los demás.

¿Cuáles son los principales problemas de México?

Mariana: La inseguridad, la desigualdad, la pobreza, el racismo y la falta de educación. Por este orden.

Arnau: En México controlan la economía del país siete familias. Hay mucha diferencia entre ricos y pobres. En Ciudad de México no se puede salir a la calle porque te roban. Hay mucha gente que no tiene nada.

borracho hard-drinking, drunk

digno decent, honorable

faltar to be absent, to be missing

el logotipo logo, trademark

como merecen the way they deserve

machacados crushed, oppressed

mejorar to improve

oprimir to oppress

un pasamontañas ski mask, balaclava

pegar to hit

los peores the worst

el portavoz spokesman

fields.headline: Sophie is 'PR lightweight'
fields.trailText: 11.30am:The Countess of Wessex's PR firm has been branded 'lightweight and superficial' by a public relations expert, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Countess of Wessex's PR firm has been branded "lightweight and superficial" by one of the industry's leading authorities on public relations.

And the chairman of the Public Relations Standards Council said her company had brought the whole industry into disrepute.

Roger Haywood said the way Sophie Wessex and Murray Harkin ran their business had long been the subject of speculation in the PR industry.

"There has been some concern in the industry that their business was lightweight and superficial," said Mr Harwood.

"To have carried out business is this way, without proper credit and rating checks on potential clients would suggest the organisation is working on a superficial level. In other words they were skating on thin ice."

Talking on Radio 4's Today programme this morning, he said this weekend's revelations were damaging to the PR industry, reinforcing the mistaken belief that PR is about froth and frivolity.

"PR is about good standards and winning the public's goodwill and nothing to do with fixing, sleaze and connections," said Mr Haywood.

He is also disappointed in the way Sophie has used her royal marriage to further R-JH's business.

"It is a great disappointment the countess has behaved in this way. She shouldn't use her connections like this. It's not good for the clients or the business and is damaging to PR in general," said Mr Haywood.

fields.headline: £600m for crisis-hit farmers
fields.standfirst:
 Brown to unveil compensation package
 Tourism trade hit by cancellations
 Next few days crucial, says minister
 Supermarkets report huge profits

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 Brown to unveil compensation package
 Tourism trade hit by cancellations
 Next few days crucial, says minister
 Supermarkets report huge profits
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.body:
Farmers affected by the foot and mouth crisis have been allocated more than £600m in compensation, Nick Brown was expected to announce today.

In a statement to the House of Commons, the agriculture minister was expected to tell MPs that more than £247m of that figure is direct compensation for slaughtered animals.

But the results of a survey released today have stoked fears that the rural tourist trade could suffer further losses as people cancel Easter breaks over fears of foot and mouth.

NFU Countryside, an affiliate organisation to the National Farmers' Union, found that 66% of just over 500 visitors to its website who were questioned indicated that they were planning to take a countryside break over Easter. But of those, 65% had cancelled their plans because of foot and mouth.

Respondents had voiced a demand for clear, practical information about what visitors can still do in the countryside and where.

The organisation's head of membership David Hellard said: "The overall impact of foot and mouth on the rural tourist trade has been widely noted, but our findings really bring home just how hard the industry is going to be hit over what is traditionally an extremely busy holiday period." New, unexpected outbreaks were confirmed yesterday, dampening hopes that the disease was coming under control.

An outbreak in the village of Nelson - 20 miles from the nearest case in Monmouthshire - was one of two confirmed in Wales yesterday.

Mr Brown today claimed the next few days are likely to form a "clear trend" for how the foot and mouth crisis will progress.

The new outbreaks appearing in areas previously unaffected should be "stamped on" quickly through the slaughter policy, he said.

"I would expect by the end of this week for a clear trend to be discernible. But whichever way it is going, let me make it absolutely clear that there can be no room for complacency," he said.

"We have to remain vigilant until we have this terrible disease outbreak brought to a firm conclusion."

Meanwhile, two of Britain's largest supermarket groups were today celebrating a surge in profits despite the foot and mouth crisis. Profits at market leader Tesco are forecast to break the £1bn barrier tomorrow while Sainsbury's announced a 4.8% increase in like-for-like sales for the first three months of the year.

The National Farmers' Union today declined to comment on the figures.

Farmers have consistently complained of being sold short by the big chains which they say operate a price stranglehold on the meat market.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 49: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 49: In most papers, coverage of the Sophie Wessex affair has taken precedence over reports on the farming crisis.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Independent
On its front page, the paper picks up on fears the disease is being spread by the wind after three new cases - miles away from existing outbreaks - were confirmed.

The Guardian
On page nine, the paper claims the crisis is beginning to recede because the number of new cases dropped over the weekend.

Financial Times
On its front page, the FT reports one in 10 pubs across the country is being hit by a downturn in trade. Twenty establishments in the worst affected areas of Cumbria and Devon have closed altogether, according to figures from the Brewers and Licensed Retailers Association.

The Daily Telegraph
The paper reports on its front page that Misty, a pet goat, was "murdered" by lethal injection on the orders of Maff as part of a precautionary cull.

The Mirror

webTitle: Spirit bear helps save Canadian rainforest

fields.headline: Spirit bear helps save Canadian rainforest
fields.standfirst: Environmentalists have saved a swath of rainforest from destruction by exploiting the image of one of its rarest inhabitants, writes Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: Environmentalists have saved a swath of rainforest from destruction by exploiting the image of one of its rarest inhabitants, writes Anne McIlroy in Ottawa.
fields.body:
The mystical spirit bear, a rare pure white creature that wanders the rainforests of British Columbia on the west coast of Canada, has a new sanctuary.

Last week British Columbia's provincial government, with the agreement of forestry companies and first nations, protected 2,316sq miles of the spirit bear's remote island habitat from logging. The government designated another 2,000sq miles of the Great Bear rainforest for further study. Much of the temperate rainforest that will now be protected is on two large islands frequented by spirit bears - in total, an area close to the size of Northern Ireland is now largely off limits.

Five years ago, few Canadians, let alone Europeans, Americans or Britons, had ever heard of the spirit bear, which is believed to be a subspecies of the black bear. But it was turned into the panda bear of Canada by crafty environmental groups such as Greenpeace, to save a chunk of what is left of the country's original forests.

They launched a campaign for an international boycott of British Columbian lumber that convinced three British home-repair chains to say they would shift away from Canadian suppliers. BBC World Publishing told its suppliers it did not want to buy from a company active in the region. US giants Home Depot and Lowes shunned Great Bear rainforest wood.

The British Columbian Premier, Ujjal Dosanjh, said the decision was about protecting both the markets for the state's timber and the environment.

Mixing the practical with the poetic, he said: "This protects our markets. It is the right thing to be done.

"[The area] is truly that island paradise of legend. And it will be, forever."

Last week, jubilant environmentalists called off their dogs, saying the decision to protect the Great Bear rainforest had transformed British Columbia from environmental villain to hero.

"This is going to set a precedent for forest conservation around the world," said Greenpeace campaigner Catherine Stewart.

Forestry companies suffering from the boycott approved the deal, even though they claim it will cost 650 jobs. The agreement includes cash compensation, although far less than the industry is looking for.

The Great Bear rainforest is home to extremely rare and endangered wildlife, including white spirit bears, grizzly bears, salmon and eagles. The ancient forest is also renowned for its 1,000-year-old cedar and spruce trees.

But it was the mysterious spirit bears that helped save it. There are between 120 and 400 of these bears, also called Kermode bears. The rest of the 1,200-strong Kermode bear population are black. Scientists are not sure why some are born pure white.

Whatever their biological secrets, they became the poster animal for a successful campaign that saved the forest that is their home.

fields.headline: Monday's rumours
fields.standfirst: We've always known that today's rumours are completely useless at their jobs in PR and only hold them down because of their connections to a certain German family, so where's the story?
fields.trailText: Another club has joined the race for Spurs defender Sol Campbell. West Ham manager Harry Redknapp has, according to Planet Football, admitted: "I spoke to Sol's advisors very recently but they haven't got back to me. I would be very keen to get the boy as I have always said that the club needs to make a couple of major signings in the summer." However, with Arsenal, Manchester United and Liverpool all interested in the England man, a move to Upton Park seems unlikely.

webTitle: Banderas threatened by ETA, Crowe protected by FBI

fields.headline: Banderas threatened by ETA, Crowe protected by FBI
fields.trailText: Antonio Banderas has played down reports that he has been targetted by terrorists; Russell Crowe is being given FBI protection on the set of his latest film
fields.body:
Spanish star Antonia Banderas has played down reports that he is the target of terrorist threats from the Basque separatist organisation, ETA, and denied that he has taken any extra security measures.

The 40-year-old actor, who arrived in Britain yesterday with his actress wife Melanie Griffith for the premiere of his new film Spy Kids, told reporters: "This is one of the risks of this profession."

Banderas revealed recently that threats had been made against him by ETA because he had criticised its campaign of violence, but the Evita star looked relaxed as he posed outside the Odeon in Leicester square.

Banderas also confirmed that he will take the lead in the film version of the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, The Phantom of the Opera. After some hitches over the script, Banderas said that he was now delighted with the final version.

Meanwhile, the producers of Oscar-winning Russell Crowe's latest film are taking the kidnapping threats against their New Zealand star very seriously. Despite being largely set in New York and Boston, A Beautiful Mind, which examines the life of Nobel Prize winner John Nash, is being filmed at an undisclosed group of warehouses at a military base in Bayonne, New Jersey.

According to a source on set, both studio bosses and the FBI (who are still protecting Crowe) felt that Bayonne, which has a population of under 60,000, was the best place in which to protect the star. "In a movie like this, if something happens to your star then the movie is a write-off. The studio is willing to do almost anything to protect him."

fields.headline: Record-breaking Australia win 22-0
fields.trailText: Australia have smashed the world record for the biggest win in international football by beating Tonga 22-0 in a first-round qualifier for the 2002 World Cup finals.
fields.body:
Australia have smashed the world record for the biggest win in international football by beating Tonga 22-0 in a first-round qualifier for the 2002 World Cup finals.

Coventry striker John Aloisi scored six, while Wolves midfielder Kevin Muscat five. There were also goals for Damian Mori (3), Scott Chipperfield (2), David Zdrilic (2), Tony Popovic, Tony Vidmar, Archie Thompson and Con Boutsiania.

A spokesman for Fifa, world soccer's ruling body, said the previous record victory in an international was China's 20-0 defeat of Bhutan in an Asian Cup qualifier in 2000.

Australia's score also beats the record for the largest victory in a World Cup qualifier, held by Iran, who beat Guam 19-0 in Asia's first round of World Cup qualifying in Tehran last October.

The Fifa spokesman said there were "rumours" that Libya had beaten Oman 21-0 in an international in 1966, but this was unconfirmed.

fields.headline: Internet giants seek deal
fields.trailText: 11am: AOL Time Warner and Tiscali are in talks over a mutually beneficial working relationship in Europe, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
AOL Time Warner and Tiscali are in talks over a mutually beneficial working relationship in Europe.

According to reports in Milano Finanza, a leading Italian financial daily, senior management teams have already met several times.

The deal being discussed is a plan to give AOL a wider exposure to the European market through Tiscali's subscriber base, networks and contacts.

Tiscali is the second largest operator in Europe after T-Online, with 5m active users and 10.7m clients.

Together, Tiscali and AOL would tap into 9.4m subscribers, and be catapulted into the top two positions in the UK, Germany, France, and Italy.

Milano Finanza also hinted that a full-blown merger could be on the cards.

A deal is expected to involve the swapping of shares and respective stakes in both businesses.

Should something materialise from the talks, AOL would be able to consolidate its European position, and possibly gain a separate listing for AOL Europe.

Following the completed merger of AOL and Time Warner at the end of last year, the combined group is now looking to boost its presence in Europe by any means possible.

Speaking to analysts and investors earlier this year, AOL Time Warner management suggested they would be looking at partnerships and acquisitions, in addition to a local flotation.

webTitle: One to forget as reality kicks in

fields.headline: One to forget as reality kicks in
fields.trailText: So Tottenham always win the FA Cup when the year ends in a one? The notion may have appealed to the romantics but for those who prefer to deal in realism it was time yesterday to empty a bucket of cold water over the tired old myth.
fields.body:
So Tottenham always win the FA Cup when the year ends in a one? The notion may have appealed to the romantics but for those who prefer to deal in realism it was time yesterday to empty a bucket of cold water over the tired old myth.

For Spurs to survive such lung-splitting pressure before finally caving in, their wretchedly limp-wristed season disintegrating into dust, was an object lesson in staying power, if little else.

But when the dust settles and the distance they have fallen behind Arsenal is analysed properly, the inquest into this painful humbling will be a torturous affair.

"There were too many disjoinments," volunteered Glenn Hoddle, treating the English language with the same disregard as his players had shown the football. "We were too negative in our passing and it just wasn't good enough. Arsenal were better than us and we didn't do enough to win. If we had passed the ball better, we might have had a chance. But we didn't and that's the bottom line."

Indeed. Perhaps the story of the season's most comprehensive 2-1 thrashing was best encapsulated by Arsenal's tally of 22 attempts on goal. Everyone knew that in terms of quality there was some distance between these two clubs but, at times here, the gap seemed more like a chasm.

It is doubtful the entire Spurs team managed 22 telling passes. While it is one thing to deploy methods of containment, Tottenham's reluctance to venture into opposition territory was something to behold. "They just wanted to block us, stop us playing," said Arsène Wenger.

Nothing wrong with the theory, maybe. Put into practice, however, Tottenham's attempts to sterilise the game once Gary Doherty had snaffled the opening goal was undone by a concoction of abysmal defending and some exhilarating attacking play from their opponents.

"We created chance after chance," said Wenger. "It was an outstanding performance. When you play at 1.30pm and 60,000 people have travelled the length of the country to see it, you know just how much it means. This is a proud day for our football club."

Among the manager's tributes, an honourable mention deservedly went to Patrick Vieira, imperious in midfield and contributing the equalising header and a superb assist in Robert Pires's winner. "In his position I don't think there is a better player in the country," said Wenger. "I would expect him to be a strong contender for player of the year."

Preserving 1-0 leads, is George Graham's forte not Hoddle's. Never short of an excuse, he was keen to emphasise that his first week had been hindered by injuries. For an ordinary game, he said, four or five players, among them Sol Campbell and Steve Carr, would not have played.

As it was, when Campbell hobbled off, a picture of misery after damaging his right ankle, Tottenham's hopes of repelling Arsenal faded.

"With all due respect to Wycombe, I think we could have got away with it against them," said Hoddle. Yet that did not explain why his team were as wooden as a table-football side. With all due respect to Spurs, it could be argued Wycombe would have made a better fist of things.

So Arsenal make the journey to the Millennium stadium on May 12. Their fans will remind us that from the evidence of the 70s and the 90s they also tend to do well when the year ends in a one. They just don't talk about it so much.

For the time being Tottenham's supporters will no longer get away with believing that fate is on their side. Not for another 10 years, at least.

fields.headline: Secrets of the people smugglers
fields.standfirst: After his brother's death in the Dover lorry tragedy, a Chinese immigrant reveals the tactics of the 'snakehead' gangs. Nick Paton Walsh  reports
fields.trailText: After his brother's death in the Dover lorry tragedy, a Chinese immigrant reveals the tactics of the 'snakehead' gangs. Nick Paton Walsh reports.
fields.body:
He had dreamt of little else for two years. For Gui Chan, the dream was always the same: he would make his way from a dingy bedsit in Birmingham to Chinatown in central London where Quan, his younger brother, would be waiting to meet him.

After embracing, the brothers would head for an evening train to Birmingham. Within hours, they would be discussing their plans for a life in Britain and drinking to memories of their childhood in China's Fujian province.

It was not to be. Instead, Chan was this weekend reflecting on the harrowing last moments of his brother's life and regretting the day he suggested paying the people-smugglers known as 'snake heads' to get him from China to Europe.

While Gui Chan had successfully made it two years earlier, it was only a matter of time before the journey undertaken by thousands of immigrants each year ended in tragedy. On 18 June last year, Quan and 57 other Chinese suffocated in a lorry on its way by ferry to Dover.

Last week, Perry Wacker, a 33-year-old Dutch lorry driver, was jailed for 14 years for manslaughter. It emerged that after boarding the ferry at Zeebrugge for the five-hour crossing, he had deliberately shut off the only air vent to stop noise from filtering out. It was the hottest night of the year.

At Dover, Wacker's Mercedes-Benz truck was opened up by customs officers. Corpses, including Quan's, littered the cramped container. Most of the victims had torn their clothes off; others had tried to claw their way out. Two had survived, though they were barely alive.

Most of the victims had paid up to £20,000 to end up in the back of Wacker's lorry. With 60 people crammed inside, the 'snakeheads' had already collected £1.2m million from the human cargo. Wacker's cut was £500 for each person he successfully delivered, netting a payout of £30,000.

Gui Chan spoke with sadness last week about how he had convinced his brother to take a fatal chance. Now in hiding after helping Kent police with their investigation, he says the advice he gave Quan still haunts him.

In Budapest, the Hungarian capital, Quan had been detained by immigration officials. But the 'snakeheads' secured his release from a refugee detention centre after apparently paying an official and he called his brother for advice on his next move. Last week, as Gui sat in the office of a London lawyer, he sobbed as he told how he had advised his brother to head for Britain. 'You have no choice in Budapest,' he told Quan. 'You have to move on. There is no way back once you reach Hungary. And there is no way to know your fate from there on.'

Gui, 38, leaving behind his wife and two children, agreed to pay £9,000 to go to Hungary in 1998. In a small hotel in Beijing, the criminal gang behind the scheme gave him a false passport, with an immaculate visa stamp for entrance into Hungary. He said he asked no questions and boarded the Aeroflot plane to Budapest.

The Chinese market in the east of Pest is full of immigrants in search of home comforts as well as passage to the UK. The immaculate visas Gui and his brother received were obtained through a network of 'snakehead' contacts in Hungary. A source at the visa department of the Ministry for the Interior told The Observer last week how Chinese businessmen court visa workers. 'They give workers mobile phones, just so they can call them up and ask for "help",' said a source. 'They buy them meals and gifts - rarely giving them money at first. It's simple to issue a visa through official channels, but never record its existence.'

Gui said he waited days in a half-way house in Budapest before being packed on to a lorry heading west. The lorry stopped and the group was marched across mountains into what was probably Austria. There, two men with hunting rifles loaded them on to another truck.

After arriving in Kent, Gui telephoned his family in Fujian who paid the gang for transporting him to the UK a total of £17,000. He was marched to a waiting taxi which took him to Chinatown in London. After a series of manual jobs he found work with a building company in Birmingham while his asylum application was considered.

When Quan died, it was Gui who broke the news to the family. The body was shipped back to China, among 58 wooden coffins laid out on the tarmac of Beijing airport.

For Gui, the future is uncertain. His asylum application is not guaranteed and his testimony to police means that, if the snakeheads catch up with him, he faces death or injury. 'I was so desperate to leave China. You have no option with the government on your back. After my brother's death, the situation in China was exposed. But, since I have spoken out, the snakeheads have been looking for me. Their grip never seems to end.'

Pal Nyiri, a senior research fellow at Oxford University, said: 'The Chinese do not normally fear the people who arrange the trip. They are providing a service. Yes, it is expensive and sometimes dangerous, but it is an investment the Chinese think they can recoup from working in a better economy.'

He added: 'Few Chinese are surprised at being threatened when they don't pay up. In their minds, they have reneged on the deal. After all, it was not the snakeheads who killed the 58 people, it was the man who closed the vent.'

While Gui Chan had successfully made it two years earlier, it was only a matter of time before the journey undertaken by thousands of immigrants each year ended in tragedy. On 18 June last year, Quan and 57 other Chinese suffocated in a lorry on its way by ferry to Dover. Last week, Perry Wacker, a 33-year-old Dutch lorry driver, was jailed for 14 years for manslaughter. It emerged that after boarding the ferry at Zeebrugge for the five-hour crossing, he had deliberately shut off the only air vent to stop noise from filtering out. It was the hottest night of the year. At Dover, Wacker's Mercedes-Benz truck was opened up by customs officers. Corpses, including Quan's, littered the cramped container. Most of the victims had torn their clothes off; others had tried to claw their way out. Two had survived, though they were barely alive. Most of the victims had paid up to £20,000 to end up in the back of Wacker's lorry. With 60 people crammed inside, the 'snakeheads' had already collected £1.2m million from the human cargo. Wacker's cut was £500 for each person he successfully delivered, netting a payout of £30,000. Gui Chan spoke with sadness last week about how he had convinced his brother to take a fatal chance. Now in hiding after helping Kent police with their investigation, he says the advice he gave Quan still haunts him. In Budapest, the Hungarian capital, Quan had been detained by immigration officials. But the 'snakeheads' secured his release from a refugee detention centre after apparently paying an official and he called his brother for advice on his next move. Last week, as Gui sat in the office of a London lawyer, he sobbed as he told how he had advised his brother to head for Britain. 'You have no choice in Budapest,' he told Quan. 'You have to move on. There is no way back once you reach Hungary. And there is no way to know your fate from there on.' Gui, 38, leaving behind his wife and two children, agreed to pay £9,000 to go to Hungary in 1998. In a small hotel in Beijing, the criminal gang behind the scheme gave him a false passport, with an immaculate visa stamp for entrance into Hungary. He said he asked no questions and boarded the Aeroflot plane to Budapest. The Chinese market in the east of Pest is full of immigrants in search of home comforts as well as passage to the UK. The immaculate visas Gui and his brother received were obtained through a network of 'snakehead' contacts in Hungary. A source at the visa department of the Ministry for the Interior told The Observer last week how Chinese businessmen court visa workers. 'They give workers mobile phones, just so they can call them up and ask for "help",' said a source. 'They buy them meals and gifts - rarely giving them money at first. It's simple to issue a visa through official channels, but never record its existence.' Gui said he waited days in a half-way house in Budapest before being packed on to a lorry heading west. The lorry stopped and the group was marched across mountains into what was probably Austria. There, two men with hunting rifles loaded them on to another truck. After arriving in Kent, Gui telephoned his family in Fujian who paid the gang for transporting him to the UK a total of £17,000. He was marched to a waiting taxi which took him to Chinatown in London. After a series of manual jobs he found work with a building company in Birmingham while his asylum application was considered. When Quan died, it was Gui who broke the news to the family. The body was shipped back to China, among 58 wooden coffins laid out on the tarmac of Beijing airport. For Gui, the future is uncertain. His asylum application is not guaranteed and his testimony to police means that, if the snakeheads catch up with him, he faces death or injury. 'I was so desperate to leave China. You have no option with the government on your back. After my brother's death, the situation in China was exposed. But, since I have spoken out, the snakeheads have been looking for me. Their grip never seems to end.' Pal Nyiri, a senior research fellow at Oxford University, said: 'The Chinese do not normally fear the people who arrange the trip. They are providing a service. Yes, it is expensive and sometimes dangerous, but it is an investment the Chinese think they can recoup from working in a better economy.' He added: 'Few Chinese are surprised at being threatened when they don't pay up. In their minds, they have reneged on the deal. After all, it was not the snakeheads who killed the 58 people, it was the man who closed the vent.'

fields.headline: Week 32: the expert's view
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £163.04
The Prince of Punts aka Paul MacInnes = £55.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £38.46
Sean Ingle = £10.32
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £163.04
The Prince of Punts aka Paul MacInnes = £55.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £38.46
Sean Ingle = £10.32

Scott Murray: Southampton to win at Leeds - £5 @ 6/1

It is rapidly becoming clear why Mr Murray is over 50% up on his initial £100 bank after nearly a season-long battle against the bookmaker. Week in, week out he consistently finds long odds value singles, which although individually are more likely to lose than win, in the long run will come in enough to more than make up for the losers.

As I have stressed before, finding a bet whose odds are bigger than the chance of the event happening are crucial to becoming a winner punter. Those who stake large amounts on short-priced selections are more likely to back winners, but when they lose, their loses cut a deep hole into their bankroll.

Therefore, although Southampton ultimately were a well-beaten side on Saturday, there is no doubt they had more than a 14.29% of winning this match. Leeds have often performed badly after one of their monumental European performances and looked ripe for the picking by a well-motivated and in-form (prior to the Ipswich debacle anyway) outfit. So Scott lost this week, but I confidently predict that he will finish the season with a healthy profit.

The Punters Collective: Wycombe to draw with Liverpool @ 4/1

FA Cup semi-finals, hmmmmmmmmmmmm. Traditionally tense, dour affairs, where teams often don't play to expectations due to nerves and tension.

I am of the opinion they aren't the best medium for punting. Having said that, I can appreciate the logic of your selection. Liverpool would readily admit that the FA Cup was bottom of the list of their priorities, behind the Uefa Cup and a Champions League place in the Premiership. Wycombe, providing they didn't freeze during the big occasion, were always likely to provide stern opposition during the early stages of the tie, before tired limbs might cause Liverpool to pull away in the closing stages.

Whether 4/1 was value for this selection is a moot point, but nonetheless it nearly provided the Punters Collective a nice-priced and much-needed winner.

Sean Ingle: Rebrov to score the first goal and Spurs to win 1-0

Just as Mr. Murray's bet was a good example of his season long quest for value, this week's monstrosity was archetypal of some of the bets Mr Ingle has presented us with.

Possibly the two most profitable markets for the bookmaker (and therefore least profitable for the punter) on a football match are first goalscorer and correct score. To attempt to combine these two markets with a double is almost impossible. Week after week the bookmaker takes hundreds of these types of bets, and rarely has to pay out winners. A value-seeking punter would steer a wide berth around such a bet. I would guess only a seer could make money from such a bet.

I am not adverse to trying to hit a big-priced jackpot once in a while, and I appreciate the desperation of Mr. Ingle's cause with such a dwindling bank, but I feel bets such as this aren't the road to long-term punting success.

fields.headline: Oxygen runs out
fields.trailText:
10.45am: The internet firm backed by Elisabeth Murdoch and Matthew Freud has collapsed, writes Amy Vickers.
Special report: dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.body:
They epitomised the dot.com digiterati - but now the internet company backed by Elisabeth Murdoch, Matthew Freud and Manchester United chairman Martin Edwards has collapsed.

Oxygen Holdings, an investment company, was set up at the peak of dot.com mania at the end of 1999.

But within days of a dream flotation in February 2000 it share price crashed from 58p to 31p.

The share price last week hit rock bottom at 1.27p before being suspended to allow Oxygen to be taken over by one of its own clients.

Its downfall was not unexpected. Incubators, the investment firms that nurture a start-up from concept to launch, have been having a tough time of late.

The business model of an incubator is dependent on turning their clients into successes - an impossible goal in today's downtrodden market. One of Oxygen's high-profile investments was Toyzone.co.uk, which closed down earlier this year.

Oxygen, founded by Manchester entrepreneur Mike Edelson and his 26-year-old daughter Emma, has bought Finnish technology consultancy and investor Tera for around £5m in a reverse takeover of 395m shares.

Tera bosses will take over the business, although Mr Edelson and his daughter will stay with the company, operating the remnants of Oxygen as a subsidiary of Tera.

Elisabeth Murdoch is believed to have pulled out of her non-executive position on Oxygen's board, even though she has some 3m shares in the company.

Tera was set up in January 2000 to invest in early stage technology companies in the Nordic region.

fields.headline: Keeping up with the Jones
fields.standfirst: Text messaging will enable fans to become friends with Bridget - tap into her sex life, diet, how much she drinks and smokes. Has her author created a monster? Amy Vickers reports
fields.trailText: Text messaging will enable fans to become friends with Bridget - tap into her sex life, diet, how much she drinks and smokes. Has her author created a monster? Amy Vickers reports
fields.body:
If sex, men, smoking, drinking, diets, self-help books and text messaging are your bag, then you may well find yourself as inextricably drawn to the next piece of the Bridget Jones jigsaw - Bridget text messaging. It starts this Friday and, like the book, is guaranteed to reel people in - hook, line and sinker.

If you've seen the film, and bought into the Bridget ethos, then the logical next step is to become friends with Bridget - to allow the relationship with her (yes a fictional character) to become more personal.

It is unsurprising, then, that a text messaging marketing campaign has been developed to sit tidily next to the grand launch of the film. An apt marketing gimmick, given that text messaging is fast becoming a neurotic obsession and the ultimate flirtation tool.

The linchpin of the campaign is a daily text message from Bridget which gives details of her weight, how many alcohol units she's consumed, how many cigarettes she's had and any other facts that might draw you into her life, and encouraging you to text her back.

An example of the type of messages is: "Valentine's day should be banned by law. Reply Y/N."

The story of Bridget Jones has been well documented. Within minutes of the book hitting the bookstands in 1996, a phenomenon was created. It was an overnight success, selling more than 6m copies. Women holding down semi-successful jobs and playing the field found a curious empathy with the obsessive Bridget, who became an alter ego for a post-feminist generation of single women in their thirties living in the disenchanted 1990s.

Now, with an all-new version of the Bridget Jones diary coming to mobile phones, Fielding could be on the verge of creating a monster.

Remember Online Caroline, last year's contentious attempt at web drama? After a few weeks, the constant cries for help and advice from Caroline had her former "friends" ditching her in droves and screaming "stalker". Not a pretty sight.

At first it seemed harmless, cute, a bit different. Caroline was friendly (some would say too friendly), and her chatty emails were amusing - she invited people into her life, shared secrets with them and asked their advice. Then she became over-sensitive if her new "friends" hadn't called in to see her and began a barrage of daily emails that bordered on harassment.

The Bridget text campaign taps into the same kind of immersive principles, albeit via just one medium rather than the three (phone, email and web) used by Online Caroline.

In the same way that Caroline pulled people into her life, Bridget will become your friend, if you allow her to, and suck you into her life. Before you realise, you may find yourself asking a fictional character for advice on men, sex, diet, drugs or alcohol, even if you know the answer you'll get will be a typical Bridget Jones one.

You may even find yourself taking the Bridget quiz, or the personality tests to find out how "Bridget" you really are, or even start using Bridgetisms such as "smug marrieds" or "mentionitis".

Who knows what effect this will have on susceptible women. Is it right to put a gibbering obsessive on a pedestal and then tie the whole thing up with one of today's most addictive pastimes? It has the potential to make Bridgettes even more obsessive and knock us back 30 years in the feminist stakes. Bridget Jones author Helen Fielding says that's pretty much the aim of the SMS campaign. "Texting allows one to be more obsessive even than email. You can be in communication with others any time, anywhere (or not, which can be heartbreaking and obviously requires major analysis and discussion through further texting)," she says.

Fielding has gone back to the drawing board to create typical Bridget messages tailored for mobile phones, even though text messaging wasn't around when the Bridget phenomenon took off. "I have no doubt that after pioneering email flirtation, Bridget has by now become an SMS junkie," says Fielding.

The whole experience has been cleverly crafted from start to finish. After you've opted into the daily Bridget messages, you're only one step away from the accessories. And no self-respecting Bridget fan will be complete without her logos and icons, and of course, the ubiquitous ringing tones based on songs from the film.

Jan Wellmann, chief executive of Riot-E, the company providing the software and the know-how to Universal Pictures which made the film version of Bridget Jones, says Bridget is the first of many big screen characters that will be brought to life by mobile phones. No doubt another extension of the Bridget phenomenon will be a computer game, a TV show, a diet plan, a fashion line - who knows where it will stop.

Wellmann thinks there is just one essential ingredient to enable a character from a book or film to make the jump to a mobile phone, and that's a ready-made community of fans. It's not difficult to imagine the likes of The Blair Witch Project, Star Wars or even The Matrix being perfect fodder for SMS games. Already Riot-e has proved it can successfully take a game from the big screen to the ubiquitous fashion accessory that is the mobile phone.

In Italy last year, Riot-e had more than 16,000 people playing an X-Men text message game, which resulted in about a million messages being sent. Tellingly, the Wap version of the game wasn't nearly as popular and only managed to pull in around 8,000 players.

A long-term licensing deal with X-Men rights holders Marvel Enterprises means that Riot-e now has the mobile rights to more than 4,700 Marvel characters. And now that the company is ready to expand into new markets outside its native Finland, it's only a matter of time before British menfolk will get their very own SMS game, given that the Bridget one is really just for girls. Another SMS game Riot-e is bringing to the UK is an esoteric Finish fishing game, where users can catch fish by sending text messages.

Riot-e, which has so far raised $19m in funding from the likes of Nokia, Softbank and the Carlyle Group, is signing long-term rights deals with movie studios, sports clubs, games companies and TV companies. Imagine if the BBC had the foresight to develop a "who shot Phil" SMS game - it could have had the nation frantically text messaging and put funds back into the corporation piggy bank.

Licence owners typically receive a cut of 12-20% of the revenues made from messages (normally around 12p apiece) with the rest of the money split between the mobile operator and Riot-e. The revenues soon add up, and the trick is to get as many people as possible sending messages. With enhanced messaging (EMS) that will allow users to text each other attachments like minute-long movie clips just around the corner, text messaging could end up dwarfing the internet as a revenue generator.

The task in hand at the moment, however, is to fashion Bridget Jones communities worldwide.

Will it become a global success? Hard to say. After the endless hype, even the most ardent of Bridget fans may find their patience becoming tested. But this campaign, the first of its kind in the UK for a famous fictional character such as Bridget, has the potential to be a fun testbed for a new adjunct to the traditional forms of promotion.

webTitle: Most wanted man aspires to Nobel

fields.headline: Most wanted man aspires to Nobel
fields.standfirst:
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Radovan Karadzic, the wartime Bosnian Serb leader listed by the International War Crimes Tribunal as its most wanted man, has predicted that he will one day write an account of his life that will become so successful he will be nominated for a Nobel prize.
fields.body:
Radovan Karadzic, the wartime Bosnian Serb leader listed by the International War Crimes Tribunal as its most wanted man, has predicted that he will one day write an account of his life that will become so successful he will be nominated for a Nobel prize.

In a rare interview with a Bosnian weekly paper, Mr Karadzic said he was finishing an autobiography called Radovan and Serbia to be published by a western publisher later this year. "The book will become a bestseller, and I'm sure even be proposed for the Nobel prize," he said.

The Mostar-based Danas said Mr Karadzic, indicted twice by the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague along with his wartime military chief Ratko Mladic, had invited its reporter to interview him in a Serb-controlled village in southern Herzegovina. The reporter was brought to the interview blindfolded, but Mr Karadzic denied he was in hiding.

"I am not in hiding at all, my people are hiding me. You can ask any Serb if he would betray Radovan Karadzic... I walk around normally, go to baptism ceremonies, associate with my friends and my soldiers, I have recently been even in Sarajevo," he said.

"I will not fall into their hands alive," he added, in what appeared to be his first public comments since he was forced to resign from politics in July 1996 under international pressure.

"Although if I knew my surrender would benefit the Serb people and their interests, I would do it immediately," he said.

"But it would be absurd to surrender to those who have killed Serb children and the elderly. And it would be even more stupid to believe that tribunal would be unbiased."

During a visit to Bosnia last week, the chief prosecutor of the war crimes tribunal, Carla Del Ponte, said she wanted the arrest of all 38 people indicted and still at large. Mr Karadzic was a priority, she said.

"Del Ponte said the other day that a search for Karadzic was a mere cipher. Please let her know it will remain so," Mr Karadzic told the newspaper.

Mr Karadzic's autobiography may shed new light on the role of Yugoslavia's former president Slobodan Milosevic, who backed Bosnian Serbs in their fight to carve out an ethnically pure Serb state but then distanced himself from them in 1995.

"My book will explain many things and it will cast a dark shadow over Slobodan Milosevic. I will never forgive him, and neither will the Serb people, for the fact that he set up borders between Serbia and Bosnian Serbs," he said.

The United States has offered a reward of up to £3.5m for information leading to the arrests of Mr Karadzic and Mr Mladic.

"Don't even dare to try and use this interview to earn these millions offered by those international fools," he warned the reporter.

fields.headline: A sting in the tale
fields.standfirst:
As the furore surrounding comments made by the Countess of Wessex and her business partner Murray Harkin runs into its second week, Roy Greenslade presents the definitive account of a PR disaster

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: April 9: As the furore surrounding comments made by the Countess of Wessex and Murray Harkin runs into its second week, Roy Greenslade presents the definitive account of a PR disaster.
fields.body:
Hang on a moment! Have Britain's newspapers really devoted countless pages for eight days to trivial statements made - and, in some instances, not made - by the wife of the fourth child of the monarch? Oh yes, they have.

Compared to the previous taped royal intimacies of Camillagate and Squidgygate, Sophiegate is tame stuff, but it illustrates two truths, palatable or unpalatable, according to one's views on royalty. One, the royal family's public standing is now so fragile that it can be destabilised by a couple of Sunday tabloids in pursuit of a minor indiscretion by a woman married to the seventh in line to the throne. Two, the press, suffering from a post-Diana dearth of palace tittle-tattle, will now pull at any thread in the royal fabric in its desperation for headlines.

But what is truth? From the moment the story of the Countess of Wessex and the Sheikh of Wapping broke, there has been a farrago of rumour, speculation and fantasy of which virtually every newspaper should be ashamed. I have pieced together what I believe to be a definitive account of the whole tawdry tale that debunks some of the week's most far-fetched, and oft-repeated, allegations and fanciful conspiracy theories floated by apparently experienced commentators.

The saga began towards the end of February at R-JH, the public relations company run by the countess and Murray Harkin. A disaffected employee, account manager Kishan Athulathmudali, decided he had an explosive inside story to tell.

There are two contrasting versions of what happened next and since each side swears theirs is the correct one, I'll report both. According to the News of the World, Kishan first contacted its investigations department, headed by Mazher Mahmood. He didn't ask for money. He just wanted the world to know that the countess was using her royal connections to drum up business for her company. Then, at some time during the debriefing process, Kishan took fright and decamped to the welcoming arms of Max Clifford.

According to Clifford, confirmed in Kishan's legal deposition sent to R-JH lawyers, Kishan went straight to him almost seven weeks ago, long before he met Mahmood. He listened to Kishan's story and thought the most appropriate paper to run it was the Mail on Sunday. The paper's chief reporter, Fiona Barton, then spent three hours with Kishan at Clifford's West End office and, some days later, Clifford was surprised when the MoS rejected the idea of buying the story. Evidently, Barton did not want to rely on Kishan as a witness. Clifford then introduced Kishan to Mahmood, and both parties agree what happened from this point on: Kishan spoke not only of the countess trading on her royal links, but also made accusations about Harkin's private life.

Mahmood's team of spies and assorted poseurs then set about pulling off one of their notorious sting operations. Their bait: a potentially lucrative deal to promote a new leisure centre in Dubai. Their main target: Harkin. Their public-interest defence for using subterfuge: if what was alleged was true, he was not an appropriate person to work with a royal. Inside R-JH, the path was smoothed by Kishan, who assured Harkin and Rhys-Jones that he had checked the fake sheikh's bona fides.

There were two hotel meetings in early March between the robed "Sheikh Mohammed" - one of Mahmood's cronies - and Harkin, but he wasn't lured into making any sensational incriminating statements.

A frustrated Mahmood, playing the role of the sheikh's assistant, pushed Harkin hard. Asked about "rumours" involving Prince Edward, for instance, Harkin replied: "I'm a great believer that there's no smoke without fire." Questioned about drugs, Harkin did admit that he quite liked "the odd line of coke" and had taken ecstasy a couple of years ago. He was similarly vague when asked whether he knew how to hire male prostitutes. In the jargon of hacks who perpetrate these entrapment techniques, Harkin just "wouldn't play". He had not said anything good enough to publish. Then he suddenly gave the gloomy eavesdroppers a reason to smile. Next time we meet, he suggested, perhaps the countess should come along.

Mahmood quickly organised lunch at the Dorchester Hotel on March 14, and the single prior request made by R-JH was a fax of the menu. Harkin and Rhys-Jones were still reliant on Kishan's word, and the only means they had of contacting the sheikh was a mobile phone number.

Mahmood was again in western attire, as was the bogus sheikh, who had previously worn a rather fetching ankle-length thawb for the meetings with Harkin. Initially, Rhys-Jones was as careful as her partner, reminding her Arab hosts that they must regard R-JH in the same light as any other PR company. But it wasn't long before she became less guarded, gossiping about members of the royal family and politicians.

Much of what she said was both indiscreet and crass. She referred to the prime minister as "President Blair", suggested that William Hague "sounds like a puppet" and confided that Charles and Camilla were "possibly number one on people's unpopular people list". These were balanced by very complimentary comments about Hague and the prince. Perhaps her most tactless comment, breaking royal protocol on political neutrality, was about Gordon Brown's budget being "a load of pap".

Despite her apparent ease at that lunch, when Rhys-Jones returned to her office she was suspicious enough to demand another check on the sheikh and gradually realised she had been duped. Recalling what she and Harkin had said, or what they thought they had said, she then alerted Buckingham Palace.

Meanwhile, at the NoW, there was, surprisingly, no clinking of champagne glasses. After reading a transcript of the tapes, editor Rebekah Wade wasn't sure the material was strong enough to publish. There was evidence of a blurring of the line between Rhys-Jones's PR business interests and her membership of the royal family, but was there enough?

She certainly appeared to be exploiting her position, and Harkin had confessed to personal misdemeanours, but Wade was oddly hesitant. Her legal advisers were also worried whether the use of subterfuge might be challenged as "a fishing expedition", and therefore fall foul of the Press Complaints Commission.

Once the identity of the sheikh became clear to Rhys-Jones, her company's lawyers moved swiftly, pursuing Kishan for breach of confidentiality, issuing an injunction against the News of the World which required the paper to hand over tapes and transcripts. Other papers, as a matter of course, also received injunctions.

At the palace, communications director Simon Walker called PCC chairman Lord Wakeham in some alarm. He explained that he and the Queen's private secretary, Sir Robin Janvrin, urgently needed advice, so the following day, March 21, Wakeham and PCC director Guy Black visited them at the palace. (Some people might think that an ordinary member of the public would not get such attention from the PCC, and some people would be right.)

In what was supposed to be a confidential conversation, Wakeham and Black stuck to their usual script. The palace had two choices: to let the paper do its worst and complain after publication, or to contact the editor and, in Wakeham's words, "see if some accommodation could be reached". It would appear from the nature of this conversation that R-JH's lawyers had already conceded that they could not prevent the NoW from publishing.

Despite widespread speculation to the contrary, I am convinced that Wakeham and Black did not specifically suggest a deal, and certainly did not broker one. As far as they were concerned, the ball was in the palace's court and Walker, misreading the advice about "accommodation", then made a terrible mistake. He called Wade and, to her shock and delight, made her an offer she couldn't refuse.

In return for agreeing not to publish the material obtained at the hotel, the NoW could have an exclusive - and unprecedented - interview with the countess at Buckingham Palace. They would, of course, expect copy approval. Wade agreed, upsetting some of the more gung-ho members of staff who did not expect that an interview with a PR woman experienced in dealing with the press would yield much of a story.

In fact, Rhys-Jones surprised the NoW's journalist, Carole Aye Maung. Without much prompting, she spoke about rumours about her husband's sexuality, providing the paper with a front-page headline: "Sophie: My Edward is NOT gay". Wade didn't think the palace would approve the copy, let alone the headline, and was astonished when Walker made only the most minor of changes.

But Walker's headache was only just beginning. He was unaware that Rhys-Jones had written letters to the Blairs, Hague and Prince Charles apologising for what she might have said to the undercover reporters. On the day before publication, Saturday March 31, Walker received calls at about midday from the Mail on Sunday's Fiona Barton and the Sunday Mirror's Andy Buckwell. Both reporters claimed to know of indiscreet statements made by Rhys-Jones, but Walker did not appear to think that either had genuine evidence.

When the first editions dropped that evening, Walker was shocked to read specific quotes attributed to Rhys-Jones which he had not read in the transcript of the hotel tapes and thought were untrue. According to the Mail on Sunday, Rhys-Jones had described Blair's wife, Cherie, as "horrid, horrid, horrid", had called the Queen an "old dear" and had referred to Hague as "deformed". He immediately drafted a statement denying the veracity of the allegations in the Mail on Sunday and Sunday Mirror and issued it to the Press Association.

Some time later Walker discovered that PA was refusing to transmit the statement because, he was informed by a member of staff, it would upset a customer: the MoS. So he faxed his statement to as many Sunday papers as he could before, very late at night, finally speaking to a senior PA executive who countermanded the previous instruction.

By Monday, the hapless Walker was in a terrible state. He began to brief journalists about the PCC having suggested the foolish deal, hinting that they might have brokered it. A furious Wakeham hit back, leading to a breach with the palace, only partially healed by diplomatic phone calls to Wakeham from Janvrin. Then Walker discovered his position was even more untenable when Rhys-Jones also refused to talk to him. He is clearly being lined up as the scapegoat for the whole episode and could well end up leaving his post earlier than expected.

He certainly deserves some sympathy. In his previous job, as communications supremo at BA, he had a staff of 120. At the palace, he works with just three press officers. At BA, he had easy access to the chairman. At the palace, he is not in daily contact with the queen. That said, he was guilty of breathtaking naivety in his dealings with the NoW, as was Rhys-Jones. It's hard to believe they both earn their money from public relations.

There are still many questions left to answer. Was there a genuine public interest that made it appropriate for the NoW to use subterfuge? Was the NoW right to renege on its deal with the palace by publishing 10 pages of the tape transcripts in yesterday's paper? Why didn't R-JH's lawyers seek a further injunction to prevent publication having issued one a week earlier? What was it about the material originally obtained by Mahmood that made Wade hesitant to publish in the first place? How did the MoS obtain such specific quotes which, as far as it is possible to judge, did not appear in the transcript? Why, if R-JH's lawyers knew that the MoS quotes were incorrect, did they not sue the paper?

R-JH public relations
Buckingham palace biography of Duke of Wessex
Sophie Wessex fan site

webTitle: No 10 split on job rights for mothers

fields.headline: No 10 split on job rights for mothers
fields.trailText: New rights for mothers choosing to work part-time will be drawn up by an independent commission under plans being considered by Tony Blair.
fields.body:
New rights for mothers choosing to work part-time will be drawn up by an independent commission under plans being considered by Tony Blair.

In an appeal to women voters, Labour is expected to back 'flexible working' in its election manifesto.

But Downing Street, wary of a backlash from business, is seeking a compromise over calls for a legally enforceable right for women to reduce their hours after giving birth.

The Prime Minister is locked in negotiations over whether the right should be compulsory or merely voluntary best practice for employers. One option is to propose new rights but promise that details of what they would include and when they would take effect would be left to an independent commission involving employers.

Downing Street has already privately promised business leaders that there will be no new employment rights legislation for two years.

'This is the most important issue for most women at work - control over their hours - but it is also a huge challenge to business,' said Harriet Harman, the former Cabinet Minister who has been working closely on the proposals.

'My view is that we are likely to solve this problem. We don't want to ditch this, because it is too important, but neither will we charge headfirst into a row with business that can be avoided.'

Research suggests many new mothers reluctantly give up work because they cannot juggle a full-time job and a baby, when they could have returned successfully from maternity leave had they been able to work part-time.

A survey by the Equal Opportunities Commission found half of new mothers who sought to reduce their hours were refused.

A legal right to flexible working was first floated by the Women's Ministers Baroness Jay and Tessa Jowell, and taken up by Trade Secretary Stephen Byers in a recent Green Paper.

Business protests convinced many at Westminster that the idea would be shelved. However, senior fig ures point out that business leaders fiercely opposed the minimum wage but now accept it.

The creation of the independent Low Pay Commission to set a rate was pivotal in reassuring them, a tactic that could be repeated for flexible working.

The issue has divided Downing Street's policy unit, with Geoff Norris, Blair's industry adviser, and Lord Haskins, the Labour-supporting tycoon who advises the Government on red tape, said to be resisting new legal rights.

But Byers, Jay, Jowell, junior Employment Minister Margaret Hodge and policy unit adviser Carey Oppenheim have argued in favour.

The decision is now said to be in the balance, but retreat risks a backlash from women voters already showing greater signs than men of disillusionment with Labour.

Meanwhile the issue of working parents will rise up the political agenda on the eve of the election campaign, with Cherie Booth due to challenge her husband's Government over parental leave.

She is due in court for the TUC next month to argue that millions of parents have been wrongly excluded from the promise of three months' unpaid time off.

TUC general secretary John Monks called yesterday for the Government not to be 'so frightened' of business.

The unions want unpaid parental leave - currently limited to those with children born after 15 December 1999 - extended to another 2.7 million parents of under-fives born before that date. Its case, led by Booth, will be heard by the European Court of Justice on 3 May.

'We do not understand why the Government is dragging out this case - every expert expects them to lose,' said Monks.

'You would think Ministers would see this as an ideal opportunity to demonstrate their child-friendly credentials before the election.'

It is not the first time Booth has appeared in court against the Government - she uses the 'cab rank' principle of taking whichever cases come along - and famously appeared for the TUC weeks before giving birth to her son Leo.

This case, however, falls at a particularly sensitive time.

fields.headline: Everything is coming up turnips for the royal family
fields.standfirst:
We are watching the dying fall of pomp and circumstance

Special report: future of the monarchy
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: April 9:The private political wisdom of the Countess of Wessex amounts to little more than a regurgitation of Mail leaders, writes Peter Preston.
fields.body:
Fasten your seat belts: prepare to be so shocked that the chairman resigns. William Hague is "very intelligent... with real vision". Cherie Blair is "intelligent" too. Prince Charles is "great fun, he really is". John Major was "far too nice" to be prime minister. And - oh yes! - "the Tories will lose the election". At which point, perhaps, it might be prudent to stop the news of the world, and get off.

The private political wisdom of the Countess of Wessex, now taped in full across 10 tabloid pages, amounts to little more than a regurgitation of standard Daily Mail leaders. Tony Blair "doesn't understand the countryside". "Foxes have to be kept down or numbers will increase." As amazing sensations go, this goes nowhere.

Nor, in truth, is the grotty PR pitch of Sophie's partner to some phoney sheikh so stunning either. A few snorts of cocaine, a few nice boys for a gay party... It's amazing what a sheltered world our red-top editors live in. They should stop sitting at home knitting sweaters for Ross Kemp and live a little with the once and continuing R-JH.

This story - as a "triumph of investigative journalism" - doesn't go much beyond a petty, back-biting sting. It's hard to dignify any immediate reach of it with even a patina of seriousness. And yet there are two second-phase issues, rolling forward from yesterday's wrath and cosmetic resignations, which won't go away so easily.

One, of course, is the future of the royals revisited. Can they survive? A question of brute practicality - for the disasters that continually befall them are all of a pattern, a trail of debris from Di to Sarah to Sophie. Every marriage, every liaison, comes up turnips.

The pat current prescription here - as so often elsewhere - is downsizing. Cut the minor players adrift, let unsteady Eddie and Soph and Beatrice and Eugenie and the rest fend for themselves without inflated titles, flummery or civil-list cash. No more Princess Pushies. Concentrate on the "core" family - the Queen, the Duke, the Prince of Wales and his two sons. Let the rest make their own way.

It sounds neat enough, but it is just more day-dreaming. Downsizing might have spared us the Count and Countess of Whereverssex, but we'd still have had Margaret, Diana and Camilla: we would still get William and Harry in spades. The idea is little more than a tinkering with the odds. Nothing begins to work here unless such royals as remain after the cash cull are rendered ordinary, modest and profoundly boring, humdrum figureheads without glamour or constitutional significance.

But that, apparently, is the "Scandinavian way" and not the way of the Windsors. It is not what the family wants. It wants its palaces and privileges preserved. It wants to be loved and revered as heretofore. It wants to have its Royal Duchy of Cornwall shortcake and eat it.

That's why it employs two - rival - press machines for image-burnishing purposes. That's, dismally, why the Edward nuptials were turned into a TV circus. That's why, in default of suitable European princesses, supposed PR experts are the brides of first resort. That's why the Ruritanian title mines had to open a Wessex extension. The anger at St James's Palace this morning is not that the reality of a modern monarchy has been undermined by the blundering oafs over at Buck House, but that years of careful image-building has gone to waste.

Problem: the royals don't want to be ordinary, they demand to be extraordinary. They want to star in their own soap, to enjoy great polling results, to be rich and adored. They build themselves up to let themselves down. And it doesn't work; nay, it cannot work. The cast of characters can't play the parts any longer. They are trapped in a celebrity culture they have helped create which can no more be thrown overboard than Mr Richard Desmond in a Daily Express hurricane.

They are, in short, what they are. Chairman Sophie can melodramatically quit, but carry on dealing. You can sack a disaster-prone minister, but you can't sack a count or countess with a grotesque mortgage to service. The iron law of heredity means no one embarrassing ever goes away until the reaper calls. The plastic law of celebrity (Desmond's law, Rupert's law) means that one embarrassment piles on another.

This is a show that won't close, merely stagger on for decades. It isn't a great constitutional debate, merely a running into the sands, a dying fall of pomp and circumstance which we who pay the bills are doomed to endure as our society curls around the edges.

And the other issue, rolling forward? That, too, tells us something seedy about ourselves. Here's Murray Harkin, Sophie's partner, explaining to the cardboard sheikh what the countess can and can't do according to her current palace guidelines. "It's just the word endorsement. It's just being clever about it. If, for instance, the two of you were photographed together by the media in Dubai, it would not be a problem. Her doing a photo-shoot would be. That way the photographs are an advertisement. If it's a party or an event, and she's there, it's not a problem."

Here's Sophie herself threading the same needle. "I'm not there to endorse other people's products on a commercial basis, that's not what it's about. [But] if anybody gets some kind of additional profile or benefit from being involved with us, because of my situation, that's an unspoken benefit. It's not something that anybody promises, it's just something that occurs."

Now where have we heard that refrain before? Is it a tune they whistle for Lord Ashcroft as he trips up the steps at central office? Did Mark Thatcher hum it as he worked the Middle East cashpots of the 80s? A hymn sheet unwittingly left by the whips in the lobbies of the Lords?

Perhaps... but surely the full orchestral version is far grander and far more contemporary? Let's call it the Hinduja Variations on the Dome Symphony (by Mandelson and Straw). A riff which makes no promises but from which something just occurs. Formula one.

What, you wonder, would have "occurred" if the fabled Mazher Mahmood had kitted himself out as some Indian billionaire seeking citizenship? What if he'd sought asylum? We'll never know, because that would have been a serious investigation in candyfloss times, a sting not worth the proprietorial investment, not calculated to churn copies on a newsstand.

"My Lord, the Countess of Wessex and her faithful Harkin are without..."

"Without, sirrah?"

"Ay, my Lord, without common sense or dignity or reputation - but not without certain wider tidings of malign import. They crave an audience."

"Then, varlet, show them in. For in their tale of greed and woe we may yet find sustenance for the years ahead."

fields.headline: Sunday Best
fields.standfirst: Too busy to read the Sunday papers? Don't worry, we've done it for you.
fields.trailText:
Too busy to read the Sunday papers? Don't worry, we've done it for you.
Click here to sign up for our daily Media Briefing
fields.body:
Virtually all of the Sunday papers splashed on the Countess of Wessex, but as the royal family worries, others in the media continue to make news. Here are the best of the rest.

Sunday Times
Rolf Harris to be news arts presenter for the BBC, taking on ITV's Lord Bragg.
The BBC pays £15m for new Spielberg TV series Band of Brothers. The most expensive TV drama ever made, the BBC is hoping it will restore its battered reputation.
Former Buckingham Palace press secretary Dickie Arbiter returns to advise Prince Edward's company Ardent Television as palace draws up new guidelines for royals in business. Prince Edwards dismisses as "totally wrong" reports he had used a royal tour of the Far East to line up a documentary about the Sultan of Brunei.
Sunday Times launches a fund-raising campaign for Daily News in Zimbabwe after printing presses were bombed and editor threatened.

Sunday Express
Embarrassment for Conrad Black after correspondence revealed he couldn't afford to make donations to the Tories because the Telegraph was losing money. The letters date back to 1988. At the time it was revealed Rupert Murdoch had donated £150,000 to the Conservatives.

Sunday Mirror
Interview with BBC arts correspondent Rosie Millard.
Who Shot Phil Mitchell, Part 11. This Thursday the EastEnder tough guy faces the gun a second time - this time Dan threatens him.

Sunday Business
Sky may pull out of TV horseracing consortium Go Racing as it grows impatient with slow progress of talks with racecourse owners. It may launch talks with GG Media, which has been set up to bid for media rights to races at 26 of Britain's smaller trackes. GG has set a deadline of Friday.

Observer
Lord Birt has been dropped as Tony Blair's crime tsar. All he came up with was a few "daft" ideas say Labour insiders.
The paper also prints picture of Mahzer Mahmood. This will not go down well with the News of the World, which has spent years keeping his identity secret.

Independent on Sunday
BBC director general Greg Dyke clamps down on black tie events. Bafta TV awards will cost the corporation £40,000 with nearly 200 executives attending
