fields.headline: Palace launches shake-up
fields.standfirst:
An avalanche of tabloid revelations forced the Countess of Wessex to resign as chairman of her PR firm, write Matt Wells, Stephen Bates and Michael White.

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: An avalanche of tabloid revelations forced the Countess of Wessex to resign as chairman of her PR firm, write Matt Wells, Stephen Bates and Michael White.
fields.byline: Matt Wells, Stephen Bates and Michael White
fields.body:
Buckingham Palace was forced to begin a wide-ranging review of its wrecked policy of allowing royals to pursue their own business interests yesterday when an avalanche of tabloid revelations forced the Countess of Wessex to resign as chairman of her PR firm.

As the fake sheikh fiasco deepened, Murray Harkin, with whom the countess founded RJH four years ago, also stepped down. The affair left a serious question mark over the company's viability.

The Queen was furious at the News of the World's tactics. Buckingham Palace said she "deplores the entrapment, subterfuge, innuendo and untruths to which Edward and the countess have been subjected".

The paper defended its story as being in the public interest, as backbench Labour MPs called on the government to instigate a review of the monarchy's role.

The NoW yesterday finally published, spread over 10 pages, the story it had originally obtained when it sent its investigations editor, Mazher Mahmood, to examine allegations of improper practices at RJH. In a now-famous sting, he posed as an Arab businessman seeking to promote a new Middle East venture.

Although the comments attributed to the countess and Mr Harkin were less serious than had been anticipated, such was the cumulative effect of the past week's pressure that the pair were forced to step down from RJH.

It transpired yesterday that the countess did not describe the Queen as an "old dear", nor call Cherie Blair "horrid", nor William Hague "deformed". But she implied that clients benefited from her royal status.

"If anybody ever gets some kind of additional profile or benefit from being involved with us because of my situation, that's an unspoken benefit," she told the undercover team. "It's not something that anybody promises, it's something that just occurs."

In a statement issued through the palace, the countess expressed her distress at being entrapped but acknowledged her regret at her misjudgment. It added: "I take very seriously the issues raised and naturally regret any embarrassment above all to the Queen. I believe my overriding duty is to support the Queen and the monarchy. I realise fully that I am in a privileged position and I am conscious that my conduct must be above reproach. In view of this experience I need a period of time to reassess my own role."

The countess said she wanted to stay in public relations but will step aside from RJH while Lord Luce, the lord chamberlain, considers new guidelines for members of the royal family engaging in business.

RJH announced that Mr Harkin, the countess's friend and business partner, would resign as managing director. He admitted to the NoW that he had dabbled in cocaine and ecstasy, told of his knowledge of the London gay scene and suggested ways for a potential client to exploit the countess in promoting itself.

Buckingham Palace later indicated that the Queen acknowledged the difficulties faced by Prince Edward and the countess. "It is not an easy option and they are breaking new ground but it is right in this day and age that they should be allowed to do so," a statement said. But it added: "The Queen recognises that there are and always have been real issues around ensuring and being seen to ensure that royal and business interests do not conflict."

Rebekah Wade, editor of the NoW, insisted that the paper's investigations had been legitimate and in the public interest: "The disclosures that followed our inquiries have generated a major national debate."

After the consumer affairs minister, Kim Howells, angered Downing Street last week by saying that royal families were "all a bit bonkers", ministers stayed out of the royal row. But one high-profile, Labour pro-monarchist said: "The Countess of Wessex has disqualified herself from any role in public life. She should not leave her PR firm, she should leave the other 'firm'. Though she should continue to be Prince Edward's wife she should cease to be a member of the royal family."

Tony Wright, chairman of the public administration select committee, led backbench demands for a special commission to examine options for a scaled-down monarchy. But Tony Blair will ignore the calls. "He is perfectly happy with the monarchy the way it is," a senior official said last night. Tory MPs, led by William Hague, were more sympathetic to the royal family, and condemned the NoW as intrusive.

As the affair again dominated the headlines, the palace strategy appeared in tatters. Yesterday's announcements came from Penny Russell-Smith, the Queen's chief press officer, rather than Simon Walker, the British Airways executive seconded last September to mastermind the royal family's media strategy. In a disastrous week during which the palace was repeatedly wrongfooted, there was speculation that his job was on the line. Instead of tangling with the tabloids, Mr Walker will concentrate on helping to organise next year's jubilee celebrations.

webTitle: It seemed a good idea at the time

fields.headline: It seemed a good idea at the time
fields.standfirst:
A way for teenagers to make internet purchases looked like a winner. Then came the dot.com 'correction'

More internet news
fields.trailText: A way for teenagers to make internet purchases looked like a winner. Then came the dot.com 'correction'.
fields.body:
This is our final column. Over the past year we have tracked the development of our business, Rools, from a three-person team working for free out of a room lent to us by a former employer, through multimillion-pound funding to a live operation with thousands of customers. However, we have reached an important milestone.

We are abandoning our original business plan to set up an online teen payments service, and hope, instead, to move into new areas.

It was a difficult decision, particularly for ourselves who invested a lot emotionally in building a new internet teen payments business.

We have cash to last us until 2002 - plenty of time to start generating revenues and raising new funding, you might think. Not necessarily, particularly when it is not clear when we would be able to launch the full teen pay service, as for this we require a banking partner. Our original partner, Zebank, has indefinitely delayed its launch in Britain (though it launched in France earlier this year), which has had a knock-on effect on our own plans. We have therefore concluded that we would rather be proactive in pursuing opportunities outside the teen pay area.

We are considering developing business-to-business applications for our advanced real time transaction processing, billing and account management system.

We are also investigating the possibility of buying a technology company that would benefit from the systems we have developed. Such companies are being affected by the contraction in the venture capital market and the stock market downturn, meaning that there are some bargains to be had. With the cash we have in the bank, such a purchase is potentially attractive.

In the meantime, there is obviously some value in the assets that we have built up - our pre-registered membership base, retail network, brand and website, for example. We have already agreed to sell some of these to a business-to-business payments company, and are in negotiation over the remainder.

Moving away from the business we started represents an end of an era for us personally, as well as for the business. The 18 months or so that have passed since we first had the idea for a secure online payments service have been as busy, interesting and challenging as any we have spent previously.

Development of the business really accelerated around a year ago when we received our funding. Since then we have launched an operational service, backed by a sophisticated and secure payments system. In doing so we have put together a high-quality team, though we do acknowledge one or two recruitment mistakes along the way. We also have a decent network of partners and a sizable user base. Our investment in Teenfront.com and their continued success continues to be a source of much excitement to us.

We were particularly pleased to have completed the deal at a time last year when the investment climate for dot.coms was as drab and uninspiring as our recent weather. We have built relationships with some very interesting people.

The buzz around the business has been fantastic. Having a team that works well together helps, but everyone has been motivated by being in a small but growing business in a virgin market. It is self-selecting; the people who join are typically those that are attracted to the entrepreneurial firms.

But there are also - inevitably - some areas where we feel that we could have done better. Our most glaring error was the decision to invest in marketing our service to consumers at a time that, in hindsight, looks ludicrously early.

The fact that aggressive and early marketing was the prevailing dot.com strategy at that time is little consolation.

We could also, perhaps, have focused more attention on the front-end of our ser vice - effectively making the website more attractive rather than focusing on the functional and security aspects of our system.

Some of the biggest frustrations have been outside of our control, however.

Most notable among these has been the delayed launch of our banking partner, but - and let's be polite here - the "correction" in investment sentiment towards technology start-up businesses has also had an impact, if somewhat less direct and immediate.

We end the Rools teen payments era vastly more experienced. We have had a richness of experience that would simply not have been available to us in our previous roles as management consultants.

The need to be flexible but determined, to think strategically but also to be on top of the detail, and the responsibility we have enjoyed in a revolutionary new industry has given us a real feeling of personal empowerment as we look to the future and our next venture.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools

fields.bodyText: This is our final column. Over the past year we have tracked the development of our business, Rools, from a three-person team working for free out of a room lent to us by a former employer, through multimillion-pound funding to a live operation with thousands of customers. However, we have reached an important milestone. We are abandoning our original business plan to set up an online teen payments service, and hope, instead, to move into new areas. It was a difficult decision, particularly for ourselves who invested a lot emotionally in building a new internet teen payments business. We have cash to last us until 2002 - plenty of time to start generating revenues and raising new funding, you might think. Not necessarily, particularly when it is not clear when we would be able to launch the full teen pay service, as for this we require a banking partner. Our original partner, Zebank, has indefinitely delayed its launch in Britain (though it launched in France earlier this year), which has had a knock-on effect on our own plans. We have therefore concluded that we would rather be proactive in pursuing opportunities outside the teen pay area. We are considering developing business-to-business applications for our advanced real time transaction processing, billing and account management system. We are also investigating the possibility of buying a technology company that would benefit from the systems we have developed. Such companies are being affected by the contraction in the venture capital market and the stock market downturn, meaning that there are some bargains to be had. With the cash we have in the bank, such a purchase is potentially attractive. In the meantime, there is obviously some value in the assets that we have built up - our pre-registered membership base, retail network, brand and website, for example. We have already agreed to sell some of these to a business-to-business payments company, and are in negotiation over the remainder. Moving away from the business we started represents an end of an era for us personally, as well as for the business. The 18 months or so that have passed since we first had the idea for a secure online payments service have been as busy, interesting and challenging as any we have spent previously. Development of the business really accelerated around a year ago when we received our funding. Since then we have launched an operational service, backed by a sophisticated and secure payments system. In doing so we have put together a high-quality team, though we do acknowledge one or two recruitment mistakes along the way. We also have a decent network of partners and a sizable user base. Our investment in Teenfront.com and their continued success continues to be a source of much excitement to us. We were particularly pleased to have completed the deal at a time last year when the investment climate for dot.coms was as drab and uninspiring as our recent weather. We have built relationships with some very interesting people. The buzz around the business has been fantastic. Having a team that works well together helps, but everyone has been motivated by being in a small but growing business in a virgin market. It is self-selecting; the people who join are typically those that are attracted to the entrepreneurial firms. But there are also - inevitably - some areas where we feel that we could have done better. Our most glaring error was the decision to invest in marketing our service to consumers at a time that, in hindsight, looks ludicrously early. The fact that aggressive and early marketing was the prevailing dot.com strategy at that time is little consolation. We could also, perhaps, have focused more attention on the front-end of our ser vice - effectively making the website more attractive rather than focusing on the functional and security aspects of our system. Some of the biggest frustrations have been outside of our control, however. Most notable among these has been the delayed launch of our banking partner, but - and let's be polite here - the "correction" in investment sentiment towards technology start-up businesses has also had an impact, if somewhat less direct and immediate. We end the Rools teen payments era vastly more experienced. We have had a richness of experience that would simply not have been available to us in our previous roles as management consultants. The need to be flexible but determined, to think strategically but also to be on top of the detail, and the responsibility we have enjoyed in a revolutionary new industry has given us a real feeling of personal empowerment as we look to the future and our next venture.  Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools Useful link: Rools

fields.headline: Councils refusing to reopen footpaths
fields.trailText: Many councils are ignoring scientific advice and refusing to reopen thousands of miles of footpaths to walkers, the Ramblers' Association said yesterday.
fields.body:
Many councils are ignoring scientific advice and refusing to reopen thousands of miles of footpaths to walkers, the Ramblers' Association said yesterday.

As ministers set off on the tourist trail to demonstrate that the countryside is open for business, the 250,000-strong association attacked blanket closures of scenic walkers' routes.

Nine out of 10 councils shut almost all their rural paths when emergency restrictions were first declared last month.

A survey of 69 councils found that eight out of 10 still have almost as many paths closed now.

Seven in 10 councils are expected to persist in blanket re strictions by the Easter weekend when the tourist season takes off.

Jacquetta Fewster, of the Ramblers' Association, said: "It is atrocious that these councils can so casually ignore scientific fact and destroy the livelihoods of thousands of local people in the process. These paths need to be open by Easter."

The walkers' charity described West Sussex, Lincolnshire, Buckinghamshire, East Sussex and Hertfordshire as among the "worst offenders" of the 171 councils with powers to close public rights of way.

Almost two thirds of people who were planning a countryside holiday over the Easter break have cancelled their trips due to foot and mouth, according to a separate survey.

A poll of 500 users of the NFU's Countryside website revealed a demand for clear, practical information about the options for holidaymakers.

David Hellard, of NFU Countryside, said: "The survey illustrates just how far-reaching an effect the outbreak is having on people's leisure activities."

webTitle: Orange beats predictions on mobile sign-ups

fields.headline: Orange beats predictions on mobile sign-ups
fields.trailText: Orange will today reveal that it signed up a better than expected 1.2m net new customers in first three months of this year, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
Orange will today reveal that it signed up a better than expected 1.2m net new customers in first three months of this year, although it fell short of taking over BT Cellnet as Britain's second largest mobile network operator.

By taking 35% of all new mobile customers in the first quarter, Orange now has 11m British customers - just 200,000 fewer than BT Cellnet. Market leader Vodafone has 12.3m.

Orange's figures are better than most analysts had predicted and are likely to be of reassurance to shareholders who have seen the value of their stock trade below its issue price since the company was relisted in London in February.

BT Cellnet and Orange have each added almost double the number of customers Vodafone, and the fourth largest operator One2One, put on during the quarter. Some industry watchers attribute the growth to the higher commissions on sales that they have been paying phone shop dealers.

About 92% of Orange's growth came from pre-pay mobile sign-ups, however - the area that all operators are trying to move away from. They want to sign up "quality customers" on long-term contracts.

All four operators are putting up the price of their pre-pay packages by about 40%. Revenue rather than customer number growth has become the priority because of the huge sums operators are spending on licences and infrastructure for next-generation networks.

"As markets develop we will be reinforcing our efforts to encourage loyalty and usage among customers," said Orange chief Jean Francois Pontal.

fields.headline: Europe may bridge 3G cash gap
fields.standfirst: Commission fears operators will delay network investments
fields.trailText: The European Investment Bank may be called in to help finance the building of third generation mobile phone networks, according to a report at the weekend. By Mark Milner.
fields.body:
The European Investment Bank may be called in to help finance the building of third generation mobile phone networks, according to a report at the weekend.

The move by the European Commission is a response to concerns that telecom operators, strapped for cash because of the high costs of acquiring 3G licences and building new high-speed networks, might introduce the service more slowly than expected.

Bringing in the EIB, effectively the European Union's in-house bank, was proposed by Wim van Velzen, a member of the EC's industry committee. The idea is being considered by telecoms commissioner Erkki Liikanen, according to the Observer.

Yesterday, a spokesman for the EIB said he was unable to comment. Executives are likely to be concerned at any suggestion that the bank bails out the mobile phone companies - many of which are struggling with heavily stretched balance sheets.

The bank's mandate does allow it to back financially viable infrastructure projects, especially in areas such as communications, transport and energy. More especially, the bank's Innovation 2000 initiative is focused on fostering the creation of a knowledge-based economy in Europe.

Among Innovation 2000's targets are information and communication technology networks.

The EIB is pledged to "focus its lending in this field on innovative technology projects such as ADSL, XDSL and UMTS".

The strategy is a response to the EU's aim of making available "in all European countries, high-speed interconnected networks for internet access and to foster the development of state of the art information technology and other telecom networks".

Third generation mobile telephone networks will allow users access to the internet through mobile telephones and were initially seen as a must-have asset for telecoms companies.

The high cost of acquiring the licences in Britain and Germany and worries about how quickly the networks would deliver the revenues required to finance their cost prompted a rethink by some within the industry.

Problems for telecoms companies have been compounded by the sharp fall in share prices in the technology sector which has hit hopes of financing the networks by selling stakes in subsidiary companies.

One alternative is to link up with the network equipment providers which have shown themselves willing to help finance network rollouts.

fields.headline: Over-65s ignore safe sex warnings
fields.standfirst: Viagra, better health and divorce have led to pensioners being more promiscuous - and their rates of sexual disease are soaring
fields.trailText: Viagra, better health and divorce have led to pensioners being more promiscuous - and their rates of sexual disease are soaring.
fields.body:
It could be something in the cocoa or too much titillation on Coronation Street: Britain's pensioners are shedding their cardigans and getting down to it.

But the men and women who began the sexual revolution as twentysomethings in the late 1950s are not only finding new passion and partners in their retirement, they are also responsible for a dramatic rise in sexually transmitted diseases.

People living longer and healthier lives, rising divorce rates, the absence of work or family-related stress, even Viagra, may be responsible for the new promiscuity of older people who seem to have missed two decades of public sexual health messages often targeted at the younger, more at-risk groups.

A charity is now calling on the Government to investigate and to create a new safe sex advertising campaign aimed at older people. 'This should come out of the closet,' said Tessa Harding, head of policy at Help the Aged. 'I think there's very little public or professional recognition of the sexual health of older people. It's not one of those topics people want to talk about.'

In America last week the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported that the incidence of HIV in people aged over 50 is increasing at twice the rate for those younger.

Officials have speculated that a more open society, people entering the dating scene after the monogamy of a marriage and the absence of a fear of pregnancy is causing the alarming rise in sexually transmitted infections.

Grandparents behaving badly is not something either society or their kids want to think about. A north London care home worker told The Observer that 'residents being found entwined' was a not uncommon embarrassment for visitors while last year four elderly people had been asked to move out after being caught in 'a midnight orgy' in the dayroom.

'The idea that doctors shouldn't approach this question because it might be offensive is really passé,' said a CDC spokesman. 'If we don't change this predilection in physicians, we're essentially condemning elders with HIV to an early death. That's true more today than ever with the disease management tools we have.'

Dr Marcia Ory, chief researcher at the US National Institute on Ageing, and chair of an Aids and Ageing conference, held last week in Maryland, said: 'We can't ignore the older population, and have to understand the role they're playing in the HIV/Aids epidemic.' She said that 10 per cent of HIV cases were now in the elderly population.

In the UK, sexually transmitted infections have increased across the board from 624,000 in 1990 to almost one and a quarter million in 1999 - the most recent figures.

While in the whole population rates of gonorrhoea and syphilis have increased by 55 per cent since 1995, in the 65-plus age group the rise is more than 300 per cent.

But the rise could possibly mean that the stigma of attending an STI clinic is eroding, according to veteran agony aunt and social campaigner Claire Rayner.

'Years ago an older man who caught a dose of the clap from a prostitute would not be contacting his doctor. People were stoical and not over keen to present themselves for treatment but now more people are prepared to seek help.

'People do insist in thinking that older people are asexual. Believe me they are not, they have been having a randy time for a long time.

'The male menopause panic has always made men run out and find a younger woman to prove they can still do it and now women are doing that too. Safe sex has always for them been about avoiding pregnancy not avoiding infection so once that fear is gone they throw caution to the wind.'

The Department of Health is compiling a strategy for tackling the STI issue across the board. 'Sexual health is not just an issue for young people, it's an issue for people of all ages,' she said. 'More of our proactive work is focused on younger people because we know that is the biggest at-risk group, but we are presently compiling a report on sexual health which will give us the clearest picture to date of what is happening. We will be looking to see how relevant the rise in STIs in the older age group might be.'

It's not one of those topics people want to talk about.' In America last week the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported that the incidence of HIV in people aged over 50 is increasing at twice the rate for those younger. Officials have speculated that a more open society, people entering the dating scene after the monogamy of a marriage and the absence of a fear of pregnancy is causing the alarming rise in sexually transmitted infections. Grandparents behaving badly is not something either society or their kids want to think about. A north London care home worker told The Observer that 'residents being found entwined' was a not uncommon embarrassment for visitors while last year four elderly people had been asked to move out after being caught in 'a midnight orgy' in the dayroom. 'The idea that doctors shouldn't approach this question because it might be offensive is really passé,' said a CDC spokesman. 'If we don't change this predilection in physicians, we're essentially condemning elders with HIV to an early death. That's true more today than ever with the disease management tools we have.' Dr Marcia Ory, chief researcher at the US National Institute on Ageing, and chair of an Aids and Ageing conference, held last week in Maryland, said: 'We can't ignore the older population, and have to understand the role they're playing in the HIV/Aids epidemic.' She said that 10 per cent of HIV cases were now in the elderly population. In the UK, sexually transmitted infections have increased across the board from 624,000 in 1990 to almost one and a quarter million in 1999 - the most recent figures. While in the whole population rates of gonorrhoea and syphilis have increased by 55 per cent since 1995, in the 65-plus age group the rise is more than 300 per cent. But the rise could possibly mean that the stigma of attending an STI clinic is eroding, according to veteran agony aunt and social campaigner Claire Rayner. 'Years ago an older man who caught a dose of the clap from a prostitute would not be contacting his doctor. People were stoical and not over keen to present themselves for treatment but now more people are prepared to seek help. 'People do insist in thinking that older people are asexual. Believe me they are not, they have been having a randy time for a long time. 'The male menopause panic has always made men run out and find a younger woman to prove they can still do it and now women are doing that too. Safe sex has always for them been about avoiding pregnancy not avoiding infection so once that fear is gone they throw caution to the wind.' The Department of Health is compiling a strategy for tackling the STI issue across the board. 'Sexual health is not just an issue for young people, it's an issue for people of all ages,' she said. 'More of our proactive work is focused on younger people because we know that is the biggest at-risk group, but we are presently compiling a report on sexual health which will give us the clearest picture to date of what is happening. We will be looking to see how relevant the rise in STIs in the older age group might be.'

fields.headline: I too was Maxwell's plaything
fields.standfirst: It's not just the City that was duped. That man had chutzpah. Who can doubt he has talked his way into heaven
fields.trailText: How, city commentators asked last week, did Robert Maxwell get away with so much villainy for so long? Part of the answer, as demonstrated in this paper, is that the city institutions were supine and the banks venal. But there is one aspect of the explanation which, understandably enough, has been neglected. It concerns Maxwell's personality. His chutzpah was invincible. I have reason to know.
fields.body:
How, city commentators asked last week, did Robert Maxwell get away with so much villainy for so long? Part of the answer, as demonstrated in this paper, is that the city institutions were supine and the banks venal. But there is one aspect of the explanation which, understandably enough, has been neglected. It concerns Maxwell's personality. His chutzpah was invincible. I have reason to know.

Early one morning - about six months after I had broken the news to Neil Kinnock that Maxwell had secretly bought the Mirror - I was invited to the offices of that newspaper to discuss "writing a regular column". To my surprise, I was ushered into the presence of the proprietor who made me an immediate offer. What, I asked, does the editor think about this? "It's none of his business," Maxwell replied. Then, noting my consternation, he added: "He'll be delighted when I tell him."

Perhaps it was my reaction to the demonstration of Maxwell's management technique that ruined my chances. But whatever the reason, the subject was swiftly changed to the Mirror Group's devotion to the Labour party. To demonstrate the close connection, no less than four Labour peers - all of them Maxwell employees - were paraded before me. "See," said Maxwell, "I'm the only one without a title." Hoping to be rude, I told him: "You'll want one before long." He was still denying any such ambition when, true to my flirtation with tabloid journalism, I made an excuse and left.

I heard no more about the Mirror column. Indeed, I heard no more of the proprietor until - many months later - I was telephoned at home by one of his minions. Would I take a call from Robert Maxwell? Of course I would. The minion telephoned several times more to make sure that I was still available and then the great man himself boomed down the line. "We were just talking about you," he said with absolute conviction. "Do you remember when you told me that I was after a peerage?" He gave a stage laugh and added: "Very cheeky!" Then he rang off.

Two days later a journalist phoned me from the high court. Maxwell, giving evidence in his libel case against Private Eye, had announced that I had once offered him a peerage - a fact which, he explained, had been confirmed with me earlier in the week. Two other Labour politicians - both of them, like me, in no position to influence the honours list - were also cited as would-be benefactors. They, however, were dead.

My first instinct was to issue what is known in the trade as an angry denial. Wiser counsels prevailed. Persuaded to take the advice of Derry Irvine, I learnt that to contradict evidence in the way which I proposed might be regarded as a contempt of court. Proper procedure required me to offer myself as a witness to Maxwell's adversaries. Unattracted by that prospect, I telephoned the Mirror. To my astonishment, Maxwell came on the line at once.

He accepted, without qualification, that he had given the jury the wrong impression but, he explained, he had been badly disturbed by the mention of Adolf Eichmann who had been responsible for the death of several Maxwell relatives. He would gladly make a correction under cross-examination next day. An American student - not doing much in my office - was dispatched to the high court. He returned with the news that Maxwell had completed his evidence without making the retraction.

I telephoned the Mirror again. Maxwell, I was told, was not available. As I began to argue, there was a rasping noise as he snatched the receiver from his secretary's hand. Again he pleaded guilty as charged. Then he went on to explain his second failure to keep the promise. Just as he was about to clear my name, a piece of paper had been passed to him. It contained the message that a helicopter which he owned had come down in the North sea. After that, he was too worried about the safety of the crew to think about anything else. Knowing when I was licked, I decided that all I could do to protect my reputation was spread the story about.

I spread it so widely that Tom Bower picked it up when he was preparing to write his Maxwell biography. Not surprisingly, it became one of the passages to which Maxwell took exception when he attempted to suppress the book's publication. As the hearing of his injunction approached, one of his employees approached me with a request. Would I sign an affidavit saying that the whole story was invention? I declined - adding to the pompous stuff about truth and integrity as I could not imagine why Maxwell should expect me to do him a favour. The young man came back to me with the news that he had relayed my message to his chief. "Bob," he said, "hopes you'll do it out of friendship." Who can doubt that he has talked his way into heaven?

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.standfirst: by John Kampfner
fields.trailText: by John Kampfner
fields.body:
It's called flying below the radar. It's about circumventing the national media to get the message across. The government is doing it increasingly, flogging policies through regional newspapers, radio and television, avoiding a sceptical Westminster village.

The New Deal is a prime example. Since December, Tessa Jowell, the minister responsible, has made nine day-trips to the regions of England and Wales, ending in the north-east last Tuesday. Nobody in London SW1 would have heard a word about it. This is strictly not for them.

The idea came from a familiar channel - Tony Blair to Alastair Campbell (or was it the other way round?), through the Strategic Communications Unit in Downing Street to the head of media relations at the Department for Education and Employment, Julia Simpson. She handed it to one of her deputies, who drew up an outline proposal along with the head of the Welfare to Work Communication Division. They then asked the press officers from each of the nine regions of the Employment Service to contact media outlets in their areas.

Local political and industrial correspondents were invited to bid for interviews, to attend photo-ops and other meetings. Some of the minister's "consultation" sessions with employers and employees were deemed out of bounds.

It's certainly labour-intensive. Last Tuesday's trip began just after 8am with an interview with Radio Newcastle's breakfast show, which Jowell did live on the phone in her official car on the way to the Heathrow Express. They pulled over so she wasn't cut off when going under a tunnel.

On arrival at Newcastle Airport, which has taken on several New Dealers, there were interviews with the Journal and the Chronicle. Down-the-line chats with Century Radio and Sun FM were put back; she did them from the car too. During her lunchtime tour of the Beamish Museum, an open-air historical museum in County Durham, Jowell was accompanied by the Northern Echo. Then it was off to Nissan with the Sunderland Echo.

So how much do these ventures achieve? The only measure the government has is the volume of copy - steady but unspectacular. Page 12 in the Northern Echo: "Yes Minister, Rural Attractions Are Open" (combining the New Deal with foot and mouth and tourism), and page 5 in Sunderland: "Minister in City Visit". This follows a pattern. Her first sortie into the regions, on 6 December, saw pieces in the Eastern Daily Press, Peterborough Evening Telegraph, Leicester Mercury, Lincolnshire Echo and Nottingham Evening Post. "Minister Will See New Deal At Work" read one headline, "Minister Hails Jobs Success" was another.

The tone was certainly helpful, not the "cynical" the-only-news-is-bad-news approach that Campbell is convinced drives Fleet Street. As for the impact: page 22 in one, page 12, even a page 36, at best page 3.

Something, though, is better than nothing. The more frustrated Downing Street becomes about coverage from the parliamentary lobby, the wider it casts its net for alternatives. The media operation has tried glossy magazines (with varying success - and nothing can compare in crassness to William Hague's drinking exploits confession to GQ); they've done daytime television (Blair got himself into an awkward spot by suggesting that Glenn Hoddle should go as England manager); and they do the internet (but that's now being seen as subject to a law of diminishing returns).

Regional coverage is deemed to be straighter; it's also more prepared to engage on the government's human interest terms. Says one spinner: "It's something we're trying to do more and more. The New Deal was written about so much, even before this government came to power, that Westminster hacks got bored." A similar strategy is being applied to the 10-year transport strategy and to various crime initiatives.

In the old days, regional coverage was seen, at most, as supplementing national coverage. Now in some areas it is being developed instead of it. More press officers are being deployed in the regions. But, according to one, old habits die hard. "The trouble is that the cuttings pack ministers receive each morning is culled from the nationals. Regional copy comes in piecemeal, and often several days late. And if they don't see their names and their faces straight away they get disheartened."

webTitle: Go by air or road, says transport minister

fields.headline: Go by air or road, says transport minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, yesterday urged Virgin Trains' long-suffering passengers on the west coast line not to put up with the latest 10% fare increases, but to consider going by road or air instead.
fields.body:
The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, yesterday urged Virgin Trains' long-suffering passengers on the west coast line not to put up with the latest 10% fare increases, but to consider going by road or air instead.

He rejected growing calls for renationalisation of Railtrack as being "emotionally and politically" attractive, but impractical. It would cost too much and cause an "investment freeze" that would delay Labour's plans for the railways. In an interview with BBC1's On the Record, Lord Macdonald, who works under John Prescott's overall lead, made plain ministerial frus tration with the 10% rise announced last week by Sir Richard Branson's group.

"There's nothing we can do about that particular rise, which I think is very regrettable because it's not the kind of message you want to be sending out when you are getting passengers back on the railway," he said.

Since 1997 most fares have gone up by the rate of inflation.

Pressed by John Humphrys to admit there was nothing he could do against a "sovereign" company, Lord Macdonald replied: "It's really for the passengers to look at and say 'Well, can we get to Manchester more quickly by air or by coach or by car? Is there an alternative service we can take? They are in a market place."

Lord Macdonald expressed an optimistic view of railway prospects as up to £60 bn or more of public/private investment improved the service. As many were travelling by train as had done before the Hatfield crash led to what he called "the biggest engineering project of its kind in Europe" to repair the tracks - though potential growth in the system had been lost, he conceded.

Some 92% of services had been restored and 82% of trains were running on time, compared with 86% pre-Hatfield, he claimed. Railtrack "admits it's been badly managed" and would be appointing a public interest director.

"We need more investment, better management and better regulation," Lord Macdonald said.

 Railtrack is offering graduates and senior executives "golden hellos" in an attempt to end a recruitment crisis.

Students will be given up to £2,000 for choosing the troubled company, while senior executives could be presented with thousands of pounds along with tailored packages.

High-quality staff have ignored Railtrack following the battering it has taken since the Hatfield rail crash.

Senior executives say staff feel humiliated by criticism of the company and are concerned by the plunge of its stockmarket value. It is likely to fall out of the FTSE-100 in the next quarterly reshuffle.

webTitle: £1.6m bill ignites row over fireworks fiasco

fields.headline: £1.6m bill ignites row over fireworks fiasco
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: A row has broken out between the government and Ken Livingstone over who should pay a £1.6m cancellation bill submitted by the pop impresario Sir Bob Geldof for the New Year's Eve fireworks debacle.
fields.body:
A row has broken out between the government and Ken Livingstone over who should pay a £1.6m cancellation bill submitted by the pop impresario Sir Bob Geldof for the New Year's Eve fireworks debacle.

Three months after the non-event, Keith Hill, the minister for London, and the mayor are arguing over a contract originally signed on behalf of John Prescott, the deputy prime minister.

Sir Bob's company, 10 Alps, won the contract from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) to organise the huge party and fireworks in London last New Year's Eve.

The ministry says Mr Livingstone accepted the deal, so he should pay up. Mr Livingstone says the contract was imposed on him, so the ministry should pay.

The government had trumpeted plans for the party as the best in the world. But the celebrations were cancelled amid concerns over transport and safety.

Confidential correspondence, seen by the Guardian, shows that Mr Livingstone wrote to Mr Hill on November 22 - just after cancellation - pleading for the government to reimburse the Greater London Assembly (GLA).

He said: "On termination, 10 Alps became entitled only to those costs which they can prove were unavoidable. At a meeting on Thursday, 10 Alps estimated these to be around £1.45m, though they subsequently reviewed that estimate up to £1.6m, and they will not know for certain until they have established their liabilities to sub-contractors."

He added: "As you know the GLA budget does not make provision for the cost of a New Year's Eve event." Mr Hill wrote back: "I cannot endorse a payment to the GLA for cancellation costs. There was a small amount that we thought might be used for event management costs, but that amount was intended to be used for celebration not cancellation."

Mr Hill has also disputed that the government can have anything to do with the contract, saying that from July 24 the contract was transferred to the GLA under parliamentary legislation. "The secretary of state is no longer a party to the contract," he said.

In another letter, Mr Livingstone says the terms of contract were imposed on the GLA - and the terms were negotiated with the government, not the GLA.

GLA officials said in an internal note that the original contract was "inadequate" and suggested that DETR officials "were incompetent, or indifferent because the contract was to transfer to the GLA".

Last night a spokesman for the mayor's office confirmed that the compensation sum was still not agreed with Sir Bob nor who would pay it. "It is hoped the final figure will be nearer £800,000 than £1.6m," he said.

A DETR spokeswoman reiterated that neither Mr Prescott nor Mr Hill had responsibility for the contract and that the ministry would not pay cancellation costs.

No spokeswoman was available from 10 Alps. They are said to be in negotiation.

Eric Ollerenshaw, leader of the Conservatives on the Greater London Authority, who chaired the investigation into what went wrong, said: "It is outrageous that London's council taxpayers should be asked to pay back the government for an event that never happened."

webTitle: Leader: There are plenty of uses for Sophie's PR skills

fields.headline: Sophie's choice
fields.standfirst:
There are plenty of uses for her PR skills

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: If taking cocaine were a bar to a career in PR the public relations industry in this country would be decimated. If holding banal and uninformed views on politics were an obstacle to membership of the royal family the monarchy would also have to shut up shop.
fields.body:
If taking cocaine were a bar to a career in PR the public relations industry in this country would be decimated. If holding banal and uninformed views on politics were an obstacle to membership of the royal family the monarchy would also have to shut up shop. So the likely reaction of many to the supposedly sensational material spread across 10 pages of the News of the World yesterday will have been a weary shrug.

The Countess of Wessex emerges as a woman of unexceptional views and an underdeveloped sense of discretion. She did not, it now appears, speak of the "deformed" William Hague or the "horrid" Cherie Blair. Instead, we learn that she was not impressed by Gordon Brown's budget, which she thought was a pre-election "load of pap" and that she believes that, under New Labour, the man in the street is paying something like an additional 40% in tax. Her business partner, Murray Harkin, was taped confessing to the occasional use of drugs. They both speak about the "unspoken benefit" of having a member of the royal family working on an account. If there is little here we didn't know or suspect, there is undoubtedly a mild frisson generated by seeing our suspicions pinned down in such excruciating detail.

Sophie Rhys-Jones has discovered what many others have learned: that marrying into - or even coming into contact with - the royal family has a toxic effect on personal lives. Some will blame tabloid journalists - and they do, indeed, have a heavy responsibility for their part in stripping bare so many lives so ruthlessly. But editors would soon stop running royal stories if there were widespread public disgust at their prurience. The contrary is true: the greater the intrusion, the bigger the sales. The British public laps up every tapped phone, stolen picture, entrapped countess and bugged conversation it is offered. There is little evidence that we set much store by the privacy of our first family.

There is something profoundly destructive and unhealthy going on here. All polling suggests that we are attached to the notion of the royal family. At the same time all circulation figures suggest that we have contempt for many of the individual members. The reason for this paradox is not elusive. At a time when farmers, car workers and steel-makers - among many others - are having to face up to the cold realities of economic life, it is hard to understand why the taxpayer is effectively subsiding Prince Edward's unsuccessful film production company. Since the Queen is one of the richest women in the world, why do we continue to subsidise her so lavishly that she has apparently been able to build up a civil list surplus of more than £35m over the past decade? How do we reconcile the Duke of York's annual "parliamentary annuity" of £249,000 with a lifestyle that seems to centre disproportionately around luxury yachts and racy New York night clubs?

If the case for the royal family is that they are dedicated public servants, then they should concentrate a bit more on public service. Now she is stepping down as chairman of her company Ms Rhys-Jones should find plenty of uses for her PR skills in places such as the British Council or the NHS. Alternatively, she could drop her titles, the civil list payments and the Bagshot mansion and make it on her own two feet. Either is an honourable course. It must be increasingly obvious to all at the palace that she can't do both.

webTitle: Leader: Putting ethics on the map

fields.headline: Putting ethics on the map
fields.standfirst:
Robin Cook's achievement deserves support

Special report: Labour party
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Ethics, that is to say the application of morals to human conduct, has always been a difficult area. Even Plato had his problems. So when Robin Cook added an ethical dimension to British policy in 1997, the Foreign Office's answer to Socrates seemed to be just asking for trouble.
fields.body:
Ethics, that is to say the application of morals to human conduct, has always been a difficult area. Even Plato had his problems. So when Robin Cook added an ethical dimension to British policy in 1997, the Foreign Office's answer to Socrates seemed to be just asking for trouble. In the peripatetic school of modern politics, low-brow pedestrians of all parties, egged on by the press, were only too happy to put the boot in. What vain and foolish posturing, they cried. What hypocrisy! Mr Cook has been trying to act philosophical ever since.

What is rarely, if ever, noted is that Mr Cook's attempt publicly to anchor policy in morality, while easily mocked and obviously imperfect, was a brave and creative step. The foreign secretary is said to believe that helping depose Serbia's Slobodan Milosevic is his most important achievement to date. But the emphasis he has placed on human rights may have a more lasting impact. No future British government will be able to ignore the much derided ethical dimension. Nor, as foreign policy is increasingly collectivised, will any other EU member state.

In effect, Mr Cook has attempted that most difficult of things: to change attitudes. British diplomats now receive human rights training as a matter of course. Mr Cook has established de facto criteria by which all future policy will be judged, be it overseas arms sales, bilateral aid or humanitarian intervention. Britain has championed the UN's international criminal court. And in East Timor, Sierra Leone and Zimbabwe, for example, Britain's actions have gone well beyond narrowly defined national interest. Its position was all the stronger for being morally justified.

There remains plenty of cause for complaint, about lack of consistency and apparent blindspots. In a recent speech on the government's human rights record, Mr Cook criticised China's numerous abuses but made no reference to Russia's appalling behaviour in Chechnya. For many people, Mr Cook's words have not been reflected in policy in Iraq, in Kurdish areas of Turkey and in respect of Israel's conduct in Palestine. Draft arms exports regulations have been slow in coming and contain serious loopholes. And Britain is still reluctant to criticise Saudi Arabia and the US over such matters as the death penalty. But in a world mostly beyond Britain's control, Mr Cook's overall effort to raise expectations and set standards deserves support, not scorn.

webTitle: Downing St stays cool as Labour MPs seek review

fields.headline: Downing St stays cool as Labour MPs seek review
fields.standfirst:
Demands for an inquiry are likely to go unheeded

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Labour backbenchers called on Tony Blair to institute a review of the future role and structure of the royal family yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour backbenchers called on Tony Blair to institute a review of the future role and structure of the royal family yesterday.

Although Downing Street rejected as "total nonsense" suggestions that No 10 had encouraged Labour MPs to begin a debate on the future of the royalty, some reform-minded backbenchers could not resist thinking aloud about the issue.

The leftwinger Jeremy Corbyn said it was time for Britain to have an elected head of state.

Tony Wright urged a more cautious modernisation towards "the Scandinavian bicycling model".

Mr Wright, chairman of the Commons public administration select committee, told Radio 4's The World this Weekend: "My view is if we don't have something like a select committee, or a commission on the monarchy, it will be the end of the monarchy anyway. The magic, I'm afraid, has gone."

Clive Soley, chairman of the parliamentary Labour party, attacked the News of the World's intrusion, as did William Hague. But a complaint to the press complaints commission would almost certainly fail on public interest grounds.

To most Labour MPs and activists, the NoW's version of the Countess of Wessex's crude political analysis of "President Blair", his awful wife and "frightening" tax rises confirm what they instinctively knew: the shared class prejudices of hersuburban background and the royal establishment make them dislike Labour.

Mr Blair and pro-royal rari ties such as Peter Mandelson excepted, the feeling is reciprocated. But conspiracy theorists on the right have no evidence to support the claim that ministers with leftwing pasts like Stephen Byers and Kim Howells were told by No 10 to weigh in with their own critical comments.

"The royals don't need help from us; sometimes I think some of them must be closet republicans working on the inside," quipped a middle-ranking minister who calls himself a republican.

A senior colleague was more circumspect. "My own view is that I am politely indifferent to the monarchy. I would be more hostile if I honestly thought we could create a more acceptable alternative at the moment. But a constitutional presidency is not something the British public is gagging for."

Even before 1997, Downing Street often felt impatience with the self-destructive conduct in the House of Windsor. John Major played a role in "modernising" the monarchy's taxes.

But the Tories are culturally pro-monarchy in the way Labour has not been for a generation.

Mr Hague's remarks on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost were, therefore, supportive. "Is there anyone of us in public life who hasn't made a mistake? Well, here one person has made a mistake, and it is unfortunate that a member of the royal family has been tricked by a journalist."

Mr Blair differs from his friends at the Sun on abolition of the monarchy, one of Rupert Murdoch's hobby horses. The prime minister's "people's princess" stance helped save the palace from its own stubborn attitude towards Diana when she was killed in 1997.

He would like it to operate on a more down-to-earth scale and believes it is making progress towards concentrating on what some courtiers call the "core business" - a phrase that links the Queen Mother with Prince William and quietly distances bit players such as the Wessexes.

fields.headline: Councils refusing to reopen footpaths
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Many councils are ignoring scientific advice and refusing to reopen thousands of miles of footpaths to walkers, the Ramblers' Association said yesterday.
fields.body:
Many councils are ignoring scientific advice and refusing to reopen thousands of miles of footpaths to walkers, the Ramblers' Association said yesterday.

As ministers set off on the tourist trail to demonstrate that the countryside is open for business, the 250,000-strong association attacked blanket closures of scenic walkers' routes.

Nine out of 10 councils shut almost all their rural paths when emergency restrictions were first declared last month.

A survey of 69 councils found that eight out of 10 still have almost as many paths closed now.

Seven in 10 councils are expected to persist in blanket re strictions by the Easter weekend when the tourist season takes off.

Jacquetta Fewster, of the Ramblers' Association, said: "It is atrocious that these councils can so casually ignore scientific fact and destroy the livelihoods of thousands of local people in the process. These paths need to be open by Easter."

The walkers' charity described West Sussex, Lincolnshire, Buckinghamshire, East Sussex and Hertfordshire as among the "worst offenders" of the 171 councils with powers to close public rights of way.

Almost two thirds of people who were planning a countryside holiday over the Easter break have cancelled their trips due to foot and mouth, according to a separate survey.

A poll of 500 users of the NFU's Countryside website revealed a demand for clear, practical information about the options for holidaymakers.

David Hellard, of NFU Countryside, said: "The survey illustrates just how far-reaching an effect the outbreak is having on people's leisure activities."

fields.headline: The royal statements
fields.standfirst: Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The statements from Buckingham Palace and the Countess of Wessex in full.
fields.body:
The statement from Buckingham Palace:

The Queen has discussed issues arising from this week's media coverage with the Earl and Countess of Wessex.

Her Majesty accepts that despite the difficulties of recent days, both the earl and countess understandably want to try to pursue working careers and they have her full support in doing so.

It is not an easy option and they are breaking new ground, but it is right in this day and age that they should be allowed to do so.

In following careers they are always open to accusations of exploiting their royal status in pursuit of their own business interests. Both the earl and countess vigorously deny that they have deliberately set out to do so.

The Queen deplores the entrapment, subterfuge, innuendo and untruths to which [they] have been subjected in recent days.

The Queen recognises that there are and always have been real issues around ensuring and being seen to ensure that royal and business interests do not conflict where members of the royal family pursue their own careers.

Ways to address and avoid such potential conflicts of interest need to be recognised... and this will be done over the coming weeks.

"Whilst this is undertaken, the Countess of Wessex has suggested, and the Queen has agreed, that [she] should step aside as chairman of RJH, as the issues facing the company are considered."

The statement from the Countess of Wessex:

This has been a difficult time for me. I take very seriously the issues raised, and, naturally, regret any embarrassment above all to the Queen.

I am grateful for Her Majesty's support both on a personal level and for my being able to pursue a career.

I believe my overriding duty is to support the Queen and the monarchy.

I realise fully that I am in a privileged position, and I am conscious that my conduct must be above reproach.

I am deeply distressed by the carrying out of an entrapment operation on me and my business but I also much regret my own misjudgment in succumbing to that subterfuge.

I have discussed the situation with the Queen and I have decided to step aside as chairman of RJH while the issues raised by recent events are carefully considered.

In view of this experience I need a period of time to reassess my own role.

Over the past few days I have taken great comfort from the friendship and support of my colleagues at RJH and of our clients.

I feel an obligation to them, and I believe a way can be found for RJH to continue as a successful company.

Over the next few weeks the business will be restructured in order to allow this to happen.

webTitle: Sting that put the countess on the spot

fields.headline: Sting that put the countess on the spot
fields.standfirst:
Conversations cover sex, drugs and politics

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The publication of secretly taped conversations in which the Countess of Wessex and her business partner made indiscreet comments reveal opinions on everything from their own business practices to members of the royal family and public figures. By Rebecca Allison.
fields.body:
The publication of transcripts from a series of secretly taped conversations in which the Countess of Wessex and her business partner Murray Harkin made indiscreet and outspoken comments reveal opinions on everything from their own business practices to members of the royal family and public figures.

The conversations, in two separate meetings at London's Park Lane Hilton and Dorchester hotels with undercover journalists posing as a rich Arabs, begin with references to drugs and the legal status of cannabis.

Mr Harkin says the ban on cannabis is "crazy", adding: "We've got a client in Amsterdam... when people have been in the coffee shops there they have to throw it all away before they get on the plane to come back to England."

He admits: "I don't do lots of drugs, but you know, the odd line of coke I quite like and trying, you know, trying to find it, it's just a nightmare: America, apparently it's dead easy."

When asked if he has taken ecstasy, he replies: "Not for a couple of years. It was really terrible stuff... the problem with it is the after effects, it's like three or four days later."

The conversation about drugs is interspersed with a discussion on Thailand in which Mr Harkin recommends some "really sleazy" bars in Bangkok and then offers to organise a gathering of "nice boys" for his client in London.

He says: "I can invite some very interesting people... discreet nice gentlemen that he would like.

"How young does he like? Does he like Asian boys? And how young? Are we talking about 20, 21, 25, 28?"

Chat then apparently moves on to the cost of rent boys, with Mr Harkin confiding: "In India, I gave somebody like two weeks' pay."

Earlier, Mr Harkin is quizzed about the Earl of Wessex's sexuality, to which he replies: "There have been rumours for years about Edward. I'm a great believer that there's no smoke without fire... he's not what you expect."

When conversation turns to business Mr Harkin agrees with the suggestion that his partner gives special kudos to RJH's ventures in a similar way that Princess Diana's involvement in projects did, adding: "Except she's a lot more intelligent."

He suggests the countess might go to Dubai, and "there's potential for Edward as well", adding that they have already made a visit together: "Between you and me they went to one of our clients... they'd gone for the weekend. So again, it's like she's bought into it and she got Edward involved."

Discussing what the countess could do to promote clients, Mr Harkin explains: "We've got to be very careful... it's just being clever about it. If for instance the two of you were photographed together by the media in Dubai, it would not be a problem. Her doing the photo shoot would be. The way the photographs are, that's an advertising shot."

He then explains how the problem can be circumvented: "One easy way you may want to do that is to take over a press trip in which she takes the press, and at that point you make the announcement that she's going to be looking after your project. We do this all the time, Sophie and I."

webTitle: NoW editor hits back at critics

fields.headline: NoW editor hits back at critics
fields.standfirst:
Wade cites 'public interest'

Special report: future of the monarchy
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: News of the World editor Rebekah Wade launched a strong defence of her decision to publish the 'Sophie tapes' yesterday, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Rebekah Wade, editor of the News of the World, launched a strong defence of her decision to publish the "Sophie tapes" yesterday in an attempt to head off allegations that she might have broken the newspaper industry's code of conduct. In her statement yesterday the Queen spoke of "entrapment, subterfuge, innuendo and untruths".

Ms Wade hit back, arguing that there was a strong public interest defence for publishing the material, since it had generated massive debate.

The editors' code, administered by the press complaints commission, states: "Subterfuge can be justified only in the public interest and only when material cannot be obtained by any other means."

There is a clear definition of the public interest: exposing crime or a serious misdemeanour, protecting public health and safety, or preventing the public from being misled. Clearly, the News of the World would seek to invoke the first and possibly the third defence: drug-taking is a crime and Murray Harkin, the countess's business partner, admitted to having taken drugs in the past.

It could also be argued that Mr Harkin and the countess misled the public when they insisted publicly that her royal connections would not be used to promote the firm.

Ms Wade said in a statement: "Our methods were entirely legitimate in the circumstances. The disclosures that followed our inquiries have generated a major national debate.

"In my view, no one can possibly claim that the News of the World's investigation, which was conducted throughout in strict adherence to the PCC's code of practice, was not in the public interest."

Stuart Kuttner, managing editor of the paper, said he doubted that it would receive a complaint. But he acknowledged that there was what he described as "creative tension" between the palace and the media.

fields.headline: How the key players fared
fields.standfirst:
Affair has been a disaster for most of those involved - even the paper that got the story

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: By Stephen Bates and Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Sophie Wessex

The revelations emerging from the News of the World yesterday may not have been quite as damaging as predicted but this has been a disastrous week for Sophie, Countess of Wessex, calling into question her professional competence as a public relations executive as well as her common sense and discretion. They have also, temporarily at least, cost her control of her company and her career as a PR executive.

The countess was supposed to bring a new, modern career-girl business acumen to the royal family, with the added advantage of one versed in public relations skills, when she married the Queen's youngest son two years ago. Instead, the News of the World's sting operation revealed that she was prepared to sail close to the wind by trading on her royal associations in pursuit of a client, that she was happy to chatter away indiscreetly about sensitive political matters to someone she had only just met, and that she would bandy intimate matters about her husband's sexuality and her fertility even in a formal interview with the tabloid Sunday newspaper. Naff, naff, naff, as the Princess Royal might say.

Prince Edward

HRH the Earl of Wessex (as he likes to be known) has come out of the crisis little better than his wife. Although exasperated by the furore, and probably with Sophie's conduct, what has been most harmful to him has been the renewed media interest in his company, Ardent Films, and the couple's finances.

The fact that the affair has once more called into question Prince Edward's career pretensions and reopened questions about the monarchy itself may still be of lesser importance to him. But he will hardly have relished his wife's volunteered assertion that he is not gay, or that she may have to resort to IV fertilisation in order to conceive - perhaps the most toe-curlingly embarrassing things ever said on the record by a member of the royal family - being splashed all over the nation's most intrusive tabloid.

Although Ardent, which has run up debts of £1.9m in its eight-year existence, may be about to slide into profit, attention has once more been drawn to the prince's alleged use of his royal status to pursue potential business opportunities. Almost as embarrassing will have been the details of the couple's finances, showing them as barely adequate to meet the enormous running costs of their large Surrey mansion, Bagshot Park.

Simon Walker

The Queen's director of communications, Simon Walker, has had perhaps the most disastrous week of all. It has left him isolated at the palace and shunned by the press complaints commission. The decision to allow Sophie Wessex to try to buy off the News of the World with a formal interview must be among the most spectacular PR catastrophes of recent times. Walker, a well-regarded lobbyist in Brussels and competent manager of British Airways' public relations during the rocky period of its tailfin redesign, arrived at the palace on a two-year secondment only last September.

Of most concern will be the fact that he tried to be too clever by half in offering an interview and that he sat in on it while Sophie made her indiscreet remarks, then passed the interview for publication. Even more culpable was Walker's attempt to spin the palace out of the crisis by suggesting the PCC had been consulted about the strategy, provoking its chairman, Lord Wakeham, to sever relations. Walker is not likely to be forgiven for his part in landing the palace in its biggest public relations disaster for years and then not being able to contain it. And, unlike Sophie, he is expendable.

News of the World

While the full Sophiegate story was finally splashed over Britain's best-selling tabloid yesterday, it was the end of almost a month of editorial hand-wringing that resulted in the substance of the story appearing in two rival Sunday papers last week. The episode was highly embarrassing for the editor, Rebekah Wade.

Wade, it is understood, felt hamstrung by legal advice - Buckingham Palace had taken out an injunction against the former employee of RJH, the countess's PR firm - and pressure from some executives. But after a week in which rival newspapers appeared to get more details of the "fake sheikh" tapes, the paper had no choice but to run the transcripts in full.

The episode has embarrassed many News of the World staff, who believe that Wade should have run the full story in the first place. Mazher Mahmood, the undercover reporter who masterminded the sting, was understood to have been furious that his story was buried in favour of the official interview with Sophie.

Murray Harkin

The immediate professional future of the PR partner of Sophie Wessex is in tatters. Harkin, 36, was forced to resign as a director of the company after yesterday's revelations. In other circumstances, he might have been able to ride out the storm. Indeed, some colleagues in the industry were rather surprised that he appeared to think that cocaine was not easily available in London, and far from providing a coterie of rent boys for the "Middle Eastern businessman", he appeared to reel off a list of gay bars in London and suggested what appeared to amount to little more than a dinner party with some of his friends. But his association with the countess, and the sheer weight of media pressure, meant that even such anodyne comments made his position untenable.

Press complaints commission

The newspaper industry watchdog was drawn into the controversy when Buckingham Palace suggested that it had come up with the idea for the officially sanctioned interview with the countess. Lord Wakeham, the PCC chairman, was furious. Simon Walker, the palace director of communications, was held to have been responsible for the fiasco and was cut out of the loop: all future dealings between the PCC and Buckingham Palace will be made through Sir Robin Janvrin, the Queen's private secretary.

fields.headline: Hypocrisy gibe at motherhood activist
fields.trailText: A national campaigner for full-time motherhood is facing accusations of hypocrisy after deciding to stand as a Conservative parliamentary candidate in the general election.
fields.body:
A national campaigner for full-time motherhood is facing accusations of hypocrisy after deciding to stand as a Conservative parliamentary candidate in the general election.

Alison Holley, who has spent the last 12 years at home with her three children aged between six and 12, is contesting the Labour-held seat of Bassetlaw in Derbyshire.

Mrs Holley, a personnel manager before having children, is a committee member of Full-Time Mothers, a campaign group aiming to "promote understanding of the child's need for a full-time mother". She has accused feminists of "trying to do away with the vital bond between mother and child".

She wants to become an MP at a time when campaigners are increasingly critical that "family friendly" modernisation promised for Westminster has failed to materialise.

Even after initial attempts to reform Commons hours, MPs are still obliged to be at Westminster from Monday to Thursday, with some Friday sittings.

Mrs Holley said she would use a parliamentary seat to fight for a better deal for full-time mothers, who she believes are neglected by policy makers. She acknowledged she would miss her own children if she were to win the seat, but said her husband would leave work to look after them.

Mrs Holley initially stood down from the Bassetlaw list in 1997 citing a desire to spend more time at home. In a letter to the Daily Telegraph in 1998, she explained her decision, writing: "The reason is nothing to do with policies or leadership. It is quite simply that, as the mother of three small children, I feel I already have a full-time job."

Lorna Fitzsimons, chairwoman of the backbench group of women Labour MPs, accused Mrs Holley of hypocrisy in supporting a party which has few policies to increase parents' choices in balancing home and work.

webTitle: Blair rejigs manifesto to allay fears of anticlimax

fields.headline: Blair rejigs manifesto to allay fears of anticlimax
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his senior colleagues are engaged in last-minute changes to Labour's election manifesto to prevent it becoming an anticlimax because most key policy pledges have already been announced.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his senior colleagues are engaged in last-minute changes to Labour's election manifesto to prevent it becoming an anticlimax because most key policy pledges have already been announced.

If the May 3 timetable for the election had not been derailed by the foot and mouth crisis Labour's manifesto, and those of its rivals, would probably be being published this week.

Labour's tactical problem lies in its decision two years ago to avoid a "big bang" manifesto this time and to set out its long-term plans well ahead of polling day, as the plans for crime, transport, NHS and education have been.

However, a minister said: "The manifesto will be jam-packed with pledges. That is what party supporters have told John Prescott they want during his 'get ready' tours of the country."

The delay has given Blair's team time to redraft and strengthen the dominant themes which include now familiar commitments to social and economic progress through better public services and wealth-creating attacks on poverty and poor skills.

It has not been finally decided whether to include a 2001 version of Labour's five early pledges, the eye-catching commitments made in 1997 on class sizes, NHS waiting lists, youth crime, unemployment and the economy.

A Labour policymaker admitted last night: "People forget that they were made in 1997 to show we were not a tax-and-spend party, that we could do these things without spending money. It was the product of polling, advertising and campaigning and it worked in the campaign. The problem is they weren't very good policies."

That is an admission that management priorities were distorted in schools and hospitals to get class sizes below 30 for five- to seven-year-olds and to cut waiting lists to 100,000 below the Tory inheritance.

Most ministers expect there to be pledges, but less prominent in the campaign now the party has a proven track record. Pledges would include such obvious priorities as extra teachers, police and medical staff.

In the battle to justify talk of a radical second term - an article of faith to activists who believe Labour has been too cautious so far - there are still controversies over what goes into the manifesto.

Harriet Harman, former social security secretary, is lobbying hard for women who want to return to work after childbirth to be given a legal flexible working right to do so.
