Harriet Harman, former social security secretary, is lobbying hard for women who want to return to work after childbirth to be given a legal flexible working right to do so.

webTitle: Mega-casinos on UK horizon if calls for liberal gambling laws get official backing

fields.headline: Mega-casinos on UK horizon if calls for liberal gambling laws get official backing
fields.standfirst: Blackpool bets on rule change with plan for gaming hotels
fields.trailText: Blackpool bets on rule change with plan for gaming hotels.
fields.body:
Las Vegas-style casinos are expected to come a step closer to Britain when a government review to be released this summer backs a fundamental rethink of gambling laws.

Sir Alan Budd, former chief economic adviser to the Treasury and now provost of Queen's College, Oxford, is heading the inquiry. He is expected to conclude the laws are out of date and that restrictions on live entertainment inside casinos and on advertising should be relaxed.

Britain's casinos are governed by restrictive legislation introduced in 1968 after several scandals involving Mayfair casinos. It regulates how casinos can advertise, restricts the hours of opening and obliges new members to go through a 24 hour "cooling off" period before they can play.

The gambling review, according to a leak to this week's Economist, is expected to recommend that a single regulatory board be set up to control casinos, bingo clubs, horse racing and the new industry of spread betting.

Only the national lottery, which is already covered by the national lottery commission, would remain outside its aegis. Changes to the lottery are specifically outside the remit of the official review.

The changing face of gambling in Britain is exemplified by the launch today of a proposal by Blackpool Challenge Partnership to build six Las Vegas-style hotel casinos on Lancashire's faded golden mile.

The £1bn regeneration scheme will be backed by the tourism minister, Janet Anderson, but its promoters are gambling that the Home Office review recommends a fundamental relaxation of the law. It is expected to report in June, after the election.

Blackpool's bid is modelled on Atlantic City in New Jersey, and the first of its mega-gaming hotels is scheduled to be Pharaoh's Palace, with pyramids, sphinxes and obelisks, to be built by 2006.

Until recently, casino advertising was banned, and even now it is restricted to discreet ads in the classified columns of magazines and newspapers. The kind of mass billboard advertising used to promote Atlantic City and Las Vegas across the US is still banned.

Also prohibited is staging live entertainment and providing alcoholic drinks at gaming tables. While American and European casinos boast row after row of one-armed bandits, only 10 slot machines are allowed in each British casino and only eight games are allowed, including blackjack, roulette, craps and poker.

Ministers are believed to acknowledge that the current regulation is overbureaucratic and uncompetitive. Despite Gordon Brown's background as the "son of the manse", the chancellor's decision to scrap betting tax in his Budget is also expected to lead to a more liberal gambling environment.

Any further relaxation of the laws is expected to be accompanied by an expansion in treatment facilities for problem gamblers, tough controls on under-age gambling and measures to keep the industry free from money laundering operations and infiltration by organised crime gangs.

When the review was launched in December 1999, the junior Home Office minster, Mike O'Brien, said that in the 30 years since the current gambling laws came into effect social attitudes had changed, and the law was fast being overtaken by technological developments.

Betting figures

 Global gambling totals £986bn a year, £7bn in UK

 35m visited Las Vegas in 2000 (up from 21m in 1990); Atlantic City had 33m visitors

 Nine of 10 largest hotels in world are in Vegas: The Bellagio, a £1bn copy of Lake Como, has 36 floors, 3,025 rooms and 400 suites

 In 1998, Americans spent more on gambling than on recorded music, theme parks, video games, spectator sports, and movie tickets combined

 An estimated 5.3m Americans are gambling addicts, and 300,000 in UK

 300,000 Britons a year visit Las Vegas, more than from any other country in Europe

 1m work in gambling in US; average wage is $26,000

 There are 116 UK casinos; the 23 in London account for 70% of takings. Total "drop" (money exchanged for chips) in 1999-2000 was £3.1bn.

 72% of UK adults gambled in some way in 1999

Esther Addley

webTitle: Roy Hattersley: I too was Maxwell's plaything

fields.headline: I too was Maxwell's plaything
fields.standfirst:
It's not just the City that was duped. That man had chutzpah. Who can doubt he has talked his way into heaven

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It's not just the City that was duped. That man had chutzpah. Who can doubt he has talked his way into heaven, writes Roy Hattersley.
fields.body:
How, city commentators asked last week, did Robert Maxwell get away with so much villainy for so long? Part of the answer, as demonstrated in this paper, is that the city institutions were supine and the banks venal. But there is one aspect of the explanation which, understandably enough, has been neglected. It concerns Maxwell's personality. His chutzpah was invincible. I have reason to know.

Early one morning - about six months after I had broken the news to Neil Kinnock that Maxwell had secretly bought the Mirror - I was invited to the offices of that newspaper to discuss "writing a regular column". To my surprise, I was ushered into the presence of the proprietor who made me an immediate offer. What, I asked, does the editor think about this? "It's none of his business," Maxwell replied. Then, noting my consternation, he added: "He'll be delighted when I tell him."

Perhaps it was my reaction to the demonstration of Maxwell's management technique that ruined my chances. But whatever the reason, the subject was swiftly changed to the Mirror Group's devotion to the Labour party. To demonstrate the close connection, no less than four Labour peers - all of them Maxwell employees - were paraded before me. "See," said Maxwell, "I'm the only one without a title." Hoping to be rude, I told him: "You'll want one before long." He was still denying any such ambition when, true to my flirtation with tabloid journalism, I made an excuse and left.

I heard no more about the Mirror column. Indeed, I heard no more of the proprietor until - many months later - I was telephoned at home by one of his minions. Would I take a call from Robert Maxwell? Of course I would. The minion telephoned several times more to make sure that I was still available and then the great man himself boomed down the line. "We were just talking about you," he said with absolute conviction. "Do you remember when you told me that I was after a peerage?" He gave a stage laugh and added: "Very cheeky!" Then he rang off.

Two days later a journalist phoned me from the high court. Maxwell, giving evidence in his libel case against Private Eye, had announced that I had once offered him a peerage - a fact which, he explained, had been confirmed with me earlier in the week. Two other Labour politicians - both of them, like me, in no position to influence the honours list - were also cited as would-be benefactors. They, however, were dead.

My first instinct was to issue what is known in the trade as an angry denial. Wiser counsels prevailed. Persuaded to take the advice of Derry Irvine, I learnt that to contradict evidence in the way which I proposed might be regarded as a contempt of court. Proper procedure required me to offer myself as a witness to Maxwell's adversaries. Unattracted by that prospect, I telephoned the Mirror. To my astonishment, Maxwell came on the line at once.

He accepted, without qualification, that he had given the jury the wrong impression but, he explained, he had been badly disturbed by the mention of Adolf Eichmann who had been responsible for the death of several Maxwell relatives. He would gladly make a correction under cross-examination next day. An American student - not doing much in my office - was dispatched to the high court. He returned with the news that Maxwell had completed his evidence without making the retraction.

I telephoned the Mirror again. Maxwell, I was told, was not available. As I began to argue, there was a rasping noise as he snatched the receiver from his secretary's hand. Again he pleaded guilty as charged. Then he went on to explain his second failure to keep the promise. Just as he was about to clear my name, a piece of paper had been passed to him. It contained the message that a helicopter which he owned had come down in the North sea. After that, he was too worried about the safety of the crew to think about anything else. Knowing when I was licked, I decided that all I could do to protect my reputation was spread the story about.

I spread it so widely that Tom Bower picked it up when he was preparing to write his Maxwell biography. Not surprisingly, it became one of the passages to which Maxwell took exception when he attempted to suppress the book's publication. As the hearing of his injunction approached, one of his employees approached me with a request. Would I sign an affidavit saying that the whole story was invention? I declined - adding to the pompous stuff about truth and integrity as I could not imagine why Maxwell should expect me to do him a favour. The young man came back to me with the news that he had relayed my message to his chief. "Bob," he said, "hopes you'll do it out of friendship." Who can doubt that he has talked his way into heaven?

fields.headline: Best if the Americans apologise now - soon the Chinese could rule the US
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: China
fields.trailText: Chinese Americans are bracing themselves for a bruising bout of Sinophobia. Dianne Feinstein, the senior senator from California, was unusual in rushing to apologise for the EP-3 incident, declaring herself "deeply sorry".
fields.body:
Chinese Americans are bracing themselves for a bruising bout of Sinophobia. Dianne Feinstein, the senior senator from California, was unusual in rushing to apologise for the EP-3 incident. The former mayor of San Francisco declared herself "deeply sorry". Her contrition is explained by last week's census which shows a concentrated mass of Chinese Americans around the Bay Area.

Feinstein is one of the few American politicians who has ever had to take account of the interests of her Asian electors. Rush Limbaugh, the voice of the people (and the highest-paid news commentator in the world), suffers no such constraints on his constitutional right to Sinophobia.

He too, he says, will join with Senator Feinstein. Apologise, that is, for his government's doing nothing in the face of China's enslaving millions of its population, massacring thousands of students in Tiananmen Square, perverting American presidential elections (by illegal campaign financing) and stealing the crown jewels of America's nuclear weapons technology.

And now China dares hold two dozen patriotic American Navy spies captive.

There is yellow ribbon fluttering on trees all over the US and red rage in the chatrooms. The following, posted by "joh_jizum" on the Yahoo board, catches the belligerent mood of cyber-vox populi: "Blockade their ports with submarines. Blow up their dams with cruise missiles. It is time to take the gloves off. Give them pain and get our plane."

At the (mainly) scientific university where I teach in the US, some 30% of the students are Asian, about 80% of them of Chinese extraction. The figures run that high in most top-ranked educational institutions in the Pacific Rim. An intellectual elite is emerging.

In Silicon Valley, dominated as it is by young entrepreneurs and electrical engineers, that elite already controls the most dynamic sector of the American economy. Is America ready for the social-political consequences? Will it make room at the top table for Chinese-Americans? (Can you, for instance, name three famous Americans from that ethnic group? Amy Tan, and who else?)

My colleague James Lee makes the points - wearily familiar to Asian Americans - that the other 90% of the population never seems to take on board. There is no yellow peril. The American immigration authorities have a website on which they post a league table of the Illegal Alien Resident Population of the US. Chinese illegals don't even make the first 20. They are lower than the undocumented Irish, Polish and Canadians. No peril there.

Limbaugh's virulent allegations about espionage allude to the recent case of Wen Ho Lee. A Chinese American, Dr Lee worked at the Los Alamos laboratory. He was accused of selling his country's nuclear secrets to the People's Republic which, it was feared, would promptly sell them on to Antichrist Saddam, who would start world war three.

Lee was held in solitary confinement for months. FBI agents provided false testimony to keep him locked up. Of the 59 charges against Lee, all but one was dropped - to which he made formal acquiescence. Negligent handling of classified materials (an offence even directors of the CIA have confessed committing). Pure Dreyfus.

What Dr Lee was guilty of was being American Chinese in a paranoid season. Last week, the New York Times put together a table of major espionage in America since the second world war. The list was dominated by the former Soviet Union, its satellites, and (recently) Israel. No Chinese.

It is, of course, proven that the People's Republic greased palms in Washington with the aim of getting "normalised" trade relations. But, however you look at it, the Chinese lobby (representing a fifth of world's population) is nowhere near as powerful as other interest groups in Washington. The British and the Israelis, for example.

The roots of American Sinophobia go ineradicably deep. The pioneering Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 was directed solely against them. The yellow man was the archetypal outsider. He still is.

A relative of one of the captive airmen, Jason Hanser, is reported as saying: "I have a feeling the Chinese will pull something sneaky." That word says it all. And, if it's true, Americans have a lot more to worry about than losing a plane. In 10 years' time, if merit has anything to do with it, their sneaky Chinese compatriots will be running the country.

fields.headline: The Kilshaws' surprising legacy
fields.standfirst: The couple at the centre of the internet twins case have made the issue of adoption a national talking point - and made legal reforms a political priority, writes Linda Steele
fields.trailText: The couple at the centre of the internet twins case have made the issue of adoption a national talking point - and made legal reforms a political priority, writes Linda Steele.
fields.body:
The whole unpalatable saga of the internet twins, whose future has been decided in the high court today, has wider repercussions for adoption in this country.

The case brought the issue of adoption into the nation's homes. Everyone had a view on whether or not Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the couple who paid an £8,200 fee to adopt the children in the US, were fit to be parents. Lurid tabloid tales of their past behaviour, slovenly housekeeping and seeming need to court the media did much to undermine their case in the public mind.

It raised the spectre of a market in children as people became aware that, whatever the facts in this particular case, there was a trade in infants over the net.

"It's immoral and should be illegal," said Michelle Elliott, director of Kidscape children's charity, summing up a national mood. "The idea we can buy and sell babies to the highest bidder over the internet as if it is an auction cannot be in any child's interests."

"It's an appalling way of placing children; it's back to the bad old days where people paid under the table for babies. But I think there are enough unscrupulous people and enough desperate parents that it will always be there. People will find a way of doing this, so there has to be an emphasis on immigration and proper papers for the baby when they're brought in at Heathrow.

However, Ms Elliott said that the internet is not to blame. "It's a shame because the internet can be a force for good and can put you in touch with agencies that do have children's interests at heart. The point is: how do you regulate it?"

And the need for regulation has been plain for all to see. The appearance on the Oprah Winfrey show of the Kilshaws and their American rivals for "ownership" of the twins, Richard and Vickie Allen, made the whole affair seem more like a game show than a process to decide on the future of two tiny, vulnerable human beings.

Since the case hit the headlines, "the dangers of unregulated adoption services are more clearly painted and the intercountry aspects are seen as important", points out Association of Directors of Social Services president Moira Gibb.

Previously, if anyone had thought about overseas adoption at all, it might have been because of an occasional article in the press saying - rightly - how hard it is to adopt babies in this country. One that perhaps told a tale of unhelpful, ideologically driven social workers preventing willing and loving people from giving needy children in this country a home, and perhaps telling of a couple who were "forced" to go abroad.

While there are almost certainly cases of potential adopters driven to distraction by bureaucracy and the adoption process isn't an easy ride, there's another side to the tale. "There's been ill-informed media comment implying that people were driven to adopt [abroad] because of the negative views of social services to adoption," says Ms Gibb. "The facts - about how many children are available, how long they wait and the shortage of adoptive parents - were only covered by a few."

And the facts are that most children in this country who are adopted are older, may have physical, mental and behavioural difficulties and troubled pasts. More children are being adopted from care - but these are often not easy adoptions for either the children or the recipient families and social services have a duty to ensure the needs of the children being placed - not the adults wanting to adopt - are paramount.

However, while adoption may have been topical, it's unlikely that the case will dramatically change the public perception of social services. Flintshire social services were lucky to get a metaphorical pat on the back rather than a slating when they took the twins, Belinda and Kimberley, away from the Kilshaws. Usually, images of social workers taking children into care provoke cries of know-it-all professionals breaking up families. But, in this case, the family had little, if any, public sympathy.

But Ms Gibb doesn't think that'll change the stereotype of interfering social workers. They will still be "damned if they do [intervene] and damned if they don't", she says. "The whole issue of intervening in family life is fraught with difficulties. And, inevitably, the public don't have the full facts."

The biggest effect has undoubtedly been on the law. Ministers were rattled. An adoption bill - which almost certainly would have had to take its place in the queue of post-election legislation - has been brought out, following an exchange in the House of Commons over the internet twins.

While it focuses on matters at home, the bill constitutes the biggest overhaul of adoption law in 25 years.

In terms of international adoption, the main effect has undoubtedly been to speed up the implementation of a recent law on adopting from overseas.

Until the Kilshaws popped up in every tabloid on every TV screen, there was no timetable for implementing the Adoption (Intercountry Aspects) Act 1999. The act makes it unlawful for a UK resident to bring a child into the country in order to adopt them, unless a recognised agency (such as a local authority social services department) has carried out a full assessment of the prospective parents.

But bringing the law into effect has become a political priority. From the end of this month, it'll be a criminal offence to bring in a child for the purposes of adoption without approval from a recognised adoption agency, punishable by fines of up to £5,000, or a prison sentence of up to three months, or both. (As it happens, the Kilshaws probably wouldn't have fallen foul of this new piece of legislation, as they had obtained an interim adoption order within the US, which is currently recognised under UK law.)

So, for months, the Kilshaws have been a source of fun (and worse). Today's reports of Mrs Kilshaw being led from the court, screaming abuse, will add to their notoriety. And the judge has decided that it would "not be in the welfare interests of the twins for them to be returned to Mr and Mrs Kilshaw".

But, as they fade from public view, it seems the couple will have a surprising legacy. Their shocking and unsuccessful and attempt to add to their family has done children awaiting adoption a big favour.

"It's an appalling way of placing children; it's back to the bad old days where people paid under the table for babies. But I think there are enough unscrupulous people and enough desperate parents that it will always be there. People will find a way of doing this, so there has to be an emphasis on immigration and proper papers for the baby when they're brought in at Heathrow. However, Ms Elliott said that the internet is not to blame. "It's a shame because the internet can be a force for good and can put you in touch with agencies that do have children's interests at heart. The point is: how do you regulate it?" And the need for regulation has been plain for all to see. The appearance on the Oprah Winfrey show of the Kilshaws and their American rivals for "ownership" of the twins, Richard and Vickie Allen, made the whole affair seem more like a game show than a process to decide on the future of two tiny, vulnerable human beings. Since the case hit the headlines, "the dangers of unregulated adoption services are more clearly painted and the intercountry aspects are seen as important", points out Association of Directors of Social Services president Moira Gibb. Previously, if anyone had thought about overseas adoption at all, it might have been because of an occasional article in the press saying - rightly - how hard it is to adopt babies in this country. One that perhaps told a tale of unhelpful, ideologically driven social workers preventing willing and loving people from giving needy children in this country a home, and perhaps telling of a couple who were "forced" to go abroad. While there are almost certainly cases of potential adopters driven to distraction by bureaucracy and the adoption process isn't an easy ride, there's another side to the tale. "There's been ill-informed media comment implying that people were driven to adopt [abroad] because of the negative views of social services to adoption," says Ms Gibb. "The facts - about how many children are available, how long they wait and the shortage of adoptive parents - were only covered by a few." And the facts are that most children in this country who are adopted are older, may have physical, mental and behavioural difficulties and troubled pasts. More children are being adopted from care - but these are often not easy adoptions for either the children or the recipient families and social services have a duty to ensure the needs of the children being placed - not the adults wanting to adopt - are paramount. However, while adoption may have been topical, it's unlikely that the case will dramatically change the public perception of social services. Flintshire social services were lucky to get a metaphorical pat on the back rather than a slating when they took the twins, Belinda and Kimberley, away from the Kilshaws. Usually, images of social workers taking children into care provoke cries of know-it-all professionals breaking up families. But, in this case, the family had little, if any, public sympathy. But Ms Gibb doesn't think that'll change the stereotype of interfering social workers. They will still be "damned if they do [intervene] and damned if they don't", she says. "The whole issue of intervening in family life is fraught with difficulties. And, inevitably, the public don't have the full facts." The biggest effect has undoubtedly been on the law. Ministers were rattled. An adoption bill - which almost certainly would have had to take its place in the queue of post-election legislation - has been brought out, following an exchange in the House of Commons over the internet twins. While it focuses on matters at home, the bill constitutes the biggest overhaul of adoption law in 25 years. In terms of international adoption, the main effect has undoubtedly been to speed up the implementation of a recent law on adopting from overseas. Until the Kilshaws popped up in every tabloid on every TV screen, there was no timetable for implementing the Adoption (Intercountry Aspects) Act 1999. The act makes it unlawful for a UK resident to bring a child into the country in order to adopt them, unless a recognised agency (such as a local authority social services department) has carried out a full assessment of the prospective parents. But bringing the law into effect has become a political priority. From the end of this month, it'll be a criminal offence to bring in a child for the purposes of adoption without approval from a recognised adoption agency, punishable by fines of up to £5,000, or a prison sentence of up to three months, or both. (As it happens, the Kilshaws probably wouldn't have fallen foul of this new piece of legislation, as they had obtained an interim adoption order within the US, which is currently recognised under UK law.) So, for months, the Kilshaws have been a source of fun (and worse). Today's reports of Mrs Kilshaw being led from the court, screaming abuse, will add to their notoriety. And the judge has decided that it would "not be in the welfare interests of the twins for them to be returned to Mr and Mrs Kilshaw". But, as they fade from public view, it seems the couple will have a surprising legacy. Their shocking and unsuccessful and attempt to add to their family has done children awaiting adoption a big favour.

fields.headline: Watch out
fields.standfirst: Glyndebourne Grange Park Opera should soon get the home it deserves in one of our finest country houses, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Glyndebourne Grange Park Opera should soon get the home it deserves in one of our finest country houses, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
In 1804, aged 26 and just back from a tour of Greece and Asia Minor, the young Cambridge scholar William Wilkins was commissioned to refashion the Grange, a handsome late 17th-century Hampshire country house, in the latest Grecian mode. He performed his task admirably. Today, although largely abandoned and in a state of pleasing decay, the Grange remains a startling and wonderful sight: here, in a quiet English valley, is a rural acropolis, a touch of ancient Greece.

The Grange is one of the finest neoclassical houses in Britain but, until recently, also one of the most forgotten. It is Wilkins's best work; his National Gallery on Trafalgar Square seems weak-kneed compared with this muscular design, set in some 650 acres of landscaped gardens and woods at Northington.

The house emerged from long years of isolation in 1998 when it became the summer home of the newly founded and critically acclaimed Grange Park Opera. In the summer season, its noble Doric portico has been flanked by colourful Indian tents and resounded to the sounds of singers, orchestras and popping champagne corks. There are 20 indoor performances each summer, attended by some 8,000 people in total.

Grange Park Opera is one of three rural English opera companies, the others being Glyndebourne (founded in 1934) and the younger Garsington Opera (1988), of which Wasfi Kani, founder of Grange Park Opera, was once chief executive. Now Kani wants to expand opera at the Grange and is seeking planning permission to install a subtle new auditorium tucked away at the back of Wilkins's masterpiece.

The new works, designed by Studio E Architects, will cost £2m. The horseshoe-shaped auditorium, sans fly-tower, will be sunk four metres into the ground, and seat 500. Its design is based on Wilkins's own horseshoe plan, which you can still see at the theatre he built at Bury St Edmunds.

The idea is that the audience will sit on faded old velvet seats under six grandiose chandeliers where the theatre is now in the Picture Gallery. This was rebuilt in about 1890 from the Orangery designed by CR Cockerell (architect of the Graeco-Roman Ashmolean Museum, Oxford).

In the new design, they will look through what is now the north wall of the gallery into a new building containing stage, wings and a new orchestra pit. This will be contemporary in style, but hidden demurely behind a re-creation of a wing designed by Robert Smirke (of British Museum fame) in 1817 but later demolished. The wing will be used for storing scenery as well as providing a passage for performers, who change in the basements of the main house.

From a strictly architectural perspective, the wing will pull the composition of the Grange together: at the moment the Picture Gallery is detached from the main body of the house, which has never seemed right.

The interior of the Grange is all but empty, decoration and detail stripped away over the years. During the summer, opera-goers picnic on the lawns or in the grand, empty rooms of this curious monument to the architectural fashions of a well-travelled and flamboyant Regency.

One of the best things about this project is that neither the opera chaps nor the architects want to undermine the Grange's magical, gently haunting quality by making the new works too swish and smart.

The new auditorium will be romantic and just a bit wobbly - not structurally, of course, but aesthetically. As for the new stage-wings/orchestra-pit extension, this will be clad in soft brick and green timber, merging into the fabric of the Grange like moss does with old brick.

The happily low-key project will let the Grange come back to life as slowly as it faded from the 1930s. The opera company has been granted a lease until 2018 by present owner Lord Ashburton (John Baring). The idea is not to be too ambitious (who now remembers the loudly trumpeted scheme to build a rural opera house at Compton Verney?) but to let opera take root, if not naturally - there's nothing natural about opera - then aria by aria, act by act.

This seems appropriate because the history of this extraordinary house is as complex as the libretto of an 18th-century Italian opera. It changed its glamorous disguises with impunity in its first 250 years. Built between 1664 and 1673, it started life as the red-brick and Portland stone country seat of Sir Robert Henley, Lord Chancellor and 1st Earl of Northington. He sold it to the Drummond banking family in 1787; it was then leased from time to time to George IV's "sisters" (hemhem) and sold it on to Alexander Baring shortly after its Grecian transfiguration.

Changes came thick and fast during the 19th century. In 1933 it was sold to the millionaire industrialist Charles Wallach, who made his fortune selling medicinal paraffin to Edwardian ladies with dicky tummies. He lived in a solitary wing after the second world war, by which time the house had been knocked about a bit by US soldiers billeted here. No one has lived in the house since Wallach's death in 1964.

John Baring bought The Grange soon after and various ruined bits were demolished. In 1975 he brought in English Heritage as the Grange's guardian and the house was made watertight. This summer it will echo to the sound of Cosi Fan Tutte, I Capuleti e I Montecchi and Fortunio, but probably not too many sheep, which always enhance the look of English country houses.

David Lloyd Jones, speaking for Studio E Architects, describes the Grange plans as "bespoke reversible building". This is a nice conceit; what it means is that, at no vast cost, when the lease runs out and if no one wishes to renew it, the new works can be taken down and the house left to fall back into its long postwar after-dinner sleep.

But for now - if Wasfi Kani raises the money and English Heritage approves - the Grange will have been brought out of the land of neglect and into the nymphs-and-shepherds Arcadia it was meant to represent. This summer, foot and mouth permitting, go and see, and even hear - if you can afford a seat - this great survivor for yourself.

· Grange Park Opera's summer season starts on June 14 with Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutte. Box office: 01420 565690.

fields.headline: Picks of the week
fields.trailText: If youre only going to see one thing this week
fields.body:
If youre only going to see one thing this week

Waterboys, Friday

His hat was big, his music was even bigger. Mike Scott, wild-eyed shaman and dreamer  all right, hippy  slept out much of the 90s with under-publicised solo efforts, but he has returned to splendidly over-egg his massive musical pudding. His latest LP, My Love Is A Rock In The Weary Land, is apparently a response to London, how he responds to Maidstone, meanwhile, may be more emotive still. Soul Café, 110 Week Street, Maidstone (01622-751415) 7.30pm, £17.50.

Pop

Monday: Muse

With Muse, it's not so much a question of "sing when you're winning" as "squeal in an alarmingly high voice when you're winning". And winning, the west-country three-piece undoubtedly are. Their records remain daft, but live, evidently, this is their domain. University Of East Anglia, Earlham Road, Norwich (01603-508050) 7.30pm, £10.50.

Tuesday: Dido

Carefully synchronised with the release of Eminem's Stan, Dido has risen on the back of something very interesting indeed, with something not especially interesting at all. Her music's a lightly folky, mildly clubby sort of thing  if that's your dinner party, rave on. The Academy, Dale End, Birmingham (0870-903 2222) 7.30pm, £12.

Wednesday: Shed 7

Shed 7 are the underdogs who roll on, but will not roll over. Genuine adversity has recently befallen them: being dropped by their record company, the departure of their lead guitarist, and the use of one of their songs on an advert for Link mobile phone warehouse, but to them this is all in the job description. Dorking Halls, Reigate Road, Dorking (01306-881717) 8pm, £12-£14.

Thursday: Autechre

Autechre's music is highly structured, disciplined and difficult, constructed on intellectual lines much more than hedonistic ones. Still, harsh sounds for scratched chins and egg heads. New Trinity Centre, Trinity Road, St Phillips, Bristol (0117-9299008), 8pm, £11.
John Robinson

Classical

Monday: Il Trovatore

It's a bit like that television programme where the director of ICI has to go and mix paints for a week: Anthony Payne, general director of English National Opera, has abandoned his office for the daunting task of staging a new production of Verdi's Il Trovatore. Payne appears to relish this rare chance of working at "the coal face of production". London Coliseum, St Martins Lane, London WC2 (020-7632 8300) 7.30pm, £3-£52.50.

Tuesday: Tear And Lill

Not a new comedy duo but a joint recital by two of our most distinguished musicians, tenor Robert Tear and pianist John Lill, including songs by Britten and the Appassionata Sonata. The Concert Hall, Blagrave St, Reading (0118-960 6060) 7.30pm, £14.50 & £16.50.

Thursday: Passion Time

Last year the 250th anniversary of Bach's death prompted many choirs and orchestras to step up their performances of choral masterpieces such as the Passions. This year there are if anything even more Passions to choose from in Holy Week. Here the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra shows true dedication (and considerable stamina) by offering two consecutive performances of the St Matthew, the second on Good Friday. Sakari Oramo conducts this great masterpiece with soloists that include Rufus Muller as the Evangelist and Paul Whelan as Christus. Symphony Hall, Broad Street, Birmingham (0121-780 3333) 7pm, £6-£32.50.

County Youth

First of two youth orchestra concerts at the Wiltshire Music Centre: tonight the Wiltshire and Swindon Youth Orchestra play Delius, de Falla, and Sibelius, followed on Saturday by the Somerset County Youth Orchestra with a programme that includes Elgar's Enigma Variations. Wiltshire Music Centre, Ashley Road, Bradford-on-Avon (01225-860100) 7.30pm, £8, concs £6.
Christopher Lambton

Theatre

Fourteen Songs, Two Weddings And A Funeral

Bollywood comes to the stage with Tamasha's delightful musical featuring romance, comedy, melodrama, tears and song. It is impossible not to enjoy yourself at this heartfelt, witty and imaginative evening. Birmingham Rep, Broad Street, Birmingham (0121-236 4455) Tue-Fri 7.30pm, Sat 4pm, 8pm, Thurs mat 2.30pm, £5-£16.

Coriolanus

Will it be a hat trick for the Tobacco Factory whose productions of Lear and Measure For Measure have been models of clear, simple storytelling that brings Shakespeare alive? It is almost a sure thing that Andrew Hilton will pull it off with this tale of a soldier at war with himself. The Tobacco Factory, Raleigh Road, Bedminster, Bristol (0117-902 0344) 7.30pm, Sat mat 2.30pm, £9-£15.

The Lieutenant Of Inishmore

Who knocked "Mad Padraig's" cat over on a lonely road and was it an accident? The RSC don their Irish accents to premiere the latest slice of Irish life seen through the satirical eye of Martin McDonagh. The Other Place, Waterside, Stratford Upon Avon (01789-403403) Wed-Sat 7.30pm, Sat mat 1.30pm, £10.

Amy's View

Art, theatre and politics are the subjects of David Hare's 1997 success.Susannah York plays Esme, a painter's widow and successful actress who in the course of the play loses everything but her talent. The play sets up a debate by pitting Esme against a former theatre critic and media hustler. New Theatre, Park Place, Cardiff (029-2087 8889) Tue-Sat 7.30pm, Thurs and Sat mat 3pm, £7-£19.
Lyn Gardner

Exhibitions

At Home With Art

The popular artist/Homebase collaboration in which nine sculptors were invited to design functional items for the home proved so popular that demand exceeded expectation. This exhibition features preliminary drawings by Anish Kapoor, Anthony Gormley and Alison Wilding. Victoria Art Gallery, Bridge St, Bath (01225-477233) until 27 May, free.

Spike Island Invitational

Art duo Adam Dade and Sonya Hanney recently dismantled a hotel room to its foundations, their piece for this site specific group show will, I'm sure, be just as thorough. Spike Island, Bristol (0117-929 2266) until 7 May, free.

Dayanita Singh & Beatriz Milhazes A double bill featuring the exotic floral paintings of Brazilian artist Beatriz Milhazes and black and white photographs of the closed and private world of the Ashram by Indian artist Dayanita Singh. Ikon Gallery, Oozells Square, Birmingham (0121-248 0708) until 13 May, free.

John Piper

War artist best remembered for his dramatic, theatrical-like paintings of bomb damaged London; John Piper painted the nocturnal fires that raged across the city during the blitz. Glynn Vivian Art Gallery, Alexandra Rd, Swansea (01792 -655006) until 20 May, free.
Jessica Lack

Cinema

Best In Show

In this little gem of a comedy, director and co-writer Guest tells the story of the "Mayflower Dog Show", following the fraught lives of the key competitors and their tremulous, talented pooches. A nimble, agile, quick-witted, intelligent little film. (12) (Christopher Guest, 2000, US) Christopher Guest, Parker Posey. 90 mins
*****

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

2001 has got off to the best start possible with this fantastic film. Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is a martial arts movie in a traditional Chinese action idiom which manages to be both electrifyingly exciting and sweetly romantic. (15) (Ang Lee, 2000, China/US) Chow Yun-Fat, Michelle Yeoh, Zhang Ziyi. 120 mins
*****

A One And A Two

This spacious family drama is exquisitely considered, richly textured, beautifully acted, moving, funny and wise. A film about the interconnecting tribulations of one extended family in contemporary Taipei, it revolves around a man beset with problems, who meets the person he jilted when she was a schoolgirl 30 years before. (15) (Edward Yang, 2000, Taiwan/Japan) Nien-Jen Wu, Elaine Jin. 173 mins
*****

State And Main

Mamets new work is an amiable comedy about a Hollywood crew invading a Vermont backwater. Hoffman plays an idealistic young dramatist who has sold his soul to the movies  specifically Macys fast-talking director, into whose mouth pop comic jewels by the dozen. (15) (David Mamet, 2000, US) Alec Baldwin, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, William H Macy. 102 mins
*****

You Can Count On Me

Lonergans film has the virtues of classic American furniture: sturdy, unfussy, substantial. And Laura Linney has it all. She can do a steamy sex scene, get laughs, provoke tears  and most importantly of all, she is loyal to the US small town. (15) (Kenneth Lonergan, 1999, US) Laura Linney, Mark Ruffalo. 111 mins
*****
Peter Bradshaw

webTitle: Hawks goad leaders in US and China

fields.headline: Hawks goad leaders in US and China
fields.standfirst:
Damage to trade from the spy plane dispute is the last thing mainstream politicians want - but hardliners are pushing them to be tough

Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Under pressure from rightwingers to take a tougher line with China, the Bush administration yesterday warned Beijing that trade relations could be damaged if the 24 crew members of a crippled US spy plane being held on the island of Hainan were not freed in the next few days.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Washington and  John Gittings in Shanghai
fields.body:
Under pressure from rightwingers to take a tougher line with China, the Bush administration yesterday warned Beijing that trade relations could be damaged if the 24 crew members of a crippled US spy plane being held on the island of Hainan were not freed in the next few days.

And in Beijing, there was speculation that hardliners in China's military were similarly pushing their politicial leaders to take an unyielding stand over the mid-air collision on April 1 between the US EP-3 electronic surveillance plane and one of two Chinese jet fighters that challenged it over the South China sea.

The American warning, delivered by Vice-President Dick Cheney and the secretary of state, Colin Powell, was a distinct change of tone from last week's conciliatory remarks.

The crew were said to be in good condition yesterday by US diplomats paying a third visit to them on Hainan, where the spy plane made an emergency landing. But the pilot of the damaged Chinese jet - who was reported as having ejected - is missing.

There had been high hopes in Washington that the crew would be released this weekend after President Bush expressed regret, but China wants a full apology. The US has refused, saying the collision was in international air space and there was no evidence that its crew was at fault.

China admits the incident was not in its state air space, but argues that the area is one of special Chinese influence and control. Its military has not made clear who ordered the jets to challenge the American aircraft, and who then controlled their movements.

In a television interview yesterday, Mr Cheney voiced growing impatience. "I don't want to put a timetable on it," he said, "but every day that goes by without having it resolved raises the risks to the long-term relationship."

Mr Powell said "serious damage" was already being done. Congressional leaders and businessmen had cancelled trips to China, he said, and it was possible that a US delegation led by Mr Bush would not attend September's Shanghai conference of Apec (the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group). But he still believed the dispute would be resolved by diplomatic exchanges; they continued yesterday.

Beijing was also sending mixed messages. The official People's Daily hinted clearly at the view of some political leaders - left dealing with the fallout from a military confrontation - that the crisis must not be allowed to harm trade with the US or China's hopes of joining the World Trade Organisation: "Everything [in China] depends on economic development and on having a stable environment for it."

Mirroring the US hawks, however, a Chinese military paper, the Liberation Arms Daily, said Beijing had the right to "investigate thoroughly" the crew and their plane.

The defence minister, Chi Haotian, said: "It's impermissible for them [the US] to want to shirk responsibility ... The People's Liberation Army does not agree to it, the Chinese people don't agree to it."

webTitle: Hopes raised as figures for new cases stay stable

fields.headline: Hopes raised as figures for new cases stay stable
fields.standfirst:
Outbreaks are contained at 20-25 a day but farmers are warned not to be complacent as virus makes biggest unexplained jump

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The first signs that the foot and mouth crisis is beginning to recede emerged at the weekend as the numbers of new cases dropped.
fields.body:
The first signs that the foot and mouth crisis is beginning to recede emerged at the weekend as the numbers of new cases dropped.

Outbreaks are being contained at between 20 and 25 a day, compared with between 40 and 45 a day early last week.

The government has urged caution, saying that scientists will need to analyse the figures over seven days before a trend can be confirmed.

There is still a backlog of animals waiting to be slaughtered, and it was confirmed at the weekend that the virus has made its biggest unexplained jump since the crisis began.

An outbreak was confirmed at Ashes Farm at Ruswarp, near Whitby, North Yorkshire, 40 miles from the nearest case.

The Ministry of Agriculture is investigating whether a vehicle travelling from Cumbria to Whitby was responsible for the spread.

Meanwhile, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, urged livestock farmers not to undermine the government's strategy by appealing against the culling of their animals.

Mr Brown wrote to all 85,000 livestock farmers in England urging them to appeal against culling only in "very exceptional circumstances".

Farmers had been exercising their right to appeal as a matter of routine, officials said.

It is considered vital to slaughter animals on neighbouring farms within 48 hours if the disease is to be controlled and eradicated. The government also faced criticism from the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, who attacked what he called the continuing failure of the British authorities to disinfect vehicles bound for Ireland from British ports.

He announced a plan to have Irish workers do the job, as efforts continue to keep foot and mouth restricted to one isolated outbreak.

Mr Brown said in his letter that although there were signs that the culling policy was starting to "bite", there was no room for complacency.

Figures from the last 10 days show that the exponential growth originally feared by scientists had not materialised.

But the minister said the virulent nature of the disease meant it was too early for the authorities to drop their guard.

Over a million animals will have been slaughtered by the time the disease is eradicated and compensation to farmers is likely to total £200m, Mr Brown said yesterday.

The number of confirmed cases had risen to 1,126 by last night.

Members of the Chinese community protested yesterday over the allegation that a Chinese restaurant was responsible for importing foot and mouth.

Around 500 demonstrators marched from Gerrard Street in the heart of London's Chinatown through Whitehall to the Ministry of Agriculture, waving placards and chanting "Mr Blair - Be Fair" and "Justice for the Chinese". Chinese restaurants closed for two hours as owners showed their anger at being blamed for the crisis.

After meeting members of the Chinese civil rights action group, the agriculture minister said: "One issue of particular concern to them was the impression given in some sections of the media that investigations into the source of the current foot and mouth outbreak have positively demonstrated that the initial infection came from waste from a Chinese restaurant.

"This is untrue. The investigations into the source of the outbreak are still continuing, and ill-informed, groundless speculation does nothing to help the situation."

webTitle: Vietnam crash kills 16 in search for American MIA's

fields.headline: Vietnam crash kills 16 as the forlorn search goes on for America's missing
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The ghost of the Vietnam war claimed more victims at the weekend when a helicopter carrying 16 people crashed in the central Vietnamese highlands. Its passengers had been taking part in the dogged US search for soldiers still missing in action a quarter of a century after the conflict ended.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Washington and  Owen Bennett Jones  in Hanoi
fields.body:
The ghost of the Vietnam war claimed more victims at the weekend when a helicopter carrying 16 people crashed in the central Vietnamese highlands. Its passengers had been taking part in the dogged US search for soldiers still missing in action a quarter of a century after the conflict ended.

The team of nine Vietnamese and seven American servicemen had been scouring Quang Binh province for remains of downed US aircraft and their crews in the hope of clearing up some of the war's unanswered questions. Instead, after an as yet unexplained accident on Saturday, it was their bodies that had to be recovered yesterday from a hillside 280 miles south of Hanoi, adding to the trauma inflicted on both countries by the conflict.

President Bush alluded to the sad irony of the accident when he paid tribute to the dead yesterday: "Although not lost in a hostile act, like those for whom they search, they too have lived lives of great consequence, answering a calling of service to their fellow citizen."

The Vietnamese foreign minister, Nguyen Dy Nien, also expressed "deep condolences" to the Vietnamese and US families of the victims, a reflection of the role the joint search for the war dead has played in healing the wounds between the two countries.

Most of the 16 bodies from Saturday's accident were so badly burnt they had to be identified by their own unit, the "joint taskforce: full accounting" which was established in 1992 to find the MIAs - soldiers missing in action - in south-east Asia. "To put it bluntly, it depends how badly mangled the bodies were in the crash," said Lieutenant Commander Sean Kelly from the taskforce's Hawaii headquarters. "And only after that process is complete will next of kin be informed."

A joint inquiry has begun into the causes of the accident. Witnesses said the Soviet-made Vietnamese-piloted Mi-17 helicopter had made unusual swinging motions before crashing into the mountainside and exploding. According to some reports one man was still alive when rescuers reached the site, but he died soon afterwards.

According to the US embassy in Vietnam, those killed were on the way to a previously identified site to gauge whether it was worth excavating. Ninety-five investigators are to arrive in Vietnam this month to intensify the search; agreed after a visit to Vietnam last November by President Clinton.

The US spends $70m (£43m) a year on the MIA search, and at any one time there are a significant number of US military personnel at work in the Vietnamese countryside. Twenty-six years after the end of the war, there are 1,498 Americans still unaccounted for in Vietnam (and a further 496 in Cambodia, Laos and southern China), and 300,000 Vietnamese soldiers and civilians. The Pentagon has provided 350,000 pages of wartime documentation to help pinpoint war graves. Some US veterans have also supplied their maps of battles and mass graves, as well as wallets and photographs taken as souvenirs from the Vietnamese dead.

The number of US MIAs in Vietnam pales in comparison with the 8,000 from the Korean war, and 80,000 still missing from the second world war. But the Vietnam MIAs are a far more explosive issue, due to a lack of consensus in the US on why the war was lost. Many former servicemen and American rightwingers believe that the soldiers were betrayed by politicians who lost their nerve, and who abandoned captured servicemen in prison camps. There is a widespread belief that some PoWs may still be alive - a belief nurtured in Hollywood by films including Rambo, in which special forces are sent to save the PoWs but are left for dead by schemers in Washington.

The MIA investigators make little secret of the fact that they do not believe any of the missing are still alive, but it is too controversial for them to say so publicly. Senator John McCain, a former PoW and Vietnam war hero, was accused of betrayal by some veterans during last year's election campaign for saying he did not believe prisoners were still being held.

The black PoW/MIA flag, depicting a prisoner under a camp watchtower, flies on public buildings throughout the country. One of the main activist groups, the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in South-East Asia, maintains a website with news of the effort to identify remains and the flickering hope that not all the missing are dead.

It says: "Official intelligence indicates that Americans known to have been alive in captivity in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia were not returned at the end of the war. In the absence of evidence to the contrary, it must be assumed that these Americans may still be alive."

Conclusive evidence to the contrary may only lie in the central highland jungles of Vietnam, where plane wreckage and clues to the fate of their pilots are being still being unearthed.

Typically the search for missing servicemen begins with military historians asking Vietnamese villagers for information about where battles took place and the location of planes that were shot down. Once a site has been identified, archaeologists look for human remains.

In cases that involved a high-impact air plane crash they often unearth just a few chips of bone which are then repatriated with full military honours.

When Mr Clinton visited Vietnam in November he went to stand in the mud of a rice paddy to watch the excavation of the remains of Captain Lawrence G Evert: a fighter pilot who was shot down in 1967. Mr Clinton vowed the US would "keep at it" until "every possible fallen hero" was brought home". But he was attacked for restoring normal trade relations with Hanoi by several MIA groups who argued the Vietnamese were still withholding vital information about survivors.

Since the war ended in 1973, the remains of 591 US service members formerly listed as unaccounted for have been returned to their families. And in a statement issued yesterday, the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, pledged that the programme will continue.

webTitle: Website keeps US MIA rumours alive

fields.headline: Conspiracy theorists keep hope alive with website rumours
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
More internet news
fields.trailText: Conspiracy theories about US servicemen missing since the Vietnam war still abound, and there are numerous websites devoted to exchanging details about alleged sightings.
fields.body:
Conspiracy theories about US servicemen missing since the Vietnam war still abound, and there are numerous websites devoted to exchanging details about alleged sightings.

Global Spy magazine says on its website that an Arizona teacher was told by Vietnamese officials that missing US soldiers were being held and would be released only if the embargo then in force against the war-ravaged country was lifted.

The site advertises a video, A Nation Betrayed, featuring Colonel James "Bo" Gritz, described as a decorated Vietnam war hero.

He claimed to have returned from Indochina with evidence of up to 47 missing Americans being held at one camp, though little information in is given in support of the claim.

Some of the conspiracy theories suggest dark political machinations.

A 1991 copy of a little known fringe magazine called Spotlight said: "Because of a desire to exploit the oil reserves of Indochina, the United States is trying to cover up the issue of live PoWs until they are all killed next January or February, the Senate was told November 7.

"This charge was made before the Senate select committee on PoW/MIA affairs by Hamilton Gayden, a circuit court judge in Tennessee, who has written a book on the subject.

"Gayden has long been active in efforts to bring home hundreds of the 2,000 missing men who, extensive evidence shows, are still alive.

"Government bureaucrats fear 'the ever-present threat that the Vietnamese and Laotian leaders will disclose to the American people the existence of live Americans who still want to be repatriated', Gayden said.

"'The government is determined to declare all missing men dead because of the intense outrage that would result if the American public learned of their abandonment,' Gayden said.

Those Americans nurtured on Rambo films who believe their government is lying to them took further heart when the former US presidential candidate Ross Perot claimed that information about PoWs who might still be alive was suppressed.

The Vietnamese themselves are not immune to rumour and conjecture. An organisation in Hanoi snappily known as the Science Technology Union for Informatics Application coordinates the services of psychics who claim that they can help bereaved relatives communicate with some of the country's missing 300,000 soldiers.

Vietnam crash kills 16 as the forlorn search goes on for America's missing

Global Spy magazine says on its website that an Arizona teacher was told by Vietnamese officials that missing US soldiers were being held and would be released only if the embargo then in force against the war-ravaged country was lifted. The site advertises a video, A Nation Betrayed, featuring Colonel James "Bo" Gritz, described as a decorated Vietnam war hero. He claimed to have returned from Indochina with evidence of up to 47 missing Americans being held at one camp, though little information in is given in support of the claim. Some of the conspiracy theories suggest dark political machinations. A 1991 copy of a little known fringe magazine called Spotlight said: "Because of a desire to exploit the oil reserves of Indochina, the United States is trying to cover up the issue of live PoWs until they are all killed next January or February, the Senate was told November 7. "This charge was made before the Senate select committee on PoW/MIA affairs by Hamilton Gayden, a circuit court judge in Tennessee, who has written a book on the subject. "Gayden has long been active in efforts to bring home hundreds of the 2,000 missing men who, extensive evidence shows, are still alive. "Government bureaucrats fear 'the ever-present threat that the Vietnamese and Laotian leaders will disclose to the American people the existence of live Americans who still want to be repatriated', Gayden said. "'The government is determined to declare all missing men dead because of the intense outrage that would result if the American public learned of their abandonment,' Gayden said. Those Americans nurtured on Rambo films who believe their government is lying to them took further heart when the former US presidential candidate Ross Perot claimed that information about PoWs who might still be alive was suppressed. The Vietnamese themselves are not immune to rumour and conjecture. An organisation in Hanoi snappily known as the Science Technology Union for Informatics Application coordinates the services of psychics who claim that they can help bereaved relatives communicate with some of the country's missing 300,000 soldiers. webTitle: New proposal to revive Kyoto treaty

fields.headline: New proposal to revive Kyoto treaty
fields.standfirst:
Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Bush administration is putting forward alternative guidelines for a new international global warming agreement, it was reported yesterday, as it finds itself increasingly isolated on the world stage for its rejection of the Kyoto treaty.
fields.body:
The Bush administration is putting forward alternative guidelines for a new international global warming agreement, it was reported yesterday, as it finds itself increasingly isolated on the world stage for its rejection of the Kyoto treaty.

The guidelines were put forward by a US deputy secretary of state, Richard Armitage, at a meeting on Friday with a Japanese delegation. Tokyo had sent its representatives to express its concern over the US declaration that it had "no interest" in the 1997 Kyoto protocol, in which the leaders of the world's industrialised countries, including President Clinton, agreed to cut emissions of greenhouse gases.

Japanese reports of the meeting were vague about the details of Mr Armitage's proposals, but said they were built around a three-point agenda. These points appeared to address longstanding US objections to the Kyoto accord: the exemption it offers developing countries; the burden it puts on the US as the world's biggest offender to curb emissions; and the lack of consideration given to new technologies and market-based ways of tackling global warming.

Mr Armitage said the US proposals would be ready to present to a convention on climate change to be held in Bonn in July. But in a joint article published at the weekend, the president of the European commission, Romano Prodi, and the Swedish prime minister, Goran Persson, argued that it would be better to amend the Kyoto agreement to make allowance for US objections than to tear it up entirely.

"If certain parts of the agreement prevent the United States from ratifying it, we should negotiate about those parts rather than bury the entire agreement," the two leaders wrote in the Swedish regional daily newspaper Goteborgs-Posten. "In our opinion, it would be a tragic mistake to tear up the agreement and start over from scratch. We would lose time, and that would make us all losers."

The pressure on Washington to limit its greenhouse gas emissions will mount this week when a report is published by several of America's leading scientists assessing the damage global warming is likely to inflict on the US economy and its environment.

Meanwhile, the diplomatic campaign to force Mr Bush to rethink continued yesterday with a joint communique from the environment ministers of Japan, China and South Korea, saying they "sincerely hope" that the US will cooperate with other countries at Bonn to put together a plan to implement the Kyoto accord.

In the US, the Democrats have moved fast to capitalise on the Bush administration's isolation, pushing a measure through the Senate on Friday which restores $4.5bn (£2.8bn) in funds for programmes addressing climate change, which the White House had attempted to cut. The bill drew significant Republican support and reflected uneasiness about the way the administration has handled the issue.

"While no one is under the illusion that Kyoto is perfect, this vote today... underscores that the Bush administration's initial approach of ignoring climate change altogether is beyond imperfect - it's unacceptable," said John Kerry, a Democratic senator.

The vice-president, Dick Cheney, defended the White House's environmental policies yesterday and accused its critics of hypocrisy: "Kyoto was a dead proposition before we ever arrived in Washington. All we did was to make it clear that the US would not be bound by it."

fields.headline: Schmoozing the Balkans
fields.standfirst:
Special report: European integration
Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Javier Solana, the affable Spaniard who rejoices in the title of high representative of the European Union for common foreign and security policy, has really been clocking up the air miles recently.
fields.body:
Javier Solana, the affable Spaniard who rejoices in the title of high representative of the European Union for common foreign and security policy, has really been clocking up the air miles recently.

Having bombed Serbia in 1999 when he was Nato secretary-general, he is now donning the mantle of Balkan peacemaker, cajoling the Macedonian government into making their disgruntled Albanians feel more at home. The idea is that a closer relationship with Europe will sooth away all that inter-ethnic nastiness.

Success is far from guaranteed. Yet there is no doubt that a decade after the start of the wars of the Yugoslav succession, the EU is starting to be the major player in the south-eastern corner of the continent. Brussels, not Washington, calls the shots. Colin Powell, glad to be away from the Toxic Texan, is going to Skopje himself this week - on Solana's advice. "We can manage," the high rep told the US secretary of state, "but you should visit too."

Finally, years after Henry Kissinger asked his famous (and frankly disingenuous) question about who he should call if he needed to know what Europe thought, Americans have the answer: Solana. Try his mobile, though, as he's rarely to be found in Brussels.

If the Bush administration knew what it wanted, it would be happy that Europeans are starting to do their bit. But it is less pleased about Solana's schmoozing with Vladimir Putin, who last week highlighted the importance of Russia's relations with the EU and his desire to cooperate with its fledgling defence initiative. (Strikingly, when human rights abuses in Chechnya came up at the Stockholm summit, it was raised not by the EU but by Sweden, which was in the chair: a nice and very diplomatic distinction, you might say, but one which Moscow certainly noticed.)

Solana is as good a public face as the EU could hope for, though in the Middle East, another area of American disengagement and long-standing European ambition, being touchy-feely may win friends but doesn't much influence people who want to kill each other. And anyway, it is a constant refrain that France and Britain don't let him do very much.

Institutionally, the arrangements are messy, with Solana doing the backslapping and photocalls on behalf of the 15 governments, and Chris Patten, across the road at the supranational commission, controlling the cash. It's far from perfect, as the policy wonks are always pointing out. But hey, this is the EU - a work very much in progress.

 Good news for Romano Prodi, president of the EU commission, who is happily able to hold on to one of the most talented members of his team. His fellow Italian, Mario Monti, the softly spoken competition commissioner, has turned down Silvio Berlusconi's offer of a ministerial job after next month's Italian elections so he can carry on prowling the global mergers and acquisitions beat. But Brussels is worried: Prodi and Berlusconi cannot abide each other and have been known to go to considerable lengths to avoid being in the same room.

And even assuming that "post-fascist" National Alliance leader Gianfranco Fini and Umberto Bossi of the Northern League behave themselves in power - and avoid a repeat of last year's crisis over Austria's Jörg Haider - another difficulty looms: Berlusconi's plan to slash taxes in defiance of euroland discipline. Ireland has been slapped down for its overheating economy pour encourager les autres. But Italy's 58m population makes the problem of a different order. Not at all what Prodi, the European central bank or anyone else want months before 12 member states scrap their national currencies.

 Whoever said Brussels was boring? Dreary eurocrats and anoraked aficionados have had a burst of noisy excitement thanks to the Swedish presidency and Malmo artist Jan Cardell, whose bizarre fibreglass and steel musical sculpture - aka the ktree - has been towering over the barren courtyard of the council of ministers building for the past few months.

The ktree's crown consists of percussion instruments and horns, played by pushing a button or by composing and uploading rhythms via the internet. Some ill-tempered, but possibly hearing-impaired, official taped over the button. But my delighted daughters managed to set if off the other day, banging and honking away and doubtless wreaking havoc with union business.

In a way it's like the EU itself: when pressed - Dubya's wrecking of the Koyoto global warming pact - it does sometimes roar into life. Now that it's time for the ktree to return to its native soil in Malm, a silent and rainy gloom descends again over the beating heart of Europe.

fields.headline: Paddington rail crash charges considered
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Paddington train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Crown prosecutors are reconsidering bringing corporate manslaughter charges against senior managers of Railtrack and Thames Trains in connection with the Paddington rail crash, sources close to the criminal inquiry revealed last night.
fields.body:
Crown prosecutors are reconsidering bringing corporate manslaughter charges against senior managers of Railtrack and Thames Trains in connection with the Paddington rail crash, sources close to the criminal inquiry revealed last night.

The grounds are that Railtrack was well aware of the dangers of signal 109, where the accident occurred, but did little to address them. The driver of a Thames train leaving Paddington passed through signal 109 at red, directly into the path of a high-speed train approaching Paddington from Cheltenham.

In the resulting accident 31 people were killed and more than 400 injured.

At the public inquiry, chaired by Lord Cullen, evidence was produced that the driver's view of the signal might have been impaired by its position and bright sunlight.

Thames Trains could be charged with failing to give its drivers proper training: evidence was also given at the inquiry that some drivers were not fully aware of the train paths into Paddington, one of the busiest mainline stations in Britain.

The CPS said yesterday that no charges were imminent. But the British transport police are re-examining the evidence to see whether charges of manslaughter on the grounds of gross negligence can be laid.

In the period leading up to the accident, Railtrack convened several meetings with health and safety officials and the unions to discuss the potential dangers of signal 109, but no action was taken. The signal was taken out of commission immediately after the crash, in spite of legal protests by Railtrack, and has not been restored.

Widespread alterations were made to the approach to Paddington station, including the signalling and tracks, to accommodate the introduction of the Heathrow Express service from the airport to Paddington three years ago. Speed restrictions into Paddington imposed after the crash are still in place.

Relatives of the dead have been pressing for corporate manslaughter charges to be brought against Railtrack and Thames ever since the accident in October 1999. They have become increasingly concerned about the delay, and are anxiously waiting for Lord Cullen's report, to be published in the summer.

Although it will almost certainly criticise Railtrack and Thames, evidence given at a public inquiry is not admissible in criminal proceedings. The police therefore have to make their own inquiries before deciding whether to go ahead with a prosecution.

The position would be easier for them if the legislation being considered by the Home Office to introduce an offence of corporate manslaughter was on the statute books.

If manslaughter charges are not brought, individual managers of Railtrack and Thames Trains are likely to be charged under the Health and Safety at Work Act. This happened after the Southall rail crash in 1997, when Great Western Trains was fined £1.5m for running a Swansea-to-London high-speed train in the knowledge that safety equipment in the driver's cab was not operating. In December the health and safety executive concluded that signals in the area of the Paddington crash were "exceptionally difficult" to read and did not comply with industry standards. Many were too high, making them particularly difficult to read when the sun was low in the sky.

Signal 109 had been passed at danger seven other times in five years, and was among the 22 most dangerous signals on the railway network, it found.

In the six months before Paddington there were 109 serious incidents of signals being passed at danger. The incidence fell after Paddington, but the HSE reported last month that it had risen again to approximately the level of the mid-90s.

webTitle: Excommunication is latest weapon in war against Eta

fields.headline: Excommunication is latest weapon in war against Eta
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: Spain's Roman Catholic church is about to take the unprecedented step of excommunicating members of the armed Basque separatist group Eta, senior church figures told the Spanish newspaper El Mundo yesterday.
fields.body:
Spain's Roman Catholic church is about to take the unprecedented step of excommunicating members of the armed Basque separatist group Eta, senior church figures told the Spanish newspaper El Mundo yesterday.

The head of the Spanish Bishops' Council, Cardinal Antonio Rouco Varela, has called a special meeting of the country's 85 most important archbishops and bishops to set in motion the excommunication process in two weeks' time.

The planned excommunication of Eta and its gunmen was reported to have the explicit backing of the pope and the Vatican hierarchy. Excommunication, usually reserved for heretics, has not been used in Spain since 1951, when it was applied to a popular soothsayer in Seville.

In recent years the Roman Catholic church in Latin America has used it against drug cartels and the kidnappers of the entire congregation of a church in Colombia and against kidnapping gangs and torturers in Mexico.

"There is no doubt about the legality of applying excommunication as terrorism is clearly an offence against life and liberty," argued one Spanish archbishop, Jose Manuel Estepa.

"We need to atone for the scandal provoked by the fact that it appears that quite a few Eta members have come from the ecclesiastical community."

Excommunication would be a powerful tool in the propaganda battle against Eta as Basques are the most intensely religious people in Spain - with 40% still attending Mass at least once a week.

The Jesuits are particularly strong, with the order's founder, Saint Ignatius, hailing from the Basque hill town of Loyola.

Eta itself was founded in the 1960s by a group of people who were close to the church and, in many cases, had been to Jesuit seminaries or schools. Some Eta members are still fervent Catholics.

At least one priest, Father Jose Ramon Trebino, has been jailed for giving refuge to separatist gunmen on the run from the law. Other members of the Basque clergy are believed to support Eta's separatist aims.

Inaki Esnaola, a leader of Herri Batasuna, the party allied to Eta, is a former priest.

The Basque language, Euskara, was kept alive by local priests when it was banned during the Franco dictatorship.

In practical terms the decision would make little difference to religious life in the Basque country, but it would mean that funerals of Eta members could no longer be held in their local churches. The bishops' debate on excommunication will come just three weeks before Basques go to the polls for regional elections on May 13.

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: Investing in land
fields.trailText: Investing in land.
fields.body:
Folk wisdom has it that the safest investment is land because "they have stopped making it". Actually, the mania for property speculation has left London with some of the most expensive and overcrowded office space in the world, and its investors a good deal worse off than they need have been.

To begin with: they are still making land. London is, geographically speaking, a rubbish dump in a swamp, and as Londoners dump more rubbish, London gets bigger. The very slow development of the former docklands is the latest example of a process that dates back to the Romans. But human life is short, the temptation of fast money is strong, and high office rents encourage office building. The Corporation of the City of London, which has remarkable autonomy, slackens its own planning laws to create more office space to maintain its pre-eminence against rival locations, and soon London has more offices than businesses.

High as London rents are, research by property consultants DTZ Debenham Tie Leung shows that they have yet to recover the strength they had 10 years ago before the last property boom went pear-shaped. Meanwhile, the cheap 10-year leases negotiated in the wake of the crash are up. Just as Canary Wharf has begun to work, the poor souls dumped there when it was a bleak desert have now been dumped further east in the bleak desert of South Quays.

The property rollercoaster is kept going because businesses prefer short-term leases. The consequence is uncomfortable offices. Office buildings are put up in a hurry when times are good, with no thought of who is going to occupy them. The interiors are as bare as barns. When they are occupied, they are planned very badly.

And just as the pneumatic drills begin to ease off at Canary Wharf, the new development in Paternoster Row, by St Paul's, gets under way. Watch this space.
