webTitle: Putin ally's trial is on despite Russia

fields.headline: Putin ally's trial is on despite Russia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The first prosecution of a senior Kremlin official on corruption-related charges could collapse within days if a Geneva court decides that the two-year investigation has yielded insufficient evidence to warrant a trial.
fields.body:
The first prosecution of a senior Kremlin official on corruption-related charges could collapse within days if a Geneva court decides that the two-year investigation has yielded insufficient evidence to warrant a trial.

Pavel Borodin, a former senior Yeltsin aide who gave Russian president Vladimir Putin his first job in the Kremlin, was formally charged and remanded in jail in Switzerland on Saturday. He is accused of laundering several million dollars in commission payments through Swiss banks while he managed the Kremlin's financial and property affairs in the 1990s, and of participation in a criminal organisation.

The former head of the presidential administration under Boris Yeltsin was extradited from the US after he dropped a protracted New York court battle, claiming that he wanted to clear his name. Mr Borodin, who still holds public office as head of the Russia-Belarus Union, was arrested in the US on an international warrant last January, sparking a diplomatic row between Washington and Moscow.

Dominique Poncet, Mr Borodin's Swiss lawyer, said: "He has contested committing any kind of offence, as he always has done, and on top of that we consider that the Swiss authorities have no competence in this affair. The Russian authorities are adamant that he has not broken the law in Russia."

Legal analysts believe that without evidence from Russia that the £17.7m commission payments to Mr Borodin and his family were gained illegally, the Geneva prosecutors will have trouble proving money laundering.

Although the Russians triggered the investigation three years ago which the Swiss subsequently trailed to Mr Borodin, they now claim they have no evidence of anything suspicious, a decision the Geneva prosecutor feels was politically motivated.

Swiss judges complain of insufficient resources. Money-laundering investigators recruited in recent years have quit their jobs in frustration at the obstacles they face.

However, some of the evidence which was leaked last year suggests that a trial, if it goes ahead, would be embarrassing for the Russian regime regardless of the outcome.

A total of £43m in bribes is alleged to have been paid by Mercata Trading, the Swiss-based company at the centre of the case, through an Isle of Man-based company and other offshore companies and foundations between March 1996 and July 1998.

In a letter to his Russian counterparts last July, the Geneva investigating magistrate, Daniel Devaud, alleged that the payments followed Mr Borodin's decision to award a £341m contract to Mercata and an associate company, Mabetex, to renovate official buildings, including the Kremlin, and to refit the Russian president's aircraft.

Fourteen other suspects, mainly Russian associates, are under investigation in Switzerland. Four of them are facing similar charges to those made against Mr Borodin.

fields.headline: Croat separatists target Nato base
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Croat nationalists are threatening to blockade a Nato supply base today near the port of Split in Croatia, in protest against the seizure by members of the international peacekeeping force of a bank in the Bosnian town of Mostar.
fields.body:
Croat nationalists are threatening to blockade a Nato supply base today near the port of Split in Croatia, in protest against the seizure by members of the international peacekeeping force of a bank in the Bosnian town of Mostar.

Twenty-five people, including 21 members of the S-For stabilisation force in Bosnia, were injured in riots on Friday in the former Yugoslav republic, after auditors, backed by UN police and Nato soldiers, took control of the Hercegovacka bank and several of its branch offices.

The worst clashes were in Grude, south-west of Mostar, where the rioters took hostages and threatened to kill them. They were later released.

"We are disgusted with the treatment by international forces, the Bosnian government and the leadership in Croatia of the Croats in Bosnia," said Petar Kacunko of a veterans' group that is organising today's blockade.

The international administrator in Bosnia, high representative Wolfgang Petritsch, called the rioters "paramilitary thugs" and alleged that the bank was being used to finance "illegal parallel structures" - a reference to the efforts of radical Croats who are trying to set up a mini-state of their own, Herzeg-Bosna, in south-west Bosnia.

Croat veterans in Bosnia and Croatia are among the most vehement supporters of the proposed breakaway state. Mr Petritsch sacked the Croat leader, Ante Jelavic, from Bosnia's tripartite presidency five weeks ago, after an illegal "Croat National Congress" was set up. It was meant to act as a nucleus for a new state.

Since then the separatists have appealed to Croat soldiers serving in the joint Muslim-Croat Federation army, to desert - presumably with the intention of setting up an "ethnically pure" Croat army.

Most soldiers and officers obeyed the call, prompting Nato peacekeepers on Saturday to seize arms depots held by the Croats since the end of the 1992-95 Bosnian war.

The Croats are pushing ahead with their plans, despite much condemnation - most notably from the Croatian government in Zagreb.

The radical Croats in Herzegovina have largely survived since the war by pocketing some of the £70m each year supplied by Zagreb to the Croat component of the Bosnian armed forces. Intelligence sources in Zagreb estimate that half that money ended up in private hands, and a part is now being used to bankroll the new Croat "statelet".

Soldiers who leave the federation army, and local police who refuse to wear Bosnian Federation insignia on their uniforms, have been warned that they will no longer be paid. The success of the new statelet could depend on its ability to pay its own security forces.

webTitle: Marconi unions brace for 1,300 British layoffs

fields.headline: Marconi unions brace for 1,300 British layoffs
fields.trailText: Marconi is expected to confirm within the next 48 hours that it plans to layoff around 1,300 workers in Britain as part of a cost cutting programming that it is likely to lead to more than 3,000 job losses worldwide.
fields.body:
Marconi is expected to confirm within the next 48 hours that it plans to layoff around 1,300 workers in Britain as part of a cost cutting programming that it is likely to lead to more than 3,000 job losses worldwide.

The communications group born out of GEC has become the latest British company to feel the effects of the global economic slowdown and may be forced to issue a profits warning following similar moves by its US rivals Nortel and Lucent.

The majority of the job losses are likely to occur at factories in Liverpool and Coventry and it is thought that union leaders representing Marconi's 20,000 UK workforce will be told of the cuts at a special meeting this evening.

Shares in Marconi, which is run by former Rover boss Lord Simpson and focuses on telecoms in the US, have collapsed over recent months and the company has been under pressure from the City to take action and to give a trading update.

On Friday the shares closed at 320.5p compared with a year high of 800p.

Since March 1999 Marconi has spent several billion dollars buying up telecoms equipment manufacturers including Fore Systems, Reltec and a division of Bosch.

The economic slowdown has hit US firms the hardest so far and it is unclear how badly Marconi has been affected, particularly as it does a lot of business in Europe.

Analysts expect the company to make an operating profit of £790m-£850m in the year ending March 2001 but say figures for the current financial year could be depressed by wider market conditions.

Cisco, Lucent and Alcatel are among an increasing number of big hi-tech players exposed to the telecoms sector that have been forced either to lay off staff or to to warn that profits will be lower than expected.

Marconi remains the only major telecoms equipment manufacturer with large exposure to the US not to have warned in recent months. On Friday analysts at Credit Suisse First Boston downgraded earnings forecasts fearing Marconi was about to announce bad news.

Cable & Wireless recently made a profits warning which hurt its share price while mobile phone manufacturer Motorola is tomorrow expected to report its first quarterly operating loss in more than 15 years.

fields.headline: Sainsbury farms out payroll operations
fields.trailText: Sainsbury's has contracted out its payroll operation for 135,000 employees and 12,000 pensioners in the biggest deal of its kind in Britain.
fields.body:
Sainsbury's has contracted out its payroll operation for 135,000 employees and 12,000 pensioners in the biggest deal of its kind in Britain.

The supermarket chain has awarded RebusHR a £20m eight-year contract. More than 50 Sainsbury's staff will transfer to RebusHR, and the first payroll run under the deal is likely to take place before the end of the year.

The move is the second big outsourcing deal struck by Sainsbury's since Sir Peter Davis joined as chief executive early last year and is part of a wider drive to reduce costs across the group.

In November, Sainsbury's signed a seven-year deal to outsource its IT functions to Andersen Consulting, which saw the transfer of around 800 employees. That contract will save £35m a year.

Hamish Elvidge, director of the supermarkets division, said the payroll deal would generate additional cost savings. "This is an excellent deal for both parties." Press Association

webTitle: Wind of change Power sector under siege

fields.headline: Wind of change Power sector under siege
fields.trailText: Britain's electricity sector is facing a further shake-up in ownership with Powergen and Seeboard thought to be about to receive takeover bids.
fields.body:
Britain's electricity sector is facing a further shake-up in ownership with Powergen and Seeboard thought to be about to receive takeover bids.

E.ON of Germany was yesterday close to offering £10bn or 800p per share for Powergen - which is behind the Blyth wind farm - after almost three months of talks, while Electricité de France was reportedly preparing a £1.5bn bid for Seeboard.

The mooted 800p per share offer for Powergen would represent a 13% premium to Friday's close price and give the German firm a useful outpost in the US. E.ON is cash rich after selling a 45% stake in mobile phone operator Viag Interkom to BT for £4.4bn.

Its proposed bid for Powergen has not been received well, however, and it has been the worst performing utility stock in Europe this year.

State-owned EdF has been looking for ways to boost revenues and sees Seeboard, which was recently put up for sale by its US owner AEP, as a useful acquisition. Analysts say it may face competition from Scottish & Southern Energy.

Northern Electric could also be put up for sale, some analysts believe.

fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Royal & Sun Alliance is in talks to sells its life insurance division to Dutch rival Aegon in a deal worth £1bn. The insurer's fund management operations are also up for sale as RS&A focuses on its core insurance business.

BT is close to selling £2bn of real estate to Land Securities, in an attempt to reduce its £30bn debt mountain. The deal includes 7,500 properties, which BT will then lease back and continue to occupy.

Sunday Telegraph

State-owned Electricité de France is preparing a bid for Seeboard, the south eastern electricity company, which is valued at up to £1.5bn.

Venture capital firm PPM Ventures is to back a management buyout bid for Arcadia's Warehouse, Principles, Racing Green and Hawkshead brands.

Enterprise Inns, the tenanted pub company, is preparing a £50m rights issues to help fund acquisitions.

Sunday Times

Consultancy firm Accenture has scrapped plans for a £14bn June stock market flotation because of poor market conditions.

Bernie Ecclestone has offered to sell half of his family stake in formula one racing to the five motor manufactures that are threatening to set up a breakaway Grand Prix circuit.

Tesco is set to unveil record profits of more than £1bn this week - or £2.7m a day - sparking accusations that farmers and shoppers are being exploited.

IoS

Jarvis, the civil engineering group, is in talks to buy EuroTelecom from its administrators.

Railtrack's property portfolio is for the first time since privatisation worth more than its stock market value.

Carol Galley and Stephen Zimmerman, the fund managers who are leaving Merrill Lynch, are understood to be contemplating a return to the market.

Sunday Business

The Stock Exchange will stay in the City, moving to new premises in the Paternoster Square development, next to St Paul's Cathedral.

The Department of Trade and Industry is investigating Claims Direct after anonymous internet postings ramped the shares. The company announced last month it would make a £20m loss this year due to one-off payments including ex-gratia awards to dissatisfied clients.

Railtrack is set to miss its May 24 deadline to restore Britain's railways as the backlog of routine maintenance work builds up.

Motorola has blocked a plan by Symbian, the wireless software company, to float on the London stock market later this year. Symbian is a joint venture between Motorola, Ericsson, Nokia, Psion and Matsushita. Only Psion was prepared to back the float.

Mail on Sunday

Representatives of some of the biggest high street banks have walked out of talks on setting up a Universal Bank after the government refused to indemnify them against money-laundering losses.

Staff at investment bank Merrill Lynch are preparing for job cuts this week as the slowdown in financial markets continues.

Sunday Express

The Prudential faces a six-month delay before it will know the outcome of its $21bn (£14.6bn) offer for American General.

Planet Rapido, the maker of Channel 4's Eurotrash, seems set to part company with 50% owner Virgin Communications.

webTitle: Caution as many fewer business fail

fields.headline: Caution as many fewer business fail
fields.trailText: Business failures in Britain have fallen dramatically despite foot-and-mouth disease and the US slowdown, according to figures published today.
fields.body:
Business failures in Britain have fallen dramatically despite foot-and-mouth disease and the US slowdown, according to figures published today.

Failures were down 12.6% from 10,710 to 9,360 in the three months to March 31, compared with the same period last year, said business information group Dun & Bradstreet. This is the largest drop for the first quarter since 1994.

Philip Mellor, a senior analyst at D&B, said: "If there is a further slowdown in overseas markets, we could see a significant increase in business failures in the third and fourth quarters. There is a difference between going under and clinging on for dear life, and at the moment businesses are clinging on by their fingertips."

D&B said business failures fell more than 30% in Wales and south west England, and in northern England by more than a sixth. In the southeast the figures dropped by more than a fifth and in the Midlands and East Anglia by about a tenth.

Small firms are in better shape than larger companies, with fewer than 5,000 going bankrupt during the first quarter, a drop of 17.5% on last year. Company liquidations fell 6.3%, from 4,693 to 5,395.

Mr Mellor said the figures were great news given economic uncertainty, but pointed to a 15.4% rise in failures in London, from 1,285 to 1,483, as a sign of things to come. The second quarter would be crucial.

"The rise in business failures in London is the first since 1992, and that is a direct result of institutions and finance houses making cutbacks," he said. "This has rebounded on to smaller companies in support services, like printers, and usually what happens in London is a precursor to what happens elsewhere."

webTitle: Pressure grows on ailing Marks & Spencer

fields.headline: Pressure grows on ailing Marks & Spencer
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer was last night considering making a statement to the stock exchange after the latest damaging revelations about the group's decline.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer was last night considering making a statement to the stock exchange after the latest damaging revelations about the group's decline.

A confidential internal document, revealed in the Guardian on Saturday, spelled out the detail of the appalling slide in the chain store's sales and profits. The leaked report - circulated to the chain's 13 directors and a small group of senior employees - underlines the level of dissent and infighting at the highest level in the company. An internal investigation is now under way in an attempt to find the source of the leak.

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst:
9. Claudio Silvestrin
Wonder: Barcelona Pavilion
Blunder: Bilbao Guggenheim
fields.trailText:
9. Claudio Silvestrin
Wonder: Barcelona Pavilion
Blunder: Bilbao Guggenheim
fields.body:
There are many interesting buildings - particularly modern buildings - but the stone, steel and glass Barcelona Pavilion designed by Mies van der Rohe is outstanding.

The pavilion, which was built in the late 1920s, then demolished in 1930, only to be re-created decades later, is a beautiful and elegant structure. At the same time, because of the materials used in its construction, it is impressively solid.

Yet the most important thing about the pavilion is that it was designed so long ago. It was an amazing vision, far in advance of anything else of the time. It was, and remains, a hundred years ahead of the competition.

The elegance and beauty of the pavilion, the materials used and the proportions are perfect in every detail. Everything is like a jewel.

It is an astonishing and unique structure that provides so much inspiration for me. I have seen it at least half a dozen times, and every time I go to see it I get something new and different from the experience. So many more recent buildings seem so much more conservative.

After this sublime vision, Frank Gehry's titanium-clad Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao seems like an ego-trip. It is a structure that cares only about the surface and neglects other important aspects.

It may be sensational but it is also sensationalist; it represents everything that I don't like about today's culture. I do think sensationalism has a place in architecture, but it is not something that I get particularly excited about.

 Claudio Silvestrin designed the Stanley Spencer exhibition at Tate Britain.

webTitle: How Italy betrays innocent witnesses against the mafia

fields.headline: How Italy betrays innocent witnesses against the mafia
fields.trailText: Revenge, mutilation and death are compelling reasons for Italians not to testify against the mafia. Tonight television will show them another: betrayal by the state.
fields.body:
Revenge, mutilation and death are compelling reasons for Italians not to testify against the mafia. Tonight television will show them another: betrayal by the state.

Out walking his dog one evening, Mario Nero saw a man scramble over a gate, drop a gun and run, leaving behind a corpse in a pool of blood. A businessman named Giovanni Panunzio had been assassinated for refusing to pay protection money and Mr Nero was the only witness.

He returned home and said nothing for three days until Mr Panunzio's son appeared on television, pleading: "If you know, come forward."

Mr Nero drove to the police station and made a statement. That was nine years ago. What happened since has scandalised Italy, mortified the government and damaged the fight against organised crime.

A saga of official bungling and ruthlessness turned the witness into a criminal, persecuted his family and warned other Italians not to be heroes. The story has been made into a film which will be broadcast tonight on Italian television. Advance publicity has flushed out other cases of betrayed, ruined witnesses.

It was the last thing anti-mafia investigators needed when witnesses were already deterred by savage mafia reprisals. "If you talk, we will drink your blood," is a common threat.

In November 1992 Mr Nero had a wife, a four-year-old son, infant daughter and quiet life in the city of Foggia, on Italy's heel. Before making his statement police officers guaranteed anonymity. From photographs he identified the hitman, Donato Delli Carri.

Two weeks later police officers entered Mr Nero's home before dawn to say he and his family would have to flee and enter a witness protection programme. Returning to Foggia or contacting relatives was out of the question but in return there was to be a new house, identity, job and life.

The family was dumped in an apartment in the Tuscan town of Pistoia. Minutes after police left, the manager of the apartment block arrived to demand identity documents.

But the Nero family had been given no documents. In a country as bureaucratic as Italy, where the simplest act requires paperwork, that doomed them to suspicion.

Neighbours assumed Mr Nero was a so-called pentito, a former mobster placed under protection after ratting on colleagues. Pentiti are despised as self-serving criminals.

"My daughter was ill but they stopped me bringing her to hospital because I didn't have the right papers. The doctors refused to come to the house because they considered me a mafioso," Mr Nero told the newspaper La Repubblica.

After more than a year police provided a false name, Ferretti, and badly faked documents. Three times the family moved city, but the pentito rumour followed.

In 1997 Mr Nero's evidence helped to convict 46 mobsters. No longer needed, his monthly stipend was cut off and the family evicted. With the help of a magistrate, Alfredo Manto vano, he was readmitted to the protection programme with a doubled stipend but remains angry and fearful. "The state was an enemy," said Mr Nero.

La Repubblica has found similar cases where the state has failed to protect anti-mafia witnesses. In 1993 Giuseppe Carini appalled his mafia-connected family in Sicily by identifying two gunmen who killed an outspoken priest.

He was moved to a northern city, but then promises of a new identity evaporated and he was forced to abandon medical studies under suspicion of being a gangster.

Another witness, unnamed, ended up homeless, broke and divorced after his evidence exposed a mafia boss. His monthly £200 stipend ended with a £1,700 pay-off.

Massimo Brutti, an interior minister, said the cases were representative but would not recur under a law passed in January.

"Now there is a structure for witnesses and one for judicial collaborators. I do not deny there was a lot of confusion."

fields.headline: Versace sale
fields.standfirst: Buyers splash out at charity auction of designer's belongings
fields.trailText: Buyers splash out at charity auction of designer's belongings.
fields.body:
Gianni Versace tastes got posthumous validation of a sort when a sale of his furniture, art and sketches raised $10m (£6.9m), far beyond expectations.

Versace, whose sometimes garish creations opened up the wallets of film stars, pop icons and royalty across the world, was an avid collector.

Yesterday the organisers of a three-day sale in New York of 600 items from the designers Miami home, Casa Casuarina, were celebrating the windfall. Among the beneficiaries of the sale will be a charity promoting gun safety and a fashion scholarship.

Versace's collection went back to the 16th century and trod a thin line between gaudy and baroque.

It included his own designs such as an outfit featuring Marilyn Monroe and James Dean, and a painting by Dubost called Le Retour d'Helène, which was the most expensive item, selling at $236,750 (£164,400). Armchairs and ottomans upholstered in his own fabric fetched $75,000 (£52,100), more than nine times the predicted price.

Versace, 50, was shot in the back of his head on the steps of his Florida house in 1997 by a gay serial killer who later committed suicide.

webTitle: Controversy rains on Berlin's Love Parade

fields.headline: Controversy rains on Berlin's Love Parade
fields.trailText: It was billed as the world's biggest party. But more than a million techno fans will be disappointed this summer after Berlin city council banned the rave following protests from local environmental campaigners.
fields.body:
It was billed as the world's biggest party. But more than a million techno fans will be disappointed this summer after Berlin city council banned the rave following protests from local environmental campaigners.

The Berlin councillor responsible for policing, Eckart Werthebach, stunned the organisers last week by announcing that he had refused permission for what was to have been the city's 13th Love Parade on July 14.

He said the route had already been booked for a counter-demonstration by an ad hoc group of conservationists who claim the vast open-air rave inflicts unacceptable damage on the Tiergarten, Berlin's main central park.

"I regret this," said Mr Werthebach. "But the legal regulations simply give us no alternative. Whoever registers first has priority."

The Association for the Protection of the Tiergarten said it was hoping for 25,000 people at its demonstration. Estimates of the number of ravers who came to Berlin for last year's Love Parade range from 800,000 to 1.3m.

The parade's giant floats which crawl through the Tiergarten from two directions, meeting up at the Siegessäule, or Victory Column, for a party which goes on into the night. Last year, there were more than 50 floats manned by 250 DJs from all over the world.

The park suffers damage in numerous ways. Plants and flowers are trampled and branches broken off trees and bushes. Environmentalists say the soil is being progressively degraded by ravers relieving themselves in the bushes.

But the parade also brings in an estimated £80m in tourist revenues, and - perhaps more importantly at a time when Berlin is promoting itself as the new capital of Europe - it helps the city shake off its grim historical associations. Local politicians of the right and left alike have been deeply reluctant to criticise the Love Parade in any way.

It was at first assumed that the event could be staged on another date. But it has emerged that other groups, sympathetic to the Association for the Protection of the Tiergarten, have managed to all but block-book the route through the park for the rest of the summer.

Council officials said at the weekend that there was a possibility of shifting an event planned for the following weekend. At the same time, they were reported to be trying to tempt the organiser, Planetcom, on to other routes.

Four days after the initial announcement, Planetcom had still given no official reaction, but all the indications were that it was unwilling to compromise on either the time or place of the Love Parade. At the weekend they were said still to be considering an appeal against the council ban. "This is going to go on for some time," warned a spokesman.

Claudia Hämmerling of the Berlin Greens claimed that if the Love Parade was routed away from the Tiergarten, the organisers stood to lose advertising revenue.

That has not stopped other German cities offering to give the event a new home. They include Hanover, Düsseldorf, Frankfurt and Leipzig.

Taking the Love Parade away from Berlin, though, would be like moving the Rio carnival to Brasilia. It was first staged in the year the Wall fell and is quintessentially a manifestation of the city's liberated, eccentric post-cold war spirit. It also celebrates a genre of music which the DJs of Berlin have decisively influenced.

fields.headline: Low-flying vet completes 65mph Australian odyssey
fields.standfirst: The Welsh vet who came last at every stage finally finishes
fields.trailText: The Welsh vet who came last at every stage finally finishes.
fields.body:
While a team of four British aviators were flying the $1.5m Spirit of Kai Tak to victory in a re-enactment of the historic London-Sydney air race, several thousand feet below was Maurice Kirk, spluttering along at 65mph in the oldest plane in the competition.

Mr Kirk, a vet from South Wales, finished hours behind the other competitors at every stage of the 28-day, 14,000-mile "kangaroo route", which retraced Ross and Keith Smith's first flight from Britain to Australia in 1919.

British team, Mark Wilkinson and Tim Ellison, a paraplegic since his RAF Harrier plane crashed, finished second fastest, and a helicopter flown by Britons, Jennifer Murray and Colin Bodill, beat off competition from American, Australian and Dutch crews to finish third.

But the flying vet in his 1943 Piper Cub was the first to land in Sydney on Saturday after he was banned from joining the 31 other planes in a formation flypast the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Race organisers had heard rumours that bets had been placed on Mr Kirk becoming the first pilot ever to fly a loop of the bridge.

It was just one of many brushes with the authorities for Mr Kirk <->- "either really a brave guy or a lunatic" judged one of Kai Tak's pilots, Mark Graham.

"I can't stand the bureaucracy of airports and this thing of having to land when you're told to and where," said Mr Kirk, 54, standing by his battered plane on Sydney's Bankstown landing strip. "Then they fine you for landing and then you pay extra for the motion lotion.

"In India the whole air race couldn't get any fuel. So I went down the petrol station and bought 20 gallons. I said to everyone: 'I'm in Rangoon first, last one home buys the drinks.' Except it all went wrong because the fuel pump jammed and I had to land on a jungle strip in Burma. Well, Burma was taboo. But they were all in skirts and treated me like royalty. They fed me, it was fantastic."

Mr Kirk, who only started the race after an American saw his "School of Rough Flying" website and stumped up the $55,000 (£35,000) entry fee, completed it with dozens of unscheduled landings.

His first came moments after taking off from Biggin Hill, Kent, at the start of the race on March 11, when his instrument panel failed. His last was on the final leg of the race after bolts flew off his propeller.

In between were more recreational touch-downs, including a visit to a disused airfield in Cairo to inspect a "graveyard" of 100 wrecked planes, and a refuelling stop on the drive of a farm in Australia, where Mr Kirk was given beer and food.

The flying vet preferred the comfort of strangers to the hospitality laid on by the race organisers. "They made us stay in these horrible, what do they call them, hotels. Horrible big expensive hotels," he said.

He got so far behind the other competitors the race organisers tried to stop him carrying on beyond Cannes. "They wouldn't let me race. It was logistics. They really couldn't cope with the Cub. Or was it Maurice Kirk? I forget which."

While the Spirit of Kai Tak's four pilots took their twin-engined turbo Piper Aerostar to 25,000ft to benefit from strong tailwinds, Mr Kirk gasped for air in his open cockpit at 7,000ft, in a plane that had never been above 1000ft in its life. He was forced to fly at just 25ft above the Timor sea because of strong headwinds, reaching Australia at nightfall, with half an inch of oil left in the sump.

The flying vet's 65mph cruising speed also attracted the suspicion of Indian officials, who detained him for nine hours and accused him of spying.

"They said: 'Why is it all the other race aircraft have come past Jaipur in three hours from Karachi and you've landed nine hours after the others? We believe you've landed and have taken photos of our installations. We couldn't see you on radar.'

"I said: 'What? You couldn't see me on radar? I'm going straight back to Pakistan. I could make a fortune on this one - I'm going to sell it to them.' They didn't like that," said Mr Kirk. "Very quiet trip otherwise."

The flying vet said it was time to get back to Wales to do a day's work. "She's a tired old lady, like her pilot," he said, patting his Cub. Then Mr Kirk gave a grin. "That doesn't mean I'm not going to loop the bridge before I leave Australia."

He was forced to fly at just 25ft above the Timor sea because of strong headwinds, reaching Australia at nightfall, with half an inch of oil left in the sump. The flying vet's 65mph cruising speed also attracted the suspicion of Indian officials, who detained him for nine hours and accused him of spying. "They said: 'Why is it all the other race aircraft have come past Jaipur in three hours from Karachi and you've landed nine hours after the others? We believe you've landed and have taken photos of our installations. We couldn't see you on radar.' "I said: 'What? You couldn't see me on radar? I'm going straight back to Pakistan. I could make a fortune on this one - I'm going to sell it to them.' They didn't like that," said Mr Kirk. "Very quiet trip otherwise." The flying vet said it was time to get back to Wales to do a day's work. "She's a tired old lady, like her pilot," he said, patting his Cub. Then Mr Kirk gave a grin. "That doesn't mean I'm not going to loop the bridge before I leave Australia." Useful links www.airrace.com.au London to Sydney air race www.kirkflyingvet.co.uk/ Maurice Kirk's website

webTitle: Gloomy forecast: not-so-Great Lakes, not-so-great states

fields.headline: Gloomy forecast: not-so-Great Lakes, not-so-great states
fields.standfirst:
From coast to coast, the consequences of global warming in America could be devastating, scientists warn

Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: From coast to coast, the consequences of global warming in America could be devastating, scientists warn.
fields.body:
As George Bush and his friends in the Texas oil industry try to turn the clock back on commitments the United States has made on fighting global warming, a new report by America's leading scientists confirms the serious effects of climate change on the world's most prosperous and polluting nation.

Three hundred of the most illustrious names in US science were consulted before the National Science and Technology Council produced the report, published this week, reviewing the costs and benefits to America. A copy is being sent to every senator and congressman so that they can see the effect on their voters.

In the wake of the report it will be increasingly difficult to claim, as Mr Bush has in the last few weeks, that the science of climate change is still unproved. Instead the scientists hope the debate will move on to what actions need to be taken to mitigate the effects of climate change which the report says will happen whatever what the administration decides to do.

The general picture painted in the report is of a country with a tradition of wilderness and wide open spaces placing its natural heritage under increasing pressure. The spectre of the Great Lakes beginning to dry out, trout and salmon disappearing as rivers warm and alpine meadows and snow fields under threat is balanced by greater agricultural productivity in the warmer north and increased tree growth.

Coastal threats

But it is the 95,000 miles of coastline and the 3.4m sq miles of ocean inside US territorial waters where the news is most alarming. Corals are already dying because of the heat, damaging the tourist industry, wetlands needed for fish breeding are disappearing, and the 53% of the US population that live in the coastal zone are threatened by sea level rise.

The best estimate is that sea levels will rise by 48cm (19in) this century but it could be as much as 95cm (37in). Coastal land levels are falling because of the way silt from floods is prevented from reaching the coast by river management.

The report will make daunting reading in particular for Florida, the state whose controversial voting system put Mr Bush in the White House. "Atlantic and Gulf coast shorelines are especially vulnerable to long term sea level rise as well as an increase in the frequency of storm surges or hurricanes," the authors say.

Most erosion is caused suddenly during storms. The slope of areas like Florida is so gentle that a small rise in sea level produces a large inland shift of the shoreline.

"When buildings, roads, sea walls block this natural shift, the beaches and shorelines erode, especially during storm events. Coastal towns and cities, especially those in storm-prone regions such as the south-east, are particularly vulnerable to extreme events. Intensive residential and commercial development in such regions put life and property at risk."

Other heavily populated regions away from the coasts also have bad news. The extra heat trapped and retained by cities, particularly at night, make many old, ill and poor people vulnerable to heatstroke and related illnesses. Insect- and rodent-borne diseases are expected to become more widespread. Air pollution which also kills is noticeably worse in hot spells.

The report is being published on Friday in a week when Mr Bush will come under increasing diplomatic and domestic pressure to change course on climate. Having rejected carbon dioxide curbs on electricity producers his policy increasingly leans towards helping Texas oil interests.

The New York Times revealed at the weekend that an energy task force headed by the vice-president, Dick Cheney, was intending to open up millions of acres of public land to new oil and gas exploration. Along with the already controversial Arctic National Wildlife Reserve in Alaska, which has been flagged up by Mr Bush as a target, Mr Cheney has earmarked other sensitive areas.

These include large protected areas of the Rockies, parts of the Lewis and Clark National Forest in Montana and the Jack Morrow Hills in Wyoming. Another 17m acres of federal land in 11 western states under temporary protection from energy development would be removed. There is 137 trillion cubic feet of gas, mostly under the Rockies, enough to supply the US for six years.

"Natural ecosystems, which are our life support system in many important ways, appear to be the most vulnerable to the harmful effects of climate change," the report says.

As well as predictable outcomes of climate change there will be surprises. Alterations in ocean circulation, cloud distribution, or storms could bring prolonged spells of completely different weather wrecking normal agriculture.

The assessment is based on greenhouse gas emissions continuing on present trends. But even with reductions brought about by international agreements the the US and the rest of the planet are certain to experience more than a century of climate change, owing to the long lifetimes of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide already in the atmosphere and the momentum of the climate system.

Internationally, the EU, Japan and Russia, the three largest parties to the Climate Change Convention, look increasingly likely to gang up on Mr Bush. The Kyoto protocol, which Mr Bush has repudiated, could still come into legal force without the US if these countries cooperate. If developed countries with 55% of global emissions of greenhouse gases in 1990 all ratified the treaty it should come into binding effect, but without the US. The EU, Russia and Japan all said last week that this was their intention.

If the plan works, the effect on climate change would not be great. However, US industrial giants are likely to be unhappy about being cut out of worldwide carbon trading and billion dollar export markets transferring clean technologies to developing countries.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rally opposes Russian TV sale
fields.body:
Rally opposes Russian TV sale

Thousands of supporters of NTV, Russia's only independent national television channel, massed in St Petersburg yesterday, backing what the station's journalists call a fight against the Kremlin to save free media.

Around 4,000 people packed Troitskaya Square, opposite the Winter Palace, a day after a Moscow rally to support NTV's stand against last week's bid for control by the state-dominated gas giant Gazprom.

Reuters, St Petersburg

Peru votes after dirty campaign

Peruvians went to the polls yesterday to choose a new president to succeed Albert Fujimori. The favourite after a campaign marred by mudslinging is Alejandro Toledo, 55, an economist who is one of 16 children born to a bricklayer in a remote Andean village. A runoff will be needed in late May or early June between the two frontrunners in the race.

AP, Lima

Egypt criticises Israeli actions

Egypt's foreign minister Amr Moussa has condemned Israel's "provocative" response to the Palestinian intifada, after a meeting yesterday between Palestinian president Yasser Arafat and his Egyptian counterpart Hosni Mubarak. He said Israel was seeking a Palestinian "surrender," which Arabs could not accept.

Reuters, Cairo

Father copies son's suicide

A row over a bad school report ended in a double suicide last Thursday in a village near Avignon, France. Frédéric Vivaroli, 15, shot himself after his father told him off.

When his father saw him lying dead with the report beside him, he picked up the same gun and killed himself in front of his grieving wife.

Reuters, Paris

Fire shuts down Schiphol airport

Thousands of people were evacuated from Schiphol airport in Amsterdam yesterday after an explosion and large fire in the passenger terminal. The explosion apparently occurred in an oven of a Burger King restaurant.

AP, Amsterdam

webTitle: Arms firm supplied cars to ANC officials

fields.headline: Arms firm supplied cars to ANC officials
fields.trailText: A European weapons maker at the centre of an investigation into alleged influence-buying in South Africa has admitted delivering luxury cars to 30 top government, defence and aviation officials while bidding for a multimillion pound arms contract.
fields.body:
A European weapons maker at the centre of an investigation into alleged influence-buying in South Africa has admitted delivering luxury cars to 30 top government, defence and aviation officials while bidding for a multimillion pound arms contract.

The admission came after weeks of controversy about how two Mercedes cars bought by the firm, the European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company, came to be registered in the names of the ruling African National Congress's parliamentary chief whip, Tony Yengeni, and his wife.

Thabo Mbeki's government is facing accusations of covering up graft in the awarding of contracts for a highly controversial and unpopular arms deal worth 43bn rand (£4bn). Critics have asked why a na tion with many people sorely in need of better housing and medical services is using such a sum on arms.

Last week, the head of one of three government agencies investigating, said prosecutions are likely in the biggest corruption scandal in South Africa since apartheid ended.

The European consortium, EADS - owned by DaimlerChrysler and the arms companies Aerospatiale Matra of France and Casa of Spain - admitted in a statement to Sunday newspapers in Johannesburg that it had "rendered assistance" to about 30 officials to get luxury vehicles. DaimlerChrysler also owns Mercedes-Benz.

"The sectors concerned were the civil airlines, defence, electronic industries, diplomatic and political officials," it said.

This assistance amounted to "price discounts" and ensuring those favoured were moved up waiting lists, it said, but de clined to specify how cheaply the cars were sold. It claimed it still profited from the sales.

All of the favours were awarded in the past three years during negotiations that led to EADS winning a £37m contract to supply missiles and radar for four new navy corvettes.

The admission comes after EADS - previously called Daimler Chrysler Aerospace - repeatedly stalled over questions about how and why Mr Yengeni got a Mercedes through the company. Records showed that the £32,000 vehicle was ordered as a staff car by EADS but within days of arriving in South Africa in October 1998, was transferred to Mr Yengeni. At the time, he was chairman of parliament's defence committee. It was heavily involved in the arms deal.

Mr Yengeni eventually came to a financial agreement with DaimlerChrysler to start paying for the vehicle, but only after rumours started in parlia ment that he had received it as a gift and failed to declare it.

In February this year, Mr Yengeni, as chief whip, ordered ANC MPs on a watchdog committee to reject proposals for the country's leading anti-corruption investigator, Judge Willem Heath, to scrutinise the arms deal.

Among voters and MPs many wanted the judge to look into the matter after South Africa's auditor general said there may have been kick backs and nepotism in the awarding of contracts.

Mr Yengeni told parliament last week he did no wrong: "The acquisition of the vehicle did not in any way whatsoever influence the award, or is related with the award of any contract in the arms procurement" under investigation.

Last month it was revealed that his wife also got a car through EADS. She says she paid for it, but has not revealed the price.

fields.headline: Boys from the black stuff
fields.standfirst: Somewhere beneath the dark North Sea waters off Hartlepool lie great, unmined seams of coal. Twice a day, the waves dump tons of it on the beaches and, for generations, a small band of men has scraped a living by collecting it. Now the council is trying to stop them.  Jonathan Tulloch joined the seacoalers at low tide
fields.trailText: Somewhere beneath the dark North Sea waters off Hartlepool lie great, unmined seams of coal. Twice a day, the waves dump tons of it on the beaches and, for generations, a small band of men has scraped a living by collecting it. Now the council is trying to stop them. Jonathan Tulloch joined the seacoalers at low tide.
fields.body:
A fresh easterly is the best harvesting wind. It is a bitter blow that chews the face, harries the waves high on to the beach, and tortures the anchored container ships awaiting entrance to Teesport. But it is also the wind that brings in the coal shoals of the North Sea to Hartlepool.

No one knows where the seams lie exactly, but every tide lifts its load from the seabed and drags it landward, tumbling and turning through itself like a shoal of black sprat. "We've been here as long as the gulls," Steve Wilkins says as he digs.

Seacoaling is a hard way to make a living. Dumped twice a day by the tides on to one of Hartlepool's many beaches, seacoal is fine-grained as congealing tar. A handful of it glitters slightly, and sifts pleasurably through the fingers. But mixed with acrid salt water, sand and other marine particles, it quickly loses any aesthetic qualities. It is heavy, and must be scraped up and loaded on to the specially constructed hold of a Land Rover by means only of a rake and shovel. And a constantly bending back.

One load is two tons. On a good day a seacoaler might collect four or five loads from a single tide. Steve once gleaned 18. That's 36 tons with a rake and a shovel. It was the best day he can remember. And the hardest.

No day is the same for the seacoalers. They work the tides, and consequently find themselves heading for the foreshore at any and every hour of the 24. Seven days a week. Theirs is the rota of the moon.

In all there are about 11 owners of these ex-army surplus Land Rovers. Each with their sidelad. Arriving at the turn of the tide, the seacoalers first locate the coal, then as the tide ebbs they rake it up into long furrows or molehill heaps, depending on the lie of it, and finally load up as the tide waxes again. To be able to do this, day and night, each seacoaler has had to learn to speak the language of the sea as fluently as any fisherman.

There are only two of them working the beach tonight. Steve, who owns the vehicle, and his sidelad, Mick. They work in perfect harmony, as smoothly and efficiently as an elegantly constructed piece of machinery. A massive flask of tea squats close by in the sand, vainly waiting for one of the few breaks. There is little chat. Working with the fluxes of the sea, time is of the essence.

They are heirs to a long tradition. During the great Northumbrian civilisation of the seventh century, the monks of Blackhall Rocks, just north of Hartlepool, heated their cavernous cells with what they gathered from the tide. Until recently many people in Hartlepool fed their fires with the black crop of the sea. Indeed the figure wheeling a bicycle up from the beach with four bags of seacoal balanced on handle-and crossbars is still common.

But the tradition is under threat. A vocal minority, apparently goaded on by a local newspaper, the Hartlepool Mail, are waging a vigorous campaign against the seacoalers. They are concerned about the dangers to pedestrians; an off-the-lead dog has recently been killed under the wheels of a cumbersome Land Rover. Protesters also cite the disturbance from seacoaling vehicles driving through built-up areas to their depots.

Having loaded up, Steve now begins the hazardous journey to the depot by driving into the sea. Like soil disturbed by a ploughshare, the water foams from his wheels. One by one Hartlepool borough council is blocking vehicular access to the foreshores, and tonight, since he is working the northern limit of Seaton Carew beach, Steve must round the tip of a sewage pipe. "See that bonnet?" he asks, indicating the nose of the Land Rover which is pointing to where the lonely lights of the container ships can be seen twinkling in the open sea. "When I can see the water on there, then I start to worry."

Heavily burdened, the Land Rover sinks slightly in the soft sand at the lip of the pipe. A 20ft wave is towering in. Steve eyes it. It breaks. A weird sensation of weightlessness in the cab of this heavy vehicle is followed by the welcome hasp of wheels on denser sand. "The thing is," he smiles. "I trust my judgment."

The slow, bouncy track through boulders and rocks up the seabank must be improvised anew with each tide. It is no surprise, given this and the corrosive salt of the sea, that seacoalers must change their Land Rovers once a year.

The depot, at which seacoalers are paid by the ton, is closed at this hour, but Steve has a key. Having crossed the small weighbridge, he adds our load to the heap, and quickly turns round. Inexorably the sea is coming in towards the pipe. There will only be one more load tonight. In our absence Steve's son has arrived. One look at his face, and the way he grafts, is to know him as his father's son. Already he has half-filled his own Land Rover. "Where we live," Steve explains, pausing in his shovelling only to glance at his son, "there's heroin and that. I'm lucky with this young 'un. He knows how to work." Later he adds thoughtfully. "Say if he asks me for money? I point at the Land Rover on the drive. He knows where the beach is."

In the imagination of some local people, the seacoaler stands with a shovel raised threateningly over his thread and a volley of abuse on his tongue. To some they represent the archetypal roughneck, the shadowy, lazy, even dangerous figure at the margins of the labour market. Fights between different gangs of seacoalers loom large in Hartlepool folklore. "They think we're scum," Steve says as he works. "Call us the raggy lads, they do. Anything bad happens in the town, then it must have been us."

This image contrasts with the truth. To seacoal, above all, is to know work. Steve gets home tonight at 11. He must be back at the beach for seven tomorrow morning. Anyone who is remotely lazy, overtly rowdy or too fond of a pint would not last two days working the tide.

But not only that. There is a generosity of the spirit. Within 10 minutes of meeting us, Steve had taken the front door key from his fob. "Stop with us," he had offered.

The depot is open in time for the first load of the next morning. Even in the light of day this place is black; seacoal permeates everything. As Steve takes us to meet the owner of the depot, John Kirby, his foots sinks up to the ankle. Behind towering slabs of corrugated iron, topped with barbed wire, the machinery for separating sand from coal crouches amongst the heaps, gaunt and rusty like the ghost of a gallows. An image straight from the early years of the industrial revolution.

As John shows us round the place, a skylark rises in song from behind one of the heaps. "They won't win," John says with similar soaring energy. "We'll fight until the end."

With only a shovel to his name, John's father, Ken, began on the beach just after the war. Seizing one of the few opportunities for the Hartlepudlian entrepreneur, he quickly secured a vehicle for himself, a large eight-ton ex-army truck, then a second, before finally graduating to ownership of a depot. There are six or seven well-known millionaires in Hartlepool who made their start toiling in the bitter easterlies. A tradition of enterprise continued by John, who often loans the money for those seeking to buy their first Land Rover, the beach and its people being a no-go area for banks and other credit agencies.

In the heady days of the 60s and 70s, when the local power stations took far larger orders than they do now, Hartlepool Council was forced to issue licences, bestowing its blessing on the enterprise, but before, and since then, the real story has been one of obstacles.

Individual seacoalers have frequently found themselves in court for theft, but they have always been acquitted. This is because the Flotsam and Jetsam Act decrees that the booty of the sea is free for all. Seacoaling is the expression of a common right. A fact that the Hartlepool Mail greets with such headlines as: "Thieves will not be prosecuted."

All that the council can do now is to block access, which is what they are doing as they gradually redevelop the coastline. On one occasion they laid huge boulders at a strategic point, but some time in the night, when only seacoalers are about, digging machinery ramped the immense blockage with sand. This isn't an example of the perceived anarchy that so enrages the protesters. "Whoever did that," says John with a twinkle in his eye, "knows that a right of way must be vigorously defended."

However, the sword of Damocles still hangs. The council are currently waiting for a grant from Maff to develop Seaton Carew front. Plans show that this would finish John and the 40 or 50 people whose jobs are connected with trade.

Perhaps this is a way of life dissonant with the image the council wants for the borough, with its new marina and other so-called prestige developments, but in a place where secure jobs and the dignity and stability of family life that go with them are as rare as a skylark above a coal heap, John literally holds his head in his hands at the situation. He does not ask for the grants that foreign investors demand as a right, he asks only that the playing field be as level as the gently sloping beach of Seaton Carew, which makes it the ideal natural staith, or loading place, for seacoal.

John's depot is a few hundred yards from the beach. If an access point was located closer to him, then the Land Rovers would no longer need to drive through the built-up areas. "We listen to the protesters," John says. "We'll do what's reasonable, compromise, undertake any safety measures. Just don't take our jobs away."

There are also environmental issues. Land Rovers can no longer gain access to the Middleton basin beach, and the seacoal there is already knee deep. Without Steve's shovel, the beaches of Hartlepool would all begin to resemble the depots. Then there are the melancholy container ships that haunt this coastline, all full of the oil demanded by the chemical industry of Teesside. When the inevitable spill occurs, there are techniques on hand to separate oil from sand, but not for separating coal and oil. The destruction of the seacoalers may not only be a disaster in human terms.

More seacoalers arrive on the beach. The hours of the morning are passing, and they must work whilst the tide allows them. They are a close-knit fraternity, but increasingly they have to fragment themselves on the casualised labour market. Lack of vehicle access means they can no longer work a full 12 months. Now they must also work the short-term contracts on offer by local industry. Six weeks here, six weeks there. Or take the dole. A far cry from the proud independence of seacoaling where each man is his own boss.

"See me?" Steve tells me suddenly. "I've never had a shilling off the dole."

And this is what seacoaling is all about. The dignity of independence.

It is hard to imagine more resourceful entrepreneurs. To bring up a family with values of work and independence in this bleakest of job environments is a stunning achievement. On some estates, devastated by the winds of change and decline, a wind as bitter as the local coastal blows, unemployment touches 30%.

These are the grafters who have answered the age-old paradox of the riddle song Scarborough Fair and have managed to plough that elusive acre of ground lying "between the sea foam and the sea sand".

This is because he knows, as long generations of seacoalers have always known, that a fresh easterly, no matter how cold, is the best harvesting wind.

fields.bodyText: A fresh easterly is the best harvesting wind. It is a bitter blow that chews the face, harries the waves high on to the beach, and tortures the anchored container ships awaiting entrance to Teesport. But it is also the wind that brings in the coal shoals of the North Sea to Hartlepool. No one knows where the seams lie exactly, but every tide lifts its load from the seabed and drags it landward, tumbling and turning through itself like a shoal of black sprat. "We've been here as long as the gulls," Steve Wilkins says as he digs. Seacoaling is a hard way to make a living. Dumped twice a day by the tides on to one of Hartlepool's many beaches, seacoal is fine-grained as congealing tar. A handful of it glitters slightly, and sifts pleasurably through the fingers. But mixed with acrid salt water, sand and other marine particles, it quickly loses any aesthetic qualities. It is heavy, and must be scraped up and loaded on to the specially constructed hold of a Land Rover by means only of a rake and shovel. And a constantly bending back. One load is two tons. On a good day a seacoaler might collect four or five loads from a single tide. Steve once gleaned 18. That's 36 tons with a rake and a shovel. It was the best day he can remember. And the hardest. No day is the same for the seacoalers. They work the tides, and consequently find themselves heading for the foreshore at any and every hour of the 24. Seven days a week. Theirs is the rota of the moon. In all there are about 11 owners of these ex-army surplus Land Rovers. Each with their sidelad. Arriving at the turn of the tide, the seacoalers first locate the coal, then as the tide ebbs they rake it up into long furrows or molehill heaps, depending on the lie of it, and finally load up as the tide waxes again. To be able to do this, day and night, each seacoaler has had to learn to speak the language of the sea as fluently as any fisherman. There are only two of them working the beach tonight. Steve, who owns the vehicle, and his sidelad, Mick. They work in perfect harmony, as smoothly and efficiently as an elegantly constructed piece of machinery. A massive flask of tea squats close by in the sand, vainly waiting for one of the few breaks. There is little chat. Working with the fluxes of the sea, time is of the essence. They are heirs to a long tradition. During the great Northumbrian civilisation of the seventh century, the monks of Blackhall Rocks, just north of Hartlepool, heated their cavernous cells with what they gathered from the tide. Until recently many people in Hartlepool fed their fires with the black crop of the sea. Indeed the figure wheeling a bicycle up from the beach with four bags of seacoal balanced on handle-and crossbars is still common. But the tradition is under threat. A vocal minority, apparently goaded on by a local newspaper, the Hartlepool Mail, are waging a vigorous campaign against the seacoalers. They are concerned about the dangers to pedestrians; an off-the-lead dog has recently been killed under the wheels of a cumbersome Land Rover. Protesters also cite the disturbance from seacoaling vehicles driving through built-up areas to their depots. Having loaded up, Steve now begins the hazardous journey to the depot by driving into the sea. Like soil disturbed by a ploughshare, the water foams from his wheels. One by one Hartlepool borough council is blocking vehicular access to the foreshores, and tonight, since he is working the northern limit of Seaton Carew beach, Steve must round the tip of a sewage pipe. "See that bonnet?" he asks, indicating the nose of the Land Rover which is pointing to where the lonely lights of the container ships can be seen twinkling in the open sea. "When I can see the water on there, then I start to worry." Heavily burdened, the Land Rover sinks slightly in the soft sand at the lip of the pipe. A 20ft wave is towering in. Steve eyes it. It breaks. A weird sensation of weightlessness in the cab of this heavy vehicle is followed by the welcome hasp of wheels on denser sand. "The thing is," he smiles. "I trust my judgment." The slow, bouncy track through boulders and rocks up the seabank must be improvised anew with each tide. It is no surprise, given this and the corrosive salt of the sea, that seacoalers must change their Land Rovers once a year. The depot, at which seacoalers are paid by the ton, is closed at this hour, but Steve has a key. Having crossed the small weighbridge, he adds our load to the heap, and quickly turns round. Inexorably the sea is coming in towards the pipe. There will only be one more load tonight. In our absence Steve's son has arrived. One look at his face, and the way he grafts, is to know him as his father's son. Already he has half-filled his own Land Rover. "Where we live," Steve explains, pausing in his shovelling only to glance at his son, "there's heroin and that. I'm lucky with this young 'un. He knows how to work." Later he adds thoughtfully. "Say if he asks me for money? I point at the Land Rover on the drive. He knows where the beach is." In the imagination of some local people, the seacoaler stands with a shovel raised threateningly over his thread and a volley of abuse on his tongue. To some they represent the archetypal roughneck, the shadowy, lazy, even dangerous figure at the margins of the labour market. Fights between different gangs of seacoalers loom large in Hartlepool folklore. "They think we're scum," Steve says as he works. "Call us the raggy lads, they do. Anything bad happens in the town, then it must have been us." This image contrasts with the truth. To seacoal, above all, is to know work. Steve gets home tonight at 11. He must be back at the beach for seven tomorrow morning. Anyone who is remotely lazy, overtly rowdy or too fond of a pint would not last two days working the tide. But not only that. There is a generosity of the spirit. Within 10 minutes of meeting us, Steve had taken the front door key from his fob. "Stop with us," he had offered. The depot is open in time for the first load of the next morning. Even in the light of day this place is black; seacoal permeates everything. As Steve takes us to meet the owner of the depot, John Kirby, his foots sinks up to the ankle. Behind towering slabs of corrugated iron, topped with barbed wire, the machinery for separating sand from coal crouches amongst the heaps, gaunt and rusty like the ghost of a gallows. An image straight from the early years of the industrial revolution. As John shows us round the place, a skylark rises in song from behind one of the heaps. "They won't win," John says with similar soaring energy. "We'll fight until the end." With only a shovel to his name, John's father, Ken, began on the beach just after the war. Seizing one of the few opportunities for the Hartlepudlian entrepreneur, he quickly secured a vehicle for himself, a large eight-ton ex-army truck, then a second, before finally graduating to ownership of a depot. There are six or seven well-known millionaires in Hartlepool who made their start toiling in the bitter easterlies. A tradition of enterprise continued by John, who often loans the money for those seeking to buy their first Land Rover, the beach and its people being a no-go area for banks and other credit agencies. In the heady days of the 60s and 70s, when the local power stations took far larger orders than they do now, Hartlepool Council was forced to issue licences, bestowing its blessing on the enterprise, but before, and since then, the real story has been one of obstacles. Individual seacoalers have frequently found themselves in court for theft, but they have always been acquitted. This is because the Flotsam and Jetsam Act decrees that the booty of the sea is free for all. Seacoaling is the expression of a common right. A fact that the Hartlepool Mail greets with such headlines as: "Thieves will not be prosecuted." All that the council can do now is to block access, which is what they are doing as they gradually redevelop the coastline. On one occasion they laid huge boulders at a strategic point, but some time in the night, when only seacoalers are about, digging machinery ramped the immense blockage with sand. This isn't an example of the perceived anarchy that so enrages the protesters. "Whoever did that," says John with a twinkle in his eye, "knows that a right of way must be vigorously defended." However, the sword of Damocles still hangs. The council are currently waiting for a grant from Maff to develop Seaton Carew front. Plans show that this would finish John and the 40 or 50 people whose jobs are connected with trade. Perhaps this is a way of life dissonant with the image the council wants for the borough, with its new marina and other so-called prestige developments, but in a place where secure jobs and the dignity and stability of family life that go with them are as rare as a skylark above a coal heap, John literally holds his head in his hands at the situation. He does not ask for the grants that foreign investors demand as a right, he asks only that the playing field be as level as the gently sloping beach of Seaton Carew, which makes it the ideal natural staith, or loading place, for seacoal. John's depot is a few hundred yards from the beach. If an access point was located closer to him, then the Land Rovers would no longer need to drive through the built-up areas. "We listen to the protesters," John says. "We'll do what's reasonable, compromise, undertake any safety measures. Just don't take our jobs away." There are also environmental issues. Land Rovers can no longer gain access to the Middleton basin beach, and the seacoal there is already knee deep. Without Steve's shovel, the beaches of Hartlepool would all begin to resemble the depots. Then there are the melancholy container ships that haunt this coastline, all full of the oil demanded by the chemical industry of Teesside. When the inevitable spill occurs, there are techniques on hand to separate oil from sand, but not for separating coal and oil. The destruction of the seacoalers may not only be a disaster in human terms. More seacoalers arrive on the beach. The hours of the morning are passing, and they must work whilst the tide allows them. They are a close-knit fraternity, but increasingly they have to fragment themselves on the casualised labour market. Lack of vehicle access means they can no longer work a full 12 months. Now they must also work the short-term contracts on offer by local industry. Six weeks here, six weeks there. Or take the dole. A far cry from the proud independence of seacoaling where each man is his own boss. "See me?" Steve tells me suddenly. "I've never had a shilling off the dole." And this is what seacoaling is all about. The dignity of independence. It is hard to imagine more resourceful entrepreneurs. On some estates, devastated by the winds of change and decline, a wind as bitter as the local coastal blows, unemployment touches 30%. He is one of the few people in Hartlepool who likes these cruel sea winds. This is because he knows, as long generations of seacoalers have always known, that a fresh easterly, no matter how cold, is the best harvesting wind.  Jonathan Tulloch's second novel, The Bonny Lads, is published by Jonathan Cape, priced £10.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Hugh Hefner

fields.headline: No 1855
fields.standfirst: Hugh Hefner
fields.trailText: Hugh Hefner.
fields.body:
The Playboy bloke? The porn king? I'll have you know Playboy is full of serious features and interviews.

No one reads it for those. On the contrary. Thousands of blind readers peruse the Braille edition every month.

To learn about beauty queens? No, for in-depth pieces about top personalities such as Fidel Castro, John Lennon and Jesse Jackson.

But there are dirty pictures, aren't there? A few tasteful photos, or so we're told. Marilyn Monroe was the first centrefold in 1953 - a shoot that launched her on a megabucks career and hedonistic lifestyle. Brigitte Bardot, Vanessa Redgrave and Cindy Crawford have all followed as pin-ups.

Isn't he famous for sleeping with his centrefolds? None of the above, but does claim to have slept with more than 1,000 women - with a little help of late from Viagra.

So what's the old dog up to now? It's his 75th birthday today, and he's coming to London to celebrate it.

Wearing pyjamas? That's his business wear. This is relaxation. He'll be shopping, eating and partying his way round town.

Who does he hang out with? He has plenty of bunnies to choose from. Plus the parties at his LA mansion are back in fashion. Leonardo DiCaprio, Jim Carrey and Cameron Diaz have replaced the rat pack of Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin. It's all part of retro cool - cigars, martinis and Playboy.

Has no one got any morals? Al Gore declined an invite - but look what happened to him.

But the rabbit is just ridiculous, isn't it? Hugh thought it gave Playboy a frisky, playful, yet sophisticated image. He drew it in half an hour, but it became so well known that a reader's letter once reached him with just the bunny's head for an address. He even had a rare rabbit named after him - Sylvilagus palustris hefneri .

Most likely to say: "I'll pay you $100,000 to take your clothes off."

Not to be confused with: Richard Desmond, Peter Stringfellow, Larry Flynt.

webTitle: Portrait of loyalist murderer Michael Stone

fields.headline: Rogue's gallery
fields.standfirst:
He is one of Northern Ireland's most notorious murderers. Now, released from prison under the Good Friday agreement, Michael Stone is building a new reputation as an artist. But, finds Rosie Cowan, his past still stalks him

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: He is one of Northern Ireland's most notorious murderers. Now, released from prison under the Good Friday agreement, Michael Stone is building a new reputation as an artist. But, finds Rosie Cowan, his past still stalks him.
fields.body:
Michael Stone uses plenty of vivid reds, oranges and purples in his paintings. He boldly layers on oils in dominant, representational images. He's always liked bright colours but there's also a bit of black humour, a sort of dare to amateur psychoanalysts tempted to interpret his work as the outpourings of a violent, tormented soul. For this slightly built man, who amiably proffers tea and biscuits, is one of Northern Ireland's most notorious loyalist murderers, a hate figure for many Catholics since he launched a suicidal, lone attack in Belfast's Milltown cemetery in 1988.

Television cameras captured the horror as he opened fire, killing three people and injuring dozens, including pensioners and children, at the funeral of three IRA members shot dead by the SAS in Gibraltar. He later admitted his part in three other murders and numerous terrorist offences and received six life sentences, but walked free from the Maze prison last July after serving just 12 years, one of the last inmates to be given early release under the terms of the Good Friday agreement.

Born into a sectarian hotbed in east Belfast, Stone joined the Tartans, an infamous loyalist group, when he was 13. At 16, he had already joined the Ulster Defence Association and done time in Belfast's Crumlin Road jail for possession of firearms. He hatched the idea for Milltown after the IRA bomb killed 11 people attending a Poppy Day memorial service at the cenotaph in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh, in 1987.

He knew there was a chance he wouldn't get away, and it was the RUC who rescued him as he was being beaten and kicked in the aftermath of his attack. His thighbone was dislocated and he still walks with a slight limp. The brush and easel might seem a surreal choice for a man once much more familiar with gun and grenade. But he says he was always keen on art, and ironically, prison gave him the time and inclination to pursue that interest.

The man who previously chopped up prison furniture and stretched starched linen sheets over it to make surfaces to paint on now has work hanging in some of Belfast's trendiest riverside apartments and corporate boardrooms. Buyers come from as far away as the US and some of his former jailers are also proud owners of Stone originals.

"I was in solitary confinement for a year after Milltown and they gave me pencils and a sketch book to pass the time, although they took the pencils off me at night, because I was on suicide watch and could have harmed myself with them," he explained. "I had to draw from memory because obviously, there wasn't much to look at. Eventually, I got out of solitary and had access to a lot more materials, including watercolour and oil paints.

"We had excellent teachers and artists in residence, including Professor Brian Maguire, from Trinity College Dublin, who has painted portraits of all sorts of people, from Charlie Haughey [former Irish prime minister] to Martin Cahill [Dublin gangster]. Brian slept on my wing for six months.

"Prisoners were allowed to paint their cells any colour, but mine was a like a rainbow because I was always wiping my brushes on the wall. I suppose the colours were a reaction against the dull surroundings, and I also included metallic touches, an echo of the prison bars.

"For a while, there was a high sheen off everything because I could only get gloss, and everything was a square 2ft by 2ft, so that it could fit through the X-ray machine for visitors to take home." Stone soon found his talents in demand, drawing birthday and Christmas cards for fellow inmates and prison officers, and realised some of his work was taking longer to get out of the prison because the governors were showing it off to guests.

"I wanted to do bigger stuff but didn't have canvases, so I sawed up a table and a wardrobe, glued bits together and pulled linen sheets over them. Eventually, the screws caught on and I was given polyester sheets, which didn't quite work."

Stone is still painting and wants to mount an exhibition in the near future. He is well aware there is a certain morbid curiosity about his work because of his violent past but says others' perceptions are outside his control. "I know people are thinking the hands that painted these pictures killed people. Yes, I regret taking life and that is with me every day. I wanted to take out top republicans, leadership, [Gerry] Adams, [Martin] McGuinness, not others.

"I can't go back on that aim, but I am glad there is peace. I support the principles of the Good Friday agreement but many things are not working out in practice."

He spends time each week teaching art to teenagers in deprived areas of east Belfast, something he gets great satisfaction from. "Sure, I'm like some Rambo character to them when they first meet me and they ask questions about what I did. But I just tell them it isn't big and clever to kill people. Then we get down to work, making things and doing things.

"There aren't a lot of jobs or facilities in their area but they're good kids and they've got to be encouraged to make the most of what they have."

Stone's paintings are not overtly political but some have topical themes. He points to a large, rectangular piece, called Good Friday agreement, where a seated figure, representing unionism, balances precariously on a pendulum of orange and green, indicating the difficulties beneath the surface.

Around this are silver and gold masks and hands, which he says represent the silent majority, both Protestant and Catholic, who want peace but are troubled by how the accord is shaping up. All the symbols appear to be bursting out of a cell-like room, signifying how hard it is to fit all the ideals of unionism and nationalism into narrow confines.

Other paintings, like Seated Bather, have some religious connotation. He says the orange figure partially represents Eve, with the Salvador Dali-type holes in her snake-like limbs showing the decay brought by sin. "But I don't take myself too seriously," he claims. "People will always read more than is really there, but that's up to them. Sometimes I just add a little joke, like a tiny lizard peeping out from under a leaf."

His pictures, which he used to give away or sell for a few pounds in prison, now fetch anywhere between a couple of hundred and a couple of thousand pounds. But he is dismissive of any suggestion he could make his fortune.

For one thing, he's still under death threat from dissident republicans, and he and his fiancée, Suzanne, move from place to place, each safe house protected by a raft of bulletproof windows, steel doors and security cameras. He knows that killing him, a loyalist icon, could spark revenge with the potential to reignite serious sectarian violence.

"I have more bars on the windows now than when I was in the Maze," he says. "Do you know what Suzanne and I got each other for Christmas? His and hers body armour."

"I've got seven dogs and I keep tropical fish - I've even had the glass in their tanks reinforced. I don't want you to hear that Michael Stone has been drowned because the bullets hit the fish tanks.

"I'm looking over my shoulder 24 hours a day. Some people might call it paranoia but I call it not getting complacent. But I know there will always be people out to get me, after what I did. I live with that every day but I just want to keep my head down and get on with my life."
