fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

A1 Cumbria has lost what percentage of its annual tourist bookings since the foot and mouth outbreak?

a) All of them

b) Most of them

c) 80%

d) I can't count that high

A2 The English regional tourist board reckons it is losing:

a) £200m per week

b) kudos

c) the respect of Japanese tourists

d) an influx of oversized Americans to the British Isles

A3 The government promised the tourist industry an allowance of:

a) tuppence

b) £120m

c) five loaves and two fishes

d) £50 excluding VAT

A4 Chris Smith told the cabinet yesterday that the danger of "significantly reduced" bookings for the summer was:

a) serious

b) devastating for multiculturalism

b) worse than a blow to the stomach from Mike Tyson

d) likely to lead to his resignation

A5 George Bush told Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, that he:

a) thought Scotland was a county in England

b) wished Tony Blair was a cigar-munching Republican

c) empathised with the UK

fields.headline: Cut off at the pass
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: The Lake District.
fields.body:
The greatest hazard in driving over Hardknott Pass at night - years ago I used to do it regularly - was the number of sheep, mostly Herdwicks, sleeping on the tarmac and suddenly revealed by the headlights. Farmers said the unfenced roadway - the toughest bit of mountain motoring in the country - made a cooler bed than the fell grass, although I could never understand this.

These sheep would have been from the flock at Black Hall, the lonely farm at the head of Dunnerdale - the first Lake District fell farm to be hit by the foot and mouth scourge. We are rightly discouraged from driving over Hardknott and neighbouring Wrynose Pass during the present emergency - both passes through wild fell country are unfenced but, in happier days, their traverse is the shortest, most direct way from central Lakeland to Eskdale, Wasdale and the coast, and a superb scenic drive through the hills.

From the summit of Hardknott Pass, a tiny notch on the skyline, you suddenly peep down on the long, green trough of Eskdale, spattered with woodlands and farmsteads, with perhaps a sparkle of sea in the distance. Straight ahead are the Scafells, brooding over the wildest dale head in England, and halfway down the zigzags is the Roman fort of Hardknott, where the legionaries watched the pass and the Emperor Agricola once stood.

I remember driving over the rough curves of Hardknott before the last war, and then after years of tank-training exercises, when it was no better than a steep, slithery river-bed. And even when we're allowed to use the pass again, you've still got to be able to negotiate steep hairpins with confidence - sheep or no sheep.

fields.headline: Salman Rushdie
fields.standfirst: The mantra of our age: deny, deny, deny
fields.trailText: The current hit single It Wasn't Me by Shaggy (featuring Rikrok) celebrates, with wickedly infectious glee, the uses of shamelessness. A man caught red-handed cheating on his girl - a man watched by said girl making love to someone else on the sofa, in the shower, on the bathroom floor - must, or so the song tells us, at all costs, and in the face of all the evidence, deny, deny, deny. Now who and what does this remind us of?
fields.body:
The current hit single It Wasn't Me by Shaggy (featuring Rikrok) celebrates, with wickedly infectious glee, the uses of shamelessness. A man caught red-handed cheating on his girl - a man watched by said girl making love to someone else on the sofa, in the shower, on the bathroom floor - must, or so the song tells us, at all costs, and in the face of all the evidence, deny, deny, deny. Now who and what does this remind us of?

There have been some great champions of brazen denial in recent years: Diego Maradona ignoring the video evidence of his notorious handballed goal against England and ascribing it to the "hand of God"; OJ Simpson swearing to dedicate his life to finding his wife's "real" killer (any hot leads, OJ?); Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken denying their proven corruption to the point of their economic ruination; and of course the great denier himself, Bill Clinton, passim, from "I did not have sex with that woman, Ms Lewinsky" to the rejection of any improprieties in his last-gasp Pardongate.

The barefaced denial, the giving of the lie direct, has become, in this age of saturation media coverage, an increasingly prominent feature of public life. It is now routine for even the age's greatest monsters - the war criminals of ex-Yugoslavia or Cambodia - to deny their atrocities, knowing that their power of access to the world's airwaves is almost certainly greater than any journalist's power of access to the truth.

When great crimes are openly admitted - Timothy McVeigh boasting about the Oklahoma bombing, the Taliban taking pride in the destruction of the Bamiyan buddhas - it's so unusual that you find yourself fighting the urge to praise the criminals for their plain speaking.

I once sat in a courtroom in Australia, listening to the testimony of a truck driver accused of murder - of having deliberately crashed his vehicle into a bar he had been thrown out of, killing and maiming many people. The man had clearly been carefully coached in the important contemporary art of saying the thing that is not. His dress was sober, his eyes downcast, his manner shocked and decent; and for a long time, and almost persuasively, he denied his guilt.

But in the end the coaching couldn't save him. After he'd repeatedly denied that he was the sort of man who could do such a thing, he made the mistake, under cross-examination, of saying why. "For me to half-destroy my truck," he explained reasonably, "is completely against my personality." The jury quickly found him guilty and threw away the key. What did for him was that flash of unpalatable truth. A more skilful liar - or rather, denier - would have known better.

"It wasn't me." Many such consummate exponents of the arts of brazen obfuscation are presently in the news. In Britain, successive governments have colluded with the British agricultural lobby to unleash not one but two plagues upon the world. The first, BSE, was the result of (1) turning cows into cannibals and then (2) allowing farmers to save energy costs by giving their cattle food that hadn't been boiled long enough or at high enough temperatures to kill the deadly germs.

But of course the Tory government of the day did not admit its complicity; nor did the farm lobby own up to its part. Instead, both parties pretended, for a long time, that the links between BSE and its crossover human variant, CJD, were "unproven".

And now here comes foot and mouth, and we discover that three years ago the present Labour government declined to outlaw the use of pigswill as feed (even though many of our European partners had done so), and failed, once again, to ensure that the swill was boiled long enough or at high enough temperatures to be safe.

Once again, the decision was cash-driven: the farm lobby wanted to cut corners and save money, and the farm lobby got its way. Do we hear the government or the lobbyists admitting they were wrong? Of course not. "It wasn't us, it was this Chinese restaurant that imported illegal meat." So that's all right then. We can just blame the Chinese. We all know the kinds of things they eat.

Meanwhile, in India, the BJP-led government has contracted an acute case of snout-in-trough disease. The sting operation carried out by the excellent website Tehelka - what a difference the internet has made to press freedoms in India! - showed many of the country's leaders accepting bribes on videotape.

There have been some resignations, but no admissions of guilt, and much talk, by the shamed leaders and other governing party figures, of a sinister "conspiracy" against the ruling coalition. The new BJP party president has spoken of creating a new code of conduct for people in public life, but at the same time has refused to expel his corruption-tainted precedessor. Apparently, and in spite of the video evidence, it wasn't necessarily him.

And now, as the US, the world's greatest contributor to global warming, repudiates the Kyoto treaty designed to reduce environmentally harmful emissions, President George Bush goes so far as to claim that the link between greenhouse gases and global warming has not been proven. ("It wasn't us.") This is what the cigarette companies used to say about cancer, and it's about as persuasive. But the president has a big megaphone, and if he goes on repeating his claims he may even make them stick for a long, damaging time.

Just sometimes a song stumbles on a truth about the spirit of the age. The Shaggy/Rikrok hit is cheerfully unrepentant about its amoral little discovery. Deny your wrongs and you will right them. As Nancy Reagan might have put it, "Just say no." It's plainly an irresistible proposition. You hear it everywhere right now, hanging in the air like a mantra.

All together now: "It wasn't me ..."

 Salman Rushdie writes monthly in the Guardian.

fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you.
fields.body:
 David "Starsky & Hutch" Soul makes an appearance in BBC1's Holby City next week as Professor Alan Fletcher. Fortunately for those who would prefer to remember Detective Ken Hutchinson the way he was in his heyday, Fletcher will, we can exclusively reveal, have a penchant for aviator shades and flares, and will be seen tearing around in a souped-up red 1974 Ford Torino. Rumours that Antonio "Huggy Bear" Fargas is to join the Ballykissangel cast, playing a mobile library driver with connections in the County Wicklow underworld remain unconfirmed. David, though, has revealed that he is still in touch with Antonio and Paul Michael Glaser. But, he adds: "I don't think a new series of Starsky and Hutch is on the cards."

 Meanwhile, a welcome return for, arguably, the funniest book of the century. Kingsley Amis's Lucky Jim, is currently being filmed for broadcast this autumn. Stephen Tomkinson is lined up to star as the luckless academic, Jim Dixon. Also starring are Helen McCrory, Robert Hardy, and Keeley Hawes.

fields.headline: MI5 spy infiltrates Real IRA
fields.standfirst:
American double agent provides crucial evidence about terror group

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An American double agent has infiltrated the heart of the Real IRA - the terrorist organisation responsible for the Omagh bombing and blamed for recent attacks in Britain - in a spectacular intelligence coup by the FBI, MI5 and the Irish police.
fields.body:
An American double agent has infiltrated the heart of the Real IRA - the terrorist organisation responsible for the Omagh bombing and blamed for recent attacks in Britain - in a spectacular intelligence coup by the FBI, MI5 and the Irish police.

The agent, David Rupert, has provided crucial evidence about the organisation and its suspected leader, Michael McKevitt, who was arrested by Irish police last month.

McKevitt is the first person to be charged with directing terrorism under a law introduced in Ireland after the 1998 Omagh bombing, which killed 29 people. Rupert is expected to be a key witness at the judge-only trial due to open in Dublin's special criminal court on April 24.

Rupert, a 49-year-old former lorry driver from Illinois, is understood to have first contacted the Irish Freedom Committee in Chicago four years ago.

With no permanent home, he described himself as a descendant of German immigrants and Mohawk Indians. He acted as a fundraiser and soon became the main representative in the US of the 32 County Sovereignty Committee, whose paramilitary is the Real IRA.

Rupert soon became disillusioned with the Real IRA and started providing information about his activities to the FBI and MI5.

But his work in the US had so impressed McKevitt and his wife, Bernadette - the sister of Bobby Sands, one of the IRA hunger strikers who died in 1981 - that he was invited to Ireland.

While from 1998 the FBI and MI5 used information provided by Rupert to monitor the movement of Real IRA funds to a bank in the Irish border town of Dundalk, McKevitt's home town, Rupert was addressing Real IRA rallies in the town and across Ireland.

Security sources say McKevitt took to Rupert and introduced him to real IRA leaders, including the army council. Rupert passed information about the group's leaders and meetings to the FBI and MI5 which began to share the intelligence with the Garda, the Irish police.

The Garda are believed to have bugged Real IRA meet ings and secretly filmed its leaders.

Then last year, McKevitt allegedly asked Rupert to commit a terrorist offence. It was the prospect of this evidence being produced in court that prompted the Irish police to ask the FBI and MI5 if they could "blow" their agent.

After discussing the matter with him, Rupert agreed to be a witness at the trial. The FBI and MI5 also agreed, in effect ending Rupert's role as a double agent.

Security sources are confident that the joint FBI-MI5 operation will have a serious long-term impact on the Real IRA. Liam Campbell, regarded as its main strategist, is also facing terrorist charges.

The Real IRA, which is accused of planting the recent taxi bomb outside the BBC in west London as well as last year's attack on MI6 headquarters, still remains a threat, security sources say.

It is believed to have a small number of activists in Britain equipped with explosives and weapons. It is also believed to have bought arms from the Balkans.

fields.headline: Grumpy Sheila and a budgie called Pie
fields.trailText: It tells you all you need to know, you might think, about Richard Allinson's listeners that two separate callers both chose an Enya album from any CD in existence as their prize during his weekend show, Richard Allinson on Saturday (Radio 2).
fields.body:
It tells you all you need to know, you might think, about Richard Allinson's listeners that two separate callers both chose an Enya album from any CD in existence as their prize during his weekend show, Richard Allinson on Saturday (Radio 2). But this doesn't begin to reveal the gentle oddity of the ones who call in, every single one of whom supports my thesis that people who phone radio shows are a strange bunch, happy and lonely, otherworldly and suburban.

They find their perfect match in Allinson, a man who refers knowingly to Nicey and Smashie and yet exudes that very quality of claustrophobically smooth broadcasting. The phone-ins and features on his weekday evening show and especially on the weekend programme are of the ilk so thoroughly spoofed by Radcliffe and Lard on Radio 1. "You can get a little bit self-indulgent on a Saturday," says Allinson, after Oh No, Not All of It, where he plays a lengthy classic such as Stairway to Heaven in all its alleged glory.

But best of all are the callers wanting to choose the next tune to be played from The Wall of Sound. It works like this: they call in, talk surreal nonsense with Allinson from which he chooses a temporary catchphrase for them (he loves that bit, you can tell) and then snippets of music are played until they hear something they like - this is where they shout their phrase.

This weekend's callers were a bunch of busy bees, with DIY-ing, gardening, golfing, public-speaking Barbara off to a "cabaret thing" at the golf club on Saturday night (Chosen CD: Lionel Ritchie's Renaissance. Phrase: "Fore!") and Dean who sculpts toy figures for a living (CD: Pulse by Pink Floyd. Phrase: "I Love Barbie!").

Moira from Cumbernauld (CD: Tapestry by Carole King. Phrase: "Yee-hah!") sounded like one of the Krankies and planned to go line-dancing but only if she could get a lift. "Welcome to the madhouse," says Allinson in not very dangerous look-I'm-crazy-me style. If he wasn't on the radio, you know he'd be into comic topiary, a traffic-stopping hedge in the shape of a bunny with big ears, perhaps.

Last week's programme more fully lived up to the madhouse tag. Grumpy Sheila called from Scotland and was having trouble hearing Allinson because she was, she explained, in the back pantry (Phrase: "Back pantry!"). Simon (Phrase: an impersonation of a budgie eating) was altogether happier with his lot. He's in the middle of converting his flat into a forest, with big branches in the lounge and grass on the floor, all for his very free-range budgie, Pie. Yes, he lives alone with his feathered friend. "Do you ever wonder why?" asked Allison, gleefully, thrilled with the strangeness of it all.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Meridian | It's My Story | Evening Concert
fields.body:
The idea of creative torment has been around since humans first decorated caves. Now, as Mark Smalley discovers in Meridian (9.05am and 7.05pm, World Service, Tuesday 1.05am, Radio 4), modern research shows that it may be more than a myth. About one-third of us can expect to experience psychiatric problems. But the proportion rises steeply among those with creative gifts.

Dovid Katz is a New Yorker who moved to Vilnius to continue his lifetime quest. Two generations ago the Lithuanian capital had the world's largest number of Yiddish speakers. Now the language is on its knees, and Katz makes constant trips to the villages of the region to record the Yiddish still spoken by a few ageing Jews. As he tells Tim Whewell in It's My Story (8.0pm, Radio 4), he finds it nonsensical to arrange tours of Auschwitz and to ignore those whose language and civilisation were destroyed.

Throughout Holy Week Nicholas Tresilian offers a selection of ecclesiastical works in the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM). On the reputed anniversary of Palestrina's birth in 1525, Harry Christophers and The Sixteen perform his Missa Papae Marcelli - one of the key works of the period. Amid the turmoil of the Reformation, the Vatican grew concerned that intricate musical settings were masking the liturgy. The Council of Trent commissioned this Mass to illustrate the austere approach it now required from composers.

As he tells Tim Whewell in It's My Story (8.0pm, Radio 4), he finds it nonsensical to arrange tours of Auschwitz and to ignore those whose language and civilisation were destroyed. Throughout Holy Week Nicholas Tresilian offers a selection of ecclesiastical works in the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM). On the reputed anniversary of Palestrina's birth in 1525, Harry Christophers and The Sixteen perform his Missa Papae Marcelli - one of the key works of the period. Amid the turmoil of the Reformation, the Vatican grew concerned that intricate musical settings were masking the liturgy. The Council of Trent commissioned this Mass to illustrate the austere approach it now required from composers.

webTitle: Mark Lawson on TV drama The Whistleblower

fields.headline: Perform or act?
fields.standfirst: TV drama stars aren't always expected to act - producers want familiar faces. But in The Whistleblower Amanda Burton plays a woman changing her identity. Can she pull it off?
fields.trailText: TV drama stars aren't always expected to act - producers want familiar faces. But in The Whistleblower Amanda Burton plays a woman changing her identity. Can she pull it off?
fields.body:
There are reputed to be certain towns in New Zealand and Australia where if you shout out a name in the street, someone will instinctively turn round, then nervously jerk their head away. They've briefly been drawn back to what they used to be called. This is because it's widely believed that supergrasses and witnesses in terrorist trials are relocated to the Antipodes with fresh identities.

That story has such power because witness protection schemes represent an extreme example of a common human dream: to start anew somewhere else. The Whistleblower, the BBC1's big Easter drama, depicts the experience of people who have never been to drama school but are suddenly asked to become actors for the rest of their lives.

Laura Tracey (Amanda Burton), a lowly clerk at a London family bank, has discovered that her employers are a dollar laundrette for a Panamanian drug-trafficking gang. She agrees to photocopy documents for the fraud squad and the FBI, who are in on the operation so that the drama can also sell to American markets. Added international appeal is provided by a top Mexican hit-man, who comes to England to take out Laura as revenge for her evidence at the trial of the cartel and the bankers.

Laura's life can only be protected, British security concludes, by providing her with a different one. Mrs Tracey becomes Mrs Godfrey. Her children are taught new names and pasts in a serious version of a dressing-up game. In this sequence, there are strong hints that Patrick Harbison's script might have wanted to go deeper than the piece's populist ambitions permit.

It's a sweet detail, for example, that both Laura and her husband Dominic (Neil Pearson) are given cover identities that consist of lives that they have carefully avoided. Ambitious for a career, she is redefined as a housewife while he, a college lecturer, is downgraded to schoolteacher.

But, frustratingly, this fascinating material - a forced transformation in middle-age - is rapidly abandoned in favour of car chases and footage of the family shot through the sights of an assassin's rifle. The existing sexual secrets, which threaten the new secret life, also feel already-seen.

There's a double irony in the fact that the theme of The Whistleblower is deep disguise. The first is that, in its plot essentials, the two-part drama sometimes feels as if it used to be called something else. Specifically, you feel that the idea was born as The Insider, the classy American movie in which Russell Crowe ratted on the tobacco business. In fact, if you were asked to publicise this film, you'd pitch it as a cross between The Insider and Erin Brockovich.

But both of those movies, based on real stories, had a documentary edge in both detail and execution. The problem for The Whisteblower is that it's in the nature of the story that it couldn't draw on actual narratives without putting lives at risk.

In another more crucial second sense, story and reality come together. Playing a woman trying to convince the world that she is someone else, Amanda Burton is an actress desperate to make viewers forget a previous identity. BBC drama is currently struggling, with cherished projects being out-rated by ITV: the brilliant Clocking Off (reviewed here last week) is the latest show to fight Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? and lose.

In this bleak period, the autopsy drama Silent Witness has been one of the few pieces showing consistent signs of life, establishing Burton as a bankable actress. Now, by playing a banker, the actress hopes to show her range as a performer.

In the most recent Silent Witness, her character developed cancer, an intimation of the franchise's mortality. Just like the MI5 disguise team played by Bill Patterson and Penelope Wilton in The Whistleblower, the BBC drama department has enrolled her in the integrity protection programme, trying to construct a new identity.

The dark hair she wore in Silent Witness is dyed blonde, the abrasive Ulster accent is softened to City posh. She is very different, and that may be a problem.

Between the people who produce drama and the people who perform it, there are two main disagreements. One is over how much actors should be paid; the other concerns exactly how much acting they should do. Performers regard it as a measure of their skill if they become unrecognisable in a part but, for producers, it can be a disaster.

The late Alec Guinness made one of his rare returns to the stage in the role of a transvestite who spent the first act in a wig and dress. At the interval, two members of the audience were heard to ask loudly when Guinness was coming on. Similarly, in The Whistleblower, Burton acts well, but perhaps too well for the BBC's immediate cynical ratings needs.

Though distracted too often by shooty-bangs, the script contains some very nice lines. Pressed by the security services on why she has money stashed in a secret account, Laura replies: "I was going to run away. Start a new life." Showing how that human fantasy can become a nightmare, The Whistleblower could do with a better disguise of its generic history and a central performer less keen to make her known self disappear.

 The Whistleblower, Easter Sunday, 8.40pm, BBC1.

fields.headline: We're only here for the Squeers
fields.trailText: The Life And Adventures Of Nicholas Nickleby | Correspondent
fields.body:
Brimstone for breakfast isn't one of those diets they tell you about in that Celebrity Bodies magazine. Well, not this week anyway. I imagine after they've seen The Life And Adventures Of Nicholas Nickleby (ITV, Sunday) and how the pupils at Dotheboys Hall look so waifish on it, there'll be a double page spread on how to achieve that authentic "workhouse chic" look. "The chemical you can eat between meals AND spoil your appetite!" and "Forget That No Carb Diet - Go Mad for Sulphur!" That kind of thing.

Dispensed, as it was, by the thuggishly malevolent Mr and Mrs Squeers (Pam Ferris's monstrous portrayal of the latter firmly killing off any notion of her as the perennially compassionate Peggy in Where The Heart Is), the brimstone diet was probably the least appetising thing about this adaptation of Dickens's third novel.

True, it started sluggishly - with an English funeral, in fact, and you don't get more sluggish than that - but once the story picked up and you accept that every Dickens novel, bar A Christmas Carol, is the same with interchangeable characters in it (morally decent young lad down on his luck; brutish working-class folks, most probably in charge of a dark, Satanic institution; angelic maiden; regulation cripple; and Bad Rich Person), it became rather absorbing.

Bathed in sludgy blue and slate-grey light - well done that director of photography - James D'Arcy was an interesting Nicholas. (Of course, he is far too good-looking to play someone Victorian but no matter. This is TV, after all.) Unlike his performance in Rebel Heart, here D'Arcy's permanently teary eyes were an advantage. After all, it isn't much fun living humbly in ignominy and not being able to smack your uncle in the kisser because it isn't very Victorian and he's Charles Dance. It is even less fun sitting on the roof of a horse-drawn coach all the way from London to Yorkshire. Given the choice, getting the train would seem like an attractive option. Actually, things being what they are, it probably wouldn't, even now.

Similarly, D'Arcy's blank, equine face was suited to a character whose formative experiences were yet to mark themselves upon him. Here was an emotionally naive boy-man who still knew what society expected of him, and D'Arcy's eyes conveyed both admirably. However, having said that, there were times when you wished he would move his mouth, or indeed any part of his lower face. Occasionally, Nicholas had the look of someone who had just had a filling and was waiting for the anaesthetic to wear off.

The rest of the cast were of a suitable calibre, even if the roles were cartoonish stereotypes. Along with Ferris, Debbie Chazen as Fanny was a particularly frightful delight amid the squalor of Dotheboys, while in an icy clear London, Sophia Myles proved an excellent Kate. Her meek and courteous exterior hid a fiery heart. The frisson between her and Uncle Ralph (Charles Dance playing Charles Dance with added moustache twirling, albeit sans moustache) was electric. Even the posh extras of Lord Verisopht and chums with faces like rotten marrows were pitched just right.

Two hours is an awful long time to ask an audience to commit to a drama, especially one which doesn't deliver closure. However, The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby was of such a quality that it was worth the investment.

"Husbands die every day", Ralph Nickleby snapped at his sister-in-law by way of explanation of her plight. It's depressing to know that some things don't change. Correspondent (BBC2, Saturday) told the fascinating story of those left behind after Chinese gangsters attempted to smuggle desperate men from the Chinese province of Fujian into the UK with fatal consequences.

With contributions from relatives of the dead men - invariably women left behind to cope in poverty - and police officers charged with stopping the human traffic run by "snakeheads", Correspondent was comprehensive, coherent and genuinely enlightening. It raised serious points relating to the "joys" of globalisation by concentrating on the suffering of individuals, but it successfully resisted sentimentality.

At one point, a woman whose husband had paid the snakeheads to get him to the UK cried, "We are so poor. I borrowed the money at high interest rates. I've been to the bank, the city government, the police, everywhere. No one can help me. Why?" The same old story still leaves a bitter taste in your mouth.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Antz | Two Girls and A Guy | Live Football
fields.body:
Films

Antz
(Eric Darnell, Tim Johnson, 1998)
1.50pm, 6.30pm, Sky Premier

This is the DreamWorks animated blockbuster that took on Disney/Pixar's A Bug's Life (showing on the Disney Channel this evening) in the insect war. It starts hilariously, with the Woody Allen-voiced Z-4195 ("The middle child in a family of five million") on the psychiatrist's leaf, wondering if there's more to life than being a worker ant. There is romance with Princess Bala (Sharon Stone), and war with the termites is just around the corner. With Sly Stallone as a soldier ant and Gene Hackman as crazy General Mandible, this is inspired fun - even if the screen is at times stodgy with subterranean hues.

The Wicker Man
(Robin Hardy, 1973)
10pm, FilmFour

Staunch Christian policeman Edward Woodward goes to the remote Scottish island of Summerisle to find a missing girl, but uncovers ancient pagan rites - and wild, wild women such as Britt Ekland, Diane Cliento and Ingrid Pitt. Anthony Shaffer's intelligent screenplay slowly stokes up the sinister, erotic atmosphere: as the deluded Woodward's suspicions grow, the tone changes from mildly comic to horrific, and with the old devil Christopher Lee presiding as local laird, it's hardly surprising the sergeant becomes a basket case. This is a new version of the cult classic, containing 15 minutes of previously unseen footage.

The Boston Strangler
(Richard Fleischer, 1968)
1.30am, Bravo

A harrowing dramatisation of the serial killer's reign of terror in Boston in the early 60s. In its low-key, detailed approach it looks like an American cousin of the director's other evocative study of a real-life murderer, Christie, in 10 Rillington Place. To play the strangler, Tony Curtis transformed his pretty-boy looks and was never better. Henry Fonda leads the police hunt and Sally Kellerman is among the victims.

Two Girls And A Guy
(James Toback, 1997)
1.55am, Sky Premier

A mature and intelligent comedy about two women who suddenly discover they have been unknowingly sharing the same lover for nearly a year. All the action - or rather discussion - takes place on one set, the actor-boyfriend's New York loft apartment, but it never feels static: the wit of Toback's script and the performances, from Robert Downey Jr, Heather Graham and Natasha Gregson Wagner (daughter of Natalie Wood), see to that.

Sports

Live Football
7pm Sky Sports 1

After the excitement of last week's European adventures, and the tension of yesterday's FA Cup semi-finals, its back to more mundane matters in the Premiership. Not that this should be a boring match, as Sunderland aim to aid their chase for a European place by beating Middlesbrough. Terry Venables's side experienced a brief surge in form after the former England coach arrived, but have since slumped back into the relegation mire, and, with games against Arsenal and Manchester United to come, cannot afford to lose.

fields.headline: John Ardoin
fields.standfirst: Biographer, music critic and friend of Maria Callas
fields.trailText: Biographer, music critic and friend of Maria Callas.
fields.body:
The American music critic John Ardoin, who has died aged 66, was best known for his friendship with and writing on Maria Callas. Ardoin, an ebullient, forthright figure, was a lively writer, his literary personality rivalling his character in raciness and volubility. He had been a music critic of the Dallas Morning News for 32 years, retiring in 1998. He could be sharp, even caustic, but his judgments were always cogent and thought through, and based on his love of music, in particular opera. He was a longtime critic for Opera magazine.

The Dallas Opera, a company of considerable repute, following Callas's appearances there in the 1950s (she was dubbed the company's godmother), benefited from having Ardoin by its side to maintain the highest standards. He was uncompromising in his artistic goals, which stemmed from his intimate knowledge of repertory and its performers. He seemed to know everyone who was anyone in the world of music, and liked nothing better than to gossip about the state of the art.

The most important of his four books on Callas was probably The Callas Legacy, in which he analysed all her recordings in scrumptious detail, comparing her performances of a role on different occasions, although his biography of her and his book on her masterclasses at the Juillard School in New York are also fascinating. As with all his work, his writing on the diva was as entertaining as it was well informed. However, his long friendship with the soprano ended when he gave a negative review of one of her comebacks in 1974, by which time her voice was in shreds. It was a tribute to Ardoin's courage that he told it how it was.

In 1994 he produced The Furtwangler Record, a fascinating study of all the recordings of the conductor, which showed Ardoin to be as familiar with his discs and the conductor's interpretative quirks as he was with those of Callas. To be published, posthumously now, is a volume on the Kirov Opera and Ballet Company.

Ardoin was a kind and warm person with a refreshingly self-deprecatory manner. He once averred that he "went into music criticism because I loved music and didn't know what else to do".

Proud of his Cajun heritage, Ardoin was born on the same day as Elvis Presley. He attended North Texas State College (now the University of North Texas) and later the University of Texas, where he gained his degree in composition and theory. Later he took a course at Michigan State University.

After serving in the armed forces, in Europe, he worked as a composer in New York, served as editor of Musical America and wrote programme notes for the New York Philharmonic. In 1966 he became only the second music critic of the Dallas Morning News.

Ardoin was unmarried.

 John Ardoin, music critic, born January 8 1935; died March 18 2001

fields.headline: Theodore McCarty
fields.standfirst: Senior executive who transformed the fortunes of Gibson guitars
fields.trailText: Senior executive who transformed the fortunes of Gibson guitars.
fields.body:
Theodore "Ted" McCarty, who has died aged 91, presided over the Gibson company in Kalamazoo, Michigan from 1948 to 1966 and was behind some of the most beautiful, finest-sounding guitars ever built.

It was the era of Gibson's most innovative designs, and although some of the instruments were too radical to achieve immediate success, the 1960s rock and blues revolution proved that the electric guitars born into the "McCarty era" had set new standards of quality, power, sustain and tone. Without McCarty, Gibson would never have produced the Les Paul, the Flying V, the SG, the ES-335 or the Firebird. There is no great guitarist of the electric era who has not benefited from McCarty's expertise: the blues artists of the 1950s, the 1960s hotshots such as Eric Clapton, Jimmy Page and Peter Green; and countless others, from AC/DC to ZZ Top.

In 1948, after 12 years working for the Wurlitzer organ company, McCarty took the job of vice-president at Gibson. The firm had enjoyed a reputation as makers of fine mandolins, banjos, flat-top acoustic and archtop jazz guitars, but in the war years had fared badly, even turning at one point to toy production. Arriving in Michigan, McCarty found a company suffering from the attrition of skilled workers during the post-war years and struggling under top-heavy management. They were losing $100,000 a month.

McCarty set about updating the business. Among his early introductions was the ES-5, the first ever three-pickup production guitar, as used by T-Bone Walker, and the ES-175, a simple electric archtop guitar that remains a jazz workhorse to this day. But it was his reaction to the competition, particularly Leo Fender's introduction of the Broadcaster - "the world's first production solid-body electric guitar" - in 1950 that sparked Gibson's revival.

To many in the trade, Fender's simple construction methods and modern designs were the last word in poor taste. McCarty initially thought the same, calling the Fender "the plank guitar". Yet within a year he and his team set about designing a solid-body guitar that would be ready for the dawning age of high amplification without losing sight of Gibson's traditional craftsmanship and use of fine timbers.

The new instrument, named after and endorsed by Les Paul, appeared in 1952. Although discontinued briefly in the 1960s, the guitar was rediscovered by new young players who found that the later Les Paul's warm, powerful humbucking pickups gave noise-free operation, while the clever use of mahogany and maple offered unrivalled sustain, making it the ultimate tool for high-powered blues and rock.

In 1958, McCarty played an important role in the development of three other iconic guitars. The slim hollowbody electric ES-335 was his proudest achievement and is still acclaimed today: variations have been played by Chuck Berry, BB King and Larry Carlton, displaying the guitar's uncanny ability to cover rock, blues and jazz styles.

The other two were the Explorer and the Flying V: intended as a direct retort to Fender's jibes that Gibson "hadn't invented a new thing in years", these outlandish space-age designs are still adored today by everyone from hardest-rocking metal bands to U2's the Edge.

Less obvious is McCarty's involvement in a number of innovations that immeasurably improved the working musician's lot. He invented an "add-on" scratchplate with integral pickups for converting acoustic archtop guitars to electric; a one-piece bridge/tailpiece, still regarded as a vital ingredient of some of the best-sounding guitars of the century such as the early Les Paul; and the Tun-o-Matic bridge, an invention that allowed individual intonation adjustment for each string.

It was also McCarty's decision in the late 1950s to pursue and buy the Epiphone company, since the 1930s one of Gibson's closest rivals. Under McCarty's leadership the Epiphone brand blossomed, with models played by the Beatles and the Rolling Stones. McCarty did not forget Gibson's debt to jazz, instigating a number of fine Gibson "artist" models such as the Johnny Smith and the Tal Farlow.

In 1966 McCarty left Gibson. Under his leadership the company's workforce had grown from 150 to almost 10 times that number, while sales had increased by more than 1,000%. He bought, and spent the next 20 years at, Bigsby, an accessory company specialising in guitar vibrato systems.

Yet McCarty's days in guitar design were not over. In the 1990s he found himself courted by the Paul Reed Smith company, a maker of high-quality instruments much influenced by Gibson's designs, who used him as a consultant and paid him the ultimate compliment by producing a "McCarty model". In the world of guitars this is a mark of acclaim usually reserved for only the most high-profile musicians.

webTitle: Women: Michele Hanson on loud noises

fields.headline: Michele Hanson
fields.standfirst: Noise annoys
fields.trailText: Last week I took my mother to the cinema for a treat. She never wishes to go again. The noise almost dashed her brains to pieces, and she is not a stranger to loud noise.
fields.body:
Last week I took my mother to the cinema for a treat. She never wishes to go again. The noise almost dashed her brains to pieces, and she is not a stranger to loud noise. For a start, she is a shouter. A lifetime of shouting and roaring has taken its toll and left her with only one vocal cord. And here in Temper Towers, shouting, barking, blaring televisions and door-slammings are the norm. But the cinema adverts and Gladiator trailer were too much for her. Adverts, for some odd reason, are 10 times louder than film volume, which is at eardrum-killer pitch anyway.

The trouble is that half the world is now partially deaf. The younger half. To them, a squillion decibels, pain and tinnitus means pleasure. So what bad luck for Rosemary that she has a young pop star girlie living over her head, with a loud voice, a barking dog, a DJ boyfriend and a penchant for staggeringly loud music played mainly at night.

Rosemary is in hell. Just as she was settling into her new home, the blasting noise ruined everything. Even complaining is a battle. One cannot gain access. The girlie can't hear her bell ringing or the battering on her door, because her big TV, hi-fi or mixers are on nonstop at earthquake volume. Eventually Rosemary and the young fellow from the top floor got together to tell her off. They dashed along and rapped at the door in a brief gap in the tumult, but only the DJ boyfriend was in, playing loudly with his mixers.

"Bit loud last night. Sorry, mate," said the Upstairs Boy and gave an understanding wink. When one is a hip young fellow, there is no point siding with an old bat with a posh voice, even if you promised to and her health and sanity depend on it.

I have tried to boss Rosemary into more aggressive action: thunderous retaliatory noise, a crowd of heavies, me and my mother, the council noise patrol, or even a leak to the tabloids, but she is too weedy. So the next day she slipped a polite note under the door begging for quiet. Fat chance. Apparently, noise is the new silence, says Fielding. "Only a background hum, of course." Oh well. That's all right, then.

fields.headline: Why men wield the knife
fields.standfirst: As one doctor wins a six-figure payout after allegations of sexism,  Jeevan Vasagar  investigates the surgeons' old boy network
fields.trailText: As one doctor wins a six-figure payout after allegations of sexism, Jeevan Vasagar investigates the surgeons' old boy network.
fields.body:
When Su-Anna Boddy was training to be a surgeon, a male patient showed his gratitude for her efforts by saying: "Thank you, nurse, but when is the doctor coming to see me ?" And when she was sitting an oral exam for her master's degree in surgery, an examiner sought to calm her nerves with the words: "Don't fret, sweetie, have another bickie."

Now a consultant paediatric surgeon at a south London hospital, she trots out the stories to illustrate an era she believes is over. She agrees there are still a few dinosaurs lumbering around, but says the clock is ticking.

It is a moot point. Over half of medical school graduates are women, but only 5% of consultant surgeons are female. When a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer, chances are she'll be told by a middle-aged man - 96% of breast surgeons are male.

The Royal College of Surgeons recently tried to find out why women were being put off, with a survey of medical students in Newcastle. The answers were depressing. Surgery was "male dominated" and "sexist", the women said. There was an "old boy network", females were "discouraged" and it was "too difficult for women to become consultants".

By contrast, male students saw surgery as a career favourable to them. With disarming honesty, those men who gave a reason cited "male bias".

Macho attitudes in surgery have recently been in the news again. Judy Evans, a consultant plastic surgeon who complained of sexist and racist behaviour among senior colleagues, accepted £500,000 to settle an employment tribunal claim. The deal averted a tribunal expected to hear allegations of a "boys' club" culture at Derriford hospital in Plymouth - claims the hospital was denying.

If sexism is still rife in surgery, it is a problem that will ultimately affect us all as the number of women medical students increases. "We want the best people in surgery. We can't keep on choosing surgeons from an ever-decreasing pool of men," says Leela Kapila, chair of Women in Surgical Training, a group set up by the Royal College to boost female recruitment. The college wants to quadruple the number of women surgeons in 10 years, not in the name of equal rights but out of sheer practical necessity.

Kapila, 63 and a consultant paediatric surgeon at Queen's Medical Centre in Nottingham, was encouraged to take up the scalpel by a male consultant. "I had never thought of it. Like everyone else, I thought surgery was a man's job. People were surprised when I turned up because there weren't many women in surgery then, but nobody discouraged me - I got nothing but encouragement. I wear my sari to work, so I look different, but nobody has made me feel different."

Both agree that balancing work and home is demanding. Kapila says her husband is "a special person who has let me put my career first. I didn't have children because I got married late but it is perfectly possible now to have a family and be a surgeon."

It has, of course, been possible for men to combine the two by relying on the unpaid services of their wives, but now all trainees can take advantage of flexible programmes that allow them to work part-time. Boddy, 48 and a mother of two, advises the Royal College on flexible training. "It just means doing two jobs, whether your other job is looking after children or playing rugby." For her, it was a question of organisation: "Those of us who want to do surgery are Type One personalities who thrive on this sort of thing."

A younger surgeon who also works with Women in Surgical Training agrees that prejudice is no longer an obstacle. Lucy Wales, 31, works as a specialist registrar in vascular surgery at a London teaching hospital. "I have worked in four different regions," she says, "and have always worked with male consultants and found them encouraging and supportive. Surgery is seen as a male-dominated environment, but the vast majority of people you work with on a day-to-day basis are female - nursing staff, theatre staff, radiologists and anaesthetists. You work within a team and there is balance in the team."

You also need stamina - "You've got to have that extra dimension," Kapila says - and must be prepared to toe the line, as women who deviate from the norm can run into trouble. One of Britain's few female consultant breast surgeons, Briony Ackroyd, is currently suspended from Walsgrave hospital in Coventry, following complaints about her work. Critics say her complication rate was too high, but she has an army of supporters who were comforted by her unconventional approach - which included visiting patients at home.

All three women see it as their duty to act as role models for future generations. They go into schools equipped with latex arms for scalpel practice and encourage girls to take up the knife. When Kapila is asked about discrimination, she tells the children: "I'm standing in front of you. You can see the clothes I wear. You can see my name. If I can make it, you can. The only thing is, you've got to want to do it. It's no use vacillating."

 To arrange a careers talk on surgery, contact the Royal College of Surgeons on 020-7869 6211.

fields.headline: Between ourselves
fields.standfirst: When EastEnders' actor Lucy Benjamin was sworn to secrecy about who shot Phil, did she keep her mouth shut? No, she told her mum. What is it about women that compels them to confide?
fields.trailText: When EastEnders' actor Lucy Benjamin was sworn to secrecy about who shot Phil, did she keep her mouth shut? No, she told her mum. What is it about women that compels them to confide?
fields.body:
So Lisa did it. Last week it was revealed to a breathless nation that she was the would-be assassin who had gunned down EastEnders' hard man Phil Mitchell. And the nation was not that surprised - all the possibilities had been thoroughly trawled for weeks.

What was truly astonishing was that Lisa had gone all that time without telling anyone, including her best pal Mel, who was also on the suspect list after enjoying a secret night of passion with Phil. But Lucy Benjamin, the actor who plays Lisa, confessed last Friday that she had been unable to remain quite so tight-lipped and had told her mum of her character's guilt.

Women tell each other secrets all the time. It scares men (most of whom limit their daily interchanges to solid stuff, like football scores) rigid. Secrets are how a bloke's cheerful, harmless one-night stand gets turned, 30 Chinese whispers later, into a full-blown love affair and betrayal. Or how a personal problem that he probably hasn't even worded to himself, such as a beer gut or premature ejaculation, becomes the talk of the neighbourhood.

Secrets are women's social currency, our stock in trade. From little girls in the playground hissing to each other about who smells, to old ladies ostracising the weakest link from the bridge party, we use secrets to make friends and establish hierarchies. A group of women brought together for the first time will reassure each other with little secrets, each claiming to be more vulnerable/hopeless/fat than the last. Then they'll establish a more intimate friendship by confiding in groups of two or three about who they thought actually did have a weight problem.

Weight, snogging, an addiction to shopping or chocolate: these are the small change of secrets. The real state of your relationships, your depressions, your family, are the big spondulix. Secrets like that make a weight, a claim on the listener's kindness. Which is why making friends with the woman you suspect is moving in on your man and confiding in her about the state of your relationship is such a powerful weapon.

Not that all confessions are motivated by such base considerations. Many women maintain friendships for years in which there are no secrets at all, just unmediated intimacy. All that practising in the playground leaves us effortlessly able to keep secrets within a band of friends, to hide or reveal a best friend's secrets as appropriate and to keep a file of our best friend's relationship secrets even more unsparing than her own.

Since marriage got postponed and women got salaries and mobile phones, these friendships have become more important and visible; now, in Sex and the City, they have their own TV series. Though perhaps there are few women who would, Samantha-style, ring up their girlfriends to report on their new lover from his bed, there are many who might find themselves wording a call to their pals halfway through a dinner date.

Secrets told like this don't just help us place or digest experiences; they can become a narrative of their own. Sometimes, this narrative can become more real and important than what actually happens to us. It is not just teenagers who spend a second date wondering how they will explain this one to their friends, and who dump him if the task seems hopeless. A bad marriage or dreadful mistake doesn't exist until it is admitted to our friends.

The narrative can enter memory, too. Once I have made an experience into a good story for my friends, I remember the story, not the experiences. Even when I know I was lying in the first place. Sometimes I even remember a good friend's story as happening to me, or have to fight to reclaim my story from a friend who believes it is hers.

In our local cafe yesterday - a kindly, hippy hangout, a haven for sixth-formers and mothers and lame birds of all descriptions - I met a woman who moved rapidly though all the stages of female secret-telling. She started with my baby, which was just like hers. Did he cry at crèche? Hers did, too. How was my birth? Hers was just the same. It was very hard, the first few months, wasn't it?

She was self-employed, too. A writer? What a coincidence! And so on and rapidly so forth, except that it was 5.30pm and she wasn't hurrying anywhere, and she was grey and a bit smelly, and if she ever had a baby, it was a very long time ago. The secrets dynamic was just keeping her going for a bit, giving her an identity. Mine, to be precise.

She might just as easily have gone to the newsagent. She could have bought everyone's secrets, from Victoria Beckham to April Ashley. Or gone home with that spooky new magazine that advertises itself by having a deranged poppet tell us about her "new best friend". Or to a book shop. The voices of woman telling secrets to a close friend can be heard from Jane Eyre to Bridget Jones, and women cherish these books as closely as friends.

Our secrets become ourselves and that makes us vulnerable. When a friend falls so in love that she stops telling us everything and confides instead in the man, we feel deeply hurt and rejoice a little when the relationship goes wrong and confidence is restored. Adult women can be taken straight back to the playground if their secrets are betrayed. They are left winded by grief and astounded at themselves when they find a friend has let them down. It's worse than murder.

Which brings us back to Lisa. I hope the EastEnders' script-writers have done a scene for her friends. They won't be wondering why she shot Phil. They'll be upset that she didn't tell them.

When a friend falls so in love that she stops telling us everything and confides instead in the man, we feel deeply hurt and rejoice a little when the relationship goes wrong and confidence is restored. Adult women can be taken straight back to the playground if their secrets are betrayed. They are left winded by grief and astounded at themselves when they find a friend has let them down. It's worse than murder. Which brings us back to Lisa. I hope the EastEnders' script-writers have done a scene for her friends. They won't be wondering why she shot Phil. They'll be upset that she didn't tell them.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Police injured in soccer clash
fields.body:
Police injured in soccer clash

Twelve RUC officers were injured by Celtic supporters outside a pub in Ballymena, Co Antrim. One officer suffered head injuries and another had his leg broken in three places at the Grouse Inn. Police were called after men in Celtic tops began shouting and singing. When officers tried to stop them erecting a republican flag they were pelted with glasses and bottles.

Polio almost eradicated

Worldwide eradication of polio is almost complete, health experts have announced. The Global Polio Eradication Initiative, launched in 1988, pledged to make the world polio-free by 2005. Cases have fallen by 99% since 1998, from 350,000 then to 3,500 last year. And last year 550m children were vaccinated.

Breast cancer profile too high

A quarter of media articles on cancer are devoted to breast cancer, according to the charity Macmillan Cancer Relief. Lung cancer receives less than half that amount - although nearly one in five cancer patients is diagnosed with it.

Postmaster and family hostages

A postmaster and his family were held hostage for 12 hours by robbers who escaped with tens of thousands of pounds in cash. The gang burst into the post office in Maltby, near Rotherham in South Yorkshire, armed with baseball bats, a knife and a hand gun, and beat and tied up the postmaster's wife and son. They overpowered the postmaster when he returned later, and all three were held overnight. The gang escaped with the contents of the safe.

Two win £5.4m each on lottery

Two tickets each won £5.4m in Saturday's lottery. Winning numbers were 9, 19, 30, 32, 34, 44; bonus 18. There was no lottery extra jackpot winner; numbers were 9, 17, 21, 23, 35 and 42.

fields.headline: Taking the St Michael
fields.trailText: We were turned down for Marks & Spencer's food delivery service because the driver would find us too difficult to find - we are seven miles from the store (M&S slips deeper into crisis, April 7).
fields.body:
We were turned down for Marks & Spencer's food delivery service because the driver would find us too difficult to find - we are seven miles from the store (M&S slips deeper into crisis, April 7).

Only when I said that I would return to Tesco or Iceland, neither of whom had the slightest problem in delivering to us, did the staff change their mind.

But on a return visit, the driver still objected to our using the service, and once again I mentioned their rivals before being accepted. What other failing company allows an employee to veto an order worth almost £80?
Molly Fisher
Kirkintilloch, Dumbartonshire

 Another multinational employer has failed to inform and consult with its employees. The behaviour of Marks & Spencer is bad business practice (France calls for protests at M&S closures, April 6). Failure to inform and consult with employees in a timely and adequate fashion leaves not only the employees without protection but also damages the reputation of the company.

It is surely not too much for workers, many with over 20 years service, to expect common courtesy, in terms of consultation before a press release to the world at large.

Stop taking the mickey, St Michael.
Roger Lyons
General secretary, Manufacturing Science and Finance union

 With regard to the Marks & Spencer closure in Paris, the words "le bébé" and "l'eau de bain " come to mind.
Dan Lloyd
Bristol DanLloyd@11baynton.fsbusiness.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Means tests for the royals

fields.headline: Means tests for the royals
fields.trailText: Royals who work should be commended; they are helping themselves, taking the initiative, making a positive contribution to national life (Sophie affair widens as MP calls royals 'a bit bonkers', April 7).
fields.body:
Royals who work should be commended; they are helping themselves, taking the initiative, making a positive contribution to national life (Sophie affair widens as MP calls royals 'a bit bonkers', April 7).

I suggest a system of means-testing to clear up the problem of the royal family and employment. Those blue-bloods who feel they are entitled to some handouts from the taxpayer should call in at their local job centre and collect the requisite forms. They would then be required to spend some time outlining the exact nature of their work and applying for housing benefit to cover whichever palace they choose to name as their principal place of residence.

The millions which now flow automatically from the public purse into the Queen's handbag could then be adjusted, providing only a top-up to those aristocrats and hangers-on with an alternative source of income. Meanwhile, those without gainful employment should be encouraged back into work with a series of focussed interviews and perhaps a spell of employment in one of the fast food chains.
Sarah Mitchell
Matlock, Derbyshire smitchuk@hotmail.com

 "The husband of the Countess of Wessex is not the Count of Wessex, he is the Earl of Wessex" (Corrections and clarifications, April 6). Does the Count of Wessex not object to this shoddy state of affairs?
Paulinus Barnes
Rawtenstall, Lancs

 It appears that while criminals cannot have recorded conversations used as evidence against them without their prior knowledge and consent, Sophie Wessex is not entitled to such protection and positive discrimination. The royal family are entitled to the same niceties as suspects, surely?
Amanda Speedie
Truro

 You say: "Even the most steel-hearted republican must feel some sympathy for Sophie Rhys-Jones..." (Leader, April 5). I for one most certainly do not. Much as I dislike the Murdoch press, my distaste for the royal family is even stronger, and while I am grateful to the lady for letting the cat out of the bag and once again showing them as they really are, I have no sympathy for any of them.

The fact is that their whole existence is an anachronism and the more gaffes they make the sooner the people of this country will realise they have no place in the 21st century.
Mike Clutten
Leicester

 I've always been slightly mystified as to what PR actually is about, other than picking up a phone and asking favours of your well-connected friends. One thing has been confirmed: PR has replaced the church and the diplomatic service as the chosen career of upper-class thickos.
D Mitchell
Sheffield

 Why is it that journalists are continually surprised that rich people are largely corrupt, while the rest of us have always known this?
Brian Robinson
Brentwood, Essex
brirobinson@lineone.net

 How curiously apposite is FB Pinion's observation - in his Thomas Hardy Dictionary (Macmillan, 1989) - that "Wessex", for Hardy, had the "advantage of suggesting fiction which transcends realistic presentation".
Robert Goddard
Cambridge
robert_goddard@hotmail.com

 Journalistic standards have reached a new low - I have searched in vain for the headline "Sheik rattles a royal"'.
Chris Lakin
Newport Pagnell, Bucks
lakin@tia.powernet.co.uk

fields.headline: Divorced from reality
fields.trailText: So thoughtful of Darlene Edmunds (Spy plane showdown, April 4), recently divorced wife of one of the US prisoners/hostages, to tell the world's media "I'm hoping [the Chinese] won't figure out what job he does, because then they'll interrogate him..."
fields.body:
So thoughtful of Darlene Edmunds (Spy plane showdown, April 4), recently divorced wife of one of the US prisoners/hostages, to tell the world's media "I'm hoping [the Chinese] won't figure out what job he does, because then they'll interrogate him..." Just how acrimonious was their divorce?
Chris Bartle
Oxford Bartlefilm@aol.com

 A few days ago an American plane collided with a Chinese plane killing the pilot. A few months ago an American sub collided with a boat killing Japanese students. A few years ago an American plane collided with a cable car killing Italian tourists. Do they know there isn't a war on - or are they trying to start one?
Geoffrey Jordan
Nottingham

 Your report on the NUS conference (Hurt pride, Education, April 3), states that "parliamentary benches are stuffed with former executives". Since 1997 there have been 11 former NUS national executive members in the Commons At around 1.67% of members, it hardly constitutes a "stuffing" - particularly when the numbers of former doctors, lawyers and farmers in the house are taken into account.
Mike Day
Edinburgh

 I don't know whether Steve McFadden (Interview, G2, April 4) meant to include me among the "posh Oxbridge types" who trained with him at Rada: I have always assumed that the cred I lost on the swings of Oxford was outweighed by the kudos I had gained on the roundabouts of my Wigan comprehensive. Still, if Steve was indeed the "token working class student" at Rada, he wasn't the only representative of a minority: among our fellow students was at least one emissary from the Planet Zob.
Paul Sharples
Cheltenham

webTitle: Letters: A sample of opinions on help around the clock

fields.headline: A sample of opinions on help around the clock
fields.trailText: Your otherwise admirable comments on waiting for the gasman (Leader, April 7) left out the latest in the long line of hopeless utilities - the cable TV monopoly.
fields.body:
Your otherwise admirable comments on waiting for the gasman (Leader, April 7) left out the latest in the long line of hopeless utilities - the cable TV monopoly.

In Westminster people cheered when NTL replaced BT as the supplier of cable TV, promising better service. Yet, when phoning to request service, we have to wade through the "menu" of numbers interspersed with awful music. When NTL finally answer they can only "promise" am or pm service.

As a special concession to my anguished pleas that I did have a company to run, one girl last week said I'd be their "first call", and to expect the repairman on Thursday between 8 and 8:30am. When the really excellent chap did appear, at about 9:30, he explained that they didn't start until 9, from home. The fault in the equipment was fixed in a flash. My complaints to the call centre supervisor were answered with an assurance that I was lucky to have such good service.

We may expect help around the clock, but there is a conspiracy not to provide it. Your idea of delivering the Guardian in the afternoon is not much good as you live in a competitive world. They don't. What can we do to get them to pull their socks up? Is there an Ofcable?
Robert Worcester
London bob.worcester@mori.com

 Some people need to work unsocial hours due to the nature of their employment. They need access to services at odd hours. Do the majority of us really need the same?

Surely the need for 24/7 banking and other facilities is self-perpetuating and potentially damaging to society? As more people require access to services free from time restraints, so more people are required to work unsocial hours to meet the supposed demand.

The rises in stress-related work disorders is a direct result of a work force expected to conform to irregular and extended hours of employment. This situation is likely to worsen unless we learn to exercise some patience and reclaim our free time. To be constantly "on demand" is damaging to the human frame and is a trend that needs to be reversed.
Peter Wright
Stourbridge peterwright7@activemail.co.uk

 Your leader writer quite reasonably has the weekends off. He (or she) presumably spends five days a week hard at work and then expects to be able to have a couple of days at the end of it all relaxing. Fair enough. Why then the antipathy towards repairmen or deliverers when they want to enjoy the same lifestyle? Most "repairmen" are sole traders or part of a very small company and would simply have to extend their working week to six or seven days to accommodate your wishes.

I thought the Guardian was in favour of the European working times directive and against workers being forced to do long hours. Or does that only apply until it inconveniences you?
Stephen Ashley
Ickenham, Middlesex

fields.headline: No refugee consensus
fields.trailText: As co-author of the recent UNHCR commissioned report on the trafficking and smuggling of refugees into Europe, I agree with you (Leader, April 6) that trafficking and smuggling are best addressed by a sensible reform of immigration policy.
fields.body:
As co-author of the recent UNHCR commissioned report on the trafficking and smuggling of refugees into Europe, I agree with you (Leader, April 6) that trafficking and smuggling are best addressed by a sensible reform of immigration policy. This must be accompanied by a full debate on social, economic and humanitarian entry channels.

However, you are far too optimistic about the "emerging consensus" in Europe. I fear our political leaders still have a long distance to travel. Central to the debate over the coming years will be whether refugees and other migrants have "rights" (such as the right of claiming asylum) or whether Europe will manage migration according to administrative preference and public opinion.
John Morrison
Head of campaigns, The Body Shop International

 Part of me accepts your argument: no point in tackling "unfounded bigotry and prejudice" in the present climate; everything to do with asylum seekers on hold until after the election; and then we can get down to the business of reforming the voucher system, etc.

My big doubt concerns the growing gap between the political processes and the increasingly desperate plight of those seemingly caught in an endless poverty trap. To take their whole agenda out of local and general political consideration, whatever the prevailing public sensibilities, seems dishonest as well as inhumane.
Canon David Partridge
Emsworth, Hants

fields.headline: PCA called into question
fields.trailText: The police complaints authority announced last week that Essex police had failed on 15 counts in their duty to protect the life of Christopher Edwards, and in their duty to investigate effectively the circumstances surrounding his death (Police failed to protect man killed in cell, April 6).
fields.body:
The police complaints authority announced last week that Essex police had failed on 15 counts in their duty to protect the life of Christopher Edwards, and in their duty to investigate effectively the circumstances surrounding his death (Police failed to protect man killed in cell, April 6).

However, the significance of the PCA's findings is severely lessened by its inability to take disciplinary measures against the police officers concerned, many of whom have now retired. It is over six years since Mr Edwards died: yet the investigation is only now complete, and recommends improvements that should have been made years ago in the wake of that tragedy.

These issues call into question the effectiveness of the police complaints authority. Such an investigation should not have taken six years to complete; the police officers concerned should have been held accountable at the time of Mr Edwards' death.

Liberty is taking the family's case to the European court of human rights, based on the violation of Christopher Edwards' right to life.
Nancy Collins
Liberty

 We must learn from the death of one mentally ill person at the hands of another in a shared prison cell, though such an incident is dwarfed by the number of prisoners who commit suicide. A third of young offenders in prisons have a psychiatric disorder, while nine out of 10 adult prisoners have one or more problems related to psychosis, neurosis, personality disorder and drug or alcohol abuse.

We need mandatory training for police and prison staff in mental health, the NHS should take over prison mental health services and police, prison and other statutory agencies should be under a duty to exchange relevant information about individuals at risk. Only when all this is in place is it likely that suicides and deaths in prison will be reduced.
Simon Lawton-Smith
Mental After Care Association lawton-smith@maca.org.uk
